fields.headline: Man Utd 2 - 0 South Melbourne
fields.trailText: Man Utd: Van Der Gouw, P Neville, Higginbottom, Berg, Wallwork, Cruyff, Wilson, Greening, Fortune, Solskjaer, Cole. Subs: Bosnich, Rachubka, G Neville, Irwin, Silvestre, Stam, Beckham, Butt, Giggs, Yorke, Keane.
fields.body:
Man Utd: Van Der Gouw, P Neville, Higginbottom, Berg, Wallwork, Cruyff, Wilson, Greening, Fortune, Solskjaer, Cole. Subs: Bosnich, Rachubka, G Neville, Irwin, Silvestre, Stam, Beckham, Butt, Giggs, Yorke, Keane.

South Melbourne: Jones, Iosifidis, De Amicis, Blatsis, Clarkson, Panopoulos, Trimboli, Curcija, Anastasiadis, Lozanovski, Liparoti. Subs: Udvaracz, Roche, Coveny, Alagich, Cuzzupe, Magnacca, Goutzoulis, Tsekinis, Psonis, Mustafa, Culibrk.

Referee: Stefano Braschi (Italy)

1 Manchester United are now out of contention for any honours in this competition and have only pride to play for. Alex Ferguson has decided to break in some of the club's young bloods and and rest some of the more familiar faces ready for a renewed assault on the Premiership. Jonathan Greening, Danny Higginbotham, Mark Wilson, Quinton Fortune and Ronnie Wallwork all start while Ole Gunnar Solskjaer partners Andy Cole up front. David Beckham starts on the bench. Wallwork in particular will be keen to make a good impression and put to rest memories of the life ban he incurred in Belgium last year for assaulting a referee (later reduced to 12 months and applicable only in Belgium). A very quiet start as United knock it around at the back and get the feel of the conditions.
4 Jonathan Greening starts a run on the right but the move comes to nothing as the South Melbourne defence get their legs into gear.
6 Ronnie Wallwork gets in on the action and plays in Ole Gunnar Solskjaer in on the left of the area. Tackled and wins a corner. Wallwork comes up for a free header but it lacks power and South Melbourne win a free-kick when South Melbourne keeper Chris Jones is fouled.
8 Goal: Manchester United Solskjaer makes a run on the right and passes to Andy Cole just inside the South Melbourne area. He looks to have made a fluff of things but lays the ball off to the advancing Quinton Fortune who blasts United into the lead. South Melbourne defence at sixes and sevens.
13 United are doing a good job of keeping South Melbourne pinned back in their own half. Wallwork latches on to a ball at the left corner of the area, cuts inside and unleashes a shot across the face of the goal. Ferguson's youngsters keen to get in on the action while South Melbourne sulk about playing against the United creche.
17 South Melbourne venture into the United half of the field but are mustered well and dispossessed before they can offer any threat.
19 Cole works his way to the left-hand corner flag, but the ball is cleared before he can get in a cross or fiddle a corner. Steve Panapoulos passes to Goran Lozanovski as South Melbourne again try to prove that they are not just here for the suntan. They fail.
20 Goal: Manchester United Cole again the provider as he releases Fortune through the middle for the South African to race into the area and shoot over the advancing Jones for his second. Lozanovski looks as though he is having a tough time keeping United in check down the South Melbourne right. South Melbourne still appear to be unwilling to pull out the stops for United's youngsters, and United's youngsters are taking full advantage.
24 Cole the playmaker again as he threads a beautiful ball through to Greening on the right but the keeper comes out well to block after Greening shoots early.
29 Jordi Cruyff willing to take his chance to perform and is doing a good job spraying the ball around in the United midfield.
31 South Melbourne work the ball upfield for Anastasiadis to threaten the United goal but Henning Berg challenges to deny him the chance. The closest South Melbourne have come so far.
36 South Melbourne put together a few moves but fail to break the minute barrier for time spent in possession in the United half of the field.
39 The game looks to have hit dead water and the combination of little on-pitch activity after United's second goal and a barely audible whisper from the terraces is making the whole uninspiring performance somewhat surreal.
41South Melbourne now look prepared to make a game of it as the stadium shadow moves across to give the players some relief from the sun. The Australians appear to have got over what looked like a fit of pique at being denied the opportunity to face a full-strength United squad and are now willing to try for a goal.
44 United enjoying a good spell of possession and nearly score a third. The ball flies around in the South Melbourne area and eventually falls to Solskjaer on the left corner of the six-yard box; he shoots and the ball skims off the crossbar before the hapless Jordi directed Solskjaer's subsequent cross over the bar with his left knee... it would have been easier to score.
45 United continuing to hold on to the ball as half-time approaches. Half-time.

46 United start the second half hoping for much of the same - sit back, soak up the pressure and make South Melbourne pay on the break... in theory at least. United's youngsters will hoping for more glory against weak opposition, and a possible chance at a third place play-off spot.
47 Jordi sets off on a run through the left side of midfield that carries him to the South Melbourne penalty area, but he fails to find room for a shot.
49 United again come close getting a third when captain Cole does well to retrieve the ball with a little drag-back and turn near the half-way line; he runs down the right and finds Solskjaer on the edge of the area with a near-post cross but Solskjaer can only get the faintest of touches as the ball goes wide. Not his night.
54 South Melbourne win a free-kick 30 yards out. Michael Curcija has a crack but only can shake his head as the ball sails over.
57 Fortune, sensing a hat-trick, races away down the left before cutting inside to the edge of the penalty area; he slides a pass through to Solskjaer on the edge of the six-yard box but, again, he wastes the chance and shoots wide. If Solskjaer had taken his chances he would have had a hat-trick by now
60 United, and Fortune in particular, are finding lots of space down the left and at the moment their game consists mostly of probing this route to goal before being caught offside or failing to provide that final flourish to get through the South Melbourne defence. United need to step up the pace and get at least another goal if they are to have any realistic hope of gaining a third place play-off spot.
66 South Melbourne almost concede a home goal when Con Blatsis mis-judges a header back to keeper Jones; Jones at full stretch to ensure safety. Mark Wilson follows up with a shot from 25 yards but he skies his chance for fame.
70 Substitution: Jim Tsekinis on for David Clarkson. The sound of "When the Reds go marching in" comes wafting down from the terraces in an attempt to inspire United to greater things. Or, indeed, anything as Ferguson's men blow their chance for a hatful against a very weak South Melbourne side.
74 United make a mess of what should have been a good chance for a goal. Fortune, in by now familiar open territory on the left, runs upfield, cuts inside and passes into a gaggle of United players, but some frankly amateurish footwork sees them lose possession.
75 South Melbourne nearly make a breakthrough when a Vaughan Coveny shot beats Van Der Gouw with a shot from just inside the penalty that hits the left-hand post, dribbles along the line and then hits the right-hand post before being cleared.
76 Curcija comes close when he catches United exposed at the back, but his shot is parried by Van Der Gouw.
77 Substitution: Beckham on for Wilson, just as South Melbourne are enjoying the better of the play.
83 United now up for the fight again as Solskjaer comes close and misses - again. Running into the right side of the penalty area with only Jones to beat, he shoots low with his right foot and virtually helps the keeper make the save.
87 United operating in fits and starts, and apparently unconcerned that they stand a good chance of going out of this competition at the group stage.
90 Booking: Paul Trimboli. United have a final chance for a third goal when they win a free-kick on the edge of the area; Beckham takes but hits the wall. Final whistle. Manchester United 2 - 0 South Melbourne. United should have scored more in a game that was so low-key it looked like a practice match.

webTitle: How North Atlantic drift could carry away Old Firm

fields.headline: How North Atlantic drift could carry away Old Firm
fields.trailText: The chairman of PSV Eindhoven has announced that he wants his club to become full-time members of something called the Atlantic League. This league will happen and it will have huge implications for domestic leagues across the continent, not least in Scotland
fields.body:
What with Sir Alex's tantrums and Beckham's knickers capturing the national imagination last week, it was hardly surprising that the thoughts of a Dutch football club chairman failed to make the back pages. However, don't be surprised if one day Harry van Raay joins Marc Bosman as one of those who have revolutionised European football.

For those who read the sports pages without the aid of a magnifying glass and may therefore have missed what he had to say, Van Raay, chairman of PSV Eindhoven, announced last week that he wanted his club to leave the Dutch league within two years and become full-time members of something called the Atlantic League, comprising teams from the likes of the Netherlands, Belgium, Portugal, the Scandinavian nations and Scotland.

His comments came in advance of a meeting to be held next month at which interested clubs are expected to thrash out details of how the project might operate. Thus far there are only two certainties: the league will happen; and it will have huge implications for domestic leagues across the continent, not least in Scotland where the Premier League may be without the Old Firm.

Celtic's chief executive Alan MacDonald declared his club's interest in the proposal last year, and Rangers were reported yesterday to have shed their doubts and to be ready to join. But the principal driving forces behind the concept have been the Dutch clubs Ajax and PSV.

"Big clubs in the small countries in the same situation as us would like to do this tomorrow," Ajax's chief executive Frank Kales explained last month. "In Holland the newspapers are looking at the bad performances of all our clubs in the Champions League. They're saying if we continue like this then Holland will be wiped off the map because we can't compete in Europe any more. If we can't compete in Europe then all our good players will disappear."

It doesn't need a doctorate in economics to fathom why Kales is desperate to see the Atlantic League take off. This year Ajax are expected to earn about £2.5m in television revenues from domestic and European games. Celtic will earn about the same. Meanwhile clubs such as Barcelona and Juventus will make in the region of £50m from TV. The effect of this earnings difference on playing performance is clear: more money, hence better players, hence more success, hence even higher TV revenues - hence an ever-widening gap between rich and poor.

The question facing the likes of ostensibly big clubs such as Ajax, Benfica, Celtic and Rangers is how do they bridge this gap, and the obvious answer is the Atlantic League. With a potential television audience of 50m - roughly equal to that of the so-called Big Five (Spain, France, Italy, England and Germany) - they will have a better chance of securing a level of television revenue that will allow them to compete against clubs from the bigger countries.

Under the proposal floated by Kales the Atlantic would operate like a "sixth national" league, with its top three clubs gaining entry into the Champions League. Uefa, which has yet to make any public comment, may be sympathetic, not least because the Atlantic League is no threat to its own set-up.

More problematic for Kales and Co. is the effect the new league will have on domestic leagues. "The trouble is whether the federations and the national associations will allow us to do this," he says. "If we go outside the federations then it's war."

It needn't be. Already there are unconfirmed reports that the Old Firm would be willing to pay £15m a year to the Scottish Premier League to be allowed to play in the Atlantic League - money that could be used to bolster the teams left behind. Another idea being floated is that domestic competitions would act as feeder leagues in the new set-up, with annual relegation and promotion play-offs.

In any case, who's to say that a Premier League in Scotland without Celtic and Rangers (or a Dutch league without PSV and Ajax) would not be a more attractive "product" for the fans. After all, what would be better for the long-term health of the game in Scotland/the Netherlands: a genuine competition between teams of comparable abilities, or the current two-horse canter towards stagnation and, ultimately, oblivion?

webTitle: Buoyant BBC to show Brazil final live

fields.headline: Buoyant BBC to show Brazil final live
fields.trailText: The BBC will broadcast the final of the World Club Championship this Friday live on BBC1 and BBC Choice, despite the absence of Manchester United.
fields.body:
The BBC will broadcast the final of the World Club Championship this Friday live on BBC1 and BBC Choice, despite the absence of Manchester United.

If United make it to the third-place play-off, also on Friday, it will be screened live on BBC1, but if they fail then the match will be shown live on BBC2.

United's unsuccessful Brazilian expedition has at least proved good news for the BBC, which reported impressive viewing figures for the team's two live games so far.

Saturday night's match with Vasco da Gama was watched by 9.2m viewers, peaking at 9.7m, giving an audience share of 38%; the BBC usually loses out to ITV on Saturday nights but this time it scored more viewers than Blind Date and Family Fortunes. Last Thursday's match against Necaxa was watched by 11m.

A BBC spokesman said: "We have had two sets of strong figures out of this tournament that have seen off the main opposition. BBC Choice has also done very well; the figures have stood up very well."

webTitle: Tranmere given all-clear in the Cup

fields.headline: Tranmere given all-clear in the Cup
fields.trailText: Tranmere Rovers were yesterday guaranteed their place in the FA Cup fifth round when the Football Association absolved them of blame for the pandemonium that has consigned their scalping of Sunderland to the competition's hall of infamy.
fields.body:
To the intense relief of everyone connected with Tranmere Rovers, not least their bank manager, the First Division club were yesterday guaranteed their place in the FA Cup fifth round when the Football Association absolved them of blame for the pandemonium that has consigned their scalping of Sunderland to the competition's hall of infamy.

After the deliberations, the recriminations came thick and fast yesterday as the mayhem that had reigned in the final moments of Saturday's 1-0 triumph, when Tranmere were erroneously allowed to field a full complement despite having a player sent off, was laid squarely at the door of those employed to maintain order.

The referee Rob Harris has been relieved of his duties for tonight's fourth-round tie between Gillingham and Bradford City pending a special meeting of the FA's referees' committee at which it is alleged that his place in the Premiership may be forfeited.

As for the fourth official David Unsworth, responsible for inexplicably displaying Clint Hill's shirt number for substitution only moments after his stoppage-time dismissal, he would be well advised to steer well clear of the Wirral for some time.

The decision to avoid the acrimony of a rematch was hailed as a victory for common sense by Tranmere's manager John Aldridge who, perhaps understandably after 48 traumatic hours, was not of a mind to feel any degree of sympathy for the beleaguered match officials.

"It is the right decision and I salute the FA," he said. "I was always confident because we have done nothing wrong and they could not punish us while that was the case. But there was always that nagging doubt. Thankfully common sense has prevailed and we can look forward to playing at Fulham in the next round.

"Everyone makes mistakes and referees should be accountable just like managers and players are when they do something wrong. I hoped that Sunderland would be big enough to take it on the chin and I'm disappointed that after making all the right noises after the game they seemed to change their mind in their report, but I'm just glad we've got the right outcome."

An embarrassing episode was sparked when Hill's second bookable offence appeared to bypass Unsworth. Tranmere intended to substitute Andy Parkinson with Stephen Frail but, when the illuminated number displayed Hill's 6, Sunderland were offered the most improbable of escapes. Their manager Peter Reid accepted the decision with commendable dignity but beneath there lurked a profound irritation, not least in reaction to Aldridge's careless post- match comments that the Premiership club were attempting to sneak in via the back door.

"I took that inference as a personal slight because we have always tried to do things in the right manner," Reid said. "We will stand by the decision and take it on the chin."

After spending most of the day wrestling with the issue, the 16 members of the FA Challenge Cup committee concluded that Tranmere had not "knowingly and deliberately distorted the outcome of the game".

The FA spokesman Adrian Bevington said: "Referees and match officials are under considerable pressure, not least in high-profile cup ties. Their decisions on the rules of the game are final and for the good of the game they have to be accepted."

webTitle: United sit poorly with the Doc

fields.headline: United sit poorly with the Doc
fields.standfirst: The former manager of South Melbourne is unhappy with the more famous of his clubs
fields.trailText: Tommy Docherty, former manager of South Melbourne, is unhappy with Manchester United and has been amazed at the club's arrogance on the pitch and their petulance off it.
fields.body:
When they make the inevitable This Is Your Life-style programme on David Beckham, the former Manchester United manager Tommy Docherty will doubtless be wheeled out to reveal an astonishing and little-known fact.

While Docherty was starring in his own version of It Ain't Half Hot Mum as a National Service squaddie in Palestine 50-odd years ago, he played alongside a promising young midfield player called Gary West, who was to became the grandfather of one David Beckham.

The Doc, 71, thought of his old pal last week when Beckham got himself sent off in the World Club Championship game against Necaxa in Brazil. "Needless to say," says Docherty, "young David is a lot better than his grandad, who never made it as a pro. And I felt sorry for him after that red card. He did really well to handle all the terrible chants last season and now he is going to get slaughtered all over again."

Not that Docherty believes that Beckham and his team-mates should have been on the same continent, let alone within kicking distance of Necaxa, in a tournament that he believes is one of football's great follies. Today's game against the part-timers of South Melbourne, whom he also managed between 1981-82 and whom he describes as on a par with Stalybridge Celtic, is even more of a non-event.

Docherty says: "I was really looking forward to the tournament but I now believe it is one we could have done without. No team have really established themselves and I couldn't believe it when I heard that Manchester United had agreed to take part.

"It was a disgrace to pull out of the FA Cup to take part in something that seems to be all about greed.

"Brazil is probably the only country in the world where United haven't got a superstore and the only thing they've got out of it is a couple of million quid, which they hardly need, though I suppose Sir Alex Ferguson can now get a job with Fifa when he quits as a manager."

Docherty was first approached by South Melbourne when he was in charge of their National League rivals Sidney Olympic. But he returned to Britain for one of his short-lived jobs at Preston, where he lasted only eight months, before taking up the offer.

With training on only three days a week, he had plenty of time to pursue a policy of another day another Australian dollar, supplementing his wages with enough television and radio work to earn more than he would have done at a top English club.

For once in his life he also had to swap four-letter dressing-room language for diplomacy with his mainly Greek players, who, he says, "would go mad if you lost your rag with them".

"The fans were an excitable lot too. They were the best winners in the world and the worst losers.

"If we were losing they would throw apples and oranges at me, and of course, being me, I would make a big show of eating the apples and peeling the oranges. Naturally that made them even angrier and some of them would come round my house to let me know what they thought of me."

Having heard Ferguson claim that his team were desperate to win the World Club Championship and to do their bit for England's 2006 World Cup bid, Docherty was amazed at United's arrogance on the pitch and their petulance off it.

"They have left it until a bit late in the day for their public relations exercise," he says. "Before I took Scotland to Rio in 1972, I went out six weeks earlier and handed out thousands of flags, pins and other mementos to hospitals, hotel porters, whoever.

"It wouldn't have hurt United to have done the same. But seeing that they only went out there in the cause of greed, I suppose it would have gone against the grain for them to have given anything away. All they gave away in the end were those goals against Vasco da Gama."

webTitle: Queen's Park peril clouds Hampden future

fields.headline: Queen's Park peril clouds Hampden future
fields.trailText: A deal to secure the future of Hampden Park collapsed last night after the owners of Scotland's 52,000-capacity national stadium, Queen's Park FC, went into interim administration.
fields.body:
A deal to secure the future of Hampden Park collapsed last night after the owners of Scotland's 52,000-capacity national stadium, Queen's Park FC, went into interim administration.

The amateur club, formed in 1867, the oldest in Scotland, are seven points clear at the top of the Third Division but have run into financial difficulties in attempting to fund rebuilding work which had won them the right to host the 2002 European Cup final. It was first opened in 1903.

The building scheme ran into financial difficulties last year, when there were threats of legal action from the main contractor, Sir Robert McAlpine, for non-payment.

A £4.4m package agreed between the Scottish Football Association, the Scottish Executive and other bodies has seemingly proved to be insufficient to surmount the problems. However, a spokesman for the Scottish Executive last night described the move to appoint provisional liquidators as "unfortunate" and "premature".

David Taylor, the Scottish Football Association's chief executive, said: "We believe that we put together a realistic solution. It would have relieved Queen's Park of many of the financial pressures related to owning and managing the national stadium. We will continue to monitor the situation and hope that a successful outcome can be achieved."

Queen's Park won the Scottish Cup 10 times in 19 years in the 19th century and were christened "The Jolly Old Spiders" after their famous jerseys.

Watford, second from bottom of the Premiership and with only 17 league goals to their name, are expecting to sign Heidar Helguson for £1.5m and break the club transfer record for the second time this season.

The 22-year-old Iceland international striker was Lillestrom's leading scorer in the last Norwegian season, scoring 16 goals in 21 games. Terms have been agreed and Watford, who first broke their record in September by paying Real Zaragoza £950,000 for Nordin Wooter, are hopeful that he will line up when Liverpool visit on Saturday.

Blackpool's new manager Steve McMahon has signed Gary Ablett, now 34. The defender, released by Birmingham City on New Year's eve, had agreed to join Scunthorpe on a non-contract basis but made a last-minute switch to link up with his former Liverpool team-mate. He will line up alongside Kevin Richardson, 37, who has joined the Bloomfield Road club on a month's loan from Barnsley.

Celtic are to sell Harald Brattbakk to FC Copenhagen for £650,000 after the Norwegian agreed a three-year deal.

webTitle: Waugh hits out at Shoaib reprieve

fields.headline: Waugh hits out at Shoaib reprieve
fields.trailText: Trinations tournament The Australia captain Steve Waugh has spoken out strongly against the "confusing" decision to reinstate Shoaib Akhtar for the trinations one-day series as the previously banned fast bowler helped Pakistan to a thrilling two-wicket victory over India at the Gabba in Brisbane.
fields.body:
The Australia captain Steve Waugh has spoken out strongly against the "confusing" decision to reinstate Shoaib Akhtar for the trinations one-day series as the previously banned fast bowler helped Pakistan to a thrilling two-wicket victory over India with his second display of quality strike bowling yesterday at the Gabba in Brisbane.

Waugh said he personally saw nothing wrong with Shoaib's action but he criticised the International Cricket Council's about-turn after a challenge by the Pakistan board. "It hasn't been handled that well... the players don't have a lot of confidence in what's happened.

"I think everyone is confused about it. One week you can't bowl and the next week you can."

The so-called Rawalpindi Express, who had been ordered to take a month out to remodel his bouncer action, took three for 19 in a fiery spell. India were reduced to 77 for four before partially recovering to muster 195 when Saurav Ganguly (61) and Robin Singh (50) dug in.

Pakistan were soon in trouble in their reply, however, collapsing to 71 for six before defiance from the man of the match Yousuf Youhana (63).

Even so victory looked remote until the off-spinner Saqlain Mushtaq (27 not out) and Waqar Younis (13 not out) - whose stand had also secured a 45-run victory over the hosts on Sunday, set up by Shoaib's three-wicket haul - guided Pakistan home with an unbroken 47-run partnership.

 Shane Warne's side strain, which came when he tore a muscle below the left shoulder in the defeat by Pakistan, may put him out for up to four weeks. He will probably miss all of the tournament's pool stage, which ends on January 31.

The Australian leg-spinner, set to play for Hampshire next summer, said: "I won't rush back because there is a lot of cricket coming up. I've had injuries before and come back, so hopefully it will not be different this time."

webTitle: Knight makes case for Butcher's place

fields.headline: Knight makes case for Butcher's place
fields.standfirst:
South Africa Invitation XI: 253-7 dec
England: 312-7
fields.trailText: Mark Butcher and Chris Adams popped into the dressing room here at St George's Park during play yesterday, and it must have been a chastening experience. Although neither is certain of a place in the fifth and final Test and both are short of runs, they were omitted from this match against a South African Invitation XI.
fields.body:
Mark Butcher and Chris Adams popped into the dressing room here at St George's Park during play yesterday, and it must have been a chastening experience. Although neither is certain of a place in the fifth and final Test and both are short of runs, they were omitted from this match against a South African Invitation XI.

This is a flat, benign pitch and Nick Knight, not one to waste an opportunity, took full advantage. The Warwickshire left-hander, who must be pushing hard for Butcher's Test place if not now then at the start of the summer, made 111, his first century in a first-class match since the end of the 1998 season.

There were runs too for Graeme Hick, who made 57 at around a run a ball before allowing himself to be bowled, and Vikram Solanki, 40, whose first scoring shot for the senior side was a six over square leg. Not one run, though, for Darren Maddy, who is aiming to replace Butcher or Adams on Friday, only two for Gavin Hamilton, who should take the injured Andy Flintoff's place, and only 25 for Michael Vaughan.

Of the 312 for seven scored by the England XI before bad light intervened, 243 came from imports for the one-day games and 22 from no balls, 16 of them bowled by the sulky paceman Roger Telemachus.

Knight was twice dropped, at first slip when on 64 and, more difficult, at midwicket when 90. He played well enough, though, with his customary blend of attack when the field was up and the ball new, and discipline when, as is the South African way on ideal batting surfaces, the fielders went back and the Invitation side bowled a defensive line.

When Maddy poked a catch to slip in the ninth over, Knight had made 37 of the 44 for the first wicket; he reached his half-century from 65 balls. Thereafter it was harder graft, first in a partnership of 71 with Vaughan lasting almost two hours, then 99 with Hick for the third wicket, to which Knight contributed 40.

Having made his century (217 minutes, 160 balls, 12 fours) Knight tried hard to get out, spanking a further two boundaries before succeeding. Hick's powerful play brought him seven fours and a straight six which rattled the sightscreen; and Solanki looked organised and composed during his 90-minute stay, hitting seven fours to go with the six.

Knight said that it had been rather easier than he had expected after a winter lay-off. "I wasn't exactly sure how it would go because I've done a lot of indoor nets before I came out here but there is only so much you can do indoors. We were just approaching it as a practice match ahead of the one-day series.

"It was a good pitch for me first up. I was not sure how I would go but I got off to a flyer. When they set the field back I decided to be patient but aware of any bad balls. Then later it was just a case of pushing on.

"You never know what will happen for the Test, but that's not really my problem, is it? They have told us they are going to pick the guys that were already here and I just approached it as spending valuable time out in the middle."

Nevertheless Knight remains ambitious and keen to add to his dozen Test caps. To get back in, though, he must demonstrate in more testing circumstances and against significantly better bowling that the flaws in his technique - generally suspect outside off stump, with a tendency also to play around his front pad - have been ironed out.

He ascribes the faults to incorrect footwork and a wonky backlift. "The question of my technique always comes up and perhaps I have not been as consistent as I would like. I am trying to correct some things that have been with me for years, trying to get a tighter game so that, when the runs are not coming, there is something, a straighter technique, to fall back on. But I'm 30 now and time can run out. I need to push my case now."

webTitle: Bond is not enough for 007 star Brosnan

fields.headline: Bond is not enough for 007 star Brosnan
fields.standfirst: Also today, Alanis a supposed directing junkie, Harrison Ford's future looks risky, Gillian Anderson be a Jedi Knight? A talking mouse still tops US box-office, in brief, and the latest casting news
fields.trailText: Fresh from his success in The World is Not Enough, Pierce Brosnan has acquired the rights to Burnt Sienna, the as-yet unpublished novel by Rambo writer David Morrell, with a view to producing and starring in an adaptation later this year.
fields.body:
Fresh from his success in The World is Not Enough, Pierce Brosnan has acquired the rights to Burnt Sienna, the as-yet unpublished novel by Rambo writer David Morrell, with a view to producing and starring in an adaptation later this year.

Variety reports that Brosnan will play a former US marine turned artist who comes out of retirement to spearhead a CIA mission in Mexico. Production is scheduled to begin after the actor has completed work on John Boorman's fledgling project The Tailor of Panama, based on the book by John Le Carre. Both projects reveal Brosnan's unwillingness to become straitjacketed by his 007 tuxedo. Last year the Irish-born actor scored a box-office hit by producing and starring in a glitzy remake of the sixties heist thriller The Thomas Crown Affair.

Alanis a supposed directing junkie

Alanis Morrisette is mulling over a move into film direction, it was reported today. In an online interview on the music site MP3.com, the Canadian songbird (currently cameo-ing as an unlikely God in Kevin Smith's Dogma) confirmed that she has several projects at various stages of development, but would not be drawn as to their content.

Morrisette has already directed some of the videos from her recent album Supposed Former Infatuation Junkie. "I've had a little bit of exposure (to direction) but I am going to be a student in a pretty big way," she says.

The future looks risky for Harrison Ford

Harrison Ford is poised to sign up to a Hollywood agency for the first time in 15 years. The 57-year-old star, who recently scooped the People's Choice Award for Favourite Motion Picture Actor, has been represented solely by his personal manager Pat McQueeney since 1984.

Ford's move is being interpreted as suggesting a shift towards more edgy and ambitious projects. The actor established his reputation with career-making performances for the likes of George Lucas (American Graffiti , Star Wars ) and Steven Spielberg (Raiders of the Lost Ark) and blossomed into one of the 90s' most bankable players, with roles in The Fugitive and Patriot Games .

But recent pictures such as Six Days, Seven Nights and Sidney Pollack's plane-crash drama Random Hearts have fared poorly at the box-office. There is a growing feeling among industry insiders that Ford has been playing it too safe, and is in danger of devaluing his currency with conservative career choices in formulaic studio produce.

The brief for the chosen agency will be to seek out innovative scripts and younger writer-directors. "In the world of movie-making as we know it today, studio films are only one part of the equation," Pat McQueeney told Variety. "There is also another segment of the industry emerging, and that is now writer-directors that are bringing a fresh vision and an exciting voice to their material. I want to take advantage of those opportunities for Harrison and I feel the need for some help." McQueeney plans to stay on as Ford's manager and liaise directly between the actor and his agency.

Ford's search has triggered a predictable feeding frenzy within Hollywood. Agencies currently in contention number William Morris, United Talent Agency, International Creative Management, the inevitable Creative Artists Agency and Michael Ovitz's new Artists Management Group.

Harrison Ford has just completed work on the supernatural thriller What Lies Beneath, directed by Robert Zemeckis, and is now preparing a fourth instalment in Spielberg's profitable Indiana Jones series. Whatever Ford's agency choice, it seems that the riskier roles will have to wait for the time being.

Will Gillian Anderson be playing a Jedi Knight?

The latest word on Gillian Anderson purports to come from the horse's mouth. A spy on film website Dark Horizons reports: "I asked her if the following were true: according to rumour, Gillian would be playing a Jedi Council Member who is newly appointed to the Council and was trained by Qui-Gon (and may have been more to him). As I asked her this, she just smiled and didn't say a word! She did say she though she would be filming a movie outside the United States around the time Episode II will be shot.

"Then she said she would not be replacing Jodie Foster in Hannibal, as her X-Files contract currently states that she cannot play an FBI Agent in any other film as this would be in conflict of interest with her character on The X-Files."

The Mouse still owns the house

A host of Academy Award contenders turned out to be no match for Columbia's animated Stuart Little which held on to the top US box-office spot at the weekend with an estimated $11.5 million. The film, which has now grossed more than $95 million, is due to pass the $100 million mark this week. Entertainment analyst Art Rockwell observed that even Sony (Columbia's parent company) had been unprepared for the film's success. "It was a project that Sony was never quite sure of," Rockwell said. "They were unprepared for success ... as evidenced by the lack of merchandising exploitation."

In brief

Over on Dark Horizons you can check out what's rumoured to be an opening shot by shot sequence of Scream 3, which opens in the US on February 4.

Johnny Rotten will be at this year's Sundance film festival for the premiere of the Sex Pistols documentary, The Filth and the Fury. We don't know whether he'll be playing or not.

Casting couch

Patrick Swayze and Natasha Richardson are in final negotiations to star alongside Billy Bob Thornton and Charlize Theron in Waking Up in Reno for director Jordan Brady. In addition, Swayze is also in final negotiations to take on a role in Tony and Timothy Bui's indie feature Puff the Magic Dragon.

Jan De Bont, no stranger to disaster films, will direct and produce the ecological disaster project Dust. The film is based on a novel by author-scientist Charles Pellegrino, who created the dinosaur-cloning theory that inspired Michael Crichton's Jurassic Park book.
fields.bodyText: Fresh from his success in The World is Not Enough, Pierce Brosnan has acquired the rights to Burnt Sienna, the as-yet unpublished novel by Rambo writer David Morrell, with a view to producing and starring in an adaptation later this year. Variety reports that Brosnan will play a former US marine turned artist who comes out of retirement to spearhead a CIA mission in Mexico. Production is scheduled to begin after the actor has completed work on John Boorman's fledgling project The Tailor of Panama, based on the book by John Le Carre. Both projects reveal Brosnan's unwillingness to become straitjacketed by his 007 tuxedo. Last year the Irish-born actor scored a box-office hit by producing and starring in a glitzy remake of the sixties heist thriller The Thomas Crown Affair. Alanis a supposed directing junkie Alanis Morrisette is mulling over a move into film direction, it was reported today. In an online interview on the music site MP3.com, the Canadian songbird (currently cameo-ing as an unlikely God in Kevin Smith's Dogma) confirmed that she has several projects at various stages of development, but would not be drawn as to their content. Morrisette has already directed some of the videos from her recent album Supposed Former Infatuation Junkie. "I've had a little bit of exposure (to direction) but I am going to be a student in a pretty big way," she says. The future looks risky for Harrison Ford Harrison Ford is poised to sign up to a Hollywood agency for the first time in 15 years. The 57-year-old star, who recently scooped the People's Choice Award for Favourite Motion Picture Actor, has been represented solely by his personal manager Pat McQueeney since 1984. Ford's move is being interpreted as suggesting a shift towards more edgy and ambitious projects. The actor established his reputation with career-making performances for the likes of George Lucas (American Graffiti , Star Wars ) and Steven Spielberg (Raiders of the Lost Ark) and blossomed into one of the 90s' most bankable players, with roles in The Fugitive and Patriot Games . But recent pictures such as Six Days, Seven Nights and Sidney Pollack's plane-crash drama Random Hearts have fared poorly at the box-office. There is a growing feeling among industry insiders that Ford has been playing it too safe, and is in danger of devaluing his currency with conservative career choices in formulaic studio produce. The brief for the chosen agency will be to seek out innovative scripts and younger writer-directors. "In the world of movie-making as we know it today, studio films are only one part of the equation," Pat McQueeney told Variety. "There is also another segment of the industry emerging, and that is now writer-directors that are bringing a fresh vision and an exciting voice to their material. I want to take advantage of those opportunities for Harrison and I feel the need for some help." McQueeney plans to stay on as Ford's manager and liaise directly between the actor and his agency. Ford's search has triggered a predictable feeding frenzy within Hollywood. Agencies currently in contention number William Morris, United Talent Agency, International Creative Management, the inevitable Creative Artists Agency and Michael Ovitz's new Artists Management Group. Harrison Ford has just completed work on the supernatural thriller What Lies Beneath, directed by Robert Zemeckis, and is now preparing a fourth instalment in Spielberg's profitable Indiana Jones series. Whatever Ford's agency choice, it seems that the riskier roles will have to wait for the time being. Will Gillian Anderson be playing a Jedi Knight? The latest word on Gillian Anderson purports to come from the horse's mouth. A spy on film website Dark Horizons reports: "I asked her if the following were true: according to rumour, Gillian would be playing a Jedi Council Member who is newly appointed to the Council and was trained by Qui-Gon (and may have been more to him). "Then she said she would not be replacing Jodie Foster in Hannibal, as her X-Files contract currently states that she cannot play an FBI Agent in any other film as this would be in conflict of interest with her character on The X-Files." webTitle: You just can't help some people

fields.headline: You just can't help some people
fields.trailText: A man is in his house when a rain storm begins. The water starts rising so he peers out the window and for as far as he can see there's flooding.
fields.body:
A man is in his house when a rain storm begins. The water starts rising so he peers out the window and for as far as he can see there's flooding.

Roads are covered. Nothing's moving. But pretty soon a boat comes along and a rescue worker yells out: "Come on - we're here to save you. Get in the boat."

The man in the house is having none of it. "No...I've got faith that God will save me," he says. The boat leaves. The water keeps rising. The man is forced up the second floor of his house by the flood waters.

Another boat comes along. A second rescuer yells: "Come on! It's getting worse. If you don't get in the boat, you're going to drown."

From the second floor window the man says, "No...I'll be ok. I've got faith in God that he'll save me."

The boat leaves. Water's rising. The man's on the roof. A helicopter hovers overhead and the pilot shouts out, "This is your last chance. Climb up the ladder. If you don't come now you're going to drown."

The man says from the roof, "No, thanks. God will save me."

The pilot shrugs his shoulders and flies away. The water rises. The man drowns and ascends to the pearly gates. He asks St Peter, "What happened? I've been devoted to God and had absolute faith that he would save me. Why did he let me down?"

And St Peter tells him, "What do you want? God sent you two boats and a helicopter?'

fields.headline: Blake blasts Liverpool out
fields.standfirst: Blake 84
fields.trailText: Just as Liverpool were beginning to believe their renaissance was nearing completion, Gérard Houllier's world fell apart here last night.
fields.body:
Just as Liverpool were beginning to believe their renaissance was nearing completion, Gérard Houllier's world fell apart here last night.

Having laid siege to the Blackburn Rovers goal for long spells of a compelling encounter, the Frenchman's reconstructed side succumbed to a goal six minutes from time from the striker Nathan Blake.

Exposing some of the old deficiencies in Liverpool's defence, Blake found himself totally unchallenged to volley home Per Frandsen's right-wing delivery and effectively render Liverpool's season null and void.

It was no more than Blackburn deserved after a stirring display to provide further evidence supporting the theory that their own metamorphisis is near to a fruitful conclusion following troubled times.

But no such happy times for Houllier and his expensive side on another sorry occasion for a club which has known some traumatic cup nights in the past few years.

Blackburn have fond memories of the old place, having reached their zenith by prising the championship out of United's stubborn grasp on a famous day on Merseyside five years ago.

And, more recently, the indifference of their players during Brian Kidd's extravagant tenure has been ousted by a new-found solidarity and defiance since Tony Parkes finally accepted the missive of safeguarding Jack Walker's bags of gold.

In a pulsating opening Blackburn were the equal of their hosts, with Blake's pace and power in attack posing all sorts of problems.

Twice the Welsh international could have given them an early advantage after charging bullishly at the core of the home defence. On the first occasion he was culpable of bad judgment in a one-on-one position when opting for precision ahead of power and chipping his shot over the Liverpool goalkeeper Sander Westerveld but wide of the target.

His next effort carried far greater conviction but his venomous 20-yarder was beaten away by Westerveld's one-handed save.

By far the busier goalkeeper during the opening 45 minutes, Westerveld was also readily placed to contend with shots from Frandsen and Simon Grayson, a 10th-minute substitute for the injured Jeff Kenna, as Blackburn continued to bridge the gulf in status with an ease which will have troubled Houllier.

Liverpool, too, had their moments, but only sporadically. Best of all was a slick interchange of breathtaking speed that dissected the entire Blackburn defence only for Danny Murphy to remind us all that he is far from Michael Owen in front of goal.

Worst of all was a preposterous volley from Titi Camara from inside the centre-circle, of all places, that barely dribbled to the edge of John Filan's penalty area.

Murphy's final act was to divert Steven Gerrard's low centre into the side netting before being replaced by David Thompson. That allowed Vladimir Smicer to move into a more central role and, with Camara becoming an increasingly potent force, Liverpool regained the initiative in the second half without providing too many stern examinations for Filan.

But Blackburn were refusing to be overawed and Parkes looked a picture of serenity compared to Houllier and his frantic sidekick Phil Thompson.

Houllier's side may have the most impressive goals-against column in the Premiership but every now and then the excruciating fragility that has been part of their make-up over a turbulent decade pokes its head menacingly above the surface.

With that in mind, a fax was despatched from Houllier's office to Bayern Munich late yesterday detailing his intentions to open negotiations with the German international Marcus Babbel, a defender of justifed high repute who becomes a free agent at the end of the season.

webTitle: German party leader took cash from arms dealer

fields.headline: German party leader took cash from arms dealer
fields.trailText: In a new twist to the illicit funding scandal that has embroiled Germany's Christian Democrats, their leader, Wolfgang Schäuble, last night admitted he too had accepted cash from the arms dealer Karlheinz Schreiber for party funds.
fields.body:
In a new twist to the illicit funding scandal that has embroiled Germany's Christian Democrats, their leader, Wolfgang Schäuble, last night admitted he too had accepted cash from the arms dealer Karlheinz Schreiber for party funds.

The former chancellor Helmut Kohl is already under criminal investigation after admitting last year that he funnelled cash to the Christian Democrats (CDU) through a web of secret bank accounts. He has refused to name the donors, in contravention of German law.

According to a report to be published today in the newspaper Stuttgarter Zeitung, Mr Schäuble, who has always enjoyed a reputation for integrity, has been put "under massive pressure" by Mr Kohl to own up to his role in the irregular financing.

In an interview with the television channel ARD, Mr Schäuble said he took DM100,000 (£32,114) from the arms dealer which he had passed on to the party. He said that, unlike the money which Mr Kohl funnelled to the CDU, the cash he took did figure in the party's accounts but was reported under "miscellaneous income".

That would suggest that the handling of the donation contravened a law which calls for contributors who give more than DM20,000 to any political party to be identified.

Mr Schäuble, who became party chairman after Mr Kohl's crushing defeat in the 1998 election, was already under pressure to explain another mysterious - and apparently illicit - movement of funds.

Revised accounts released by the CDU at the end of last year showed that in January 1997, more than DM1m was sent by the parliamentary party to party headquarters in apparent defiance of a ban on such transfers. Mr Schäuble was leader of the parliamentary party at the time.

Mr Kohl is currently being investigated on a charge of "breach of trust", which is often used in cases of suspected financial misdemeanours. He also faces an all-party parliamentary commission inquiry which is to look into a claim that money given to the CDU during Mr Kohl's chancellorship influenced decisions made by his administration.

fields.headline: Children's book of the week
fields.standfirst: Lesley Howarth proves a master of the ordinariness of the odd in Mister Spaceman
fields.trailText: Lesley Howarth proves a master of the ordinariness of the odd in Mister Spaceman
fields.body:
Mister Spaceman </B
Lesley Howarth
Published by Walker Books
Price £9.99
Age 10+

Thomas Moon is obsessed with outer space and fantasises about becoming an astronaut. Little by little the fantasy begins to take over, until it's more comfortable to live in the spacecraft of his imagination than in the real world.

In fact, he is withdrawing in all kinds of ways. Misbehaviour on a school trip to the theatre, blown up out of all proportion by the headteacher, results in his suspension, and during his enforced time at home (like being on a long space voyage) he begins to act in ways that must look deeply disturbed to others.

But because Lesley Howarth is firmly on Thomas's side, and locates the narrative solidly with him, we're never lost. The reader can always follow his reasons for sleeping in a sleeping bag hung on a hook in his wall, for example. The crisis is resolved with great storytelling tact and craft, and the happy ending grows naturally out of the way things have been since the start of the story.

Howarth is superb at conveying the ordinariness of the odd, and the oddness of the ordinary. The deadpan humour and the offhand compassion make this, I think, her best book since the award-winning Maphead.
fields.bodyText: Mister Spaceman

fields.headline: How low can they go?
fields.standfirst: WSC wonders what the FA won't trample over in their bid to host the 2006 World Cup
fields.trailText: England's bid to host the 2006 World Cup may have many things to recommend it in comparison with its two main competitors, but if the price to be paid is the slow poisoning of English football, surely few will agree that it is worth it.
fields.body:
England's bid to host the 2006 World Cup may have many things to recommend it in comparison with its two main competitors, but if the price to be paid is the slow poisoning of English football, surely few will agree that it is worth it.

Consider the victims so far. Perhaps the loss of Graham Kelly and Keith Wiseman has not been grievously felt, but their departure in a bid-related "scandal" was a sign of the disruptive power the campaign would have. This was equally obvious at an early stage in the blows dealt to England's international credibility by the FA's falling-out with Germany and their decision to back Sepp Blatter rather than Lennart Johansson as the successor to João Havelange as Fifa president.

So far, so bad, but nothing that would cause too many ordinary fans to lose much sleep. Yet the impact of the 2006 bid on the rebuilding of Wembley stadium and on the FA Cup have been much more widely felt. If it had not been for the central significance of the bid, the debate over Wembley's potential uses might have taken place in a much less fevered atmosphere. The FA's desire to get their way over the exclusion of athletics from the stadium was a direct result of the need to have their showpiece World Cup reconstruction project under way before the decision is made this summer.

The bid's impact on the FA Cup is all too obvious in Manchester United's ill-conceived jaunt to Brazil and the bitterness it has unleashed both among fans and in the press. The fact that United could not be bothered to defend the Cup was bad enough. But the wall-to-wall coverage of their trip to Rio has also helped divert attention from the games in the Cup itself, already forced into unpopular dates on the calendar by the need to accommodate the Champions League priorities of United and Chelsea. The crowds at Sheffield Wednesday, Everton and Aston Villa in the fourth round were surely evidence enough that tinkering with the format has disillusioned many fans (particularly those asked to stump up on top of their season ticket purchase).

What part of domestic football will the World Cup bid wreck next? Well, Tony Banks's political career looks a good bet, but few will care too much about that. But if David Davies's reported keenness to stage next year's alleged "World Club Championship" in England is any guide, the nauseating crawling to Fifa at the expense of domestic football has a fair way to run yet.

fields.headline: I'd like that in writing
fields.standfirst: By law, every parent of a schoolchild in England and Wales should by now have been invited to sign a home-school agreement. In the first of a series looking at parents' role in education,  Phil Revell finds that the agreements have raised expectations and provoked irritation in equal measure
fields.trailText: By law, every parent of a schoolchild in England and Wales should by now have been invited to sign a home-school agreement. In the first of a series looking at parents' role in education, Phil Revell finds that the agreements have raised expectations and provoked irritation in equal measure
fields.body:
Improving parents' commitment to their children's education has long been thought to be one of the best ways of lifting performance. Why? Because higher aspirations generally bring better results. So in theory, the introduction of obligatory home-school agreements should be a step towards raising school standards.

"Parents will be better aware of the importance of helping their child at school," said education minister Jacqui Smith last year. "In signing these agreements, parents will be acknowledging their partnership with the school to help educate their child."

The practice, though, hasn't been so simple. Critics saw the initiative as more evidence of the government's managerialist approach, with neither parents nor teachers being trusted to raise and educate children without government direction and interference.

David Gordon, chairman of the Campaign for State Education, described the initiative as "patronising". "It is an insult to parents," he said, "to suggest that they will only get their children to school on time... and help them with their homework if they sign an agreement."

Margaret Morrisey at the National Confederation of Parent Teacher Associations described the new agreements as a "non event". Many schools had them already and in schools where there were problems between teachers and parents, she said, "the situation isn't necessarily improved by the existence of a formal document".

Like many new Labour policies, home-school agreements are actually a Conservative idea, touted by the Major government as a "contract" between parents and schools that would allow parents to call teachers to account. The word contract was soon dropped, when doubters pointed out the potential difficulties involved in enforcing either side of the deal.

But the principle neatly fitted new Labour's core philosophy. One of the key values outlined by Anthony Giddens in his book The Third Way was "no rights without responsibilities". And in 1998, David Blunkett, the education secretary, laid the blame for poor educational performance firmly at the door of parents.

"Where there is a problem," he said, "It is all too often because parents claim not to have the time... So far from being a nanny state, we must become an enabling state, which ensures that parents and families have the backing when they need it."

At Westwood High School in Staffordshire, which has had a home-school agreement for some years, headteacher George Wiskin argues that it's no bad thing to highlight the things the school believes are important. He believes that the process of setting up an agreement helped to focus on those values and led to an improvement in relationships, both inside and outside the school. But he also argues that it was "foolish" of the government to give the policy such a high profile last year and he's concerned that further development of the policy could lead to government-set benchmarks, consumer standards that schools would have to meet.

The criticism that the agreements are one-sided, that schools are in effect only promising to deliver what parents would expect as a minimum, has been made by organisations such as the National Confederation of Parent Teacher Associations. And the idea of a more equal relationship is not unattractive to parents like Gillian Wheeldon, whose children attend Sunnyhill Junior School in London.

Sunnyhill's agreement is based on the government model, which Wheeldon thinks "was a bit bland". She has no complaints about the school, where she is a governor, but she feels that parents might welcome an agreement with more teeth. "Most parents would like termly parents' evenings," she said, "but this is a dialogue which you would hope would evolve."

This point is made forcefully in a research paper based on a three-year project that examined parents' relationships with secondary schools. Author Gill Crozier of Bath Spa University College concluded that schools "have not been successful... in consulting with parents". One father was quoted in the study complaining that when consultation did occur, it was more symbolic than real.

"They've got fixed ideas about what they're doing, and how they are going to do it," he said. "I think they expect you to comply."

Annie Clews, headteacher at Sunnyhill, took a more positive view. "It's about opening up access," she said. The school's agreement (below) was drawn up by parent governors who spent the summer consulting with other parents, both formally and in playground conversation. Sunnyhill's pupils were involved and the rule about looking after one's own feet and hands came directly from them. Very few parents refused to sign the agreement; Clews is more concerned about the families who simply failed to return the form.

"These were precisely the families we'd like to see in school more often," she said. And that's the true weakness of the policy. It's naive to believe that a written document will effect changes that are deeply rooted in a family's economic and social conditions. "One parent came in to complain," said Clews, "because she was angry about having to fill in an extra form."

Clews believes that the agreements may represent just another lever for the middle-class parent and she's concerned about the "have not" groups for whom the form is just another state-inspired irritant. But, like George Wiskin, she believes the process was worth it; genuine contact took place between parent governors, parents and teachers.

 Parental Involvement: Who Wants It? by Gill Crozier (International Studies in Sociology of Education, Vol 9 No2 1999).

Promises, promises

This is the home-school agreement for Sunnyhill School in Streatham, London

Pupil's promise:

 I will keep the class and school rules
 I will deliver letters home from school on the same day they are sent out
 I will be friendly and respect others, their cultures, traditions, beliefs and rights to be different from me
 I will be polite and help others
 I will take good care of the equipment and building
 I will keep my hands and feet to myself
 I will talk quietly
 I will walk inside the building
 I will do my homework on time to the best of my ability

Sunnyhill School will:

 Have a clear behaviour policy
 Encourage children to do their best at all times
 Encourage children to take care of their surroundings and of others
 Inform parents of their child's progress annually in written form
 Inform parents of what the teachers aim to teach the children each term

fields.bodyText: Improving parents' commitment to their children's education has long been thought to be one of the best ways of lifting performance. Why? Because higher aspirations generally bring better results. So in theory, the introduction of obligatory home-school agreements should be a step towards raising school standards. "Parents will be better aware of the importance of helping their child at school," said education minister Jacqui Smith last year. "In signing these agreements, parents will be acknowledging their partnership with the school to help educate their child." The practice, though, hasn't been so simple. Critics saw the initiative as more evidence of the government's managerialist approach, with neither parents nor teachers being trusted to raise and educate children without government direction and interference. David Gordon, chairman of the Campaign for State Education, described the initiative as "patronising". "It is an insult to parents," he said, "to suggest that they will only get their children to school on time... and help them with their homework if they sign an agreement." Margaret Morrisey at the National Confederation of Parent Teacher Associations described the new agreements as a "non event". Many schools had them already and in schools where there were problems between teachers and parents, she said, "the situation isn't necessarily improved by the existence of a formal document". Like many new Labour policies, home-school agreements are actually a Conservative idea, touted by the Major government as a "contract" between parents and schools that would allow parents to call teachers to account. The word contract was soon dropped, when doubters pointed out the potential difficulties involved in enforcing either side of the deal. But the principle neatly fitted new Labour's core philosophy. One of the key values outlined by Anthony Giddens in his book The Third Way was "no rights without responsibilities". And in 1998, David Blunkett, the education secretary, laid the blame for poor educational performance firmly at the door of parents. "Where there is a problem," he said, "It is all too often because parents claim not to have the time... So far from being a nanny state, we must become an enabling state, which ensures that parents and families have the backing when they need it." At Westwood High School in Staffordshire, which has had a home-school agreement for some years, headteacher George Wiskin argues that it's no bad thing to highlight the things the school believes are important. He believes that the process of setting up an agreement helped to focus on those values and led to an improvement in relationships, both inside and outside the school. But he also argues that it was "foolish" of the government to give the policy such a high profile last year and he's concerned that further development of the policy could lead to government-set benchmarks, consumer standards that schools would have to meet. The criticism that the agreements are one-sided, that schools are in effect only promising to deliver what parents would expect as a minimum, has been made by organisations such as the National Confederation of Parent Teacher Associations. And the idea of a more equal relationship is not unattractive to parents like Gillian Wheeldon, whose children attend Sunnyhill Junior School in London. Sunnyhill's agreement is based on the government model, which Wheeldon thinks "was a bit bland". She has no complaints about the school, where she is a governor, but she feels that parents might welcome an agreement with more teeth. "Most parents would like termly parents' evenings," she said, "but this is a dialogue which you would hope would evolve." This point is made forcefully in a research paper based on a three-year project that examined parents' relationships with secondary schools. Author Gill Crozier of Bath Spa University College concluded that schools "have not been successful... in consulting with parents". One father was quoted in the study complaining that when consultation did occur, it was more symbolic than real. "They've got fixed ideas about what they're doing, and how they are going to do it," he said. "I think they expect you to comply." Annie Clews, headteacher at Sunnyhill, took a more positive view. "It's about opening up access," she said. The school's agreement (below) was drawn up by parent governors who spent the summer consulting with other parents, both formally and in playground conversation. Sunnyhill's pupils were involved and the rule about looking after one's own feet and hands came directly from them. Very few parents refused to sign the agreement; Clews is more concerned about the families who simply failed to return the form. "These were precisely the families we'd like to see in school more often," she said. And that's the true weakness of the policy. It's naive to believe that a written document will effect changes that are deeply rooted in a family's economic and social conditions. "One parent came in to complain," said Clews, "because she was angry about having to fill in an extra form." Clews believes that the agreements may represent just another lever for the middle-class parent and she's concerned about the "have not" groups for whom the form is just another state-inspired irritant. But, like George Wiskin, she believes the process was worth it; genuine contact took place between parent governors, parents and teachers.  Parental Involvement: Who Wants It? by Gill Crozier (International Studies in Sociology of Education, Vol 9 No2 1999). webTitle: Split vote may offer NatWest takeover escape

fields.headline: Split vote may offer NatWest takeover escape
fields.trailText: Anxiety mounted in the City last night that NatWest might cling to its independence by default if its major shareholders are divided in their support for the competing bids by Bank of Scotland and Royal Bank of Scotland.
fields.body:
Anxiety mounted in the City last night that NatWest might cling to its independence by default if its major shareholders are divided in their support for the competing bids by Bank of Scotland and Royal Bank of Scotland.

As all three banks began to step up their charm offensive to persuade major institutional investors to back them, Sir George Mathewson, chief executive of the Royal Bank, admitted there were some concerns that shareholders might be deluged with information in the run up to the St Valentine's day deadline.

Senior banking sources are worried this might breed apathy among investors or, as investors begin to bite on certain arguments, split the vote between the three camps.

Reflecting what was described by one banker as an increasing body of opinion in the City, one major shareholder in NatWest, said: "There appears to be some concern in the market that there could be a situation where 35% [of shareholders] go for Royal Bank, 35% for Bank of Scotland, neither one succeeds and NatWest remains independent. Yet 70% will have opted for a takeover."

NatWest's hopes of escaping the competing bids are said to have been improved since the appointment of Gordon Pell from Lloyds TSB to run its British banking operation, and whom Sir George said yesterday he might retain if his firm's bid is successful.

Sir George yesterday accused NatWest of selective use of a report by consultancy firm Deloitte Research and produced a letter from the firm saying its research had been used out of context by NatWest to prove mergers did not work.

His bank's shares have been bought by CGU, the insurance group, which spent £50m as part of its support for the offer.

NatWest, which retorted with new statistics about bank mergers, yesterday boosted its case for independence by announcing an alliance with Chase Merchant Services of the US to process credit card transactions, in which they are both market leaders.

NatWest's fund management operation, Gartmore, also announced a strong improvement in its performance to 27% over the year, which might help to raise the price for NatWest which is selling it off as part of its defence.

Paul Myners, chairman of Gartmore, which has suffered client defections due to poor performance in the past, intends to be more selective about clients taken on in future.

fields.headline: A lesson in respect
fields.standfirst: In our technology-obsessed society, the role of teacher is often overlooked. But their skills are quite irreplaceable, says  Ted Wragg
fields.trailText: In our technology-obsessed society, the role of teacher is often overlooked. But their skills are quite irreplaceable, says Ted Wragg
fields.body:
"I started crying when the best new teacher made her speech and I finished when the winner of the Lifetime Award was cheered by her class. I got through a whole box of tissues."

That was how one viewer, not a teacher, reacted to the 1999 Teaching Awards ceremony shown on prime-time television in July. Sitting in the audience as one of the judges, I experienced that same wrung-out feeling alongside hundreds of other people. There was barely a dry hanky in the house.

So why was it such an emotional occasion? After all, teaching has been a most vilified profession in recent years. Hardly a week goes by without some newspaper, politician or chief inspector pointing out yet more real or imagined failings in this battered group. You would have expected boos and hisses from the general public, not cheers and tears.

The occasion may have been cathartic. We all resent teachers to some extent, as they are usually our first authority figure outside the family, a collage of Mr Plod, the person who chases you away when you try to scrump apples, and Torquemada. Parents may dislike them even more. When your carefully house-trained five-year-old starts arguing with you, boldly asserting "But my teacher says...", even the most mild-mannered parent turns into Vlad the Impaler.

Beneath the resentment, however, lurk a mixture of gratitude and respect. We are subconsciously grateful to the people who relieve us of much of the responsibility for equipping our children to face the complexities of life. Although some hardy souls teach their children at home, most of us are delighted that we do not have to coach 10 GCSEs in the lounge every night after a hard day at work.

I once interviewed more than 100 parents as part of a research project. All had been invited into school to see their child's primary teacher at work. In reply to the question "What did you think about your child's class teacher?", most said, "I don't know how she does it. I can barely cope with my two children and she has 30."

Respect is more likely than contempt if people take the trouble to look at what teaching actually entails.

When done effectively, teaching earns respect, for it is such a complexity of knowledge, skills and personal qualities. Some people believe that teachers may become redundant in our information-rich society, where billions of facts reside on the internet alone. But there is a vast difference between "information" and "knowledge". Information is out there, sometimes alien and elusive. Personal knowledge is what we have mastered and internalised.

Imagine a class of eight-year-olds studying the national curriculum. The teacher begins: "Right. You'll be studying the Vikings this term, but you won't need me, because these computers around the room contain 500 video clips of Viking life, 1,000 still pictures of Viking maps and photos of artefacts, and 2 million screen pages of text. So you can start now." A hand goes up. "Please, Miss, who are the Vikings?" Intelligent adults help children to pick their way through these masses of facts.

Teaching is multi-dimensional. Ask world-class sprinters to demonstrate their athletic prowess and within five seconds they are 50 metres away. Some jobs are explosive and unidimensional, instantly demonstrable, immediately apparent. Teaching is for stayers, not sprinters. What do you do if someone asks you to demonstrate your teaching skill within five seconds? Tell someone off? Even worse if you are a head and someone wants quick evidence of your skill. You would have to pick up litter in the playground.

Teachers make hundreds of decisions every day in one second or less. A pupil misbehaves. Do you punish? Suppose you know the child's parents are splitting up and he is very upset? Another pupil looks baffled: "I don't understand what you said about an insect's eye." Within a second you have to decide whether to use an analogy: "It's like marbles in a polythene bag," or "It's like banks of television sets in a shop window".

The planet existed for billions of years before someone discovered that water consists of two atoms of hydrogen and one of oxygen. It takes a skilful teacher less than a minute to pass on that information. Last year's awards drew public attention to what good teachers achieve by honouring a tiny fraction of those who serve society so well. I hope this year's momentous 2000 event gives due recognition to more.

 Ted Wragg is professor of education at Exeter University.

webTitle: Teaching is for stayers, not sprinters

fields.headline: Teaching is for stayers, not sprinters
fields.standfirst: Do you know teachers who deserve credit for their work? Then get your nomination in now, says  Rebecca Smithers
fields.trailText: Do you know teachers who deserve credit for their work? Then get your nomination in now, says Rebecca Smithers
fields.body:
Teachers featured more prominently than ever before in the New Year Honours list, not least because of further plaudits given to four of the national winners in last year's first Teaching Awards.

The Lifetime Achievement winner, Maureen Davies from St Sebastian's school in Liverpool, received a CBE, while three other winners were awarded OBEs. They are Norma Machell, Primary Teacher of the Year, who was memorably recorded receiving her Plato trophy by the prime minister during a surprise visit to her school, Scarcroft primary in York; Romelda Scannelli, Secondary Teacher of the Year, of Uplands Community College in East Sussex; and Bob Jennings of St George Community School in Bristol, who was recognised for his work with parents and the community.

Lord Puttnam, chairman of the Teaching Awards, said the honours capped a tremendous year of achievement within the teaching profession.

"When we set out to establish these awards for teachers, our intention was to recognise and celebrate the tremendous contribution they make to society," he said. "These New Year Honours are yet another testimony to the extraordinary work being done up and down the country every day of the week."

As an extra incentive to enter this year's awards, schools have been given more time to nominate their top teachers and win a cash prize of up to £20,000, as well as a coveted Plato trophy.

The deadline for applications of December 6 has been extended until February 14 in order to give more schools the chance to submit their applications. This year's timetable has also been subject to some tweaking, with regional ceremonies taking place in June and the national ceremony - which will be shown live on BBC TV - being moved to October.

Remember that the awards are open to all schools in England, Wales and Northern Ireland. All teachers, from every subject and activity, are eligible, including heads. All nominees, with the exception of those in the new classroom assistant category, must have qualified teaching status.

 For further information visit the official website, email info@teachingawards.com, or telephone 020-7388 1911
