webTitle: 'When I realised I'd won I felt sick with shock'

fields.headline: 'When I realised I'd won I felt sick with shock'
fields.trailText: It's 2pm on a half-term Saturday and Flo Whitcombe is in her classroom at Inverteign Junior School in Teignmouth. She has been hard at work creating a hanging display.
fields.body:
It's 2pm on a half-term Saturday and Flo Whitcombe is in her classroom at Inverteign Junior School in Teignmouth. She has been hard at work creating a hanging display.

"I wanted to get this done earlier on in the week, but I went down with flu. It's classic - the immune system knows that there's a chance of a rest and it says to the bugs, 'Come and get me'."

Her thoughts return to the awards back in July. "When I realised I had won I felt sick with shock. I hadn't a clue. I suppose I was naive. The BBC had filmed me teaching, but the crew said they were doing the same for all the finalists.

"Apparently, when it was announced on the TV, a yell went up from the houses near the school - someone said it sounded like England scoring a World Cup goal."

Flo's nomination had been popular among parents. "I grew up on an estate like the one many of our children come from and this definitely helped me relate to the parents. I also tried not to be too stiff. Just asking people to call me by my first name helped diffuse some of the tension at my first parents' evening."

After the excitement of the awards ceremony and all the attendant publicity, the realities of teaching have kicked in again: "Winning the award has not made getting to grips with the literacy or numeracy hours any easier." She feels that a highly structured approach fits maths: "There is still room for fun - the children respond really well to the mental arithmetic exercises."

But she worries that the time for creative writing, music, art and PE is being squeezed. Hence her presence in the classroom at the weekend - "I have some very talented artists in my class, and every time I get a new masterpiece I feel it deserves to be displayed."

It is this energy and concern for detail that in part explained her nomination. "The children definitely respond if their work is celebrated. A lot of them have fairly unstructured lives and they need every boost to their self-esteem and every bit of structure that the school can provide."

Flo was pleased to see the money she won benefiting the pupils: £8,000 went on a minibus. "It was provided by Leyland Daf at about half price. My winning definitely raised the profile of Inverteign Junior and helped us attract sponsorship. I want to paint the van a crazy colour so that people can spot it on its journeys."

Next on her shopping list is converting the empty caretaker's bungalow on site into a social and life skills centre.

Her advice to anyone nominated for the 2000 award is "Go for it - it has been entirely positive for the school. It was also a huge pleasure being able to thank colleagues publicly for their efforts helping me during my first teaching years.

"You will have a lot of attention paid to you by the press, and it can be hard to fit in. I was on the front page of the local newspaper for four weeks running. But then they sorted out their news priorities, and got back to other top stories, such as children losing toys on the beach, so it didn't go to my head."

webTitle: 'Now everyone knows we are a good school'

fields.headline: 'Now everyone knows we are a good school'
fields.trailText: Norma Machell still gets stopped in Tesco by strangers who want to know if she is that teacher who was on telly. For an essentially private person, a woman who has eschewed the limelight to dedicate herself to what she most values - classroom teaching, pure, inspired and simple - last year was a baptism of fire.
fields.body:
Norma Machell still gets stopped in Tesco by strangers who want to know if she is that teacher who was on telly. For an essentially private person, a woman who has eschewed the limelight to dedicate herself to what she most values - classroom teaching, pure, inspired and simple - last year was a baptism of fire.

Coming face to face with the prime minister in the middle of holding an assembly would test the nerve of most teachers, but Norma managed to keep her usual calm when Tony Blair decided to visit Scarcroft Junior School in York, unannounced, to deliver the good news himself - that she had been chosen as teacher of the year.

The ensuing publicity is not something she would have wished for, but she has learnt to appreciate it - if only for the enormous fillip it has given the school and the sense of pride it has given children and parents. She says: "Parents, even the men, told me they had cried when they watched the teaching awards on telly. I never realised how important it is to have the recognition."

But Norma does not see the recognition as something for herself alone. "We always knew we were a good school, but everybody knows it now. A lot of our parents are aware of what we do here because they are made very welcome, but it's getting it recognised from the outside. They feel it was their school that won the award and that's very important.

"What the award has done for me has been to bring recognition to what ordinary teachers are doing in ordinary classrooms," she says.

Norma is a deputy head with a full-time teaching load. Will she use the award as a springboard to a higher post? She says: "I'm 55, at the twilight of my career. I've accepted to be a judge for the awards, but my place is here in the classroom."

Winning the award hasn't engendered complacency. She's at school at 6.30 most mornings, preparing for the day to come. She says: "It's a long day, but I enjoy doing it. Planning and organisation are crucial. If you get that right, everything else falls into place."

The most enjoyable side of winning the award has been deciding how to spend the prize money. Pupils requested a statue of "Miss Machell" for the playground. One bright lad suggested the school buy a motorbike "because we don't have one".

Staff decided to go for luxuries - "all the extras we don't have". Scarcroft has bought a mobile stage and lighting as well as a microphone, costumes and props. The school has bought a football strip, and sweatshirts for the school's newly established choir. It has also acquired new play equipment for the infants and toys for the home corner, as well as a listening centre so that a group of children can listen to story tapes together. Norma also felt it was important that staff should benefit directly. "We bought a microwave and a proper table for the staffroom so we can eat a meal properly at lunchtime, rather than balance things on our knees."

fields.headline: 'What's wrong with giving teachers applause?'
fields.trailText: "People should not be scared of taking flak from colleagues by accepting a nomination," says David Waugh - the first winner of the Dorling Kindersley Best New Secondary Teacher Award.
fields.body:
"People should not be scared of taking flak from colleagues by accepting a nomination," says David Waugh - the first winner of the Dorling Kindersley Best New Secondary Teacher Award.

His colleagues at Beauchamp College outside Leicester were right behind him. "But the process was handled well," he says. "It was democratic. Teachers, governors, parents and students all voted.

"It is quite a long haul. You are inspected as part of the regional assessments and again ahead of the final award. I had Ian Beer, the chairman of the Independent Schools' Council, with me for three lessons, and students and colleagues were interviewed about me."

David was keen that his prize money should buy something lasting. Part of his £3,500 went towards the creation of an annual Beauchamp College Citizen of the Year Award, aimed at the student who has made the biggest positive impact on the school community.

David is ambitious. He had already accepted a move to Northampton School For Boys to run maths in the sixth form before he won the award. His view of the awards is entirely positive. "Some people may have confused the scheme with performance-related pay and fast-tracking. No doubt a lot of heads threw the award pack into the bin. But it had the support of all the teaching unions - an amazing thing. And after all, what is wrong with giving teachers some recognition and applause?"

webTitle: No more 'tenderness' from stung Russian forces

fields.headline: No more 'tenderness' from stung Russian forces
fields.trailText:
Russian forces battled today to retake two key Chechen towns partially overrun
by rebel fighters, while a general admitted that the "tender-heartedness" of
Russian soldiers had enabled the rebels to fight back.
fields.body:
Russian forces battled today to retake two key Chechen towns partially overrun by rebel fighters, while a general admitted that the "tender-heartedness" of Russian soldiers had enabled the rebels to fight back.

The Russian military has been forced on the defensive in Chechnya with rebel fighters launching counterattacks and driving back federal troops in some areas. The rebel offensive caught the Russians by surprise, embarrassing senior commanders who had been predicting imminent victory.

General Viktor Kazantsev said that troops should have been more thorough in searching houses when it took the towns of Shali and Argun last month, and said that from now on, any male over 10 years old and under 60 years old would be detained and "thoroughly checked".

Russian artillery shelled Shali and Argun today, which were partly taken by Chechen rebels during the weekend. Artillery also targeted the capital Grozny, where Chechen rebels still occupy the centre.

Russian troops also fought rebels near the village of Belorechiye, where about 400 fighters are believed to be based. General Kazantsev claimed that the Russians had rebuffed the rebel advances in Shali and Argun, but acknowledged that "mistakes" had been made when federal troops took control of the areas the first time.

Asked to clarify what he meant by mistakes, Kazantsev said: "They include our tender-heartedness and frequently absolutely groundless trust" when checking the areas for militants. A curfew has been imposed in the Russian-controlled areas of Chechnya.

Defence minister Igor Sergeyev and Sergei Ivanov, secretary of the security council, held talks with acting president Vladimir Putin today. Ivanov said on NTV television that new measures would be taken "to establish order in liberated regions so that the local population can see that order is here and for a long time".

Buoyed by the success of their attacks, Chechen rebels said the Russian military was in trouble and that they would launch more offensives. "This is just the beginning of a series of actions intended to free the areas occupied by the Russians," rebel chief of staff Mumadi Saidayev claimed.

Some 20 rebel strongholds, two command posts, four anti-aircraft systems, one mobile communication system, two armored vehicles and three trucks were destroyed in today's Russian air attacks, the military claimed.

The continued fighting came after Moscow admitted yesterday that its forces had suffered major losses. After Russian ground troops entered Chechnya in late September, they made steady progress across the province and encircled the capital by mid-December. But their drive has stalled in the face of intense rebel resistance in Grozny and in the southern mountains.

fields.headline: Repairing Jack's house
fields.standfirst:
Police reform must be from the bottom up

Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Until yesterday, the home secretary deserved praise for the way he had handled the Lawrence inquiry. Not only did he set up the inquiry into the murder of the black teenager, but within four weeks of the report being published he maintained the momentum for reform with a clear ministerial endorsement of an overwhelming majority of the inquiry's recommendations. But yesterday his footwork went awry.
fields.body:
Until yesterday, the home secretary deserved praise for the way he had handled the Lawrence inquiry. Not only did he set up the inquiry into the murder of the black teenager, but within four weeks of the report being published he maintained the momentum for reform with a clear ministerial endorsement of an overwhelming majority of the inquiry's recommendations. But yesterday his footwork went awry. A special inspector of constabulary inquiry into the Met's race relations policy - recommended by the Lawrence inquiry - produced a damning indictment but only an anodyne response from the home secretary. All Mr Straw, who remains the police authority for London until next year, was ready to concede was that the report's findings "in places will make uncomfortable reading".

Some discomfort. The two inspectors from outside the Met have produced a catalogue of failure. It includes not enough consultation with minority ethnic staff; confusion over where the responsibility for race relations training lies; a lack of understanding about who will be trained and up to what standard; only one out of nine boroughs inspected had a recruitment target for minority ethnic officers; poor marketing which had made it difficult for the Met to attract suitably qualified ethnic recruits; and too little done to retain existing ethnic officers with too little attention to improving the grievance procedure or monitor their career progress.

The report rightly pays tribute to the new racial and violent crime task force, which operates across the force investigating all manner of racial crimes from harassment to murder. It also praises the community safety units, operating at borough level. It concedes the Met's culture has become more enlightened, but notes "a pervasive feeling exists among some staff that what is seen as special treatment for the victims of racist attacks can only be delivered by prejudicing service to the wider community". It bluntly concludes that "until officers understand the impact of hate crime, the initial response to victims will remain an unfulfilled challenge."

Later this week, Jack Straw intends to compare the defining cases in different decades: the miscarriages of justice suffered by the Guildford Four (and the Birmingham Six) in the 1970s and the murder of Stephen Lawrence in the 1990s. He told our political editor that in the 1970s innocent people were found guilty, but in the Lawrence case it was the guilty who got away. What he failed to say - and had better address in his lecture - is the enormous difference in the consequences. For the police, the consequences of the miscarriages were relatively straight forward: the elimination of police practices which were already against the law to ensure the abuse did not continue. The Lawrence inquiry raised a more complex challenge: changing the attitudes and behaviour of officers towards black people on the street.

There is no point in believing this will change by orders from the top. Too many home secretaries and senior officers have deluded themselves into believing that directives - and the odd training day - will change behaviour. It won't. The Met is not a military organisation. The lower ranks do not have to listen to the top. By the nature of their task, huge discretion has to be extended to the people on the street. It can only be changed by working from the bottom, as smaller forces, like Staffordshire and Bedfordshire, have demonstrated. That is the challenge facing Mr Straw - and the new commissioner who takes over next month.

webTitle: Inspectors warn pressure might lead officers to take on 'easy to solve' cases

fields.headline: Inspectors warn pressure might lead officers to take on 'easy to solve' cases
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The inspectors were not blind to the different challenges facing the Metropolitan Police compared to regional forces in England and Wales, but warned they should not be used as an excuse to reduce the significance and importance of solving murders.
fields.body:
The inspectors were not blind to the different challenges facing the Metropolitan Police compared to regional forces in England and Wales, but warned they should not be used as an excuse to reduce the significance and importance of solving murders.

And while HMIC acknowledged that the Met dealt with more murders than any other force, they did not think this a reason to accept significantly lower detection rates.

Mr Blakey rejected arguments put forward by some senior detectives that a murder in London did not have the same impact as in a small town or village, and that it jostled with other crimes - such as terrorism and corruption - for priority status.

"Murder is the most serious of all crimes," the report said. "Other violent crimes such as robbery, rape and burglary are all terrible in their effect on victims and society, but murder ... is unique." He said the investigation of murder by Scotland Yard had to set "clear standards of excellence".

In London murders are investigated by five area major investigation pools. Mr Blakey said the disadvantage of this system was that the teams could be inflexible and that they often had to cope with unusually high workloads.

Mr Blakey found that some family liasion officers were hopelessly overstretched.

The report described how senior investigating officers regularly carried a caseload of between five and 12 murders. Mr Blakey was concerned that pressure would lead officers to focus time on "new 'easy to solve' cases at the expense of longer running cases".

He said he could not understand how some SIOs could be expected to manage and prioritise murder investigations.

The inspectorate said the Met was capable of successfully investigating complex and long-running murder inquiries, but that older investigations often lost out in terms of resources against competition from newly committed murders.

Mr Blakey recommended that the Met examine the amount of work SIOs can do and review the conditions of civilian members of staff. He said he had spoken to indexers who had worked nine consecutive weekends.

"The Met does not resource its murder investigations to the same level as provincial forces," the report concluded. "Whilst acknowledging the difficulties facing the Met in staffing to the provincial level, [the inspector] believes that this disparity reduces the opportunity to more quickly detect murders."

Better liaison with the crown prosecution service at the start of murder inquiries was also important.

Mr Blakey said he was "impressed by the skill and dedication of many officers" but that "much more needs to be done and the momentum for improvement must be maintained".

The Met's strategy towards race issues was also in need of reappraisal, the report said.

Mr Crompton said the Met did not seem to have any coherent strategy for community and race relations training of officers between 1989 and 1998. Although that had changed, there was still confusion over who was responsible for training and who will be trained. He called for a single pan-London strategy to clarify matters.

The report said a target of 4,000 black and Asian officers by 2010 was more realistic than the home office stipulation of 5,662. Despite this "exceptionally challenging task", only one of the nine boroughs inspected had included a recruitment target for ethnic minority officers within its local policing plan.

On the issue of stop and search, the report called for more independent research because studies into disproportionality undertaken by the Met would be seen as tainted.

Mr Crompton praised the "range of initiatives and lateral thinking" of senior officers who were tackling the problem, including the seven pilot sites around London which were being used to develop more sophisticated ways of using the tool.

But Mr Crompton warned there was "only limited evidence that stop and search was more intelligence led. It would still remain difficult to convince those who believe stop and search is wholly led by racial stereotyping to change their view".

Mr Crompton said the internal culture of the Met had changed in recent years but that "more should be done in securing the professional hearts and minds of non-specialist police officers.

"There is a pervasive feeling that what is seen as special treatment for the victims of racial attacks can only be delivered by prejudicing service to the wider society."

He said he was disappointed to find that there was only a limited monitoring of the career progression of black and Asian staff and called for proper evaluation at all levels.

Mr Crompton said the Met needed to do more to retain black and Asian staff. "A significant level of such officers leaving the Met not only has a negative impact on recruitment, but also a more subtle impact upon community and race relations."

Speaking at a press conference after the publication of the report, Mr Crompton said the Met had made good progress over the past 18 months in the field of community and race relations issues.

"However, there are still a number of areas to be addressed. I am confident that when these are revisited in 12 months time considerable improvements will have been made."

Beverley Thompson, the director of the National Association for the Care and Resettlement of Offenders, added: "In the past and still today, the experience of many black and ethnic minority people is that the police are more interested in treating them as suspects than as possible victims or witnesses."

webTitle: Straw does claim one liberal credential. But it has a flaw

fields.headline: Straw does claim one liberal credential. But it has a flaw
fields.standfirst:
The race relations bill would exempt officials from judicial oversight

Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Jack Straw takes pleasure, twice a year, in reminding the Guardian that he is not a liberal. The message is becoming redundant. He conveys it by scoffing at real liberals for being out of touch with those famous "ordinary people", whom his colleague, Lord Falconer, Tony Blair's most intimate political friend, defined the other day as an official Blairite category.
fields.body:
Jack Straw takes pleasure, twice a year, in reminding the Guardian that he is not a liberal. The message is becoming redundant. He conveys it by scoffing at real liberals for being out of touch with those famous "ordinary people", whom his colleague, Lord Falconer, Tony Blair's most intimate political friend, defined the other day as an official Blairite category.

Ordinary people, we learn, are as illiberal as Mr Straw: as anti-jury, as anti-justice, as coarsely demagogic in their pubs as he is in his speeches. This is a deeply condescending view of the people. But it establishes how comfortable Mr Straw feels, not to be a liberal.

He has always claimed, on the other hand, one liberal credential, which is that he opposes race discrimination. He is supposed to be seriously sound on race, and, judged not only by rhetoric but by certain policies, his claim isn't empty. One of his first, and admirable, acts as home secretary was to revoke the primary-purpose rule that caused so much misery, courtesy of the Tories, to immigrants coming here to marry.

He also reacted with a proper fury to the murder of Stephen Lawrence. When the Macpherson report came out, delineating the full horror of that dreadful event, he welcomed its conclusions, and vowed to act. Among other things, Macpherson demanded that the race relations act, in its "full force", should apply to all police officers, to meet the "institutional racism" of the Metropolitan police in particular. The race relations (amendment) bill is the product. It starts its committee stage in the Lords today.

The bill may have good intentions, but is flawed in ways which a principled anti-racist minister would not countenance. It does bring public bodies fully within anti-discrimination law. But it does so half- heartedly, retaining an exemption for public institutions which no private body - Sainsburys, the Law Society, Wentworth golf club - could ever be permitted. Studiously rejecting "full force", it creates no legal right of redress against public bodies - police, home office, benefits agency - which discriminate indirectly.

Indirect discrimination, the polite term for institutional racism, is now what this social cancer is all about. Direct, intentional acts in the employment or housing fields are rare these days. Even bad employers have wised up. But policies and practices which, while not necessarily intending to, have unfair effects on ethnic minorities remain legion: police stop-and-search patterns, dress restrictions bearing down on Muslims, language demands in schools, many other habits and tendencies, sometimes inadvertent, that our multicultural society has found the need, and created the mechanisms, to correct, principally through the Commission for Racial Equality.

For sometimes, apparent discrimination may be either illusory, or acceptable on larger grounds. Thanks to the evolution of social and moral judgment, a web of decent voluntary conduct is beginning to spread across the activities of private people and corporations.

The new bill doesn't exclude all public-sector activities from its reach. Where a policeman is merely offering the citizen advice, for example, his superiors could be pursued for indirect discrimination. But not in the case of much else he does. The bill makes complicated distinctions between one species of conduct and another - some in, some out - but with an overall purpose which is simple, not to say sinister: to exempt ministers and their officials, including the police, from judicial oversight for acts and policies and practices which, in the private sector, are now routinely justiciable.

This does not mean, say Mr Straw's minions, that the public sector will be free to carry on discriminating. Far from it. There will be declarations galore of good intent, and, at the back of them, the accountability of ministers to parliament.

What they insist must be avoided, however, is ministers' accountability to the courts. In their world, accountability to the thin tribunal of a one-party parliament is quite enough. Liberalism, a word that passes the leader's lips no more often than socialism, becomes ever less congenial than bureaucratic authoritarianism, to ministers now supping for three years at the pool of its narcotic possibilities.

webTitle: Race attack thugs may face new court action

fields.headline: Race attack thugs may face new court action
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The attorney general may be asked to sanction fresh prosecutions of two thugs involved in a racist street attack in 1978, following the death of the victim after 21 years in a persistent vegetative state.
fields.body:
The attorney general may be asked to sanction fresh prosecutions of two thugs involved in a racist street attack in 1978, following the death of the victim after 21 years in a persistent vegetative state.

Relatives and friends of Hassan Musa, a Libyan-born student who was 23 when he was attacked, are discussing a formal request for the case to be reopened as a murder or manslaughter inquiry, after a coroner's inquest verdict of unlawful killing.

Mr Musa was left unconscious in the street in Sunderland after a drunken gang surrounded him outside the Painted Wagon pub, chased him when he tried to escape and knocked him to the ground. They kicked him mercilessly, behaving "like a pack of dogs", according to a crown court judge at the subsequent trial of three men on grievous bodily harm and public order charges.

The alleged ringleader of the gang, who was sentenced to four years in jail for GBH, has since died of cancer. But the two other men, who received lesser prison terms for public disorder convictions, are believed to live in the city.

The coroner's report has been passed to Northumbria police who are likely to reopen the case if they receive a formal complaint. Legal changes in 1996, after a public campaign led by victims' relatives, made it possible for murder charges to be brought in cases where victims survived the attack by more than a year and a day - the previous cut-off point since medieval times.

"They can do something about it and they certainly should. It was a terrible case - that poor lad lying there for 21 years," said Pat Gibson, who led the outcry three years ago after her 21-year-old son Michael died 16 months after being beaten-up in Darlington, County Durham. "If Mr Musa died from his injuries then I can't see why they shouldn't prosecute the attackers for manslaughter. His life was devastated and I hope something can be done about it."

Mr Musa, who lived in Chelmsford, Essex, was visiting friends in Sunderland at the time of the attack. He never spoke or gave any sign of conscious activity again, but was looked after in Ryhope general hospital in Sunderland, with contact maintained by the Libyan government. He was transferred in 1998 to be closer to relatives in Liverpool, where he died of pneumonia at the Royal Liverpool university hospital over Christmas.

The Liverpool coroner, Andre Rebella, recorded a verdict of unlawful killing and instructed that the papers be sent to Northumbria police. Detective Chief Inspector Andy Potts of Sunderland CID confirmed that the records had arrived but a review of them would await an approach from Mr Musa's family.

The office of the attorney general, Lord Williams, said only a handful of cases had been brought since the passing of the 1996 law reform (year and a day rule) act 1996, but previous lesser convictions were not an obstacle to proceeding on a more serious charge. A murder trial sanctioned under the act by the attorney general is due to begin next month in Lewes, East Sussex.

webTitle: Met told to make murder inquiries a priority

fields.headline: Met told to make murder inquiries a priority
fields.standfirst:
Report shows junior ranks still need help on the impact of race crimes
Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The Metropolitan police was ordered to devise an action plan yesterday in reponse to a report which found that many senior officers do not regard murder investigations as a "specific priority", and warned that the force was struggling to educate junior ranks about the impact of race crime.
fields.body:
The Metropolitan police was ordered to devise an action plan yesterday in reponse to a report which found that many senior officers do not regard murder investigations as a "specific priority", and warned that the force was struggling to educate junior ranks about the impact of race crime.

Although the 188-page study by the inspectorate of constabulary highlighted some areas of excellence, it also exposed startling deficiences in training, methodology and ethnic recruitment.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, said the findings made "uncomfortable reading". They also provide an early headache for the Met's commissioner designate, John Stevens, who takes over from Sir Paul Condon at the end of the month.

The report, Policing London Winning Consent, was ordered in the aftermath of Sir William Macpherson's report into the Stephen Lawrence murder inquiry. David Blakey led a team focusing on the ability to investigate murder and Dan Crompton reviewed the attitude to race issues. They made 41 recommendations.

Mr Blakey urged the Met to impress upon staff that murder was a priority, especially as the force's clear up rate of 84% was significantly lower than the 92% recorded nationwide.

He was critical of the heavy case loads shouldered by senior investigating officers and the lack of resources committed to investigations compared to some regional forces.

He found that many senior officers had up to six murder cases to deal with at any one time and that one claimed to be investigating 14. Outside London, a murder squad detective might have one or two.

One Met officer told the inspector that Scotland Yard was "not equipped to investigate lengthy murder inquiries".

Mr Blakey concluded that "too many staff are working under pressures which are avoidable and cannot be justified". This included poorly paid civilian staff, many of whom had been forced to work up to five consecutive weekends. But Mr Blakey recognised that the Met faced greater challenges than any other force and welcomed the increases in staff devoted to murder in recent months.

But he was "extremely concerned that a number of officers interviewed did not believe that the Met regarded the investigation of murder as a priority." He added: "This, coupled with the under resourcing of investigations has contributed to the (Met's) lower than average detection rates."

He called for a clearer chain of accountability in murder inquiries and a review of forensic evidence gathering processes.

Mr Crompton praised some of the initiatives taken by the Met since the Macpherson report, including the setting up of the racial and violent crimes taskforce. But he highlighted continuing problems within the ranks over racist crime investigations. "There is more to be done in securing the hearts and minds of non-specialist police officers," he said.

"A pervasive feeling exists among some staff that what is seen as special treatment for the victims of racist attacks can only be delivered by prejudicing service to the wider community. Until officers and staff understand the impact of hate crime because of skin colour or cultural difference, securing the appropriate initial response to victims will remain an unfulfilled challenge."

Mr Crompton said it would be "exceptionally challenging" for the Met to reach the home office target of 5,662 black and Asian officers by 2010. He said the force needed to concentrate on retaining staff.

The inspectors praised the "energy, leadership and commitment" of senior officers to improving the service to ethnic minorities, but said that while the Met was "en route, there's another two miles to go".

Sir Paul Condon said last night that work was in progress on 30 of the 41 recommendations and that the Met's clear-up rate for murders was higher than Paris and Amsterdam.

Assistant commissioner Ian Johnston said the report gave a skew-eyed view of the Met's approach to murder, pointing out that the force's senior investigating officers are dedicated to solving murders. In other forces, detectives have to juggle solving murders with other responsibilities.

"There is a national shortage of suitably qualified people to take on the extremely demanding and challenging role of senior investigating officer, but we have an excellent new training package to bring on new staff," he said.

webTitle: Comics find Ali G is an alibi for racism

fields.headline: Comics find Ali G is an alibi for racism
fields.standfirst:
Critics of cult character accused of taking themselves too seriously
Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: He's a Jewish, Cambridge graduate playing Channel 4's "voice of youth" who speaks the language of black street culture. But some of the most successful black comedians have accused Ali G of offensive racist behaviour - mocking black people and using language and performing material that broadcasters would not tolerate from black comedians.
fields.body:
He's a Jewish, Cambridge graduate playing Channel 4's "voice of youth" who speaks the language of black street culture. Sacha Baron Cohen's comic creation, Ali G, has become a cult figure through interviewing establishment figures for the 11 O'clock Show.

But some of the most successful black comedians have accused Ali G of offensive racist behaviour - mocking black people and using language and performing material that broadcasters would not tolerate from black comedians.

The weekly New Nation newspaper asked seven of the biggest stars on the black comedy circuit about the character, after he delivered the alternative Queen's speech on Channel 4 on Christmas Day.

Curtis Walker, whose own show Urban Heat was broadcast on BBC2 last month, described Ali G as "offensive", comparing him to Al Jolson and a 1950s style of comedy entertainment. "[He's] dishing out all the cliches and stereotypical language. I find it quite degrading and sad that this is what catches people's attention. I don't like the concept of a white guy playing a black guy anyway, and when he is playing a stupid stereotype it is even worse."

Felix Dexter, of The Real McCoy comedy series, said he appreciated the humour of an innocent confronting an expert with neither understanding the other. But, he added: "I feel that a lot of the humour is laughing at black street culture and it is being celebrated because it allows the liberal middle classes to laugh at that culture in a safe context where they can retain their sense of political correctness.

"I don't think a black comedian could do it because to me the humour is essentially coming out of a white guy pretending to be black," he said.

Though conceding she found Ali G funny, Gina Yashere of the BBC2 series A-Force, told the newspaper: "It's a good character but the only reason he has got as far as he has is because he's white. He wouldn't have been able to get arrested let alone his own TV show if he'd been a black guy. A black man pretending to be dumb like that would have seemed too real for white people. The humour would have been lost. I don't think he's racist or taking the piss out of black people. What is offensive is the whole media frenzy about him."

Even a fellow Channel 4 star, Richard Blackwood, who has his own series on the network, said he was concerned that viewers watch Ali G and think that was how black people behaved. "Someone told me he was actually doing an Asian person trying to be black but if that is the case then I don't think people are getting it. Too many people are left thinking that is how black people chat to one another, that they are ignorant and don't know about world issues."

Only one of the comedians interviewed by the paper was entirely positive about Ali G. Roger D contrasted him with Jim Davidson's 1970s Chalkie character: "Jim Davidson came across as someone who did not know black people at all, but this guy Ali G seems to have done his homework and got it down pat. He knows his character.

"As for whether a black comedian could get away with the same thing... I just doubt it would catch on in the same way and that's because Ali G is a white Jewish guy taking on this black persona and that is such a ridiculous concept that it adds to the humour."

Michael Eboda, editor of New Nation, conducted a poll of readers to accompany the comedians' comments. The paper found that more than 80% were fans of Ali G and concluded that his critics were "taking themselves too seriously". Mr Eboda compared Ali G to Harry Enfield's 1980s character Loadsamoney, a fantastically wealthy builder. "They are a critique of the times," he said. "This character is rooted in a cultural phenomena of our times - namely that many young white and Asian youngsters adopt black personas and appear ridiculous to everyone besides themselves. I don't think it's offensive," he said.

Ali G is said to have been inspired by the Radio 1 DJ Tim Westwood. Cohen is reported to have become incensed by white middle class listeners phoning in to Westwood's radio shows requesting dedications to the "the Staines Massive" and generally attempting to behave like LA gang members.

A Channel 4 spokesman denied the character was racist. He said: "The point is that it is not attempting to be an imitation of a black person, it satirises white men trying to adopt black street culture."

But he added that the comedians might be right to claim a black comedian could not perform the same material. "There is an issue as to whether people from black and Asian backgrounds get the same access into the system and it is one that Channel 4 is addressing," he conceded.

Celebrity crosstalk

Interviewing Sir Rhodes Boyson about education:

Ali G: What is the use of a kilo? Why don't they modernise and teach in ounces, quarter of ounces, eights of ounces?
Sir Rhodes: Well, it could be useful if you are baking.
Ali G: Alright, baking, for real.
Sir Rhodes: Yes, for real. I make my own breakfast every morning.
Ali G: I mean who bought a kilo of anything, except me mate Dave and he's doing a three-year stretch.

Interviewing James Whitaker, former royal correspondent and columnist:

Asked if people objected to "Carmella" because "she is so mingin", Whitaker said she was a very fit woman.
Ali G responded: "She ain't fit, man! She looks like Rod Hull."

He said: "The point is that it is not attempting to be an imitation of a black person, it satirises white men trying to adopt black street culture." But he added that the comedians might be right to claim a black comedian could not perform the same material. "There is an issue as to whether people from black and Asian backgrounds get the same access into the system and it is one that Channel 4 is addressing," he conceded. Celebrity crosstalk Interviewing Sir Rhodes Boyson about education: Ali G: What is the use of a kilo? Why don't they modernise and teach in ounces, quarter of ounces, eights of ounces? Sir Rhodes: Well, it could be useful if you are baking. Ali G: Alright, baking, for real. Sir Rhodes: Yes, for real. I make my own breakfast every morning. Ali G: I mean who bought a kilo of anything, except me mate Dave and he's doing a three-year stretch. Interviewing James Whitaker, former royal correspondent and columnist: Asked if people objected to "Carmella" because "she is so mingin", Whitaker said she was a very fit woman. Ali G responded: "She ain't fit, man! She looks like Rod Hull."

fields.headline: Quote, Talk and Speech
fields.trailText: WEAH ON THE MARCH
fields.body:
WEAH ON THE MARCH

This morning esteemed Italian sports rag Gazzetta dello Sport - like Sun Sport but not afraid of colouring itself pink - quoted George Weah as saying he would be leaving AC Milan and that "it is 100 percent that I am going to Marseille". So, obviously, by lunchtime he had joined Chelsea on loan until the end of the season.

Weah cannot play in Big Cup after turning out for Milan in their valiant last-minute defeat against Galatasaray, but if he receives international clearance (the sort of thing Gary Neville isn't very good at) he could make his Premiership debut against Spurs tomorrow night.

The arrival of a man capable of skinning an entire Serie A team should be a boost for the goal-shy Blues, although it's unlikely to do wonders for the confidence of Chris Sutton - who may now be struggling to get a place on the team coach. Chelsea's managing director Colin Hutchison meanwhile is ecstatic. "Clubs all over Europe have been trying to get him [Weah] but, fortunately, we have pulled it off," he said.

Which makes it sound like this is the first time Chelsea have signed a great player in his twilight years. The arrival of the 33-year-old former World Player of the Year brings the average age of the Blues' squad to around 276, a world record. Norris McWhirter is expected at Stamford Bridge this afternoon to confirm the feat, after signing a two-year contract with the club as cover for Frank Leboeuf.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

WIRELESS IS MORE

Talk Radio, the station you don't care about unless you follow cricket, in which case it's the station you hate because it killed Test Match Special, is about to relaunch as a dedicated sports channel. talkSPORT, as the station will be called, begins next Monday and will be a direct rival to the BBC's Radio 5 Live. That should give Alan Green something to moan about.

talkSPORT has already sorted out broadcasting rights for the FA Cup, England's home games and Manchester United's matches in Europe. It will also try to outbid 5 Live for exclusive Premiership rights. So seeing that you'll probably come across these people at some point, you may want to know a bit more about them.

talkSPORT presenters will include Alan Brazil, Lofty from EastEnders and one of the haven't-a-clue-who's-commentating-but -it's-not-Martin-Tyler clan from Sky. In charge of this motley crew is ex-Sun editor Kelvin MacKenzie, the man who made an insulting balls-up of the Sun's coverage of Hillsborough.

MacKenzie, who has a fat arse (according to authors Peter Chippindale and Chris Horrie), promised that "talkSPORT will not just appeal to fans but players, managers and everyone involved in the business of sport". The business of sport. Sigh. Well, at least you can't accuse him of not understanding the modern game.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"It took four hours to make love and in the end it wasn't very good. He kept on about the newspapers being after him for months, being caught and how bad it would look for him. It really affected his performance." - Maria Elves, Brazilian prostitute, reveals all to the Mirror about a supposed night of passion with 'Money shot' Martin Edwards.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

SAVAGE WORDS

With a wife and an indeterminate number of kids to feed, the Fiver has decided to expand its word-related repertoire and go into speech writing. More specifically, the Fiver would like to offer its services to any footballer who has just got into trouble and urgently needs to give a statement to the press.

Yesterday it was young Damian Taylor who addressed the nation's hacks. The Ipswich player, who obviously wrote every word of his speech, thanked the club "whose support for me during these turbulent times has been boundless". Actually, it was really Gary Croft who said that, but we were fooled by the disguise.

Today Leicester's Robbie Savage, a man with more unsuccessful challenges to his name than Frank Bruno, stepped up. Savage, er, savagely chopped down Kanu during the Foxes' FA Cup tie with Arsenal on Sunday, but he claims he never meant to hurt nobody. "I never go out to hurt people," he said. "It was a bad challenge but there was no malicious intention."

With the crowd in the palm of his hand, the foxy Fox with the locks of a lion went on: "I have never been sent off and I have never been suspended for an accumulation of bookings either. I will plead guilty to the crime of being energetic and enthusiastic, but nothing more." According to the Fiver's sources, Savage paid a tenner for that. The Fiver could have done it for £2.50.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Tottenham, Sunderland and Wimbledon are both interested in Southampton striker James Beattie. Dons boss Egil Olsen has already offered £1m for the player, but Dave Jones rates Beattie around the £5m mark.

Liverpool have made an official bid to sign Marcus Babbel from Bayern Munich.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Highland League clubs Elgin City and Peterhead have been elected to the Scottish Football League.

Newcastle will offer Bobby Robson a new contract as manager. They are also looking to appoint a director of football who will oversee the matters such as wages, contract negotiations, player acquisitions and disposals and youth development.

Manchester United's £4.5m goalkeeper Massimo Taibi will join Serie A club Reggina on loan until the end of the season.

Robert Molenaar and David Hopkin start their comebacks in Leeds' reserve game at Liverpool tonight.

Rangers goalkeeper Stefan Klos will be fit for the Premier League match against Aberdeen at Ibrox on January 22. The German keeper has been out of action since November after suffering a double fracture of his left wrist.

Notts County's bid to sign on-loan striker Brett Angell from Stockport County on a permanent contract has collapsed after they failed to reach a compromise over wages.

Dunfermline have signed Rangers midfielder Ian Ferguson. Pars manager Jimmy Calderwood has also announced the signing of Willem II goalkeeper Kris Mampaey.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

BBC1: Match Of The Day - Live! (8pm)
Some world thing or other.

Match Of The Day (12.55am)
Some more of that club malarkey.

ITV regions: Various highlights programmes with spurious "it's regional!" titles (11.30pm)
If you're in London, watch as Sideshow Bob tries to coerce the studio pundit into revealing the score before the match is transmitted. If you're not, enjoy the match.

Football Extra (3.35am)
Set your alarm and wake up with Iain Dowie.

Channel 4: Victoria's Secrets (10pm)
A chat show presented by Posh Spice. Arm yourself with more things to shout at that poor lad who plays for that team.

Football Italia (2.30am)
Loads and loads of famous footballers. It's a bit like reading OK! magazine.

Sky Sports 1: You're On Sky Sports! (10.15pm, 2.15am)
Welcome to the world of Diablo.

Sky Sports 2: Worthington Cup Football - Live! (7pm, 12.15am SS1)
A defender with big lips misses tackles, penalties, etc.

Eurosport: Football (10pm)
But we wanted to see a Scandinavian balance a Barratt Home on his head near a beach in Cyprus.

Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Football (7pm)
"talkSPORT? talkSPORT? Call that a radio station? There's a draught blowing right through it! An absolute disgrace."

webTitle: What's got 10 letters, three syllables and costs up to £100,000?

fields.headline: What's got 10 letters, three syllables and costs up to £100,000?
fields.standfirst: Answer: the perfect name.  Oliver Burkeman  reports on how the demand for lifestyle drugs and an increasingly savvy public have turned the branding of medicines into a multi-million-pound concern
fields.trailText: Answer: the perfect name. Oliver Burkeman reports on how the demand for lifestyle drugs and an increasingly savvy public have turned the branding of medicines into a multi-million-pound concern
fields.body:
He's not a doctor, or a research chemist, or even much of a marketing specialist. But when a multinational pharmaceuticals firm wants to launch a major new drug, James Dettore often tops the list of people to contact. Dettore, president and chief executive officer of the Miami-based Brand Institute, charges companies including SmithKline Beecham and Glaxo Wellcome up to $100,000 a time to perfect something that is fast becoming almost as crucial to a drug's success as its very clinical effectiveness: its name.

Christening a new treatment used to be a straightforward undertaking. The remedy synthesised by the German chemist Felix Hoffman in 1899 to alleviate his father's rheumatism was called aspirin, simply because it consisted of acetylsalicylic acid based on extracts from the spirea plant - and, until even recently, it seemed strong sales of any new anti-constipation powder could be guaranteed merely by appending "lax" to the name on the packet. But now - amid a boom in lifestyle drugs such as Viagra and the baldness treatment Propecia, and with record numbers of British people asking their GPs to prescribe specific treatments - the naming of drugs has ballooned into a global, multi-million-pound industry, with consultancies springing up across Europe and north America to lavish upon newly developed products all the care and attention of parents naming a newborn baby.

Dettore and his industry rivals frequent a bizarre parallel universe of strange prefixes and suffixes, of names that hint at miraculous curative properties without incurring the wrath of regulatory agencies by explicitly claiming powers they do not possess. All new drugs receive a generic name, subject to final approval by the World Health Organisation, but it is the trade name, owned by the manufacturer and under which the product is marketed, where naming consultants come into their own. The list of drugs approved in recent months by the European Union and the US Food and Drug Administration sounds like some kind of medieval incantation: Nutropin, Synercid, Ciclopirox, Avelox, Nasonex, Lipitor, Aleve, Aggrenox, Curosurf...

The process, which typically lasts around three months, begins with some high-intensity brainstorming sessions among pharmacists, physicians, nurses and consumers, explains Dettore, whose creations include Propecia, the controversial flu drug Relenza and the cholesterol treatment Lipitor. There are some basic rules at Brand Institute: the perfect name is held to consist of 10 letters or fewer, and no more than three syllables.

But much depends on changing fashions. Where once drugs companies chose chemical and latinate names that blinded the public with science, the turn of the century is witnessing a shift in the direction of airy, abstract names embodying hope and wellness and the promise of transformation. "In most cases, companies are now leaning away from names that are compound-driven and derived," says Dettore. "In the late 1980s, the US tendency was to use names indicative of the product's attributes and benefits, but the UK has always used this more arbitrary, personality- driven strategy. It's an attempt to invoke an essence of the brand."

Some of the drugs at the forefront of these changing trends make bold, brash claims for their own efficacy: Zyban, an anti-depressant aimed at people trying to quit smoking, overtly implies that it will "ban" their habit, while the name of stomach-acid treatment Prevacid is essentially self-explanatory.

Some seek out favourable euphonic associations, as in the vigour and virility of Viagra, or the implictly miraculous powers of the Parkinson's drug Mirapex. Others opt for an altogether more subtle approach. The antibiotic Vantin hints at advantage, while Prozac, naming consultants insist, carries the suggestion of the "exact" targetting of brain functions. And that upbeat prefix "pro" never goes amiss: "There are currently more than 4,000 'pro' prefix names in the various registries," Dettore says, despondently: every one that is already registered is another that he cannot use.

Adopting a ruse beloved of taxi operators, pharmaceuticals firms frequently opt for names beginning with A (recent examples include the insomnia remedy Ambien and the asthma treatment Accolate) so that they are placed near the beginning of drugs formularies. The especially devious seize the opportunity to piggyback on existing brands by borrowing parts of their names; Dettore cites the case of Abbot Laboratories' Aids drug Norvir, with its echoes of Glaxo's AZT brand Retrovir. "You have to ask yourself whether you really want to develop a truly unique name, or use a me-too strategy, to try to link to an existing market and ride on the coat-tails of another product," he says.

Devising an evocative name is only the first hurdle. Once it has been formulated, the consultancies call in linguistics experts to check that names are pronounceable worldwide and don't have obscene or embarrassing meanings in other languages: nobody wants a repeat performance of the brand-namers' favourite fiasco, the Vauxhall Nova - a car whose name means something close to "doesn't go" in an uncomfortably large number of tongues.

But by far the costliest part of the exercise involves hiring armies of lawyers to sift through trademark registries and medical regulations across the globe, to make sure that the name does not contravene consumer legislation or infringe existing marks - of which there are more than 1m in the relevant category in the European Union alone.

Choosing a name too similar to an existing one can bring more than legal pitfalls. Confusion between Merck's gastrointestinal drug Losec and the antihypertension treatment Lasix, manufactured by Hoechst, caused sufficient concern in the US for the FDA to order Merck to change it to Prilosec - though some American doctors are now reporting potentially hazardous mistaking of Prilosec for Prozac. Unsubstantiable claims can also lead to conflict: it was the FDA, again, that scuppered Pharmacia and Upjohn's plans to market its minoxidil baldness treatment as Regaine, on the basis that it didn't really stimulate permanent hair regrowth, and the name was changed to Rogaine. By contrast, in Britain - where the regulatory framework consists of a mishmash of agencies including the Medicines Control Agency, which has the main responsibility for authorising trade names - minoxidil is still available as Regaine, and Losec and Lasix continue to be distributed under their original names.

Despite the regulatory maze that multinationals must negotiate, consumer groups fear too many names still make significantly misleading claims for the efficacy of their products. "What the companies have tried to do is come up with a smooth-sounding name, overstate the benefits and understate the risks," Sidney Wolfe, co-founder of America's Public Citizens Health Research Group, has said.

"Naming is becoming more and more complicated," says Dettore. "Increasingly, in trying to create unique names, firms come up with words that aren't scriptable, or that no one can pronounce, so it's sometimes easier to take an existing root than to try to create an entirely new identity.

"A lot of people are saying we might even run out of names," he adds, with just a hint of worry in his voice.

webTitle: The definitive guide to treating common ailments

fields.headline: The definitive guide to treating common ailments
fields.standfirst: No 19: Breast cancer
fields.trailText: No 19: Breast cancer
fields.body:
Breast cancer is the commonest cancer affecting women. Survival rates are improving - through earlier detection and better treatment - but lag behind other European countries, and vary within Britain, partly due to treatment differences. Studies show that surviving breast cancer depends heavily on fast detection, reliable diagnosis and treatment by specialist teams.

Checking for breast cancer

Monthly checks are recommended by experts. Warning signs include any unusual change, such as a lump in the breast or armpit, swelling, persistent pain, differences in skin texture, size or shape in either breast, and changes in the nipples. Nine out of 10 lumps are not cancerous but seeing your GP quickly is vital - one third of women wait three months, according to the Imperial Cancer Research Fund.

Diagnosis

If the GP suspects a problem, you should be referred for tests quickly - within two weeks if urgent, the government stipulates. The gold standard test, recommended by national guidelines, is the triple assessment, involving a physical examination, mammography (x-ray) and fine needle aspiration. This usually detects more than 95% of cancers. Ideally it should be done within one day. If positive, further tests may be needed.

Treatment

Treatment by specialist teams, which should be the norm in most parts of the country, significantly improves survival. The team should include a surgeon, who specialises in breast cancer, specialist nurses and other health professionals. Together they should treat at least 100 new cancer patients each year.

A large study in Scotland found women treated by specialist surgeons had a 16% better chance of survival than those treated by general surgeons. Removing all detectable cancer is the first step. Studies show a partial mastectomy can be as successful as a full mastectomy in appropriate patients, so long as radiotherapy follows.

Radiotherapy reduces the risk of cancer returning by 24%, studies show. It is essential any affected lymph nodes are also removed. The second step is treating any undetected cancer. Almost all women, should be given chemotherapy and/or hormone therapy (like tamoxifen) after surgery. Both significantly reduce recurrence of cancer and improve survival.

 More information: Breast Cancer Care helpline: 0808 800 6000. Cancer Research Campaign: 0800 226 237.

 What works? is based on reviews of the most up-to-date and reliable evidence available. It is written in collaboration with the NHS Centre for Reviews and Dissemination at York university (01904 433 634) and verified by experts.

Survival rates are improving - through earlier detection and better treatment - but lag behind other European countries, and vary within Britain, partly due to treatment differences. Studies show that surviving breast cancer depends heavily on fast detection, reliable diagnosis and treatment by specialist teams. Checking for breast cancer Monthly checks are recommended by experts. Warning signs include any unusual change, such as a lump in the breast or armpit, swelling, persistent pain, differences in skin texture, size or shape in either breast, and changes in the nipples. Nine out of 10 lumps are not cancerous but seeing your GP quickly is vital - one third of women wait three months, according to the Imperial Cancer Research Fund. Diagnosis If the GP suspects a problem, you should be referred for tests quickly - within two weeks if urgent, the government stipulates. The gold standard test, recommended by national guidelines, is the triple assessment, involving a physical examination, mammography (x-ray) and fine needle aspiration. This usually detects more than 95% of cancers. Ideally it should be done within one day. If positive, further tests may be needed. Treatment Treatment by specialist teams, which should be the norm in most parts of the country, significantly improves survival. The team should include a surgeon, who specialises in breast cancer, specialist nurses and other health professionals. Together they should treat at least 100 new cancer patients each year. A large study in Scotland found women treated by specialist surgeons had a 16% better chance of survival than those treated by general surgeons. Removing all detectable cancer is the first step. Studies show a partial mastectomy can be as successful as a full mastectomy in appropriate patients, so long as radiotherapy follows. Radiotherapy reduces the risk of cancer returning by 24%, studies show. It is essential any affected lymph nodes are also removed. The second step is treating any undetected cancer. Almost all women, should be given chemotherapy and/or hormone therapy (like tamoxifen) after surgery. Both significantly reduce recurrence of cancer and improve survival.  More information: Breast Cancer Care helpline: 0808 800 6000. Cancer Research Campaign: 0800 226 237.  What works? is based on reviews of the most up-to-date and reliable evidence available. It is written in collaboration with the NHS Centre for Reviews and Dissemination at York university (01904 433 634) and verified by experts.

fields.headline: Diary of a hypochondriac
fields.trailText: Ten days after Rebecca and I gave up smoking, I think it fair to say that, even in this house, relations have been more genial.
fields.body:
Tuesday

Ten days after Rebecca and I gave up smoking, I think it fair to say that, even in this house, relations have been more genial. The atmosphere after dinner, when the pangs are at their fiercest, suggests a catholic pub in Glasgow in the hours after Celtic have lost heavily to Rangers. "What are you looking at?" Rebecca asks when I glance towards her, hoping to gauge from her features that she is suffering more than me. "Nothing. Care to make something of it?" "Oh yeah? And what if I do..." And so it goes on, in classic Govan style, albeit that where Rab C Nesbitt would have offered me "Outside" my wife offers a wintry "Goodnight" and floats icily up to bed.

Wednesday

Although the physical craving begins to fade as the nicotine works its way out of the bloodstream, such is the psychological torment that only the operation on my deviated septum on January 28 keeps me going. Major surgery is particularly perilous, it goes without saying, for the heavy smoker.

Thursday

The third worst thing about giving up smoking (after not being able to smoke, and the guilt at leaving former brethren to fund what remains of the NHS on their own) is the unmasking of symptoms that were suppressed by the chemicals. Today, for example, I'm suffering not only mouth ulcers, throat soreness and tongue inflammation, but also an infuriating tickly cough from somewhere deep in the chest that comes on late at night and prevents sleep.

Friday

In Tesco I bump into Dr Beverly MacDonald, whose small ops clinic I hope to attend (to have the spot on my nose frozen off with liquid nitrogen), if I come through the septum operation. She asks how I am - something she instantly regrets, to judge by the flash of panic that illuminates her eyes. I mention the cough, and ask if she thinks it might be emphysema. She says that at my age it is unlikely, "but if it's troubling you, come to the emergency clinic tomorrow". Emergency? You know something, doctor, don't you? Assuring me she knows nothing, the doctor points her trolley towards table sauces and is gone.

Saturday

I wish I had gone to the emergency clinic. All the time, the source of the tickle feels deeper in the lung. With every breath more coughing ensues. I begin to fear mesothelioma, a terminal tumour of the chest cavity. I check my proof copy of the Bloke's Diagnose-It-Yourself Guide to Health, an excellent new reference book (my physician Sarah Jarvis , who is writing the "girlie version", tells me it is published this week) but one aimed at men with less specialist knowledge than myself. There is no word about it.

Sunday

Marital relations take another dive when Rebecca catches me rooting through her bag. "You're searching for my address book, aren't you, to ring Sarah Jarvis?" Reluctantly confirming this, I point out my fears about lung cancer. "For God's sake," she says, "you know I've got exactly the same thing. Does the fact that we've got the same cough at the same time suggest anything?" "You think you've got mesothelioma too?" Sullenly, she dials the doctor to arrange my usual Monday slot at 6.20pm, and then retires to the top of the house.

Monday

At the Grove surgery, some organisational fiasco causes Dr Jarvis to summon me at precisely 6.20. After she expresses amazement that "you do not have, or claim to have, this nasty flu", I present my symptoms, perform coughs, allow her to listen to my chest and state the diagnosis. "Mesothelioma?" she says. "But you get that from exposure to asbestos. Have you been exposed to asbestos?" "Yes." She looks up sharply. "When?" she says. "In chemistry, when we were using a Bunsen bur..." "It's a cough," she says, "probably brought on by giving up smoking." Dr Jarvis is pointing to her door. "Out," she says. It seems a good moment to excuse myself, and head back to the clean but cool air of the marital home.

fields.headline: 'I was allergic to being pregnant'
fields.standfirst: She was too dizzy to walk, her limbs shook and she was vomiting up to 30 times a day...  Sonia Purnell  relives the hell of a pregnancy that almost killed her
fields.trailText: She was too dizzy to walk, her limbs shook and she was vomiting up to 30 times a day... Sonia Purnell relives the hell of a pregnancy that almost killed her
fields.body:
At first I could suppress the nausea with determined chewing of American hard gums - the harder the better for venting the frustration. I got through so many packets that I frequently jumped off the Tube mid-journey to work because I could no longer wait for fresh supplies.

By the time my pregnancy was confirmed, at about six weeks, the nausea was overwhelming and even two pounds of gums a day were failing to help. The gastric effects of sailing through a mountainous Bay of Biscay in a force 10 gale had nothing on the sickness engulfing me by now - not just in the morning, but afternoons, evenings and nights, too.

Then the vomiting began. Everything came back up - from dry toast, to plain biscuits, to a mere sip of water. I was sick not only through my mouth some 25 to 30 times a day - but often through my nose, too. I struggled in to see my GP, having been sick in her car park, her waiting room loo and very nearly on the yucca plant next to her desk, pleading for help.

Her response was that morning sickness was normal in pregnancy, and that, anyway, as I was moving, my new GP should take on my case. Chastened, I returned to work but barely surfaced from the ladies' loo once again. By the next day, eight weeks on, I had kept down no water for 36 hours, my limbs were trembling, my lips parched and my skin leathery.

I pleaded with the doctor, in the area where I was to move to in four months time, to see me. Just one look at the wreck in front of her and she sent me to a specialist emergency clinic at Queen Charlotte's maternity hospital in west London. I stopped the taxi during the short journey between her surgery and the hospital no fewer than eight times to vomit.

Once there, an enormously patient male doctor took my details from the other side of the door in the bathroom where I had had to ensconce myself. I emerged finally, looking 30 years older than usual, to be met with a flurry of doctors and nurses and the first acknowledgement that this might be a bit more than run of the mill.

First off was an emergency scan - interrupted twice by mad dashes to the loo - to try to find the problem. No, I wasn't expecting twins (which can cause terrible sickness) and nor were there any other visible causes. Indeed, there in the centre of the picture was a strong, regular, pulsating white light - my son's heartbeat, and a sight so wondrous, it convinced me that whatever happened would be worth it just to save it.

I was taken upstairs to a ward and connected to a saline drip to re-hydrate me, and was given powerful anti-emetic injections to stop me being sick. My tearful protests about the dangers of drugs in pregnancy, and particularly anti-morning sickness ones in the wake of thalidomide, were met with reassurances about the relative safety of modern versions - and a warning that I had no choice if I wanted to keep the baby.

In effect, they explained, I was allergic to pregnancy. My body was at war with the key pregnancy hormone Beta HCG and its line of attack was constant vomiting to try to get rid of it. The only way to go was to restrict potential damage to both of us by reducing the vomiting. Wired up to the drip and drugged to the eyeballs, I was later able to enjoy my first two-hour blissful break from being sick in a fortnight. Five days later, I left hospital weak and nauseous but with the vomiting under control. But over the next three weeks, it slowly built up again, even more corrosively this time. It felt like I was drowning in nausea.

Spring is my favourite season, but that year the colours of the spring flowers all faded into grey and beige and everything I tried to eat tasted of metal. Once again, water would not stay down and I was rushed into hospital for another bout of treatment. Now five months pregnant, I returned to work and prayed the phone wouldn't ring on my desk, as moving to answer it would make me sick. I prayed no one would speak to me, as speaking made me sick. And then I hoped I wouldn't have to leave my desk, as walking made me dizzy - until one day the floor appeared to rise up and a blackness descended.

Another trip to the doctor unearthed high sugar levels in my urine - a sign of diabetes, and possibly brought on by my unprecedented consumption levels of American hard gums, as well as the erratic nourishment my body had been getting.

At 34 weeks, feeling like a zombie and at my wits' end, my waters broke. It was one of the most dramatic moments of my life. Not only was there water everywhere but the nausea and the vomiting stopped instantaneously - that very second. I felt hungry for the first time for seven and a half months and, although urged to go straight to hospital, I insisted on eating one of the biggest meals of my life.

I had second helpings of my mother's homemade hamburgers, mashed potato and leeks (a childhood favourite) and second helpings of apple crumble (another) as well. And still I wanted more, the sheer joy of tasting food and the freedom from nausea made me want to laugh and laugh - and eat and eat.

At last, we drove to the hospital, where I was kept in until an infection brought on early labour four days later. I was warned that waters breaking that early are almost certain to spark infection but that it was important to keep the baby inside me for every hour possible.

I sat and ate to my heart's content. NHS fare tasted like Michelin-rated cuisine. I was pregnant and at last I felt great to be alive. Then on the fourth morning, I woke with pains in my knees and I vomited again. Slowly the pains spread and my temperature soared. The midwives monitored the baby's heartbeat and I could see long faces all around.

My partner, Jonathan, arrived after the mild contractions began. I was ordered to stay in bed, until suddenly my son's heartbeat started to falter. They pushed me and my bed out to the lift to the surgical floor at breakneck speed but it failed to arrive. When we finally got to the delivery suite, no one was smiling. We were given five minutes to see if there was an improvement. There was none.

There was more running and I was told it would have to be general anaesthetic for the operation, as it worked quicker than an epidural and the baby had to come out now. My last memory is of a man in a dark jacket, I presume the anaesthetist, complaining he had not had time to change before attending to me.

Sometime later I awoke in huge pain: when the anaesthetic wears off there is little to protect you from the searing wound in your abdomen. As it was an emergency, they had had to shove a tube down my throat to clear my stomach before operating, and it had taken my voice away. My only mode of communication was to draw the letters P-A-I-N with a finger on my palm. After what seemed like an age they brought some morphine, and my partner told me we had a perfect little boy. I was so dopey I never asked where he was, or if I could see him.

That night I slept next to the operating theatre, dreaming strange drug-induced dreams of fields and flowers. At six sharp the next morning, I was given a bed bath by two midwives while a couple of floors down my son was also being given a wash and brush-up. At 7.15am, 12 hours to the minute after he was born, we were introduced to each other, both trying to look our best for such an important meeting.

He was a tiny but perfect human being, who had entered the world after all our traumas with the lustiest of cries. Despite being six weeks early, his birth weight was a respectable five and a half pounds, and he looked like a giant compared with the minute little ones in the special care unit where he stayed for two nights for observation, and a course of prophylactic antibiotics. He looked so gorgeous, I wondered whether he was really mine. Could there not have been a mix-up in the furore surrounding his birth?

My fears of associating him with all the pain and suffering have been completely unfounded. As time goes on, I think I love Laurie all the more for what we went through together to bring him into the world. But every spring, when the trees are in bud, I dare not look - even two years on the sight still makes me feel queasy.
