fields.headline: The Isles by Norman Davies
fields.standfirst:
Stephen Moss assesses the critical verdict on Norman Davies's romp through the whole of British history
Buy The Isles at BOL
fields.trailText: Sometimes - frequently, in fact - one doesn't know quite what to make of critics, or of the flatly contradictory conclusions they reach. Take Norman Davies's The Isles (Macmillan, £30), a 1,200-page romp through the whole of British history, which has produced a remarkable divergence of opinion.
fields.body:
Sometimes - frequently, in fact - one doesn't know quite what to make of critics, or of the flatly contradictory conclusions they reach. Take Norman Davies's The Isles (Macmillan, £30), a 1,200-page romp through the whole of British history, which has produced a remarkable divergence of opinion.

I had rather given up on Professor Davies's epic survey, on the basis of an initial batch of reviews that were cynical both about the motivation for the book and about the speed of execution. Christopher Harvie, in the Independent, was by far the rudest:

"The Isles is a puzzle of a book more to be explained, perhaps, by the politics of publishing than by its actual programme."

Davies is a distinguished historian of east and central Europe. His History of Poland was highly praised and his book on Europe welcomed, though not without attracting critics. The idea of locating the experience of the British Isles in European history must have seemed logical, given the huge sales of Sir Roy Strong's shamelessly anglocentric The Story of Britain.

Professor Harvie - no academic niceties here - soon got even ruder.

"Publishers are, these days, selling personality, not fastidiousness. Hence, I suppose, the decision to circulate a proof copy that seems closer to a first draft than to anything more elaborated. The proof's lacunae, question marks and remotely recollected quotations read at times like a collaboration between Private Eye's Lord Gnome ('as Disraeli said. . . [some suitable quotation, please]') and Bertie Wooster ('Tum-ti, tum-ti, tum-ti tum/ I SLEW HIM!'). Doubtless, by now, Toby or Caroline from Macmillan will have slotted in stuff from the shelves of the London Library, but they had better have made sure that - inter alia - Asquith stops being 'a Scots orphan' and Britannia doesn't get scrapped."

Paul Johnson, in the Sunday Telegraph, also had his doubts about the genesis of the book (there's an old-fashioned feeling at work here that writers should approach publishers with ideas for books, not the other way round):

"I have a nasty suspicion that he agreed to do it under pressure from his publishers, who wanted to cash in on his earlier success with another blockbuster, and who thought that with Tony Blair taking a hatchet to the Union, now was the time to write its history."

Johnson enumerated some of the errors in the book:

"George Borrow would have been very surprised to find himself a clergyman, almost as surprised as Leo Amery to discover he overthrew Chamberlain's government in 1939 or Cardinal Heenan to be told he died in 1943."

Ian Jack, while applauding the book's "lively details and thoughts" in the Daily Telegraph, was also troubled by the slips:

"Can he hope to be as evenly accurate, never mind as evenly insightful, about Neolithics, Plantagenets and the poetry of Hugh MacDiarmid? The incidence of simple error suggests not. It may not matter too much that steam locomotives disappeared from British Railways in the 1960s rather than the 1970s, as Davies writes; or that Gaelic song festivals were a feature of Scottish life long before he seems to think. Even with a researcher and a manuscript vetted by appropriate historical authorities, a book containing so much information is bound to get some of it wrong. But when Davies thinks the West Lothian Question is called the Midlothian Question, questions concerning fundamental carelessness, superficiality and writing speed need to be asked."

Andy Beckett, in The Guardian, summed up for the prosecution:

"The Isles is unlikely to jolt more open minds. It is slightly too airless and theoretical to be truly accessible, yet too concerned with its public reception to be properly adventurous. It does not feel enduring; more of a career move or a marketing idea than something essential. Simon Schama, another British non-specialist with a high media profile, is currently working on a history of these islands too. He might give this one a cautionary glance."

Case concluded, you might think. But all was not quite lost for Davies. Roy Porter, himself no stranger to monumental histories, made a powerful case for the defence in the Times:

"The Isles is a masterwork, particularly memorable for its concluding survey of centrifugal forces in a late 20th-century Britain where there are more Muslims than Methodists. Precisely three years ago, there appeared Davies's Europe: A History. The Isles forms a fine companion: encyclopaedic, provocatively argued, and enhanced by generous quotations from works of literature in all the Isles' tongues."

Nor was he alone in forgiving Davies his occasional errors. Hugo Young, concluding a magisterial survey of the state of the nation in the London Review of Books, also found in the professor's favour:

"This is not a handing-down from on high, but an investigation of new territory by someone who wants to explore hypotheses he apprehends but is not sure of. We can therefore share his own fascination at what he finds ... Messy and subjective though it is, and unwilling to allow merit to the perspective of almost any other historian, The Isles is a key book for its time. It seizes the conventional wisdom of the moment, and destroys most of its foundations."

So, case far from proven, unless the anti-Davies faction can obtain incriminating taped evidence from that original publisher's lunch ("you'll knock off the Reformation in no time, Norman, and the first world war will be over by Christmas") or induce Toby and Caroline to come clean.

The proof's lacunae, question marks and remotely recollected quotations read at times like a collaboration between Private Eye's Lord Gnome ('as Disraeli said. . . [some suitable quotation, please]') and Bertie Wooster ('Tum-ti, tum-ti, tum-ti tum/ I SLEW HIM!'). Doubtless, by now, Toby or Caroline from Macmillan will have slotted in stuff from the shelves of the London Library, but they had better have made sure that - inter alia - Asquith stops being 'a Scots orphan' and Britannia doesn't get scrapped." Paul Johnson, in the Sunday Telegraph, also had his doubts about the genesis of the book (there's an old-fashioned feeling at work here that writers should approach publishers with ideas for books, not the other way round): "I have a nasty suspicion that he agreed to do it under pressure from his publishers, who wanted to cash in on his earlier success with another blockbuster, and who thought that with Tony Blair taking a hatchet to the Union, now was the time to write its history." Johnson enumerated some of the errors in the book: "George Borrow would have been very surprised to find himself a clergyman, almost as surprised as Leo Amery to discover he overthrew Chamberlain's government in 1939 or Cardinal Heenan to be told he died in 1943." Ian Jack, while applauding the book's "lively details and thoughts" in the Daily Telegraph, was also troubled by the slips: "Can he hope to be as evenly accurate, never mind as evenly insightful, about Neolithics, Plantagenets and the poetry of Hugh MacDiarmid? The incidence of simple error suggests not. It may not matter too much that steam locomotives disappeared from British Railways in the 1960s rather than the 1970s, as Davies writes; or that Gaelic song festivals were a feature of Scottish life long before he seems to think. Even with a researcher and a manuscript vetted by appropriate historical authorities, a book containing so much information is bound to get some of it wrong. But when Davies thinks the West Lothian Question is called the Midlothian Question, questions concerning fundamental carelessness, superficiality and writing speed need to be asked." Andy Beckett, in The Guardian, summed up for the prosecution: "The Isles is unlikely to jolt more open minds. It is slightly too airless and theoretical to be truly accessible, yet too concerned with its public reception to be properly adventurous. It does not feel enduring; more of a career move or a marketing idea than something essential. Simon Schama, another British non-specialist with a high media profile, is currently working on a history of these islands too. He might give this one a cautionary glance." Case concluded, you might think. But all was not quite lost for Davies. Roy Porter, himself no stranger to monumental histories, made a powerful case for the defence in the Times: "The Isles is a masterwork, particularly memorable for its concluding survey of centrifugal forces in a late 20th-century Britain where there are more Muslims than Methodists. Precisely three years ago, there appeared Davies's Europe: A History. The Isles forms a fine companion: encyclopaedic, provocatively argued, and enhanced by generous quotations from works of literature in all the Isles' tongues." Nor was he alone in forgiving Davies his occasional errors. Hugo Young, concluding a magisterial survey of the state of the nation in the London Review of Books, also found in the professor's favour: "This is not a handing-down from on high, but an investigation of new territory by someone who wants to explore hypotheses he apprehends but is not sure of. We can therefore share his own fascination at what he finds ... Messy and subjective though it is, and unwilling to allow merit to the perspective of almost any other historian, The Isles is a key book for its time. It seizes the conventional wisdom of the moment, and destroys most of its foundations." So, case far from proven, unless the anti-Davies faction can obtain incriminating taped evidence from that original publisher's lunch ("you'll knock off the Reformation in no time, Norman, and the first world war will be over by Christmas") or induce Toby and Caroline to come clean.

webTitle: It's still a £10 fine - even if your name is Cherie Booth

fields.headline: It's still a £10 fine - even if your name is Cherie Booth
fields.trailText: She was the most unlikely of fare dodgers: a 45-year-old barrister, four months pregnant, on her way to hear her first case as a criminal judge, and she also happens to be married to the prime minister.
fields.body:
She was the most unlikely of fare dodgers: a 45-year-old barrister, four months pregnant, on her way to hear her first case as a criminal judge, and she also happens to be married to the prime minister.

But yesterday Cherie Booth QC's career on the criminal bench got off to an inauspicious start when she was fined £10 for boarding a train without a ticket as she rushed to Luton crown court for her debut as a Recorder.

Ms Booth did not intend to evade payment when she boarded the Thameslink train at Blackfriars station in central London, near her legal chambers.

But she said the ticket office was closed and the ticket machines would take neither her credit card nor the Portuguese escudos with which she had returned from her new year holiday. Nor was there a guard with a ticket machine on board the train.

After rail operators insisted the ticket office at Blackfriars was open as normal, a Downing Street spokesman said that in Mrs Blair's haste at an unfamiliar station, she had failed to find the office.

As Downing Street confirmed the tip-offs to Fleet Street newspapers, MPs were divided over who to blame: Tony Blair for not taking sterling into the single European currency or John Prescott for not having enough rail company staff on duty to spare Ms Booth's blushes.

Staff at Luton station confirmed that Ms Booth came clean, explaining to the ticket collector that she did not have a ticket. In addition to the £9.70 return fare, she had to pay a fixed penalty of £10 - part of the drive to discourage accidental fare avoidance as well as deliberate evasion.

"She caught the train from Blackfriars without a ticket," said an unrelenting Thameslink spokesman. "If someone travels without a valid ticket they have to pay a penalty."

Mr Blair's spokesman, Alastair Campbell, leapt to her defence. "She did volunteer to pay," he said. "The alternative would be to jump over the barrier which is quite difficult for a pregnant woman to do."

webTitle: Irving accuses historian of destroying his livelihood

fields.headline: Irving accuses historian of destroying his livelihood
fields.trailText: David Irving today accused a fellow historian of destroying his  livelihood by distorting his views and scaring away publishers  from his controversial work on the Holocaust.
fields.body:
David Irving today accused a fellow historian of destroying his livelihood by distorting his views and scaring away publishers from his controversial work on the Holocaust.

In a highly-charged libel case that will raise questions about the limit of free speech on views that can incite hatred, Mr Irving argued in the high court that academic Deborah Lipstadt and Penguin Books were part of "an organised international endeavour" determined to destroy his career and "vandalise" his legitimacy as a historian.

"By virtue of the activities of the defendants... I have since 1996 seen one fearful publisher after another falling away from me, declining to reprint my works, refusing to accept new commissions and turning their backs on me when I approach," he told Mr Justice Gray.

Mr Irving claims he was libelled in Ms Lipstadt's 1994 book, Denying the Holocaust: The Growing Assault on Truth and Memory. He says that it alleges that he has denied the Holocaust, has distorted statistics and documents to serve his own ideological purposes and reach historically untenable conclusions, and has knowingly consorted with extremists.

Penguin and Professor Lipstadt, holder of the Dorot Chair in modern Jewish and Holocaust studies at Emory university in Atlanta, Georgia, deny libel and plead justification. They claim that Mr Irving has denied the Holocaust, that gas chambers were used to carry it out, and that he holds extremist views.

Mr Irving, who is representing himself, made his opening statement in a packed courtroom.

Mr Irving has written: "The incontrovertible evidence is that Hitler ordered that there was to be 'no liquidation of the Jews'." He told the Guardian last week he did not want to use the case to "fight the second world war all over again".

But he said Jewish and left-wing organisations, which he refers to on his website as "traditional enemies of truth", were "intent on leading a global onslaught" against him. Mr Irving says Ms Lipstadt is seeking to smear his name across the world as a "Holocaust denier", which is considered a crime in several European countries, including Germany and France.

"Through the mindless blackening of my name by the defendants and others I have been excluded from almost every civilised country in the world and from their archives, which are vital to my further research," he says on his website. "Many of my friends and former colleagues have been forced to turn their back on me to protect their own careers and livelihoods."

Mr Irving was fined in May 1992 after a German court convicted him of telling a 1990 public meeting of around 800 people in Munich that there were no gas chambers at Auschwitz and that the Nazi death camp itself was built as a fake.

Mr Irving, who described Auschwitz as "a very brutal slave labour camp" where he believed around 100,000 people died, appealed in January 1993. He told the appeal court: "There were no gas chambers at Auschwitz; I will not change my opinion."

Munich's appeal court rejected his appeal and tripled the original fine to 30,000 marks ($18,000). The historian also said in his 1977 book "Hitler's War" that the Nazi leader was not aware until 1943 of the mass slaughter of Jews during the second world war.

Mr Irving was banned from Germany after his conviction there. He has also been refused entry to Canada, Italy, Austria and Australia.

Ms Lipstadt's defence case will be argued by Anthony Julius, who represented Princess Diana in her divorce from Prince Charles. The case will not be fought in front of a jury because both sides agree that its complex nature would make a jury hearing too lengthy. Charles Gray, himself a libel lawyer, will sit in judgment. The trial is expected to last three months.

webTitle: Ford unveils the car to surf your way through the traffic

fields.headline: Ford unveils the car to surf your way through the traffic
fields.trailText: After little more than 100 years the car is no longer just a people-mover; it is the internet on wheels.
fields.body:
After little more than 100 years the car is no longer just a people-mover; it is the internet on wheels.

That's the view of Jac Nasser, Ford's chief executive, who unveiled three hi-tech vehicles at the Detroit Motor Show called 24-7s - and resembling iMac personal computers on four wheels. Ford and its main rival, General Motors, have used the show this week to re-invent the car as what Mr Nasser called a portal to the net - and their companies as makers of communications tools.

The world's two biggest car groups have already announced plans to create the nearly virtual assembly-line, transfer most of their supply business online and persuade their dealers to sell direct to customers via the net.

Now the 80 minutes the average driver spends in his or her car every day can be used, especially on gridlocked roads, to surf the net for share prices, weather reports, cheap service deals, restaurant and cinema offers and, of course, buy a new car.

Voice-activated telematics is to become standard on new Ford Focus cars in Europe and in the future all models, and GM is planning to offer a similar technological lift to its range of cars, starting with the Cadillac.

The two car giants have teamed up with, respectively, America Online and Yahoo!, internet service providers, to enable drivers to book repairs or pay accounts while driving.

These moves to bring e-commerce to the automotive industry coincide with a renewed drive to replace the traditional internal combustion engine with hydrogen-based electric fuel cells and the steel car-body with more aerodynamic and safer materials.

fields.headline: Vatican defends Pope's health
fields.trailText: The Vatican was forced yesterday to break one of its own taboos and publicly defend the Pope's health after a senior bishop's loose words ignited speculation that John Paul II might resign.
fields.body:
The Vatican was forced yesterday to break one of its own taboos and publicly defend the Pope's health after a senior bishop's loose words ignited speculation that John Paul II might resign.

Bishop Karl Lehmann, who leads Germany's bishops, was accused yesterday of calling for the Pontiff to step down - virtually an act of treachery - following an interview he gave on Sunday to the Deutschlandfunk radio station.

A news agency then reported that he had said the 79-year-old should resign if illness prevented him from leading the church, which led to feverish speculation in the Italian press.

The Vatican said that the press had misrepresented the bishop's comments in the interview, in which he also said he was impressed by the Pope's physical and mental state.

But his willingness to discuss the possibility of retirement was seen by some as a shocking breach of practice.

The Pope has shown symptoms associated with Parkinson's disease and there has been speculation about his possible retirement - but never in public. His sense of his divine mission to lead the church is thought likely to prevent him from resigning.

webTitle: Government hits back at 'paranoid' freedom of information campaigners

fields.headline: Government hits back at 'paranoid' freedom of information campaigners
fields.standfirst:
Campaign for Freedom of Information
The Freedom of Information bill
fields.trailText: The home office hit back at the "paranoid and unreal" complaints of freedom of information campaigners today, after it emerged that home secretary Jack Straw had granted himself new powers to veto the release of any public documents.
fields.body:
The home office hit back at the "paranoid and unreal" complaints of freedom of information campaigners today, after it emerged that home secretary Jack Straw had granted himself new powers to veto the release of any public documents.

Home office minister Mike O'Brien said that the amendment to the government's freedom of information bill was a purely technical matter and did not undermine its commitment to openness.

"The whole objective of this bill is to create freedom of information," Mr O'Brien insisted. "That is why we are putting it through parliament."

The amendment, introduced before Christmas without Commons debate, would allow the home secretary to issue a "parliamentary order" to remove any public body from the provisions of the bill.

Unless the order was spotted and raised in parliament by an MP within 28 days, it would automatically come into force.

Maurice Frankel, director of the Campaign for Freedom of Information, told BBC Radio 4's The World at One: "They may use it in a very modest way to make technical changes but, at the same time, if they find the freedom of information act is an embarrassment and is causing them difficulties, they have the power here to gnaw away the heart of it at a stroke.

"If they need to make substantial changes of this kind, they should use primary legislation to do it and go through proper parliamentary scrutiny."

Liberal Democrat spokesman on constitutional affairs Robert Maclennan said he would be tabling an amendment to have the proposal removed from the bill.

He told Radio 4: "It is a most unacceptable, widely-based power which could be abused too easily.

"If the secretary of state decides that he can see a difficulty coming down the pipe which could cause the government embarrassment - which the public may know nothing about in advance - he can then move to strike out information of a particular kind held by a public authority."

Mr O'Brien retorted: "What both Maurice and Bob seem to be suggesting is that we want to put it through Parliament in order to then reverse it all. That is complete nonsense."

The purpose of the amendment was to allow the names of new public bodies - such as the inquiry into the death of Stephen Lawrence - to be added to the legislation, and then removed when they ceased to exist, he said.

He denied that the use of parliamentary orders would mean that changes could slip through unnoticed: "The joint committee on statutory instruments considers every one of these and if anything unusual or arbitrary were done by the home secretary - which it would not be - the committee would immediately bring it to the attention of the House."

webTitle: Straw calls for 'rounded sense of Englishness'

fields.headline: Straw calls for 'rounded sense of Englishness'
fields.trailText: Home secretary Jack Straw today backtracked on his assertion that the English have a "propensity to violence" after he was assailed as being ignorant and insensitive.
fields.body:
Home secretary Jack Straw today backtracked on his assertion that the English have a "propensity to violence" after he was assailed as being ignorant and insensitive.

Mr Straw insisted he was not denigrating the English and said he wished they would celebrate their national character and their achievements as a nation. But he stuck to the distinction he had made yesterday between English nationalism and that of Scotland, Welsh and Irish.

"We want to celebrate our achievements in England as well as in the United Kingdom, but in order to do that we have to have an understanding about why the English people's sense of nationalism is a somewhat distorted one from that of the Scots, Welsh and Irish," said Mr Straw, alluding to England's dominance of the UK.

Mr Straw's return to the debate on Englishness followed the furore he triggered with his remarks on a Radio 4 programme on English identity. Rightwing commentators such as Simon Heffer of the Mail accused Mr Straw of confusing English nationalism with soccer hooliganism. Others were quick to criticise Mr Straw focusing on the dark side of English nationalism.

Today, Mr Straw said he wished the English would celebrate their national character and their achievements as a nation. "I am English and I am also from Essex, and I want to see a rounded sense of Englishness and for us to celebrate that much more," Mr Straw said. "I wasn't saying that the English exclusively had a propensity to violence. What I was seeking to do was to explain why it feels different to be Scots or Welsh or Irish from being English. Part of that explanation is over the centuries the English have been very, very dominant."

The debate on what it means to be English comes amid concern that Labour's devolution project with the creation of separate assemblies in Scotland and Wales will lead to a splintering of the UK.

Some Conservative politicians already have expressed their unhappiness with the new constitutional arrangements. English MPs are unable to influence policy in Wales and Scotland on a whole range of matters, including high spending areas that are subsidised by the English taxpayer. Yet Scottish and Welsh MPs can vote on issues that affect the English.

France already has tried to exploit the differences between the regions. In the recent row over British beef, prime minister Lionel Jospin offered to exempt Scottish beef from the French ban, a proposal rejected by prime minister Tony Blair. But Scotland criticised Mr Blair's decision as harmful to its interests.

Mr Straw insisted that the emergence of greater national pride in the various parts of the UK as a result of devolution did not threaten unity.

"It is my own very strong belief, and always has been, that devolution is part of the way in which we understand the need for self-expression by Scotland and Wales, as well as Northern Ireland," he said today. "By doing so we bind the UK and make it much richer, rather than undermining it."

fields.headline: The AOL Time Warner deal
fields.trailText: What is all the fuss about?
fields.body:
What is all the fuss about?

The merger of AOL and Time Warner is massive by any standards. It is the biggest US corporate merger ever, creating the fourth largest company in the world, worth $350bn (£220bn), more than the output of Russia or the Netherlands. The new company will have more than 100 million subscribing customers across the globe.

The deal is even more hyped because it will create the world's largest media company from the first significant merger of an internet company with a traditional firm.

Who is the dominant partner?

AOL made $4.8bn in revenue in the 12 months to June 1999; Time Warner made $26.8bn in 1998. AOL employs 12,100; Time Warner 70,000. Despite this, AOL earned four times the net profit of Time Warner in 1998/99 and the stock market values AOL 1.5 times higher than Time Warner. So, although it has been heralded as a "strategic merger of equals", AOL shareholders will be given 55% of the new company to Time Warner's 45%, giving them effective control of the new company.

What is in it for both of them?

Much has been made of traditional media companies failing to get the net. With a media empire embracing TV news (CNN) film (Warner Bros) and magazines (Time, People), Time Warner had set aside $500 million to invest in new online efforts. Now it has a ready-made internet strategy and a vast new media platform to distribute its content. Its films, for instance, could soon be downloaded from the internet by AOL subscribers.

AOL, America's leading internet service provider (ISP) which also owns web browser Netscape, wasn't short of content, although Time Warner will provide it with more: Warner Bros offers the potential to "broadcast" thousands of films over the internet.

More importantly, the merger will end AOL's bandwidth problems. The company has struggled to find ways to speeding up its dial-up internet service for American households. Now it can now provide a far quicker, broadband internet service, carried on Time Warner's Roadrunner cable modem service. Time Warner has 13m cable subscribers, who also present AOL, which already boasts 22m internet subscribers, with a vast new market.

How will they work together?

The buzzword is "convergence". At the start of the 1990s Time's publishing empire merged with TV, film and music giant Warner. Ten years on, this merging of a traditional content provider with an online operator appears to make a lot of sense.

AOL will give Time Warner much-needed internet savvy and an established internet platform for its content; Time Warner will grant AOL high-speed cable access to households. The integrated company will be able to provided integrated media services, so that customers can get films, music, magazines and the internet all through their digital TVs.

There will be difficulties which come with forcing together two giant companies of contrasting cultures, personalities and locations. Time Warner are based in New York; AOL in Virginia; the new company will be split between the offices. AOL chairman Steve Case admitted "there are a lot of cooks on stage", with his Time Warner counterpart Gerald Levin, as well as high-profile CNN chief Ted Turner at the apex of the company.

Lower down the food chain, Warner employees may resent working alongside AOL workers made rich by their internet stock options. In turn, the AOL net millionaires may resent the value of their shares being held down by its merger with Time Warner, a traditional media firm with slower growth.

Could there be any problems with the deal?

The deal has not gone through yet. It must be subject to regulatory scrutiny. Legal experts don't foresee any significant problems in America, although AOL's alliance 50-50 joint venture with German media giant Bertelsmann in Europe and Australia could be questioned. Previous proposed mergers between internet and traditional media have collapsed, such as last year's attempted merger of internet portal and search engine Lycos with USA Networks.

What are the implications here?

British consumers will be able to take advantage of a bigger range of Time Warner content services through AOL Europe, which is handed a competitive advantage in its battle with Freeserve, Britain's biggest free internet service provider. Its share value fell yesterday.

The stock market believes this deal is the first of many. That a traditional media company, Time Warner, accepted the higher value of an internet company, AOL, also suggests that the market's high valuation of many internet companies is no chimera. More than £8bn was added to the value of London-listed media shares yesterday.

"Temporarily, maybe it leaves them in the dust,'' said internet analyst Dan O'Brien of Time Warner's traditional competitors. These media giants, such as Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, Sony or Disney, all with a significant presence in Britain, may consider striking similar deals with dedicated online companies such as Yahoo, Lycos, AT&T and Microsoft.

AOL has fiercely campaigned for high-speed cable operators to open their lines to a variety of providers, which would help ensure competitive pricing and consumer choice. It insists that its privileged access to Time Warner's cables will not change its position and both promised to promote open access on their cable network, forcing AT&T to do the same.

Critics argue AOL will surely reduce its campaign for open access. And even if they remain committed to open access that does not necessarily mean they will grant outside providers with equal access to their broadband services. AOL's services are likely to enjoy preferential services on Time Warner's cable system.

Internet idealists argue it is a massive step in the multinational corporate takeover of the internet and web content. Other internet-media mergers cannot be far behind.

fields.headline: $350bn media merger heralds net revolution
fields.standfirst:
The deal explained
Aol
Time Warner
fields.trailText: The global media industry was turned on its head yesterday when Time Warner, the US information giant whose interests range from the CNN news channel and Time magazine to Warner Bros cartoons, announced it was merging with the world's biggest internet service provider, America Online.
fields.body:
The global media industry was turned on its head yesterday when Time Warner, the US information giant whose interests range from the CNN news channel and Time magazine to Warner Bros cartoons, announced it was merging with the world's biggest internet service provider, America Online.

The $350bn (£220bn) deal, which ranks as the largest takeover ever, creates the world's fourth-largest corporation. The participants said it established "the world's first fully integrated media and communications company for the Internet Century".

Ted Turner, who owns £5.2bn worth of Time Warner shares after selling it CNN, has agreed to vote in favour of the merger and become vice-chairman of the enlarged company, called AOL Time Warner.

Seen as the ground-breaking convergence of "old" and "new" media businesses, the merger sent shockwaves through Wall Street and the City of London.

A series of copy-cat corporate marriages is now forecast in the US and Europe as financiers and entrepreneurs race to bring respected media "content" - ranging from TV broadcasting and newspapers to film archives - together with the leading companies of the new information age.

In New York commentators speculated on the future of media brands such as CBS and Disney with the frontrunners of the internet industry, such as Yahoo! and even Microsoft.

In London there was frenzied dealing on the stock market as investors bet on one or more of Britain's big media groups, such as Pearson or Granada, attempting to take over a UK internet service provider, such as Freeserve.

In both the City and Wall Street, the merger was seen as justification for the stratospheric valuations attached to shares in internet and new media companies.

The new US media giant brings together a vast array of news and entertainment brands, and one of the US's biggest cable networks, with one of the world's most established internet infrastructures, potentially giving it unheralded power in areas such as e-commerce.

AOL Time Warner will be headed by Steve Case, currently chairman and chief executive of America Online, while Time Warner's boss, Gerald Levin, becomes chief executive of the new company.

"This is an historic moment in which new media has truly come of age," Mr Case declared yesterday. "We've always said that America Online's mission is to make the internet as central to people's lives as the telephone and television, and even more valuable.

"By joining forces with Time Warner, we will fundamentally change the way people get information, communicate with others, buy products and are entertained - providing far-reaching benefits to our customers and shareholders."

Mr Levin added: "The digital revolution has already begun to create unprecedented and instantaneous access to every form of media and to unleash immense possibilities for economic growth, human understanding and creative expression. AOL Time Warner will lead this transformation."

America Online is only 15 years old, but already boasts 150m users through its various online services and many more users of its Netscape internet browsers - software that revolutionised access to the web. Some 1bn viewers worldwide are believed to have access to CNN, while Time Warner's magazine business reaches 120m readers and its young cable business already has 13m subscribers.

Despite the breadth of the deal, the merger partners do not expect any problems in gaining regulatory approval.

"Today's announcement really does change the tectonic plates in this world," Christopher Dixon, a media analyst at the US investment bank PaineWebber, said. "This underscores the strength of the internet ... It's about coming up with ways to use your computer in a TV-like experience."

Most financial and industry analysts cheered the creation of a new class of digital media company. But rivals urged regulators to ensure consumers have equal access to content such as Time Warner's magazines and TV programmes, even if they do not link with AOL's internet services.

Bulletin boards on the web were crammed with complaints from internet users who saw the deal as a blow to the web's freedom from US corporate dominance.

fields.headline: PR rules
fields.standfirst:
Labour is not about to ditch its policy on PR, says David McKie
Plus: Don't shoot the referee
fields.trailText: The great survivor, it seemed, was set to survive yet again. For a while, Britain's ancient electoral system, first past the post, almost unknown in the rest of Europe, had looked threatened as never before when the nation elected a Labour government committed to setting up an inquiry into alternative voting systems, and then giving the people their chance to decide in a referendum.
fields.body:
The great survivor, it seemed, was set to survive yet again. For a while, Britain's ancient electoral system, first past the post, almost unknown in the rest of Europe, had looked threatened as never before when the nation elected a Labour government committed to setting up an inquiry into alternative voting systems, and then giving the people their chance to decide in a referendum.

That reflected a radical shift in Labour opinion, as they sat through 18 years of Tory control, towards the proposition - until then largely the preserve of Liberal Democrats - that the balance of seats in the Commons ought more nearly to reflect the voting preferences of the people - even if that meant getting coalition governments instead of putting one party in power on its own.

But there's one near-insuperable problem in trying to change the system. Those who can't win elections want change; but they can't get change, because they can't win elections. Those who can and do win elections cannot then see why they should make a voluntary sacrifice of political power to those they have defeated.

Sure enough, after Tony Blair got his landslide, reports began to appear that Labour activists who, in the Thatcher years, had swung to PR were now swinging back again. Last week came reports that a trawling of grassroots party opinion had come out by a margin of five to one for sticking with past the post.

These reports were essentially bogus. The figures have yet to emerge, but it is fairly clear already that the party is less hostile to change than those who leaked the story want us to think. It has also transpired that thousands of those who it was claimed had expressed their opinions had merely returned pre-printed cards supplied to them by foes of PR.

But as is so often the case, a lie was halfway round the world before the truth had got its boots on. The impression that Labour might now dodge its promise of a referendum on PR swiftly took root, and will not be dispelled even by yesterday's assurance from Downing Street that it remains party policy.

All of which has left the new Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, in a fix. The PR referendum more than anything else tempted the Lib Dems into the project of collaboration on constitutional issues with Labour. And sure enough, Mr Kennedy yesterday threatened that should that commitment fold, collaboration might have to fold with it.

He may not have wanted to say it. Though never as enthusiastic as his predecessor Paddy Ashdown about working with Labour, he wants to keep at least one foot on the governmental stage. But not to react in defence of this cherished Liberal Democrat cause would make him look like a wimp, Tony Blair's pushover.

Mr Blair himself remains wedded to the notion of a grand left-of-centre collaboration against the right, and for that he needs to keep Charles Kennedy sweet. Denying that the referendum commitment has been ditched will certainly help. But the best outcome of all would be if the government were now to declare its conversion to the use of PR for local elections.

That would not just be a highly effective sweetener for Liberal Democrats; it would also dispose of one of Labour's own most embarrassing problems: the record of some of its worst local councils where, with little or no political opposition, corrupt practices flourish - as they so often do in one-party states.

Related documentary
Proportional representation: special report

Don't shoot the referee

The FA has ruled that Tranmere Rovers' cup defeat of Sunderland at the weekend remains valid, even though they sent on a substitute to replace a player whom the referee had expelled. The blame for the incident, most people now agree, lies with the match officials, especially the referee whom some say ought to be sacked.

He wasn't the only match official in big trouble this weekend. The ref who took charge of Arsenal versus Leicester City, Mike Riley, has been universally vilified for handing out too many yellow cards, for sending off City's Darren Eadie for a trivial offence, and for not sending off City's Robbie Savage for a very much worse one.

As a subject for public debate, the performances of referees nowadays are beginning to overtake those of the players. Indeed, refereeing is starting to constitute a kind of parallel game. TV pundits seem as intent on dissecting their decisions as they are on dissecting the actual game. Managers interviewed afterwards invariably concentrate on appraising the ref, and match reports in the next day's papers are moving much the same way.

It is said that the time will shortly arrive when machines will be as intelligent and competent as people, perhaps even more so. In some ways that is frightening. But in football, I just can't wait for it. Even robot referees will get things wrong from time to time. They may even let Robbie Savage stay on the pitch. But since they will be guaranteed to be free from emotions, at least we won't be able to blame it on bias.

webTitle: Weah on the way to Chelsea

fields.headline: Weah on the way to Chelsea
fields.trailText: Chelsea have signed George Weah from AC Milan on loan until the end of the season.
fields.body:
Chelsea have signed George Weah from AC Milan on loan until the end of the season.

The 1995 World Player of the Year has been out of favour at the San Siro this season and had been expected to join French side Marseille. In fact, only this morning Weah was quoted by the Gazzetta dello Sport as saying, "It is 100 percent that I am going to Marseille. I'm going because I want to finish my career in France."

Chelsea, whose lack of goals this season helped bring about a premature end to their bid for the championship, are hopeful the 34-year old striker will make his Premiership debut against Tottenham at Stamford Bridge tomorrow night.

Weah will not be eligible for the Blues' Champions League campaign after representing Milan in an earlier round against Galatasaray.

webTitle: MPs slam out of town shopping

fields.headline: MPs slam out of town shopping
fields.trailText: More supermarkets must be built on town centre sites to revitalise communities and curb traffic congestion due to out-of-town shopping malls, MPs warned today.
fields.body:
More supermarkets must be built on town centre sites to revitalise communities and curb traffic congestion due to out-of-town shopping malls, MPs warned today.

A report by the Commons environment, transport and regional affairs committee revealed the number of superstores rose from 457 in 1986 to 1,102 in 1997, while their turnover grew from £9,188 million to £34,005 million over the same period. But while there have been benefits, there have also been many problems, with the decline of the traditional corner shop, loss of greenfields and a fall in the number of independent grocers from 116,000 in 1961 to only 20,900 in 1997. Faced with this trend, the previous Conservative government introduced a tougher planning regime in 1993 that was stiffened three years later. But some stores have continued to be built as a result of planning permission being granted before 1996. Today's report urges local councils to try to reverse the trend by using compulsory purchase orders to gain suitable town centre store sites and insisting on better design. "In future, we expect that, in all but exceptional circumstances, new supermarkets will be in urban centres or on edge-of-town sites, which can be the best site in some historic towns, where a supermarket in the town centre could be very damaging. "However, if we are to have more supermarkets in town centres, they must be built to a much better design than most existing stores," say the MPs.

But the large amounts of free car parking offered by existing out-of-town supermarkets gives them an enormous competitive advantage over city centre stores, which already generate more car use, making the situation on already congested roads, worse.

"The situation needs to be addressed urgently.

"We recommend that the government outline, as a matter of urgency, the measures it proposes to address this situation," adds the report. MPs back the current planning regime, saying it works effectively and gives town centres protection, but it has only been in operation since 1996 and the office of fair trading has created doubt and uncertainty by referring planning matters to the Competition Commission. MPs say they are "appalled that before referring planning matters to the competition commission, the OFT took no evidence from planning experts and did not consult the department of the environment, transport and the regions.

"In failing to take into account such expert evidence, it has behaved irresponsibly.

"The Commission is to report in April 2000, but may well ask for an extension. Its report will then be considered by the secretary of state for trade and industry. There is likely to be uncertainty about planning policy until after the next election," warns the report.

There is praise, however, for planning minister Nick Raynsford "for his robust defence of government policy.

"He made clear the DETR will not change its policy, whatever the findings of the competition commission in respect of planning. We must conclude that the competition commission's continued consideration of planning policy is a waste of time.

"We are concerned that the competition authorities and some treasury and department of trade and industry officials who do not understand the planning system, may now be seeking relaxations in it and may hope that such a policy can be introduced after the report of the Competition Commission. This would be disastrous.

"A relaxation of the planning regime in respect of out-of-town sites would do little to encourage new entrants. It would run the risk of returning to the laissez-faire policies of before 1993 which did so much damage."

Friends of the Earth planning campaigner Simon McRae said "This is a hard hitting report.

"It rightly slams the OFT, the treasury and the DTI for kow-towing to the demands of the supermarkets and their lobbyists.

"But understandably perhaps, the report leaves Mr Blair and No 10 out of the picture. But it's clear that they belong in the same frame. "Big out-of-town supermarkets have damaged town centres and put small community shops out of business.

"We want Mr Blair to make it clear that planning policy guidance on out of town developments and restrictions on car parking will not be relaxed to suit the demands of the retail giants."

"In failing to take into account such expert evidence, it has behaved irresponsibly. "The Commission is to report in April 2000, but may well ask for an extension. Its report will then be considered by the secretary of state for trade and industry. There is likely to be uncertainty about planning policy until after the next election," warns the report. There is praise, however, for planning minister Nick Raynsford "for his robust defence of government policy. "He made clear the DETR will not change its policy, whatever the findings of the competition commission in respect of planning. We must conclude that the competition commission's continued consideration of planning policy is a waste of time. "We are concerned that the competition authorities and some treasury and department of trade and industry officials who do not understand the planning system, may now be seeking relaxations in it and may hope that such a policy can be introduced after the report of the Competition Commission. This would be disastrous. "A relaxation of the planning regime in respect of out-of-town sites would do little to encourage new entrants. It would run the risk of returning to the laissez-faire policies of before 1993 which did so much damage." Friends of the Earth planning campaigner Simon McRae said "This is a hard hitting report. "It rightly slams the OFT, the treasury and the DTI for kow-towing to the demands of the supermarkets and their lobbyists. "But understandably perhaps, the report leaves Mr Blair and No 10 out of the picture. But it's clear that they belong in the same frame. "Big out-of-town supermarkets have damaged town centres and put small community shops out of business. "We want Mr Blair to make it clear that planning policy guidance on out of town developments and restrictions on car parking will not be relaxed to suit the demands of the retail giants."

webTitle: Waiting lists climb steeply as flu crisis halts surgery

fields.headline: Waiting lists climb steeply as flu crisis halts surgery
fields.trailText: Hospital waiting lists started to climb steeply yesterday as the continuing flu crisis forced cancellation of non-urgent surgery in operating theatres across the country.
fields.body:
Hospital waiting lists started to climb steeply yesterday as the continuing flu crisis forced cancellation of non-urgent surgery in operating theatres across the country.

Ministers were confident of making good the damage in coming months, but every day that the flu outbreak rages on will throw further doubt on the government's drive to cut the waiting lists.

As he told MPs that the official number of people with flu-like symptoms had risen almost fivefold since early last month, Alan Milburn, the health secretary, said many hospitals which had planned to resume routine surgery yesterday had decided to delay until pressures subsided.

"Hospital managers and clinicians will make judgments about how best to balance their workload in light of local experience over the next few weeks," the minister said in a Commons statement.

"This approach represents a sensible deployment of NHS staff and resources."

The government remains committed to a general election promise to cut hospital waiting lists in England by 100,000 by the end of this parliament, although Mr Milburn has sought to deflect attention from this goal, stressing new priorities.

Latest published figures show that by the end of last October, the English lists had come down by 79,000. But already available November figures for Wales show a 2% monthly increase and no overall improvement over the position 12 months before.

Even if English hospitals maintained their improving trend during November, it is almost certain to have ended last month - when routine surgery was largely halted in preparation for any millennium problems - and to be now in sharp reverse.

Hospitals in London, Brighton, Bristol, Leeds, Nottingham and Newcastle-upon-Tyne were among those confirming yesterday that they had cancelled non-urgent surgery until further notice.

Mr Milburn said hospitals in England had dealt with more than 200,000 emergency admissions in the past three weeks - an increase of 30%. The evidence was that patients were "more ill than normal" and were staying in hospital longer than normal.

The NHS had risen to the challenge and was coping, the minister said, though it was true that services were "stretched".

Doctors' leaders joined calls for the government to acknowledge that the flu crisis had exposed a critical shortage of hospital beds. Peter Hawker, who chairs the British Medical Association's consultants' committee, said health care planning had to take proper account of the greater needs of the growing numbers of elderly people.

"It is time we stopped seeing this as an inconvenient extra pressure in winter and recognised that our assumptions about bed numbers need to be built on real need, rather than wishful thinking," he said.

The latest official figure for incidence of flu or flu-like illness in England is, provisionally, 197 people in every 100,000. Although this remains well short of epidemic levels, Liam Donaldson, the chief medical officer, has used the term "epidemic" because he says the count excludes many people not going to their doctor.

Douglas Fleming, director of the Royal College of General Practitioners' research unit responsible for the count, said the outbreak was no different from that last winter.

John Oxford, professor of virology at the Royal London hospital, agreed and said it had again exposed the NHS's inability to cope with the not entirely unexpected.

webTitle: Spend more on drugs, NHS told

fields.headline: Spend more on drugs, NHS told
fields.trailText: The health service could take pressure off hospitals and meet its target of saving an extra 300,000 lives in the next 10 years by spending more on medicines, according to the body representing the drugs industry.
fields.body:
The health service could take pressure off hospitals and meet its target of saving an extra 300,000 lives in the next 10 years by spending more on medicines, according to the body representing the drugs industry.

A report by the Association of British Pharmaceutical Industry argues that in comparison with the US, France and Germany, the UK has the highest death rate from cancer, but spends the least on anti-cancer drugs.

Heart disease and stroke kill 220,000 people a year in Britain. The wider use of preventive drugs could prevent illness in thousands, the ABPI says.

"Patients are not getting the effective medicines that are available on the national health service," said Trevor Jones, director of the ABPI.

"People talk about the expense of medicines but it truly represents only a small proportion of the total NHS spend - some 12%."

The report argues that £95 per 1,000 of the population is spent in Britain on anti-cancer drugs, compared with £279 in France. The percentage of cancer patients alive five years after diagnosis is significantly higher in France than in Britain.

The figure suggests that extra spending on anti-cancer medicines would free hospital resources for other uses, says the report.

webTitle: Disgraced Glitter expresses 'deep regret' for child porn offences

fields.headline: Disgraced Glitter expresses 'deep regret' for child porn offences
fields.standfirst: Former star speaks on release from prison
fields.trailText: A distraught Gary Glitter today said he deeply regretted the child pornography offences for which he was jailed last year.
fields.body:
A distraught Gary Glitter today said he deeply regretted the child pornography offences for which he was jailed last year.

Speaking shortly after his release from Bristol's Horfield prison, a clearly emotional Glitter said: "I deeply regret doing what I was sent to prison for. I've served my time and want to put it all behind me and live my life."

After his brief statement in Regent's Park, London, the disgraced pop star donned his sunglasses and strode off to a waiting car. He was thought to be leaving for Heathrow airport and a flight out of the country.

The former glam rock star, whose real name is Paul Gadd, was smuggled out of prison shortly after 8am after serving half his four-month sentence for possession of hardcore child pornography. He had admitted 54 charges of possessing child pornography downloaded from the internet but was cleared of eight charges of indecent assault and sodomy dating from 1980.

Prison officials made special arrangements for the singer's release because of security fears after anonymous death threats were made against him.

They refused to give any details in advance to reporters and photographers, many of whom camped overnight outside the prison.

Glitter is reported to have been kept separated from other prisoners during his sentence.

Glitter, who has sold 18m records over the course of 25 years, was arrested in 1997 after technicians at a Bristol computer store found indecent images on his computer's hard drive. Some of them depicted prepubescent children being sexually abused and tortured.

On his release, Glitter's name was added to a sex offenders' register. It will remain on the register for seven years, and he will have to notify police of any change of address.

fields.headline: El futuro
fields.standfirst: Beginners' Spanish
fields.trailText: Beginners' Spanish
fields.body:
Los jóvenes españoles consideran que la familia es más importante que la amistad, el trabajo, la vivienda, la educación, ganar dinero, o el ocio. Este es el resultado de una reciente encuesta del Centro de Investigaciones Sociológicas (CIS) entre jóvenes españoles de 15 a 19 años. Sólo hay un tema más importante que la familia: la salud.

Una de las amenazas hoy de las familias es el divorcio. En España el número de divorcios ha aumentado un 47 por ciento en los últimos siete años. "La gente ahora no se educa para el sacrificio," opina Cristina. "Antes de casarse la gente debe mentalizarse", advierte Cristina. "La Iglesia debe explicar y avisar sobre los peligros del divorcio", opina Begoña. Según Gemma, sin embargo, el divorcio no es un problema religioso sino social.

Otro cambio en la estructura social clásica son las unidades familiares con hijos pero sin padre o sin madre. Qué piensan los jóvenes españoles de esto? "Es difícil valorar las situaciones. Pero depende del caso. No me parece mal pero no es lo mejor para el niño. Lo ideal es tener padre y madre. Es lo normal por naturaleza. Y es lo normal en la sociedad, aunque esto puede cambiar," opina Cristina

Según Begoña es hacer las cosas al revés. "Es egoísta tener un hijo sin pareja", declara Begoña. Según Gemma es mejor tener sólo una madre que te quiere que tener un padre y una madre peleándose siempre. "Pero el papel del padre y el de la madre, los dos, son muy importantes", añade Gemma. Según la encuesta del CIS, el 50 por ciento de los jóvenes españoles opina que un solo progenitor puede educar a un hijo tan bien como el padre y la madre juntos.

ganar dinero to earn money
hacer las cosas al revés to put things the wrong way round
el ocio leisure time
la pareja partner
pelearse to fight
el peligro danger
la salud health
la vivienda housing

fields.headline: Jóvenes en crisis
fields.standfirst: At the turn of the century, Spanish youngsters seem pessimistic. How do they think the Catholic Church should face the future, after its 2000th anniversary?
fields.trailText: Secondary Spanish
fields.body:
Recién inaugurado el siglo XXI, los jóvenes españoles esperan que la tecnología sea el motor de los cambios en el futuro. Se declaran, sin embargo, pesimistas. Opinan que los desarrollos científicos y tecnológicos tienen una cara negativa: la crisis de los valores, de la sociedad, de la familia y de la educación.

El Vaticano prepara este año el 2.000 aniversario de la Iglesia católica. Según una encuesta del Centro de Investigaciones Sociológicas, del Ministerio de la Presidencia, los jóvenes piensan que la religión es más importante que la política. En España más de un 70 por ciento de los jóvenes se define como católico, aunque un 55 por ciento no va casi nunca a misa. El Vaticano alerta, entre otras cosas, sobre los peligros de Internet. Según la Iglesia católica, "Internet estimula la adicción a las drogas, la prostitución y el sida".

Cómo será la vida en el próximo milenio?

Begoña Benet (16 años): Mejorará la calidad de vida pero aumentará el consumismo. A nivel tecnológico cambiará todo incluso más rápido que en los últimos veinte años.

Cristina Rivera (17 años): La sociedad empeorará. Hay mucha libertad y todo el mundo hace lo que le da la gana.

Qué esperas del nuevo milenio?

Begoña: Las diferencias entre países ricos y países pobres aumentarán si no les ayudamos. Soluciones? Invertir en educación, por ejemplo, para que los países pobres se desarrollen por ellos mismos.

Cristina: Que la ciencia termine con enfermedades como el cáncer o el sida. Y que Internet nos ayude a comunicarnos con más facilidad. Aunque Internet también puede convertirnos en robots. Nos estamos destruyendo, nos comunicamos poco y perdemos valores.

Gemma: Solidaridad, acabar con el racismo - pero nadie hace nada. El sistema político no funciona. La gente se queja pero no hace nada para cambiarlo. Sobre Internet - no me gusta. Es poco útil y hay demasiadas cosas que no necesitamos. No estimula a los jóvenes. Hay demasiados juegos en la red.

Está desfasado el Vaticano? Qué papel debe tener la Iglesia católica y el Papa en la sociedad española del futuro?

Begoña: La Iglesia no está desfasada. Lo que está bien está bien siempre, y lo que está mal también. La verdad no puede cambiar a gusto del consumidor. No se puede cambiar lo que dijo Jesucristo. Yo voy a misa cada día y comulgo con el Opus Dei. La Iglesia debe ser un apoyo, un punto de referencia. Por ejemplo sobre Internet, la Iglesia advierte sobre sus peligros.

Cristina: La Iglesia no puede seguir igual. Debe cambiar sus ideas sobre el divorcio, la eutanasia o el aborto, por ejemplo. No se puede leer la Biblia al pie de la letra. Una cosa es lo que fundó Jesucristo y otra el montaje posterior. Hoy la gente no quiere escuchar lo que dice la Iglesia. Y la Iglesia no quiere entender el porqué y escuchar a la gente. Si la Iglesia escuchara los jóvenes le harían más caso. Yo creo en Dios, rezo cada día y voy a misa cuando necesito ir, pero no por obligación.

Gemma: Soy atea, no creo en nada, pienso que todo es una farsa. El papel del Papa es abominable. Hay mucho dinero en juego. Si fueran más convincentes quizás me apuntaría. Pero hay mucho fanatismo. Dicen que Dios lo es todo, y no admiten que hay gente muy feliz sin creer en Dios. La Iglesia tiene sus ideales y no se da cuenta de que el mundo ha cambiado. Es siempre la misma historia. Se basa en la Biblia y otros libros que podrían ser inventados. En realidad nadie puede demostrar que Jesucristo existió. La gente ahora quiere algo más. La Iglesia debería abrirse y dar respuestas a los creyentes y a los no creyentes.

Crees que los jóvenes tienen valores? Quién debe educar en estos valores?

Begoña: Hay de todo. En todo caso la responsabilidad es compartida, de los padres, la escuela, los amigos, la Iglesia.

Cristina: No, y es importante que los jóvenes tengan valores, ya sean religiosos, éticos o morales. Lo importante es distinguir lo bueno de lo malo. Y esto es responsabilidad del Estado.

Gemma: Los jóvenes son ahora unos estúpidos, no piensan. Tienen valores pero no hacen nada para defenderlos. Se quedan en casa sentados en el sofá. En los años sesenta y setenta cuando los jóvenes querían algo lo reivindicaban. Pero esto es culpa de los padres, que tienen cada día más estrés. Ni los padres ni la sociedad se preocupan por la educación. La educación es un desastre y los jóvenes son cada vez menos responsables.

Glosario/Glossary

a gusto del consumidor at the whim of the consumer
al pie de la letra literally
apuntarse to enrol on or sign up for something
el/la creyente believer
darse cuenta de to realise
dinero en juego money at stake
empeorar to get worse
hacer caso to pay attention
hacer lo que te dé la gana (colloq.) to do what you like
el montaje spin, interpretation (lit. stage-setting)
quejarse to complain

fields.headline: New South Wales lose again
fields.trailText: Australia
fields.body:
Australia

Australia's Sheffield Shield hasn't just changed its name, it has been turned upside down, with holders Western Australia languishing in second-bottom place. The only state doing worse than WA is New South Wales, another of the big fish.

Eleven wickets from seamer Don Nash were not enough to prevent NSW from going down to their fifth defeat of the season in the Pura Milk Cup, this time losing to South Australia by 78 runs at Adelaide. Nash followed up first-innings figures of 7-72 (as NSW made 248) with 4-61, but NSW, set 280 to win, could manage only 201, as Brad Young claimed 6-85. SA were indebted to 102 from opener Dave Fitzgerald in their second innings of 274. In their first, SA had been struggling at 137 for 6, before Graham Manou hit 78 from No.8 to lift the total to 253. NSW remained bottom of the table, 0.1 behind Western Australia. SA went third, still six points behind Queensland and Victoria.

Justin Langer rushed to 84* as Western Australia beat Canberra by six wickets in the one-day Mercantile Mutual Cup at Perth. Canberra reached 226 for 9, with 71 from Peter Solway, but Langer, helped by 62 from Durham's overseas-star-to-be, Simon Katich, guided WA home with 21 balls to spare.

Michael Kasprowicz (3-18) and Andy Bichel (3-22) bowled Queensland to the top of the table, ahead of WA on run-rate, as they thrashed Tasmania by 122 runs at Hobart. The Bulls made 224 for 9, then skittled Tasmania in 38.4 overs for just 102.

South Africa

A superb all-round performance from Vasbert Drakes almost guided Border to a win against KwaZulu-Natal in the Super Eights stage of the SuperSport Series. Set 327 to win, Natal finished a precarious 293 for 9, with Drakes taking 4-52; Errol Stewart saved the day with 84*. Earlier, Drakes had hit 71 in Border's first-innings total of 361, before claiming 4-65 as Natal replied with 225, of which 20-year-old Ahmed Amla made 104. Drakes then scored 32* as Border struggled to 190 in their second innings (Pieter Strydom 50, Eldine Baptiste 4-18).

Former New Zealand captain Ken Rutherford was in the runs again for Gauteng as they drew with Free State. He made 134 as Gauteng ran up 306 in response to Free State's 143 (David Terbrugge 4-41, Andrew Hall 4-35). But FS did better in their second innings, as 97 from Jonathan Beukes and 91 from Boeta Dippenaar helped them to 366. They even had time to take three cheap Gauteng wickets before the close, left-arm spinner Nicky Boje claiming 3-3.

Ex-Leicestershire batsman Martin Gidley hit 99 as Griqualand West beat North West in a rain-affected Standard Bank game at Potchefstroom. Gidley put on 186 for the first wicket with John Arthur (75) as Griquas ran up 244 for 5 in their 45 overs. North West replied with 211.

Gauteng defeated Eastern Province by five wickets, despite 96 from EP opener Carl Bradfield. EP made 242, but Gauteng raced to victory with more than six overs to spare. South Africa's reserve Test opener Adam Bacher hit 61.

Dale Benkenstein scored 58 and Andrew Hudson 50* to set up KwaZulu-Natal's seven-run win against Free State. Natal scored 223 for 4, and then restricted Free State to 216 for 8, with seamer Wade Wingfield claiming 4-42.

India

Abhijit Kale compiled a matchsaving 248* for Maharashtra as they followed on against Baroda in the West Zone of the Ranji Trophy. Kale added 198 for the 8th wicket with SV Aradhye (58), after Maharastra had stumbled to 246 for 7 in their second innings, an overall lead of just 66. Earlier, Atul Bedade had hit 139 and Zaheer Khan 48 from No.11 as Baroda reached 393.

Tamil Nadu qualified for the Super League section after thrashing Goa by an innings and 197 runs in the South Zone game at Chennai, with centuries from Sridaran Sriram (147) and Tanveer Jabbar (100*), who put on 154 for the 8th wicket with Sadagopan Mahesh (77). In reply to TN's 446 for 8 declared, Goa subsided meekly, to 112 (Yeshwant Barde 69) and 137 (Ashish Kapoor 4-33).

Hyderabad and Karnataka also made it through from the South Zone after their draw at Secunderabad. Set 356 to win, Karnataka finished on 239 for 4, after 93 from Vinay Kumar had allowed Hyderabad to declare their second innings on 312 for 6.

Ten for 149 from offspinner Bhaskar Ramprakash helped Kerala creep home by three wickets against Andhra at Kozhikode. Ramprakash claimed 6-68 as Andhra collapsed in their first innings from 66 for 0 to 168, and then 4-81 in their second-innings 179; Sunil Oasis chipped in with 5-27. That left Kerala needing 162 to win.

While India's batsmen struggled in Australia, forgotten man Vinod Kambli continued his fine form with 125* in Mumbai's draw with Saurashtra. Together with 131 from Amol Muzumdar, Kambli allowed Mumbai to bat Saurashtra out of the game, as they reached 372 for 4 in their second innings. Saurashtra, who had been dismissed for 183 first time round (Abey Kuruvilla 5-47), survived, but only just, closing on 206 for 8.

Avinash Kumar toiled away for figures of 77-18-172-4 as Bengal amassed 561 against Bihar at Jamshedpur. Saba Karim made 129 as Bengal, in response to Bihar's 341, killed the game.

There was a more exciting draw at Orissa where Assam, set 322 to beat Orissa, finished on 265 for 7, with opener and captain Zakaria Zuffri making 144. Orissa had begun the game with 425, as Sanjay Raul hit 120, before reducing Assam to 134 for 7. But they recovered to 306, thanks to 82 from Rajesh Borah and 55* from No.10 Gautam Dutta. Sanjay Satpathy took 6-86. Orissa then declared their second innings on 202 for 4.

New Zealand

An unbroken century stand between brothers Michael (62*) and Neal Parlane (53*) steered Northern Districts to a comfortable nine-wicket win over Otago in the Shell Cup. Set 128 to win after Otago had been limited to 127 (Tuffey 10-5-16-3), ND romped home. ND had earlier gone down to a 58-run defeat at the hands of Wellington, for whom Hampshire second XI batsman Chris Nevin top-scored with 56.

But the leaders after four rounds are Canterbury who made up for the abandonment of their third-round game against Central Districts with a seven-wicket win against Auckland, who are now second.

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com

fields.headline: From PC World to jailbird
fields.standfirst: Gary Glitter interactive timeline
fields.trailText: January 1997: Glitter buys a Toshiba laptop computer worth £4,734.
fields.body:
January 1997: Glitter buys a Toshiba laptop computer worth £4,734.

18 November, 1997: Takes it to PC World at Cribbs Causeway shopping centre near Bristol with a software fault. Tells the technician not to look at the files.

19 November, 1997: But he does, and Glitter is arrested as collects the computer. Police search the star's homes in Somerset and London and seize indecent videos and pictures of children. Click here for full story

December 1997: Christmas tour begins as scheduled but Glitter is cut from Spice Girls movie following his arrest and child porn allegations.

31 March, 1998: Glitter charged with 50 offences of downloading indecent photographs of children on his return form a three month holiday in Cuba. His lawyer says Glitter is "totally innocent" of any wrongdoing. Click here for full story

6 May, 1998: Police charge Glitter with a further five sexual offences, one of them relating to a girl aged between eight and 10. The first four concern a 14 year old fan who sold her story to the News of the World.

18 July, 1998: Glitter ordered to face a two-day committal hearing into child pornography and indecency charges.

30 April, 1999: Judge rules Glitter is to stand trial at Bristol crown court on child sex and pornography charges.

9 November, 1999: Jury hears evidence of sexual assault on an underage fan but is told that the alledged victim will collect £25,000 from the News of the World if Glitter is convicted. Click here for full story

12 November, 1999: Glitter cleared of sexual assault but pleads guilty to 54 charges of making indecent photographs of children under 16 and sentenced to four months in jail. Click here for full story

fields.headline: Five women of the century
fields.trailText: When Wisden Cricketers' Almanack 2000 is published on April 1, it will announce the definitive list of Cricketers of the Century - five all-time greats who have been chosen over the past few months by a panel of 100 cricketing luminaries. Not one of the five, we can exclusively reveal, will be female. Only three of the 100 voters were women, and of those three, only one is English - the very un-English-sounding Netta Rheinberg.
fields.body:
When Wisden Cricketers' Almanack 2000 is published on April 1, it will announce the definitive list of Cricketers of the Century - five all-time greats who have been chosen over the past few months by a panel of 100 cricketing luminaries. Not one of the five, we can exclusively reveal, will be female. Only three of the 100 voters were women, and of those three, only one is English - the very un-English-sounding Netta Rheinberg.

The name is an inheritance from her great-grandfather, who emigrated to Britain from Germany in the 1860s. A forthright, friendly woman with a cut-glass accent, Netta Rheinberg has been involved with cricket virtually all her life. 'I was always a bit of a rumbustious girl and I started playing cricket at school. My parents weren't very happy but I loved it.'

She went on to play at territory level and then for England - she was player/manager on the 1948-49 tour of Australia, New Zealand and Sri Lanka. She was also the secretary of the Women's Cricket Association for 12 years, wrote a book, Fair Play, with Rachael Heyhoe-Flint, and last year became one of the first female members of MCC. Matthew Engel, editor of the Almanack, chose her as a voter because, 'She's very knowledgeable and she's been associated with cricket for the majority of the 20th century. Apart from Jim [EW] Swanton, there's hardly anyone around with that kind of historical perspective.'

Netta's personal top five - Bradman, Sobers, Viv Richards, Botham, Compton - will not be causing a rumpus at Lord's. Did being a woman have any bearing on her selection? 'No I don't think it did, to be honest. I chose players that I have seen and who were the best. I don't think women view the game any differently, though I would say that women who are interested in cricket are very knowledgeable indeed - often more so than men. They certainly don't just go to a ground and do the knitting.'

Who would be her top five female Cricketers of the Century? 'Again I would go for players that I knew and played with. There are lots of stars in Australia and New Zealand at the moment but I don't know them.

'The greatest was Molly Hide. I managed her first tour, and her knowledge and flair for the game, coupled with inspired leadership, made her unique. She led England in 11 Tests [won 4, lost 2, drew 5], and was regarded as the finest allrounder in the country. She was also a long-term selector for Surrey and England. Not enough was made of her achievements when she died in 1995. She might not have gone down too well these days, but her masculine character certainly prepared her for leadership.'

Her other four choices are: Myrtle MacLagan (played 1934-54), who 'opened the batting with Hide for Surrey and was also a very fine slow-medium bowler'; Marjorie Pollard (1930s), 'one of the very first women to make her name in cricket - a great allrounder, one of the founders of the WCA and one of first women cricket journalists'; Betty Belton (1930s), 'the first well-known female fast bowler', and Betty Snowball (1930s), 'one of the most outstanding wicketkeepers in the women's game'.

Tanya Aldred is assistant editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly

webTitle: Two jailed over plot to burgle farm

fields.headline: Two jailed over plot to burgle farm
fields.trailText: Two unemployed men who admitted conspiring to burgle the home of a farmer who was later charged with murder were jailed yesterday.
fields.body:
Two unemployed men who admitted conspiring to burgle the home of a farmer who was later charged with murder were jailed yesterday.

Brendan Fearon, 29, from Newark, Nottinghamshire, was jailed for three years at Norwich crown court.

Darren Bark, 33, also from Newark, was jailed for 30 months. He was also ordered to serve an extra 12 months for an unrelated burglary.

Both men pleaded guilty to conspiring to burgle the home of Tony Martin, 54, in Emneth, Norfolk, in August last year.

The court heard how Bark and Fearon had set out to burgle Mr Martin's home with Fred Barras, 16, a Newark market trader.

Martin had opened fire with a shotgun when he disturbed Fearon and Barras, the court heard. Barras died as a result of his injuries. Fearon suffered wounds to his upper thighs.

Martin has been charged with murdering Barras and with causing grevious bodily harm to Fearon. He is awaiting trial.

Judge Mellor said publicity surrounding Martin's case had not affected the sentences on Fearon and Bark.

Ian James, prosecuting, told the court that Fearon had planned the burglary and persuaded Bark to drive to Emneth.

Fearon had targeted Martin's home after hearing other people talking about the property in a pub, the court heard.

The trio, who all had links to the travelling community in Newark, believed that they would be able to steal small antiques.

Fearon and Bark asked for seven other offences to be taken into consideration.
