webTitle: Pace on top in digital contest

fields.headline: Pace on top in digital contest
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Set-top box manufacturer Pace Micro Technology yesterday emerged as a clear winner in the fierce tussle between BSkyB, the cable operators and terrestrial broadcaster ONdigital to sign up digital television customers.
fields.body:
Set-top box manufacturer Pace Micro Technology yesterday emerged as a clear winner in the fierce tussle between BSkyB, the cable operators and terrestrial broadcaster ONdigital to sign up digital television customers.

A dramatic increase in subscribers caused by last year's set-top box giveaway saw Pace comfortably beat City forecasts with a 53% rise in first-half pre-tax profits to £12.7m.

Shares in the company, which until a year ago were languishing at less than 100p, were marked up 21% to 588p.

Pace claims to have more than 50% of its home market and a 10% share of the global set-top box business.

"There has been tremendous growth in the British market, which is growing faster than any other in the world," said Malcolm Miller, Pace chief executive. "The front room is now the front line, with people fighting not only for pay TV but internet access and e-commerce revenues."

Britain will overtake the US in penetration of digital TV by the end of the year, he predicted, with one in four homes taking services within 18 months.

Margins in the first half were squeezed from 25.9% to 20.3%, partly because of aggressive pricing to support the box giveaway and the company hopes to claw back some ground with new products commanding premium prices.

Mr Miller demonstrated plans to turn the group's set-top boxes into "home gateways" which will enable high-bandwidth applications such as e-mail and internet access.

The company hopes to launch by the year's end a handheld home shopping device and a PC attachment to be linked to the set top box via wireless technology.

Other appliances which could be linked to a broadband net through a wireless link include fridges, games and second TVs.

Turnover was 58% higher than the previous year, at £157.2m, and the interim dividend was lifted 20% to 0.3p.

fields.headline: Scoot dismisses dossier
fields.trailText: Internet entrepreneur Robert Bonnier yesterday claimed that a "malicious former employee" is behind the highly critical dossier on his Scoot.com directory service now being circulated in the City and media. The report has been dismissed by sources close to Mr Bonnier as a mixture of recycled old news and defamatory fiction.
fields.body:
Internet entrepreneur Robert Bonnier yesterday claimed that a "malicious former employee" is behind the highly critical dossier on his Scoot.com directory service now being circulated in the City and media. The report has been dismissed by sources close to Mr Bonnier as a mixture of recycled old news and defamatory fiction.

Purportedly a "due diligence" report on the company, the dossier gives no details of either the client for whom it was prepared nor the organisation - whether a firm of accountants or solicitors, or a detective agency - that put it together. In place of the usual executive summary at the front of the report is a memorandum dated yesterday and apparently angled at the media.

Mr Bonnier and his aides tried and failed yesterday to establish the identity of the report's author, and Scoot's chief executive has taken legal advice on the matter.

Scoot, formerly Freepages, offers telephone and net directory services, and has partnership agreements with Vivendi, France's entertainment and communications group, and AltaVista, the US internet search company. But, according to the dossier, its subscription base is stagnant, its salesmen are encouraged to be "ruthless" and some subscribers are dissatisfied with its service.

fields.headline: On message
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText:
Share placing
British internet solutions specialist Magic Moments Internet is placing 30m shares, raising £2.4m to provide capital and fund potential opportunities. Shares in the company rose 2p to 12p in early afternoon trading.
fields.body:
Share placing
British internet solutions specialist Magic Moments Internet is placing 30m shares, raising £2.4m to provide capital and fund potential opportunities. Shares in the company rose 2p to 12p in early afternoon trading.

Magic Moments was bought out for £14m in a reverse takeover last August by the shell vehicle Bramhall.

It attracted attention in November when its chief executive took part in the Channel 4 TV programme Show Me The Money.

Call for rethink
A draft European Union law which firms fear will stunt the growth of electronic commerce should be delayed and amended, a draft report commissioned by the European Parliament said yesterday.

The report, by Liberal Democrat MEP Diana Wallis, calls on the European Commission, which is considering the law today, to rework a proposal allowing internet shoppers to sue online firms in the shopper's country rather than the country where the firm is based. This would open up firms to the "nightmare" of lawsuits in any of the EU's 15 countries regardless of whether they had marketed products there.

In public
Internet adult publishing and cable television firm Playboy.com, said yesterday it had filed with the US securities and exchange commission regulatory documents that would take it public.

fields.headline: Virgin email security scare
fields.trailText: Richard Branson's Virgin Net has told 25% of users to change their email passwords after a potential security breach.
fields.body:
Richard Branson's Virgin Net has told 25% of users to change their email passwords after a potential security breach.

The company had to disable its incoming email service temporarily at the weekend after hackers were suspected of infiltrating its systems.

Virgin Net said it informed around 155,000 of its 620,000 users that the "integrity" of accounts could be at risk unless they changed passwords following the breach, which occurred last Thursday. It is working with police to identify the source of the problem.

Alex Heath, the managing director of Virgin Net, said there was no evidence that accounts had been abused.

"Our customers' email privacy has always been and will continue to be a top priority for Virgin Net, and as such we have acted quickly and decisively to ensure the integrity of the service."

Virgin's scare, which is likely to fuel fears about security and privacy on the net, paled against the problems encountered by an American online music retailer at the weekend.

CD Universe was contacted by a hacker who claimed he would publish customers' credit card details on the web unless he was sent $100,000.

The blackmailer, who said he was 19 and from Russia, released some details when CD Universe refused to pay up.

He set up a website allowing surfers to obtain credit card numbers, with names and addresses, by clicking a mouse.

The site was shut down yesterday following the intervention of the FBI. "The internet creates a whole new class of criminals," said Elias Levy, of computer security firm SecurityFocus.com.

"On the net you can have criminals coming from countries where we have no extradition treaties. How do you prosecute these people?"

webTitle: Geo share price jumps higher on reports of acquisition fund-raiser

fields.headline: Geo share price jumps higher on reports of acquisition fund-raiser
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Geo Interactive Media, the Israeli software company, yesterday prompted yet another leap in its stock after saying it planned to sell 11m new shares to fund acquisitions.
fields.body:
Geo Interactive Media, the Israeli software company, yesterday prompted yet another leap in its stock after saying it planned to sell 11m new shares to fund acquisitions.

Its shares rose 237.5p to close at £17.82 even though it was forced to deny a news agency report that it is talking to Finnish mobile phones group Nokia about an alliance. The shares topped 100p before falling back.

Eli Reifman, Geo's founder, told Reuters the new shares were equivalent to 9% of its equity and should raise more than $270m (164m) - valuing the company at more than $2.5bn, much to the consternation of its advisers.

They denied the same agency's report that the money raised would be used to acquire six internet start-up companies with which Geo is talking. But it is acknowledged that acquisitions are in the wind.

Geo has recently been linked with Nokia, now Europe's biggest company, after concluding deals with Energis and the Korean group Samsung to put its Emblaze technology into their products.

Emblaze enables "streaming" of audio and video over mobile phones and the internet, heralding the era when these will be used to download movies and the like.

Industry sources told Reuters that Geo was in advanced talks with Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, Lehman Brothers and Oppenheimer about placing the shares but company insiders refused to confirm this.

It was clear, however, that the decision to place the 11m shares - for which shareholder approval will be sought on January 13 - means that an earlier idea of going to Nasdaq has been shelved.

The aim of the placement in London is to try to avoid the wild gyrations in share values that have afflicted hi-tech stocks in recent weeks and escape the whims of retail investors who have been ploughing in and out of the sector.

Mr Reifman told Reuters one of the ways for an internet company to establish its position was through mergers and acquisitions activity, although he refused to name any potential partners.

Last month Energis paid £15m for a stake in Geo, which then benefited to the tune of "several million dollars" through a technology licensing deal with Samsung.

fields.headline: Minister offers £5m welfare concession
fields.standfirst: Welfare reform: special report
fields.trailText: The government yesterday held out an olive branch to disabled people and carers who were offended by last year's welfare cuts when it announced concessions worth £5.5m a year to 52,000 people.
fields.body:
The government yesterday held out an olive branch to disabled people and carers who were offended by last year's welfare cuts when it announced concessions worth £5.5m a year to 52,000 people.

The social security minister, Hugh Bayley, used the first parliamentary session of the new year to reveal that people who spend time in hospital for respite care will be eligible for their daily allowances for the day they leave hospital, instead of having it docked by the benefit office.

He also told MPs that people who live in local authority residential homes and pay the costs out of their own re sources will become entitled to receive disability living allowance or the attendance allowance. Previously such payments were available only to people living in private homes.

The current rule, which currently denies many people a day's worth of respite care costs when they leave hospital, hits 50,000 claimants, many of whom regularly spend a day a week in hospital to relieve their carers.

Both rules, involving significant sums - up to £52.95 a week - have long niggled the disabled and their allies, who were deeply offended by last year's welfare reform act which cut disability entitlements for new claimants.

fields.headline: GP trial 'tragic and disturbing'
fields.standfirst: Shipman trial: special report
fields.trailText: The judge began his summing up yesterday in the "tragic and deeply disturbing" case of Dr Harold Shipman, the family doctor who is accused of murdering 15 women patients, by telling the jury to put aside their emotions when considering the evidence.
fields.body:
The judge began his summing up yesterday in the "tragic and deeply disturbing" case of Dr Harold Shipman, the family doctor who is accused of murdering 15 women patients, by telling the jury to put aside their emotions when considering the evidence.

Mr Justice Forbes said at Preston crown court: "This is a tragic and deeply disturbing case. The allegations could not be more serious - a doctor accused of murdering 15 patients.

"You will have heard evidence which may have aroused feelings of anger, strong disapproval, disgust, profound dismay or deep sympathy. You must put all such feelings or emotions to one side and not allow it to influence your judgment. You must consider the evidence dispassionately."

The judge said the jurors must put out of their minds anything they may have read, seen or heard outside of the court. "You must decide this case only on the evidence you have heard, seen and read in court." he said.

He added that the fact that the defendant had told lies was not in itself evidence of guilt. "Lies can be told to bolster a true defence, to protect somebody else, to spare the feelings of others or told out of panic, confusion or distress."

There was no direct evidence that Dr Shipman had killed any of the alleged victims with a fatal dose of morphine or diamorphine. "Nobody actually saw Dr Shipman administer any such injection to any of the alleged victims," the judge told the jurors.

He said it was Dr Shipman's case that he did not administered morphine or diamorphine to the women and he does not know how the fatal dose was administered.

The jurors should use their common sense and experience of life and knowledge of human nature, said the judge.

They must make allowances for the strain of giving evidence in court, including the evidence given by Dr Shipman.

"It cannot be easy giving evidence in circumstances in which you face charges as serious as those faced by Dr Shipman in this trial," he said.

Dr Shipman, 53, of Mottram, near Hyde, Greater Manchester, denies murdering 15 patients and forging the £386,000 will of one of the women.

The trial continues today.

fields.headline: Russians suffer worst losses yet
fields.standfirst: Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: The officer commanding the Russian offensive in Chechnya yesterday pledged to show "no mercy" in a resumed onslaught against the guerrilla fighters whose counter-attacks spread yesterday to several points behind the Russian lines.
fields.body:
The officer commanding the Russian offensive in Chechnya yesterday pledged to show "no mercy" in a resumed onslaught against the guerrilla fighters whose counter-attacks spread yesterday to several points behind the Russian lines.

The Russians admitted that 26 troops had been killed and 33 wounded in one day - the highest daily casualty toll Moscow has provided since the war erupted in September.

But Colonel-General Viktor Kazantsev sought to put a brave face on the increasing signs of disarray among the Russians confronted by the first sustained spell of Chechen counter-attacks in the four-month war.

He announced that the two senior generals who were removed last week from commanding the eastern and western fronts in the war had been reinstated and remained his deputies. On Friday the military stated that Lieutenant-General Gennady Troshev and Major-General Vladimir Shamanov had been replaced by their deputies as part of a routine "rotation" that was generally viewed as sacking.

"Nobody has dismissed anybody. Generals Troshev and Shamanov are simply loaded with additional work," Gen Kazantsev insisted yesterday.

Contradictory statements from the Russian political and military leaderships in the past few days have compounded the sense of drift and confusion.

"The reinstatement shows that the Russians are panicking," said Pavel Felgenhauer, a Moscow military analyst. "The Russian military is losing the initiative and the other side is taking the initiative. We're seeing a drastic change. The guerrillas are highly mobile. The Russians are making tactical mistakes and are too thinly spread."

Fierce fighting was reported yesterday from Argun and Gudermes, east of Grozny; from the capital itself; from Shali to the south; and from the region of Urus-Martan, south-west of the capital. All these regions, except for Grozny, have been under Russian occupation for weeks but are now the targets of rebel counter-attacks.

"This is guerrilla warfare for which one should have been prepared," said Sergei Stepashin, the former prime minister and police chief who was heavily involved in the last war in 1994-96.

With the Russian setbacks triggering unusually adverse comment in the Russian media, Vladimir Putin, the acting president and prime minister, was sounding uncharacteristically defensive when he declared that there had been "no fundamental changes" in Chechnya.

But Mr Stepashin, Mr Putin's predecessor as prime minister, ridiculed Russia's military tactics of having "10 warplanes chasing one terrorist".

"The federal authorities must be prepared for a long, drawn-out and painful terrorist war in Chechnya," he said.

Malik Saidullayev, an influential Chechen businessman loyal to Moscow, predicted worse for the Russians.

"The guerrillas are most likely to begin an open offensive in March and then the situation in Chechnya may change seriously, which will undoubtedly affect the popularity of Vladimir Putin," Mr Saidullayev said.

Mr Putin contests the Russian presidency on March 26.

webTitle: New hope for rail crash trial

fields.headline: New hope for rail crash trial
fields.standfirst: Paddington train crash: special report
fields.trailText: The attorney general yesterday moved to allay fears that an immunity he had granted covering documents presented to the Paddington rail crash inquiry would wreck hopes of a criminal prosecution.
fields.body:
The attorney general yesterday moved to allay fears that an immunity he had granted covering documents presented to the Paddington rail crash inquiry would wreck hopes of a criminal prosecution.

Lord Williams issued a clarification which British transport police hailed as a "significant change" and which would increase the chances of prosecution if evidence of criminal wrongdoing emerged.

The attorney general's clarification follows yesterday's report in the Guardian of detectives' fears that there was virtually no chance of a prosecution because the immunity undertaking was so wide.

Officers feared that documents on which a prosecution for corporate manslaughter would have to be based would be barred from use.

The attorney general said only the individual copy of a document would be barred from use in any criminal case, not the document itself.

A police source said the attorney general's rushed clarification "made a nonsense" of the original announcement of the scope of the immunity made by Lord Cullen, who chairs the inquiry which formally opened last month.

In a statement, Lord Williams said: "It has been suggested that there is some ambiguity in the expression 'documents produced to the inquiry will not be used in any prosecution'.

"It has been argued that, on one construction, these words have the effect that service of a document on the inquiry protects the provider from the use of that document or any copy of it in any prosecution, even if it could be obtained (or already has been obtained) by the police or other investigators under their own powers.

"It is not the intention that the undertaking has this wide effect. The undertaking protects from use in any prosecution the actual documents produced to the inquiry. It does not extend to any other manifestation of the documents, whether the originals (if those are retained) or any copies which the police or other investigators are able to obtain."

The crash between a Great Western train and a Thames turbo last October left 31 dead and 250 injured.

As well as the two train companies, Railtrack and the health and safety executive are under criminal investigation.

Those leading the 40-strong team of officers now believe they could use any documents if they were obtained before being submitted to the inquiry, due to get underway in late spring.

Superintendent Tony Thompson of British transport police said the attorney general's statement removed a major obstacle to a trial: "Our initial interpretation is that it's quite a significant change from what was said in December by Lord Cullen.

"They are now talking about manifestations, which one assumes means a copy. It is a complete change around from what they said originally.

"I think providing we have obtained it in advance, we could still use any documents."

Oral evidence before the inquiry will still be covered by immunity, which is meant to encourage people to testify without fear of self-incrimination.

Louise Christian, a solicitor for eight of the bereaved families, said she wanted the immunity covering written evidence and documents lifted completely because there was no need for it.

The attorney general said the undertakings to witnesses would hasten the start of the inquiry: "It was certain that without such an undertaking being given, potential witnesses would be inhibited from providing Lord Cullen with full assistance. The public interest clearly favours Lord Cullen undertaking his inquiry as soon, and as quickly, as possible so that lessons can be learnt."

After the 1997 Southall rail crash, a public inquiry into the disaster was delayed for two years after a corporate mans-laughter trial was launched, which eventually failed.

David Miles, a survivor of the Paddington rail crash, said: "My major concern is that an inquiry is gone into as quickly as possible to try to identify what the causes were of the accident.

"But I appreciate that I am somebody who is possibly slightly luckier than an awful lot of other people who have a lot more serious injuries and who therefore may have a much greater desire to see that people are held to account."

Police have still not decided if there is a criminal case for any company or individual to answer. They hope to conclude their investigation by the end of March.

"I think providing we have obtained it in advance, we could still use any documents." Oral evidence before the inquiry will still be covered by immunity, which is meant to encourage people to testify without fear of self-incrimination. Louise Christian, a solicitor for eight of the bereaved families, said she wanted the immunity covering written evidence and documents lifted completely because there was no need for it. The attorney general said the undertakings to witnesses would hasten the start of the inquiry: "It was certain that without such an undertaking being given, potential witnesses would be inhibited from providing Lord Cullen with full assistance. The public interest clearly favours Lord Cullen undertaking his inquiry as soon, and as quickly, as possible so that lessons can be learnt." After the 1997 Southall rail crash, a public inquiry into the disaster was delayed for two years after a corporate mans-laughter trial was launched, which eventually failed. David Miles, a survivor of the Paddington rail crash, said: "My major concern is that an inquiry is gone into as quickly as possible to try to identify what the causes were of the accident. "But I appreciate that I am somebody who is possibly slightly luckier than an awful lot of other people who have a lot more serious injuries and who therefore may have a much greater desire to see that people are held to account." Police have still not decided if there is a criminal case for any company or individual to answer. They hope to conclude their investigation by the end of March.

fields.headline: Hobnobbing into trouble
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: There is still no official dictionary definition for the word "sleaze", so I suppose we can all have a guess at its meaning. My definition is: "hobnobbing with tycoons".
fields.body:
There is still no official dictionary definition for the word "sleaze", so I suppose we can all have a guess at its meaning. My definition is: "hobnobbing with tycoons".

I'm quite prepared to limit my definition, and any criticism that goes with it, to Labour politicians since hobnobbing with tycoons is obviously part of the Tory way of life. Tories can argue that their policies represent the aspirations of tycoons everywhere and that the only way properly to appreciate how today's tycoons are thinking is to hobnob with them.

For Labour politicians, however, there is this danger. Almost all tycoons have a completely different lifestyle to that of the average Labour voter. The world of Robert Maxwell and Geoffrey Robinson is a million miles away from that inhabited by the enormous majority of the citizens of Dunfermline East. So the Labour MP for Dunfermline East, Gordon Brown, is much more likely to serve his constituents properly if he stays well clear of tycoons like Robert Maxwell and Geoffrey Robinson.

Most people in Dunfermline who hear that their MP has bought a flat from a bankrupt Maxwell company, of which Robinson was once a director, will not even ask whether Robinson knew that Brown was buying the flat, or whether the two cronies ever discussed the matter. It is enough for them that Brown was a close friend of Robinson, that he spent many happy hours in Robinson's luxury accommodation, drank his vintage wine and, as chancellor of the exchequer, insisted that Robinson should become a senior minister at the treasury. A stink emerges from that association and the flat purchase which no official denial can lay to rest.

This seems an elementary lesson, for which there are precedents galore in Labour history. A few months after becoming the first Labour prime minister in 1924, Ramsay MacDonald accepted a Daimler and £40,000 in share certificates from his friend Alexander Grant, a biscuit tycoon. Weeks later, on MacDonald's recommendation, Grant was made a baronet.

MacDonald's biographer David Marquand concluded that there was "nothing discreditable" in this, but the trouble was that the Tory newspapers and thousands of MacDonald's constituents saw the matter rather differently. Before the year was out, the prime minister had to give back the shares and the Daimler. The problem was not in the intent, but in the hobnobbing.

Then there was the sad case of MacDonald's closest ally, the former trade union leader Jimmy Thomas. He hobnobbed with Alfred Cosher Bates, a heavy drinker, hard gambler and millionaire. Bates paid Thomas an enormous advance for a book he hadn't written. Before the budget of 1936, Leslie Thomas, Jimmy's son, took out two huge policies insuring Bates against a rise in income tax. Hey presto! Income tax went up and the insurance policies paid up.

Thomas and Bates had been almost inseparable during the Easter weekend before the budget, and once again people jumped to the conclusion that a crucial budget secret had been leaked. Thomas denied it of course, but a tribunal of inquiry found against him and he was obliged to resign.

The hobnobbing habit persisted after the war. In the summer of 1968, Barbara Castle, secretary of state for transport in the Labour government, fell in with the millionaire restaurateur Charles Forte in the islands off Italy, and they all engaged in what she described as "jaunts".

The following year, 1969, she was first secretary in charge of prices and incomes. In the late spring, she took advantage of Forte's yacht, which he'd lent her. With her and her husband was another secretary of state, Dick Crossman, and his wife. "It really does make life easier," wrote Barbara Castle in her diary, "to have four crew looking after six people! Charles has even sent us Gino from the Cafe Royal to wait on us, which he does day and night, most deftly. I feel uneasy about the whole thing, but no one else - not even Harold - sees any harm in it."

Well, not quite no one. As Tony Howard put it in his otherwise flattering biography of Dick Crossman: "One of the most bizarre episodes of the whole crisis was the holiday the Crossmans and the Castles took together, cruising in the Mediterranean on Charles Forte's yacht a fortnight before the cabinet forced the prime minister and the first secretary to withdraw the industrial relations bill in return for a 'solemn and binding undertaking' from the TUC."

The problem with hobnobbing is that people have an annoying habit of leaping to political conclusions which may not be justified. And as for "Harold" - Harold Wilson, Labour's prime minister - no wonder he saw no harm in the Castle/Crossman Forte holiday. He spent much of his life in the company of tycoons, who never did him any good, usually the opposite.

At any rate, no one could argue that in the business of hobnobbing with tycoons, New Labour has shifted a millimetre away from the habits of Old.

webTitle: More reasons why wage bargaining is still under way

fields.headline: More reasons why wage bargaining is still under way
fields.trailText: There's another very good reason why the minimum wage should be raised which wasn't mentioned in your leader (January 7). Many people forget that the minimum wage matters more to women than any other group. Three-quarters of those who should benefit are women.
fields.body:
There's another very good reason why the minimum wage should be raised which wasn't mentioned in your leader (January 7). Many people forget that the minimum wage matters more to women than any other group. Three-quarters of those who should benefit are women.

Working women - particularly those who are low-paid and work part-time - desperately need a higher legal minimum. The current rate has already had a huge positive impact. Since the introduction of the minimum wage in April 1999, for the first time since the 1970s the hourly pay gap between part-time working women and full-time working men has narrowed significantly.

The government claim to be tackling the gender pay gap. If they don't increase the national minimum wage, it is hard to take this claim seriously. This year the TUC is launching a campaign for fair pay for women. The uprating and effective enforcement of the minimum wage will form a central demand.

Lucy Anderson
Women's Equality Officer, Trades Union Congress
landerson@tuc.org.uk

 As a wealthy country, we should take no pride in having a minimum wage that is already far too low for people to live on without claiming additional benefits.

It is reassuring to hear that the Low Pay Commission has found none of the damaging effects of the minimum wage that its critics had feared. Having successfully introduced the wage at a low level, the opportunity is now there to increase it steadily until it provides a fitting and dignified reward to those prepared to put their time and talents at the disposal of an employer. One would have expected a government which resolutely promotes the value of work to welcome the chance to reward it adequately, rather than place the project on hold.

Dr Alison Elliot
Committee on Church and Nation, Edinburgh

 New Labour is reported to be freezing the minimum wage at £3.60 an hour. Its advisers and aides, by taking salaries of £70,000 a year, are reinforcing inequality. How does all this fit with the prime minister's pledge to abolish poverty and reduce inequality? Come to that, what has it to do with socialism?

Bob Holman
Easterhouse, Glasgow

fields.headline: In flight from romance
fields.trailText: The flight of a 15-year Tibetan monk from China is described as a "romantic story" (Comment, January 10). But what is romantic about an infant taken from his parents to be indoctrinated into the belief that he is the 17th incarnation of some long dead Buddhist saint?
fields.body:
The flight of a 15-year Tibetan monk from China is described as a "romantic story" (Comment, January 10). But what is romantic about an infant taken from his parents to be indoctrinated into the belief that he is the 17th incarnation of some long dead Buddhist saint?

Until only a few decades ago, it was common for Catholic seminaries to accept boys as young as seven, donated by pious parents eager to have a priest in the family. Thankfully, this gross denial of a child's rights was ended when the Church realised they were ordaining young men unwise in the ways of the world. Is the Buddhist practice any less barbaric? Apparently, the 17th Karmapa of the Kagyu sect was talent-spotted by a local abbot impressed by his "fine white clear features" (The boy who outwitted a superpower, January 8). It is not difficult to imagine what might be the reaction of most Guardian readers to a Jesuit superior selecting young men for a seminary on those grounds.

Chinese policies in Tibet are to be condemned, but does this justify the romanticising of what in the west might normally be described as child abuse, justified by an irrational mediaeval superstition?

Michael Carmine
Buckingham, Bucks

fields.headline: Woolly liberals: fur flies
fields.trailText: Jack Straw's simplistic attack (Straw attacks woolly liberals, January 10) is another example of New Labour's strategy for dealing with dissent: silencing it with caricature and insults. The fact is that it was many of these same liberals working alongside local activists and families who campaigned for the Birmingham Six, the Guildford Four and Stephen Lawrence, at a time when judges, police and the vast majority of politicians, in government and opposition, did not want to know the truth and were noticeable only for their silence.
fields.body:
Jack Straw's simplistic attack (Straw attacks woolly liberals, January 10) is another example of New Labour's strategy for dealing with dissent: silencing it with caricature and insults. The fact is that it was many of these same liberals working alongside local activists and families who campaigned for the Birmingham Six, the Guildford Four and Stephen Lawrence, at a time when judges, police and the vast majority of politicians, in government and opposition, did not want to know the truth and were noticeable only for their silence.

To portray liberals and others as simply acting in their own self interest is not only grossly offensive but a misrepresentation of the history of these cases. To compound matters the home secretary accuses liberals of hypocrisy. This is rich coming from one whose profession is hardly a beacon of altruistic virtue.

It is ironic that his remarks were published beside an article about possible immunity for those allegedly responsible for the Paddington rail crash. Perhaps he should be turning his attention to areas where the law still appears to favour rich and powerful individuals and institutions over the poor and powerless. It is possible to have such a debate without idealising or condoning crimes committed by the poor on run down estates. Equal condemnation by the home secretary towards the powerful with respect to their illegal activities might help to convince many of us that there is clear red water between the last government and this one.

Prof Joe Sim
School of Law, Liverpool John Moores University

 Jack Straw does not get the message. In order to defend his latest folly, the abolition of the right to elect for trial by jury, he attacks lawyers for being so conservative that they always resist reforms, woolly minded Hampstead liberals who are soft on criminals, and hard headed magistrates who have ignored his misguided policies by refusing to make curfew orders against 10-year-olds and impracticable anti-social orders.

The well known miscarriages of justice of the 1970s and 1980s arose either from brutality or fraud by the investigating police officers in obtaining alleged confessions, or from incompetence, and worse, in the presentation of scientific findings. The failure to bring the offenders to justice in the Lawrence case arose out of incompetence and institutional racism in the Metropolitan police. If it were not for the persistence of dedicated lawyers, of a liberal caste of mind, ready to challenge the investigation processes of the state at the risk of their own careers, these abuses would have remained hidden.

These scandalous cases resulted in an overhaul of procedures in the crown court, from pre-trial disclosure to judicial control of claims for public interest immunity. The magistrates court, largely white, middle-aged and middle-class, remains unreformed. Trial by jury, by an independent body of people chosen at random from the community, in which there is no discrimination by gender, race, age political opinion, educational background or sexual orientation, undoubtedly remains the safest way of determining guilt or innocence.

Mr Straw must not be allowed to evade the central criticism of his new bill by intemperate attacks upon its critics: the new privilege of trial by jury in all but the most serious cases, is to be reserved for those who can persuade a magistrate that their livelihood will be substantially diminished or their reputation will be seriously damaged by conviction - Rotarians and Masons to the crown court, the underprivileged and weaker members of society to the Beaks.

Lord Thomas of Gresford QC
THOMASM@parliament.uk

 As a Hampstead liberal, I feel honour bound to remind Jack Straw that the wishy-washy electors of Hampstead and Highgate chose to be represented by a Labour MP at the last election, thereby endorsing the well-known New Labour doctrine of being tough on crime and tough on the causes of crime.

Andrew Ross
London

fields.headline: How to beat that bug
fields.trailText: Part of the current NHS "crisis" (Flu: bed shortage row deepens, January 10) is a product of general practitioners' failure to vaccinate those over 65 and those with chronic illnesses who are on their lists. Such vaccination is cost-effective for these groups and there is increasing evidence that it is also cost-effective for NHS staff.
fields.body:
Part of the current NHS "crisis" (Flu: bed shortage row deepens, January 10) is a product of general practitioners' failure to vaccinate those over 65 and those with chronic illnesses who are on their lists. Such vaccination is cost-effective for these groups and there is increasing evidence that it is also cost-effective for NHS staff.

GPs vaccinate less than 50% of those who would benefit. This exposes patients to avoidable mortality and morbidity, causing considerable volumes of hospitalisation.

The health secretary could usefully introduce fees for practice nurses so that they have more incentive to vaccinate and overcome their GP colleagues' lethargy. Mr Milburn might also usefully publish league tables so we can detect which GP practices are lax. Such action is to be preferred to he and his chief medical officer continuing to trust the profession to underperform, thereby damaging patients, filling NHS beds and creating another NHS "crisis".

Such "crises" are usually the product of inefficient use of resources rather than merely funding deficiencies.

Alan Maynard
Professor of Health Economics, University of York
akm3@york.ac.uk

 I too would like to see the NHS become more "consumer-sensitive" (Leader, January 8); you rightly point out that a patient taking time off work, and then waiting hours for a doctor's appointment, is something that would be deemed unacceptable in other areas of life.

However, profitable private-sector companies, with well-paid, well-motivated workers, seem better equipped to meet the demands of a 24-hour consumer society than an under-resourced public sector organisation staffed by workers suffering from low morale, poor pay and difficult working conditions.

Incidentally, I recently took a morning off from work to wait for a gas engineer to sort out a heating problem; I was told he could arrive at any time from 8am to 1pm. Instead of seeing patients, I wasted several hours waiting for an engineer who failed to arrive. Is that an example of consumer sensitivity?

Dr N Sharma
Ilford, Essex

 What better way to relaunch the Dome than to turn the whole area into a Health Zone filled with emergency beds?

John Davidson
London

 Surely it would be in the spirit of the private finance initiative to commandeer beds from private hospitals until the flu epidemic is over.

Peter Bowker
London
P.Bowker@btinternet.com

fields.headline: Take your partners
fields.trailText: Sam de Vinci (Letters, January 10) should not despair at no longer finding hundreds of beautiful girls waiting to dance with him at the Hammersmith Palais. Lindy Hop, the dance from the 20s, now has a big following and there are several venues in London where he will find plenty of beautiful girls wanting to dance with him to the tunes of the dance band days. If he went to the 100 Club on Monday night with the London Swing Dance Society, he would not have to ask girls for dances, they would ask him - even if, like me, he is old enough to remember the Hammersmith Palais dances.

fields.headline: Making food safer
fields.standfirst:
Brussels can bring little to the party

What's wrong with our food? - special report
fields.trailText: The new European food safety agency to be unveiled in Brussels today is a sideshow, perhaps even an irrelevance. It will not be up and running for years - and the commission's litigation against the French over British beef may hold things up. What is proposed is an advisory body without executive powers. Yet the limits of Euro-opinionating on food safety have been shown by the fate of the EU's scientific steering committee.
fields.body:
The new European food safety agency to be unveiled in Brussels today is a sideshow, perhaps even an irrelevance. It will not be up and running for years - and the commission's litigation against the French over British beef may hold things up. What is proposed is an advisory body without executive powers. Yet the limits of Euro-opinionating on food safety have been shown by the fate of the EU's scientific steering committee. Its approval of renewed British beef sales was rejected by the French food agency (with some justification). Its chilling report on the EU-wide risk of human exposure to BSE, released last week, is being ignored by precisely those to whom it should be the most urgent reading - the countries which have so piously proclaimed themselves 100% BSE-free.

The agency has missed the boat because, in the wake of Seattle, there is churning ambivalence in all our countries about where to set the boundary between tradition, culture, the safety of citizens and freedom of trade and enterprise; not only the effectiveness but the legitimacy of international organisations is under review. For example: Germans eat lots of Kochmettwürst, one of the infinite variety of sausage enjoyed east of the Rhine. It is made with cattle brain. But given what we know - and don't - EU scientists say an elementary precaution is to exclude all "specific risk material" (head, spinal cord, spleen etc) from the human food chain. What would it take for a European institution to convince - let alone compel - Germans or Greeks or Danes, Finns and Swedes to agree with Brussels on the riskiness of their cattle? The answer is more political will than Europe looks likely to muster for a long time.

Of course there should be coordination at European level but it is not at all clear Brussels can or should go beyond existing treaty commitments on minimising obstacles to trade. Safer food depends on microscopic local attention to the detail of how animals are raised, transported, slaughtered and processed. One thing the British experience shows, thanks to the incidence of BSE here, is how vital is a reliable national apparatus of inspection, monitoring and research, and how hard it is - witness the snail's pace at which our food standards agency is being prised from the bureaucratic clutches of the ministry of agriculture - to tilt the nutritional balance away from the interests of food producers.

fields.headline: Syrian talks with Israel adjourned
fields.trailText: The American-sponsored peace talks between Syria and Israel will resume next week after a break during which the two governments will test domestic reactions to a "working document" drafted by the US.
fields.body:
The American-sponsored peace talks between Syria and Israel will resume next week after a break during which the two governments will test domestic reactions to a "working document" drafted by the US.

The latest phase of talks at Shepherdstown in West Virginia, came to an end yesterday with the announcement of "a short recess" and President Bill Clinton warning of "a time of great tension".

The US state department said that Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, and the Syrian foreign minister, Farouk al-Shara'a, would be returning on January 19 "to continue the negotiations and work further towards a peace agreement".

Mr Barak left Shepherdstown yesterday morning. Mr Shara'a was expected to leave soon after.

Mr Clinton, who joined the talks on five occasions in the course of six days, was characteristically upbeat about progress when he addressed Muslim Americans at a White House ceremony to mark the end of the holy month of Ramadan.

"These people really talked about the substance of their differences for the first time," he said. "They were very open. They were very candid. They broke a lot of new ground."

But Israel's foreign minister, David Levy, said as he left Shepherdstown: "We did not reach agreement. We did not even get near.

"We began a discussion. I believe it will continue. The sides will make efforts, with a consciousness that peace will serve both sides and the entire region."

A source close to the Syrian delegation told the Associated Press that the current round of talks had not succeeded in its aim of winning an Israeli commitment to withdraw to its pre-1967 border with Syria - the issue which is at the heart of the current diplomatic effort. Martin Kettle, Washington

fields.headline: Flat charges
fields.standfirst:
Tories need more evidence to nail Brown

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Opposition MPs are going to need more evidence before they can make a sleaze rap stick on Gordon Brown. Following an article in the Sunday Times, the chancellor stands accused of buying a Westminster flat for £130,000 in 1992 from administrators involved in a distress sale of the assets of a Maxwell company, AGB, of which Geoffrey Robinson had been a director (though he had resigned two years earlier). According to the Sunday Times, local estate agents believe the sale was made at a discount of up to £30,000 on the market price. But the same article admits that the property market was depressed in 1992 and that assets in administration "almost always sell at knocked-down prices".
fields.body:
Opposition MPs are going to need more evidence before they can make a sleaze rap stick on Gordon Brown. Following an article in the Sunday Times, the chancellor stands accused of buying a Westminster flat for £130,000 in 1992 from administrators involved in a distress sale of the assets of a Maxwell company, AGB, of which Geoffrey Robinson had been a director (though he had resigned two years earlier). According to the Sunday Times, local estate agents believe the sale was made at a discount of up to £30,000 on the market price. But the same article admits that the property market was depressed in 1992 and that assets in administration "almost always sell at knocked-down prices".

The administrators, Arthur Andersen (who were bound to seek the highest price), claim that the apartment - in Great Smith Street, Westminster, a short walk from Downing Street - had been on the open market for a year and that more than one offer had been made. So what's the problem? Even if Geoffrey Robinson had tipped off Mr Brown or one of his two brothers (who had been involved in the sale) about it - of which there is not yet evidence - it would hardly rank as a capital offence to draw to someone's attention a property that had been unsold for a year. There is doubt among Tory MPs how Mr Brown raised £100,000 to finance the bulk of the purchase after a £30,000 mortgage. But he sold at least one other flat (a bigger one in Kennington) so the financing gap, other things being equal, was not so large that he would have needed to borrow heavily from someone else.

Maybe all the facts haven't come out yet. Maybe he should have been wary of any Maxwell connection. But to make this one stick on a man with an unblemished ethical record will need more evidence. Meanwhile, all that has come out of this mud slinging is that the chancellor of the exchequer is shrewd with money. But we knew that anyway.

fields.headline: Action with added value
fields.standfirst: Being part of an education action zone has helped transform one Leicester school.  Stephen Hoare  discovers how
fields.trailText: Being part of an education action zone has helped transform one Leicester school. Stephen Hoare discovers how
fields.body:
It is shortly before the start of afternoon lessons at Rowley Fields Community College, Leicester, and two teachers are discussing a strategy that seems to be improving the concentration and confidence of their next class - set three, year 8 maths. Sarah Randerson and Meena Lyall will be organising pupils to work in groups to play maths games that reinforce basic numeracy.

Pupil groupings have been established in two previous lessons by team-building exercises. Ten children in this class have special needs and many have English as a second language, but now pupils are starting to communicate and support one another. The class comes in, the maths games come out, and the groups work together using laminated number wheels, bingo cards and dice to work out number combinations that can be added, subtracted or divided to arrive at a target number. Randerson and Lyall move between the groups, advising and encouraging.

Trying new ideas makes a lot of demands on the class teachers. In Randerson's set three class it is the two teachers who have to communicate clear instructions, pick up on individuals having problems, yet manage to keep the pace of the lesson moving and the whole class on task. Lyall's support has encouraged the school to try out new approaches such as team teaching, and she can help by leading discussions on improvement and covering lessons to release staff for training.

Randerson says: "The big problem we have is children's lack of understanding the language of maths. Working in groups forces them to communicate, and hearing the relevant words helps them." Lyall says: "We've made our own resources. When you have two teachers working together it's a lot easier to develop and try out ideas."

This approach to maths may not be revolutionary, but in terms of the school's recent past it is a breakthrough. Two years ago, Rowley Fields failed its Ofsted, was put into special measures and threatened with closure. Today the school is out of special measures, and is part of the Leicester South and West education action zone (EAZ).

As part of its target for school improvement, the EAZ recruited a group of experienced teachers to promote best practice among the zone's two secondary schools, 12 primaries and two special schools - many of which, like Rowley Fields, were failing. Lyall is a member of the best practice support team; Randerson is head of maths.

The initiative relies on money raised from the local business community, which has a vested interest in raising standards in schools. Faced with continued opposition from some quarters, EAZs cannot be lumped together, and individually they respond to local needs.

Leicester has a particular problem: with declining numbers of school-age children, more than half the city's secondary schools will have to merge or close. The city council set up the EAZ to cushion the blow and channel resources to where they are most needed.

Rowley Fields is surviving. Two nearby secondaries, Wycliffe and Mary Linwood, are closing and their pupils are being transferred to boost Rowley's roll from 600 to 900. EAZ investment and the support team will be helping to ease the transition.

Headteacher Bernard Barker, parachuted in by the local authority to spearhead the steep climb out of special measures, is grateful for the extra funding that comes with being part of an EAZ. But he maintains that the school was well on the road to coming out of special measures before the EAZ came into being last April.

"An EAZ makes very big demands on the organisation through more meetings, more interaction, more new ideas. What the school needed was good leadership. The teachers were all signed up to improvement. If we were still failing then, the support team would not have worked."

With A-Cs on an upward trend, Barker is having no truck with performance-related pay or punitive target-setting - the school has set its own realistic goals for improvement. "Performance-related pay is the one thing that any group of teachers will bitterly oppose. It is incompatible with a team approach. Our targets are modest and based on what we think we can achieve."

Barker's mission is to empower, and BBC's drama about a failing school, Hope and Glory, was favourite Tuesday night viewing. "The teachers watched Lenny Henry, and for some it brings tears to their eyes when they think of what our school used to be like."

Working in teams, the EAZ's support staff will help schools carry forward their teaching and learning-action plans. Most support team members are on two-year contracts. In the zone's primary schools, two teams will have a similar role, usually for one or two terms before moving on.

At Rowley Fields, Lyall's team includes James Humphries and Isobel Gravett, who cover English and humanities. James says: "We're organising a series of conferences on promoting the positive, accelerated learning and networking sessions for the teachers. Local schools have been set up to compete with each other - we're changing that and reintroducing support networks."

Best practice support is not about weeding out failing teachers, as the pairing between two extremely competent teachers - Meena Lyall and Sarah Randerson - shows. It is about giving encouragement, feedback and the chance to put ideas to the test - professional development in the classroom.

"This is the chance for teachers to plan as part of a team," says Lyall, "to develop new strategies and take a fresh look at what they are doing."

While teachers are weary of inspection - Rowley Fields has had termly visits from Her Majesty's Inspectorate since being put into special measures - the support team emphasises the positive and builds on teachers' strengths so that they will become confident.

And the staff welcome a fresh pair of eyes. Humphries says: "The typical experience of teachers is that people come in and make a judgment that is reported to them. No one tells them when they are doing well or helps them move on."

 Education Action Zones - where are they? www.dfee.gov.uk/eaz

fields.headline: Nothing beats a big Mac
fields.standfirst: Witchcraft, power politics, tragedy - Shakespeare's Macbeth has it all, writes  Jerome Monahan
fields.trailText: Witchcraft, power politics, tragedy - Shakespeare's Macbeth has it all, writes Jerome Monahan
fields.body:
Macbeth has always been a great crowd-pleaser, and yet it has a reputation for bad luck and its name must never be pronounced inside a theatre.

Ironically, one theory for all this suggests the reason lies in the play's historic popularity with audiences. This was the show that theatre companies might have in their repertoire in case of emergency: if interest in Hamlet was flagging, there was always Macbeth to dust off as a good box office draw.

Despite its short length, Macbeth contains a substantial amount of on-stage violence. If under-rehearsed, it is not hard to imagine that accidents would occur, and so the play's reputation for attracting the unhealthy attentions of evil forces from some dark beyond grew.

No one is quite sure when Macbeth was first performed. There is evidence that it was first performed on stage in 1611, but legend has it that it was acted for King James I at Hampton Court at least five years earlier.

There was plenty in the play to keep the king absorbed. James was fascinated by witchcraft. He spent much of his reign convinced that he was the target of a Satanic conspiracy and removed his greatest political rival in Scotland, the Earl of Bothwell, by accusing him of plotting his downfall with some North Berwick witches. James even attended the torture and prosecution of the arrested coven members. In 1597, he published the book Demonology, which summed up his thinking on the subject.

Macbeth is about many things. Read as a tragedy, it is an examination of a man who suffers from "vaulting ambition", anticipates the dangers and misery that may flow from his ruthless pursuit of power and yet pursues it all the same.

His flaw is to believe that he is beyond the reach of fate, while his defiance in the face of disaster restores his heroic status. Like the previous Thane of Cawdor, "Nothing in his life becomes him like the leaving of it."

Other critics see the play as a study in politics. Strip away the mystifying magic and ghosts, and you are left with a stark object lesson in the practicalities of power.

This "reading against the grain" places emphasis on the weakness of King Duncan, beset by enemies at the start of the play and relying on brutal warlords such as Macbeth to preserve him on the throne. Once Macbeth takes the crown, we witness the corrupting influence of absolute power and the fears that attend those who wield it.

In an extraordinary moment in the banquet scene, the realities of Macbeth's rule are laid bare. He greets his guests: "Be large in mirth, anon we'll drink a measure/ The table round." Immediately, he turns to a murderer: "There's blood upon thy face." In two juxtaposed lines the public relations of power give way to the ruthlessness that underpins tyranny.

Your unavoidable fate is that Macbeth is on the syllabus at key stage 3. There is nothing like thinking of a play as a SATs set text for draining it of its mystery. But look beyond this if you can. The scenes you will be studying in depth spotlight the process a person must go through to commit premeditated murder (Act 1 Scenes 6 and 7) and the macabre horrors of witchcraft and prediction that drive him to greater excesses (Act 4 Scene1).

It is a fascinating journey and it may colour your judgment of politicians forever.

Macbeth the movie

There are a number of film versions of Macbeth that will help give you a sense of the play in performance.

Orson Welles' 1948 Macbeth: high on shadow and spoken in strange Scots accents, the film was made in 21 days on sets made from papier maché.

Joe Macbeth (1955): a British-made gangster version that required actors such as Sid James (of Carry On fame) to speak in an American accent. "Intriguing", to damn it with faint praise.

Akira Kurosawa's Throne of Blood: don't let the fact that it is black and white and in Japanese put you off. It is visually stunning. The final sequence in which wave upon wave of arrows pepper the king is extraordinary.

Roman Polanski's Macbeth (1972): gory and brutal. Apart from a number of decapitations and hangings, it also features an early performance of Keith Chegwin as Banquo's son Fleance. Surely, on the strength of that alone the British Board Of Film Classification should consider revising the certificate down to PG?

 Jerome Monahan is currently working on an education pack for Film Education and the British Film Institute on film versions of Macbeth.

fields.trailText: What should newly qualified teachers expect from job interviews?
fields.body:
Wanted: creative, imaginative, knowledgeable, thorough, committed, tireless, lively, efficient, caring, insightful person for the most important job on the planet.

Obviously, they want a teacher.

Over the next nine months, thousands of teaching jobs will be filled by newly qualified teachers. You've read the job specification, looked at the school details, no doubt read the school's Ofsted report on the internet, and sent off an application. You've been called for interview. What can you expect, and what are schools looking for?

Selection procedures normally last a day, and although the formal interview takes place in the afternoon, there is no "dead time": judgments are being made from the moment you arrive - and you need to be punctual.

Susan Orlik, Head of Langley School, a Solihull comprehensive, is clear that appearance matters: "Candidates need to project a professional image - no dangly earrings, or plunging cleavages and no blokes who look like night-club bouncers."

There will be a tour of the school, often given by pupils. In some schools a pupil panel meets candidates formally.

There'll be time, too, in the staff room or department with your prospective colleagues. Suzanne Brown, head at Queens' Junior School in Nuneaton, says this is important: "We want to see how they behave with staff, whether they can ask questions which will make them good team members, whether they make eye contact, talk openly."

Increasingly, heads want to see evidence of what prospective teachers can do. Lois Thorpe, of Cubbington Primary School in Leamington, asks candidates to bring something from their classroom. "Often," she says, "they bring children's work - I want to see how it is marked, to see whether they treat their pupils with respect."

One candidate brought along a class book based on the Ahlbergs' Jolly Postman: "Every pupil in the class had work in the book, and it spoke volumes about her practice and commitment." She got the job.

Susan Orlik has always asked music, art and technology teachers to bring a portfolio of work; now she asks all student teachers to bring in their professional development portfolio. Val Brooks, who developed Warwick University's portfolio, agrees: "It's one source of evidence of the quality of their work."

Most candidates are asked to teach. Roger Whittall, Head of Alderman Callow Community School in Coventry, explains: "If you're going to appoint someone who'll teach 80% of the week, you can't appoint without it." He insists candidates are observed by the head of department and a parent governor: "I want to know from the parent governor how they think their child would respond in that lesson."

Martin Roberts, of Cherwell School in Oxford, also insists on teaching as a part of the selection procedures. The school selects a topic: "We're looking for the language they use, their feel for the subject and the age range, the way that they respond to pupils." Formal interviews normally take place after lunch, and will involve the headteacher and a governor, together with the head of department, deputy head or phase co-ordinator. You can expect to be asked about how you might handle critical incidents, how you would meet individual needs, about the implications of current developments.

Peter Rossborough, head at Ashlawn School, a large comprehensive in Rugby, looks for a focus on learning: "There are a lot of candidates who are committed to their subject and who enjoy working with pupils in classrooms, and they're both important, but the key thing is whether they show they understand that most kids want to achieve, and whether they can focus on ensuring that every pupil does achieve."

Other personal qualities matter too. Says Susan Orlik: "I want music teachers who play and compose, English teachers who write, history teachers who enjoy tramping about castles. I want people who understand that their job is to enrich the experience of every pupil they teach."

And if, in the end, you don't get the job, ask for a debrief and use it to learn for next time.

fields.headline: Remember this?
fields.standfirst: The quiz-style feedback used in Strathclyde lectures is just the tip of an iceberg of increasingly electronic interaction between teachers and students, writes  Simon Midgley
fields.trailText: The quiz-style feedback used in Strathclyde lectures is just the tip of an iceberg of increasingly electronic interaction between teachers and students, writes Simon Midgley
fields.body:
Strathclyde students pressing buttons to tell their lecturer whether they have understood what they are being taught are the latest recipients of the new technologies revolutionising teaching and learning in British universities. Everyone agrees things will never be the same - but academics are passionately divided on how the new tools should be used.

How far should computers be used in teaching and exams - easing the marking burden on lecturers as numbers expand - or should they be used purely as creative tools for students? At Strathclyde University in Glasgow, lecturers in the mechanical engineering department ask questions as they go along. Students select an answer from several displayed on a large overhead screen using infrared handsets. If most get the wrong answer, the lecturer will go over the topic again.

Professor Sally Brown, director of membership services at the Institute for Learning and Teaching in Higher Education in York, said that the use of information technology to support student assessment has enormous potential, particularly in removing repetition and drudgery from marking.

Computer-aided assessment - whereby students are quizzed on their level of knowledge on screen by multiple choice and other forms of questioning - is used frequently in the first year of undergraduate courses, and is now deployed in virtually every academic discipline.

Such assessments can be formative, in that they help students to improve their understanding, or summative, when they involve marking that counts towards a degree. Last year a survey by the Computer-Assisted Assessment Centre at Luton University found that more than 80 universities and colleges of higher education use such assessment in one form or another. Of these 42, were "old" universities and 30 "new" universities. Such assessments are used mostly in computing, sciences and mathematics, but are also found in social science and the humanities.

In 1998-99, students at Luton University took more than 10,000 summative assessments and 3,000 formative assessments. They were assessed in accounting, economics, leisure, travel and tourism, design, material sciences, biology, computing, mathematics, social sciences, midwifery, psychology, media, languages, law and history.

Brown, who recently co-edited a book on assessment, says the best form of formative assessment would tell students why they got an answer wrong and then give them the chance to answer a parallel question. In this way assessment could be used both for checking knowledge and as a teaching tool.

Professor Stephen Heppell, director of Anglia Polytechnic University's Ultra Lab, Europe's leading learning and technology research centre, says computers could be used as superb creative tools or wasted as ineffective teaching machines. There was very little evidence that multiple-choice question testing on screen was effective. Financial pressures on the academic world, however, meant that such tests were attractive to some universities who see it as an inexpensive way of testing large numbers of students. They were often deployed in law or engineering faculties.

Heppell says: "I cannot imagine anything less engaging or less representative of what higher education ought to be about. Higher education should be about discourse, debate, critical awareness, understanding and problem solving. These things [the tests] are just about achieving a score."

Computers could be superb creative tools for designs and art work in such disciplines as music, fine art, architecture and multimedia studies, he said.

Rhonda Riachi, of Oxford Brookes University, director of the Association for Learning Technology, which has 70 higher education institutional members, said websites were now being used as virtual classrooms.

"Students can log in to see their exam results on line, get timetables, communicate with their lecturers directly via e-mail, look at their assignments, download files put there by tutors and participate in conversations with other students in chat rooms." Quiet students tended to participate better in virtual seminars.

"And universities that are not going down this route and don't have plenty of e-mail terminals or internet points will find that they are out of favour with a certain body of students who expect this sort of thing to be provided."

 Computer-Assisted Assessment in Higher Education, ed Sally Brown, Phil Race and Joanna Bull, is published by Kogan Page at £18.99.

fields.headline: Back on the treadmill
fields.standfirst: Academics are in revolt against the quality assurance agency
fields.trailText: Academics are in revolt against the quality assurance agency
fields.body:
A proposed new inspection system for teaching at British universities will divert academics into pointless and time-consuming paper trails, universities will protest to ministers. The Quality Assurance Agency has failed to deliver the promised "lighter touch" in the next round of teaching quality assessments due to start in September, they claim.

Despite a rearguard action by universities jealous to protect their academic autonomy, the government has insisted on national assessments of teaching quality that will allow students to make simple comparisons when choosing courses. The Committee of Vice-Chancellors and Principals has finally conceded that teaching and other aspects of courses will be labelled "commendable", "approved" or "failing", but members are furious at the amount of paperwork that they believe their staff will still have to produce.

University College, London, is leading an academic revolt against the new plans.

"We disagree with the entire proposed system as it is envisaged, and we are not willing to endorse any of the plans," said Professor Michael Worton, UCL's vice-provost. "For all the all emphasis on outcomes and qualifications, there is no let up on the remorseless concentration on process and paper trails. The key issue of the quality of student experience is being overlooked."

A compromise between academic leaders and government officials was signalled last week when a new grading system for teaching quality inspections of university departments was unveiled by the agency.

Universities had strongly opposed earlier government proposals to identify the top 5% of assessed departments as beacon teaching departments. Currently half the departments assessed are classed as excellent and Dai Jones, vice-chancellor of Luton University, pointed out that the beacon proposals would suggest to overseas applicants that quality had fallen and most provision was mediocre.

Instead inspectors will now publish three assessments - commendable, approved or failing - in relation to three topics, teaching and learning, student progression, and effective use of learning resources, with some best performers occasionally highlighted.

But the central gripe from academics is that the agency has failed to introduce the "lighter touch" it promised for the new teaching inspection procedures as whole. Teaching assessments have fast developed into one of the least popular aspects of academic life, consuming time and resources for little financial reward.

"We are fully supportive of independent assessment of teaching quality, but one which is much less intrusive to institutions than current arrangements. It is not clear whether the new proposals will achieve the objective," said Dr Geoffrey Copland, vice-chancellor of Westminster University, and the current convener of the Coalition of Modern Universities, which brings together the heads of the former polytechnics.

"We want to see these schemes simplified, made more straightforward and a lighter touch applied," said Sir Alec Broers, vice-chancellor of Cambridge University.

The agency's chief executive, John Randall, denied the accusations, arguing that the new inspection system would do away with much of the bureacracy associated with current department assessments. "One of the things institutions see as the icon that represent heavy touch is what they call the base room, where they assemble all the documentation that the reviewers could conceivably look at," he said. "That will be a thing of the past. We are trying to work with institutions' own systems; that is what is going to give the major reduction in burden."

 Lee Elliot Major is deputy editor of Research Fortnight.

webTitle: Cutting down debt in the antipodes?

fields.headline: Cutting down debt in the antipodes?
fields.standfirst: David Cohen reports from New Zealand, whose new prime minister has a promise to live up to
fields.trailText: David Cohen reports from New Zealand, whose new prime minister has a promise to live up to
fields.body:
A new centre-left government in New Zealand has said that it will bring to a halt many of the country's higher education reforms of the past decade. It has also promised a more academic-friendly style in its national leadership.

In particular, the recently elected Labour Party-led coalition of Prime Minister Helen Clark has indicated its willingness to re-examine the contentious issue of the country's eight universities and their students shouldering an increasing amount of the cost of post-secondary tuition.

The new government did not envisage a complete return to the situation in the past where New Zealand students - there are currently 247,368 - were not required to pay any fees at all for most full-time courses of study. But the Labour Party was determined to bring a new focus to what Associate Education Minister Steve Maharey called "the long-term strategic direction of the tertiary sector".

That direction will merit some attention in Britain, where many of the recommendations of the bipartisan Dearing commission were made with the New Zealand experience in mind. Free post- secondary education used to be as much an underlying assumption in New Zealand life as it once was in Britain. But the tradition ended in 1990 when, at the behest of a conservative National Party government, institutions of higher learning were for the first time required to raise up to 30% of their operating costs through tuition fees.

University students in New Zealand are expected to pay about the same amount for tuition as their counterparts in Britain, usually around £1,000 each year. The obligation is roughly similar to the cost also faced by new students in nearby Australia under the Higher Education Contribution Scheme.

For about half of New Zealand's students, money for tuition - along with living costs and money for course materials - is raised through a government-guaranteed loan scheme with repayments administered by the country's Inland Revenue Service.

The local tax-gatherers, at least, ought to be happy: the country's national student debt level is projected to quadruple in size over the next two decades, from one thousand million pounds today to four thousand million. With some justification, perhaps, supporters of the user-pays ethos can point to the nation's surging university rolls, even among lower-income students, as proof of the scheme's success.

But the scheme continues to be widely unpopular both in its own right - at least among many students and educators - as well as on account of their beneficiaries being expected to pay interest rates above the usual market rate, starting from the day in which the loan is taken out.

In practical terms, the last has meant, for example, a typical £22,000 loan, taken by a medical student embarking on a five-year degree course - the country's most expensive - becoming more than £30,000 by the time of its recipient's graduation. The issue became a flashpoint during the recent election campaign with students, many of them brandishing placards and hard-luck stories, staging daily demonstrations against the conservative government.

On one memorable occasion, the minister previously in charge of tertiary education, Max Bradford, came close to being roughed up by a young protester at the University of Canterbury, in the southern city of Christchurch.

Apparently making good on a major campaign pledge, the Labour Party and its left-wing parliamentary allies passed new legislation in late December to end interest rates being levied on loans for full-time and low-income students during the course of their study. The change will be effective from early 2000.

Will it be enough? Recent net immigration figures show New Zealand to be nearing a state of intellectual haemorrhage - losing thousands of the kinds of tertiary-trained young people that more dynamic countries trawl the world for. Australia is the prime beneficiary of the outflow, but nearly a quarter of the departees in 1999 were bound for Britain, according to government statistics.

On the face of it, the new government appears to be in a good position to tackle the problem. Nearly one-third of the Labour Party's new cabinet ministers, including the Blairite Clark, a one-time political scientist from the University of Auckland, come from backgrounds as university lecturers.

Clark's deputy, British-born Michael Cullen, enjoys the distinction of being the only New Zealand finance minister ever to hold a PhD.

But exactly how these MPs will halt, and reverse, the trends they spent years in opposition deploring remains to be seen. Whatever the outcome, New Zealand politics has probably left behind forever the era in which a former prime minister, Keith Holyoake, once startled a British high commissioner when he declared with pride that he was no intellectual, was not well educated, had left school at 14 and had never been near a university.

 New Zealand's education ministry
