fields.headline: Priestly classes
fields.standfirst: In the Gormenghast-like halls of Ushaw College, Father Jim O'Keefe guides would-be priests towards their vocation
fields.trailText: In the Gormenghast-like halls of Ushaw College, Father Jim O'Keefe guides would-be priests towards their vocation
fields.body:
For the first time in over a decade, every seminary in England and Wales has seen an increase in men coming forward to train for the priesthood. Ushaw College, a seminary five miles outside Durham, has seen its numbers double this year.

But before we start to see signs of a religious resurgence at the dawn of a new millennium, let's be clear about the figures. For the whole country we're talking of no more than 280 new trainees, far too few to stem the critical shortfall in priests. At Ushaw we're talking of 13 new entrants, as opposed to six the year before. They are still rattling around a seminary built for 400.

What can be the role of a celibate male priesthood in an age which has seen the triumph of secularism in Western democracies and left the Church in crisis, ripped apart by sexual scandal among its ordained, and with increasing non-attendance by its laity? With a marked lack of fresh papal guidance on the subject for nearly a decade, this is the question that those responsible for the training of priests have to ask themselves over and over again.

Father Jim O'Keefe, the president of Ushaw, feels constantly challenged on this subject, and as the recipient of many personal letters from priests over the years, is well aware of the difficulties they face. The annual gathering of the St Cuthbert's Society, an old boys' reunion, is open to all former seminarians, even those lost from the fold. On the last occasion, O'Keefe spent the last night in the bar with three former students - all were ordained as priests but left to marry. The reunion, he believes, must be about openness and reconciliation if it is to have any purpose.

For Ushaw, like most seminaries, is in the throes of transformation. Tucked away on a wooded estate overlooking County Durham, it is a vast, rambling stone building that opens out endlessly into great halls, refectories, Pugin chapels, long corridors and inner courtyards, the nearest thing to Mervyn Peake's Gormenghast. Awesome in its scale, it was built in 1808 as a statement of the Church's mission, an act of confidence and aspiration decades before full Catholic Emancipation.

In the late 1950s, when Jim O'Keefe arrived as a boy, there were 400 seminarians from as young as 11. Now there are 30, none under 21, many in their late 20s and 30s and some approaching 50. This September may have seen modest increases, but last year saw the lowest intake of seminarians in England and Wales for nearly 150 years.

The late Cardinal Basil Hume has been praised for helping to accommodate Catholicism within the British establishment as well as speaking out for the socially excluded and sexually marginalised, but the problem of attracting ordinands remains intractable.

During Hume's term of office, numbers coming forward for the priesthood continued to fall. Sexual scandal has rocked Catholicism in Britain and Ireland and men committed to celibacy are seen as odd, if not suspect. The priest is no longer on a pedestal, and can be despised. Father Jim Overton, a former chaplain of London University, was appointed by Basil Hume to Allen Hall, a seminary in Westminster, a year before the Cardinal's death. He does not underestimate the challenge: "It's a big task and there are very few answers. What the heck the priesthood will be like in five years' time, never mind ten, I just don't know."

At the end of his course each student had his own library of handwritten treatises to take home. At their reunion former students joked about the ruses they would devise to escape the college confines. One described how, having fallen in love with the dentist's receptionist in Durham, he persuaded her to give him a pile of blank appointment cards, which he would fill in and present to the college rector at credible intervals.

A core academic curriculum remains - biblical studies, systemic theology, patristics, philosophy and religion, the study of New Testament Greek and elementary Hebrew. But the emphasis is just as much on spiritual and human development.

Students are just as likely to take courses on personal growth and pastoral care in which they focus on self-awareness and the development issues affecting childhood through to old age and on pastoral issues such as stress and depression. They are as likely to take a course in death and dying or on sexuality, gender and Christian ministry in which they will explore issues such as celibacy, singleness, homosexuality and intimacy.

He was ordained in 1972 and went to work in the north-east, where he also become religious programmes producer for local radio. He came back to Ushaw in 1977 to run its pastoral theology and communications department. Today he is rector to a body of students from very different backgrounds from his own, many of whom have worked and owned property, or gone through a period of being alienated from the Church. Current seminarians include a former driving instructor, a prison visitor and an engineer, a computer programmer, a young man with a law degree, a former member of the merchant navy, a teacher, a gardener and a supermarket worker.

Having women living at Ushaw and sharing seminars is seen as an important part of the seminarians' learning process. In addition, 16,000 visitors passed through the college's conference centre last year. CAFOD now has its regional headquarters at Ushaw, which also houses the Marian Studies Centre.

He is only too aware of the hardships they must be prepared to face. In the mid-1990s, he was a key member of the working party to the Catholic Bishops Conference of England and Wales on cases where the sexual abuse of children involved priests. He also receives letters from priests, particularly on the challenge of celibacy. One priest of 29 years wrote that celibacy had been a "crucifying experience" and "the greatest hindrance to my ministry... O'Keefe takes this type of plea seriously. Human development and self-awareness have moved to centre-stage of the curriculum. "Personal maturity is fundamental to a priest. In the past, training for priesthood was about learning to keep the rules. Now it's about being mature, about being compassionate and having the capacity for friendship and intimacy as well as leadership."

He believes that celibacy should be a choice, rather than compulsory, but he is very sure about the important role a celibate priest can play in contemporary society. Not only should the priest of the future be there to contemplate and reflect on God and society in a "very busy, relationship-oriented world", but the celibate bears witness to the fact that being a normal being "does not have to be justified by sexual activity. They can witness to the loneliness that even the sexually active experience, that is there in the lives of everybody".

However, both he and Jim Overton are aware of the responsibility facing them as educators. "Above all," says Overton, "we do not want a man not to know what he is entering into."

fields.headline: Craft work
fields.standfirst: Chris Husbands finds that PGCE students are exhausted - but they are also transformed by the course
fields.trailText: Chris Husbands finds that PGCE students are exhausted - but they are also transformed by the course
fields.body:
Lucy Edwards has just finished the first term of her PGCE: she's 15 weeks into a 35-week course which will launch her career as a secondary school teacher. And she's never been more grateful for her Christmas break.

Although she came to her PGCE course with a good degree and a masters in science, and four years in industry, she doesn't think she has ever had to work as hard, at so many different things, as in the past 15 weeks.

In her first term, she has had to come to grips with the science national curriculum, to develop her own IT skills so she can use computers in teaching, and to plan and teach science lessons to pupils ranging from those who appear brighter than she felt at 14 to those who have severe difficulties with concentration, reading and writing.

It's been a tough term. And she's loved it. In spite of her exhaustion, she knows that the opportunities to think about her subject in new ways, to unpack her understandings for youngsters, and see the impact good lessons can have on even reluctant learners have made her decision to teach worthwhile.

Few areas of education have changed more in the past decade than initial teacher training. Lucy's PGCE, like all others, is governed by tight national guidelines. These set out, for example, the number of days trainees must spend in schools during their course (90 for primary PGCE trainees, 120 for secondary trainees), the content their course must cover, and over 80 separate standards which trainees must meet to earn qualified teacher status (QTS).

The standards set out not just a knowledge base, but also classroom teaching requirements which ensure all new teachers can set learning objectives, manage pupil behaviour and maintain motivation and enthusiasm.

Other standards demand not only that trainees mark pupils' work regularly and provide feedback, but also recognise the level a pupil is achieving and understand how comparative test data can be used to set targets for pupils' achievement. It's a long list, and most trainees are daunted at first. But it is also a reminder that teaching demands high-level skills and, importantly, it is a list which demystifies the process of assessment.

Courses are planned jointly by university tutors and school-based mentors. More than 95% of PGCE courses are run by partnerships between universities and schools. Partnerships vary hugely in the way responsibilities are shared between the partners, but a common feature is that training takes place in university and school.

Time in schools is now about far more than teaching practice. In partnerships, schools have planned systematic programmes of school-based training which dovetail with university programmes.

At Lutterworth Community College, an 1,800-pupil comprehensive which works in partnership with Warwick, Leicester and Loughborough universities, Vicky Bishop has planned a programme to help trainees understand how the school is organised and how it provides for pupils with special needs and for very able pupils. There are seminars on teaching, and a weekly review session with a mentor to monitor progress.

To give trainees the best chance of meeting the standards by the end of their training, most partnerships have established some sort of competence portfolio, which records progress against the standards and provides early evidence of success.

In the Warwick University Partnership, all trainees maintain a Professional Development Profile (PDP). The PDP begins by asking all trainees to consider the strengths and experiences they bring to teaching. This provides the basis for target-setting over the year. With reference to the national standards, training needs are identified, targets set and progress monitored.

PGCE courses are demanding. The timetable is probably more intensive than any other university course. There is, of course, the academic learning needed to give a secure base for teaching and a grasp of the policy and legal framework of education. Alongside it is the learning of new skills - presenting ideas, using IT, or working with colleagues, classroom assistants and parents.

Then there is learning the craft of teaching - techniques for keeping young learners motivated, engaged and focused. PGCE courses involve rapid transitions between learning and teaching, and school and university. They are tiring, absorbing and fast-moving. Small wonder Lucy Edwards needed her break. And that she's now ready for the next 21 weeks.

fields.headline: Side lines
fields.body:
We hear the voices telling women that their views, their understanding of the world, are as important as men's. We hear TV and radio stations and newspapers saying they want - need - women journalists, even if only to bump up audience or readership figures. It is a knock, then, to open the first edition of The Journalist's Handbook in the new millennium. The media quarterly is devoted entirely to the media themes and personalities of the 20th century, the centrepiece of which is a collection of profiles of journalistic heroes. There are 23. All of them are men. No Martha Gellhorn, no Katharine Graham, no Kate Adie, Katharine Whitehorn, Mary Stott, Jill Tweedie. Roll, roll, roll on the new millennium.

 It's official. Women who play rugby are not from planet butch. In fact they have things in common with, well, normal women. Just look at the evidence. A survey of women rugby players has found that playing rugby does not disqualify wimmin from being seduced, being chatted up and having an ideal date; 28% said they'd want to go white water rafting and 80% said they like a GSOH. So next time you feel confused about whether women playing rugby are really women, do the ultimate gender test and see if she's interested in your oar and laughs at your jokes.

 How useful! How practical! How depressing. Sidelines has been sent desirable gloves. Desirable, that is, if you're dealing with your cat's litter tray, gutting fish, chopping chillies or doing housework. Yes, three pairs of household gloves without a hint of irony. And to top it off, the bumf tells us when we're scrubbing the toilet rim, these rubber monsters will protect our manicured nails and keep our hands looking young. Nice to know someone cares. Where's the chocolate?

webTitle: We ignore women at our peril

fields.headline: We ignore women at our peril
fields.standfirst:
Listen Labour: female voters want more power and rights

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's election landslide in 1997 was due to New Labour breaking down two barriers that kept us out of office for nearly the whole of the last century.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's election landslide in 1997 was due to New Labour breaking down two barriers that kept us out of office for nearly the whole of the last century.

We broadened our appeal to include middle England. And, as important, we conquered the "gender gap" and appealed to women as well as men. Not only did we neutralise the Tories' traditional ability to appeal to women, we also opened up a huge lead particularly among younger women.

Women gave Labour the benefit of the doubt because we went out of our way to banish the male-dominated image and reality. New Labour was about women as well as men. To get more women into parliament we reserved for them 50% of the parliamentary seats we hoped to win. We campaigned on what women said they wanted from government, such as childcare and family-friendly employment as well as economic stability, the NHS and schools. We projected a female as well as male face. We ended the all-male platforms at meetings and press conferences and focused on women's magazines and daytime TV as well as the "usual channels" of the political correspondents of broadsheet newspapers.

Our election triumph saw the number of women MPs in the Labour party double. Women went into top jobs in the cabinet. We set about delivering on our promises of affordable, quality childcare in all neighbourhoods and brought in a new right to time off work when children are sick as well as investing massively in schools and hospitals. Devolution also brought the feminisation of the Scottish parliament and the Welsh assembly.

Meanwhile, Tory women remain marginalised in their party. Only one in 10 Tory MPs are women. The Tories opposed the national childcare strategy, new rights for parents at work and the new investment in health and education. Tory women have warned that women won't vote for a Tory party that appears to "hark back to the subservient family woman", but William Hague shows no sign of listening.

We should be able to build on our new appeal to women voters to win a second term which would see us do even more to deliver for women. But to do so we must keep our own house in order.

Though polling on voting intentions shows women's and men's support for Labour as level, the news on "satisfaction" is less good. Women who switched to Labour in 1997 are less likely than men to say they are satisfied with the government's performance. We won the support of women at the last election by demonstrating we were "women-friendly". Polling carried out by the Fawcett society shows if we persist in that we will consolidate our support among women. But if we slip in our commitment to women they will see us as having been cynical last time, and punish us.

We must press on with increasing the number of women MPs. Though we made great strides last time women are still only one in four of the parliamentary Labour party. We must ensure that vacancies in our safest seats are filled by women as well as men. Though our women in parliament have faced much unfair criticism, women in the country are wholly positive about them. They like women in parliament.

We do not have a guarantee of more women through "women only" selections this time so we will have to work hard to make space for women in the seats that we will start selecting this month. We must have more women in government, both moving up the junior ranks and in frontline jobs in the cabinet.

We must listen to and talk to women. When women hear talk of "big hitters" and "big guns" they know that is the macho language of men talking to other men. I've never heard a woman say she wants to see a "big beast" in charge of schools, "a big hitter" tackling domestic violence or a "big gun" in Northern Ireland.

Our next manifesto must be woman friendly, including more action to recognise that women are juggling home and work responsibilities. That means much more help for those caring for elderly relatives and a radical improvement in maternity pay and leave. Women get only 18 weeks maternity pay. That limit, fixed in 1953 when women were yet to play a major role in the workforce, is wholly out of date and must be extended to a year. Maternity leave too, should be extended from six to 12 months, with a right to return part time for family reasons. The national childcare strategy should be moved up the agenda and parents who use the new right to time off for their children should be paid.

Women flocked to Labour when we threw off our male-dominated image. We must continue to speak up for and deliver for women as well as men. Twenty-first-century woman wants to see women sharing the big decisions. It was women voters switching from the Tories who gave New Labour the chance to govern. We forget that at our peril.

 Harriet Harman is Labour MP for Peckham

Twenty-first-century woman wants to see women sharing the big decisions. It was women voters switching from the Tories who gave New Labour the chance to govern. We forget that at our peril.  Harriet Harman is Labour MP for Peckham

fields.headline: Kitchen cupboard dramas
fields.standfirst: So Delia Smith is back, demanding a look in our larders and a handle on our hobs.  Anita Chaudhuri  urges the new domestic slaves to revolt
fields.trailText: So Delia Smith is back, demanding a look in our larders and a handle on our hobs.  Anita Chaudhuri  urges the new domestic slaves to revolt
fields.body:
"Life is too short to stuff a mushroom," declared Shirley Conran in her epigraph to Superwoman. Alas, her paean to slothfulness appears to have been consigned to pop culture's great dustbin, alongside cherry-flavoured lip gloss and Charlie perfume.

Now we have a far more sensible domestic superheroine to inspire us. She is rich, she has sold more than 10 million books and she loves football, just like all good post-feminists are supposed to. Let's hear it, then, for Delia Smith, the woman who has got us all scuttling back to the scullery to agonise over whether our eggs are fresh enough to whip up a hollandaise sauce. Even before the first part of her new series was broadcast last night, she had sold a million copies of the accompanying book, a sequel to her back-to-basics manifesto, How To Cook.

The BBC helpfully commissioned a survey to launch the series. This revealed that 16% of men never cook, compared with only 3% of women. (Is this news?) The survey also uncovered the fact that 85% of British cupboards contain a bottle of tomato ketchup.

Perhaps a more valuable deployment of licence payers' money would have been to discover another statistic entirely: how many women in Britain buy cookery books from which they will never create a single meal? And how many of them will feel like dismal failures as a consequence?

Despite her phenomenal success, Delia Smith and her sisters in crime (the River Cafe babes, Sophie Grigson) occupy a peculiarly anachronistic position in our lives. Everything about Delia's new book, for example, harks back to the fantasy housewife of the 50s. Her jolly, matronly tone is accessorised with the type of ingredients that put me in mind of Enid Blyton's Mallory Towers books - greengages, gooseberry fool, stewed rhubarb, herring, kippers and prunes. Added to that is her coy line in innuendo, including a Carry On-style anecdote about capers in her larder. There is a recipe for Eton Mess (mashed meringue and strawberries), but thankfully none for stuffed mushrooms.

It is not just our culinary skills that are under scrutiny now, either: this time around, Smith wants to control how we organise our store cupboards and what brands of pots and pans we buy. For a woman of a certain age and temperament, these will be issues to which she has never previously devoted a single moment of her attention. Until now. Now she will, if she is like me, be having dark nights of the soul worrying about the fact that Lakeland Plastics don't have a branch in London.

Recipes themselves have a sneaky habit of instilling panic in the calmest of souls. The current emphasis on how very easy it is to jug a hare (River Cafe) or soak and boil a pot of cannellini beans (Nigella Lawson) serves only to make the inept feel inadequate and, by proxy, unfeminine. Delia is the worst because you can hear her cooing in your ear as you try to boil an egg without cracking the shell. "This is easy, so easy." So how does that make us feel when we get it wrong?

It remains a mystery why we feel we have to live up to her and dozens of other culinary dominatrixes, though. I never feel the slightest urge to compete with the boys - Ainsley, Marco and Gary, to name but three - but then it is a curious thing that men in this business are always chefs but women rarely have that distinction bestowed upon them. Instead they are referred to as cooks, with the implied aura of domestic drudgery.

Sadly, the vogue for drudgery looks like it is here to stay - books, TV programmes, videos and even CD-roms remain huge sellers. A knock-on effect is the boom in super-complicated kitchen equipment. Now it is not enough merely to cook like a Michelin-starred chef, we must have a gleaming chrome kitchen to match, complete with Smeg six-burner oven that has enough fire-power to send us to the moon if the soufflé doesn't rise.

American writer Laura Shapiro believes this mania about cooking is part of a sinister return to domestic enslavement. In her book, Perfection Salad: Women And Cooking, she reminds us of how the 50s was in fact a golden age when home freezing and processed foods were designed to give us all more free time to devote to futuristic values such as careers and relationships.

"Whether or not they like to cook, most women liked feeling as though they were cooking," Shapiro says. "And they worried about leaving out the most powerful ingredient in any dish, the ingredient one food writer described as 'a mother's love for her family'."

Delia and co would be doing us a big favour if they went the whole hog and launched a range of Learn To Eat ready meals instead of giving us any more grief. Chocolate and prune brownie mix anyone?

fields.headline: Ordinary people
fields.standfirst: Portrait artists look beyond VIPs
fields.trailText: The Fowey lifeboat crew were yawning. They had come straight to the elegant Mall galleries in London from a day and night at sea searching for a lost Cornish fisherman.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, Arts and Heritage Correspondent
fields.body:
The Fowey lifeboat crew were yawning. They had come straight to the elegant Mall galleries in London from a day and night at sea searching for a lost Cornish fisherman.

Their group portrait, by Jeff Stultiens, is in People's Portraits, an exhibition unveiled yesterday which includes a butcher, a scaffolder, a stripper, a rabbi, a breadman and a thief.

The Royal Society of Portrait Painters, stung by the jibe that its members paint only minor royals and captains of industry for boardroom walls, sent them out to work for free, painting real people in real jobs.

The exhibition was the idea of Daphne Todd, who painted her butchers, Ron and Ray Pett, in Rotherfield, East Sussex.

Like many of the 47 subjects, Ron Pett attended yesterday's preview in his work clothes. He found sitting - or rather standing behind his chopping block - surprisingly hard work. "We did about two hours at a time, a couple of nights a week. I had to replace that turkey in the front two or three times; it was getting a bit tired looking."

The most serene face among the portraits was that of Reg Andrews, a bread delivery man and carpet weaver. A few years ago half the members of his family, along with hundreds of others in Kidderminster, Worcestershire, lost their jobs when the carpet factory closed.

"People were crying in the streets, it was like a death," he said. He got a Saturday job delivering bread. One customer was the artist John Edwards, and the rest is oil paint.

"They say I look like a Rembrandt," a proud Mr Andrews said.

The subject of portrait number 14, Anonymous Thief, did not attend. "I wanted to paint somebody from the shadows at the edge of society," the artist Robert Wraith said. "I put the word out in Oxford, and there was a message on my answering machine.

"He was very intelligent, very thoughtful, but very troubled. He turned up on my doorstep with half a bottle of whisky and a bare chest - somebody admired his shirt on the bus so he gave it away.

"He's trying to go straight because he's worried about what will happen to his dog if he goes back into prison."

The exhibition is at the Mall galleries until January 21 and will then tour the municipal galleries.

fields.headline: Facing the past
fields.standfirst: Roman lady reconstructed
fields.trailText: The face of the Roman Lady, one of the most glamorous archaeological discoveries of the last decade, was unveiled last night - and she is Spanish, suggesting previously unimagined links between late Roman London and the Iberian peninsula.
fields.body:
The face of the Roman Lady, one of the most glamorous archaeological discoveries of the last decade, was unveiled last night - and she is Spanish, suggesting previously unimagined links between late Roman London and the Iberian peninsula.

The reconstruction of the woman's face was carried out by the Museum of London and a team from the BBC2 programme Meet the Ancestors. Her deep set eyes and distinctive nose appear to confirm earlier bone and DNA analysis suggesting that her origins were Iberian.

Given the opulent grave goods packed into and around her stone and lead coffin, archaeologists deduced she came from one of the wealthiest families of late Roman London, and may have come from Spain in an arranged marriage to cement a trading alliance.

"This is a really fascinating and very important discovery," museum director Simon Thurley said yesterday. "She doesn't look at all English. She is certainly not Romano-British as we had originally assumed."

The woman's intact lead coffin was opened in front of television cameras last April.

Inside were found petrified bay leaves, believed to be from a pillow or garland, and gold threads which may have been from her shroud.

Since then the coffin and contents have been in the museum's laboratories, but the reconstructed head will go on public display at the museum this morning.

The Roman Lady was found on the edge of a huge medieval cemetery in Spitalfields, east London, by archaeologists from the museum.

fields.headline: 'Scurrilous' attack on GMB leader
fields.trailText: John Edmonds, general secretary of the GMB, accused a former employee of launching a "scurrilous" campaign of misinformation after a victimisation case collapsed at an industrial tribunal yesterday.
fields.body:
John Edmonds, general secretary of the GMB, accused a former employee of launching a "scurrilous" campaign of misinformation after a victimisation case collapsed at an industrial tribunal yesterday.

Elaine Wright withdrew her claim that Mr Edmonds and other officials at GMB headquarters in Wimbledon, south London, had bullied her after she returned to her job as a secretary after winning a tribunal case against the union in 1997.

Mrs Wright, 36, who left her job as a secretary in February last year and now works as a childminder, agreed to pay £2,000 towards the union's legal costs, which Mr Edmonds said would be paid to the NSPCC, of which he is a trustee.

The GMB agreed to drop a county court case lodged against Mrs Wright last Friday for allegedly breaking the terms of her voluntary redundancy agreement.

The union had claimed that Mrs Wright breached her £20,000 redundancy package by distributing defamatory material about Mr Edmonds and the union to newspapers, union members and MPs. Mrs Wright denied the allegations.

Mrs Wright, who has two children, brought her first action when she returned to work after maternity leave to find that her job had been demoted a grade. She won, but received no financial award.

Referring to the alleged campaign, Mr Edmonds said: "Elaine Wright was prompting scurrilous stories and I am sorry to say that one or two people believed them."

A spokesman for the Manufacturing, Science and Finance union, which offered legal advice to Mrs Wright, said: "She had nothing to do with the smear campaign. The reason she withdrew is because she was already suffering from stress as a result of the victimisation."

Mr Edmonds also rejected claims that there was a culture of bullying within the GMB. In a separate case a dozen employees at the Birmingham regional branch have accused branch secretary Ken Gregory of bullying.

fields.headline: Sport could pull in tourists
fields.trailText: Sports stars are to be asked to become tourist ambassadors for Britain - via diplomatic handshakes and promotional speeches.
fields.body:
Sports stars are to be asked to become tourist ambassadors for Britain - via diplomatic handshakes and promotional speeches.

They will be urged to play the sales game for their homeland while competing abroad under a package to be unveiled by the British tourist authority and government ministers today.

Manchester United, despite the disappointments and PR disasters of the world club championship, still have the potential to be prime envoys due to their worldwide TV exposure, according to some in the travel industry.

Solo stars such as Greg Rusedski in tennis and Lennox Lewis, the world heavyweight boxing champion, who have chosen to return to their British roots, may be recruited to the cause.

Tourist chiefs say that Britain has "cathedrals of sport" such as Lord's and Wimbledon in London, Cardiff's Millennium Stadium and St Andrew's golf course in Scotland with the potential to attract many more fans on sports packages.

They hope the new sports ambassadors follow examples such as former Olympic javelin champion Tessa Sanderson, now vice-chairman of Sport England, a leading enthusiast for the scheme, and Tony Lewis, a former England cricket captain who has long sold the virtues of his homeland abroad as chairman of the Wales tourist board.

Jeff Hamblin, BTA's chief executive, said: "Sport is both a mainstay of British life and a magnet for tourists worldwide. But there is still plenty of scope to increase its global pulling power and help Britain extend tourism throughout the country, and throughout the year."

England's hosting of the Euro 96 football tournament was considered a success in attracting foreign visitors. As a result the government is desperate to win the 2006 World Cup.

fields.headline: Horrocks joins Who's Who elite
fields.trailText: Who's Who 2000 is published tomorrow with television presenter Angus Deayton, actress Jane Horrocks and newsreader Dermot Murnaghan all making it into the list of 30,000 names.
fields.body:
Who's Who 2000 is published tomorrow with television presenter Angus Deayton, actress Jane Horrocks and newsreader Dermot Murnaghan all making it into the list of 30,000 names.

The 1,000 additions to the list of Britain's most influential people also includes street poet Benjamin Zephaniah and Annie Stewart, former editor of the black newspaper The Voice, Louise Frechette, deputy secretary general of the United Nations, and Nicholas Prettejohn, chief executive of Lloyd's of London.

Teletubbies creator Anne Wood also makes it into the book, although her impact on the world cannot be doubted with millions of children around the world now saying "eh-oh".

The entries under recreations make for some of the most interesting reading. Guardian writer and editor of the cricketing bible Wisden Matthew Engel enjoys "whingeing" as a hobby while the British ambassador to the UN, Stewart Eldon, puts down "breaking computers".

Scotland football manager Craig Brown enjoys swimming in the sea, drinking and shopping while children's television presenter Floella Benjamin lists golf, cooking and running as her favourite pastimes.

All names remain in the book until their deaths when they are transferred to Who Was Who. The new edition, which costs £115, is published on Wednesday.

The publication is also available at libraries which have subscribed to the online reference service Know UK at www.knowuk.co.uk

fields.headline: Newsreader's stalker jailed
fields.trailText: A man who stalked a TV newsreader for more than a year was yesterday jailed for two-and-a-half years and banned for life from contacting her.
fields.body:
A man who stalked a TV newsreader for more than a year was yesterday jailed for two-and-a-half years and banned for life from contacting her.

Jeremy Dyer, 30, of no fixed address, pleaded guilty at Maidstone crown court to harassing Sarah Lockett, 32, who works at the Kent studios of the ITV company Meridian.

Passing sentence, Judge Susan Hamilton QC told Dyer he was "an extremely weird young man", adding that she did not believe him when he told the court he had sent at least 80 "unpleasant and unwarranted" letters because he thought Miss Lockett would be interested in the subject.

"Many contained ghoulish and frightening references. Shortly after you started writing, the letters became overtly sexual. At no time has there been a slightest hint of any care, concern or affection for the subject of this correspondence," the judge said.

A restraining order was also imposed on Dyer, banning him for life from any contact with Ms Lockett and from coming within half a mile of her home or workplace.

Judge Hamilton said Dyer had made three attempts to meet Ms Lockett at the television studios and tried to obtain her home address.

"Fortunately you were unable to do so," the judge said. "We cannot tell what you may have done if you had found somewhere she did not have the protection of staff and of security guards."

Dyer started the correspondence from December 1998.

"The ultimate in distasteful references were those relating to the death of Jill Dando and your glee in making comparisons between Miss Lockett and Jill Dando and their profession," Judge Hamilton said.

She told Dyer he was "an extremely weird young man" although psychiatric reports found that he was not suffering from any mental illness.

Judge Hamilton said women such as Ms Lockett must be protected from Dyer's "ghoulish and threatening attention".

Dyer was earlier cleared of threatening to kill the presenter after the jury failed to reach a verdict during a five-day trial in December last year.

Ms Lockett had told the court that letters from Dyer included those about "different jackets I wore and which were more revealing than others".

After Ms Dando's death in April last year, Dyer wrote: "I was hoping a celebrity would be murdered by a stalker and it makes it even better that she read the news."

webTitle: Pensioner hopping over next door's frogs

fields.headline: Pensioner hopping over next door's frogs
fields.trailText: The three accused appeared unlikely neighbours from hell. As they sat inanimate in Glasgow district court, it was hard to believe that ornamental frogs could have driven a pensioner to such lengths. They looked innocuous enough.
fields.body:
The three accused appeared unlikely neighbours from hell. As they sat inanimate in Glasgow district court, it was hard to believe that ornamental frogs could have driven a pensioner to such lengths. They looked innocuous enough.

It was not, however, their appearance that Catherine Watt claimed had pushed her to the edge of reason. Yesterday she told the court that the frogs' constant croaking had made her life a misery.

It was alleged that the ornamental frogs, fitted with movement sensors, would croak whenever someone walked past or the wind blew strongly. Eventually Mrs Watt, 65, could take no more. "It was just croak, croak, croak," she said. "I thought if they don't keep quiet I'm going to go off my head."

She told the court that last February, suffering from a sleeping disorder and high blood pressure, she left home at 6am after a dispute with her husband. webTitle: Census to ask people about religious beliefs

fields.headline: Census to ask people about religious beliefs
fields.standfirst:
Proposal to seek details of income abandoned

Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The government has abandoned plans to ask everybody in Britain for details of their incomes next year as part of the official 2001 census, but it will ask people to give their religion for the first time since 1851.
fields.body:
The government has abandoned plans to ask everybody in Britain for details of their incomes next year as part of the official 2001 census, but it will ask people to give their religion for the first time since 1851.

Another question to be included on the census form for the first time will be used to determine the size of the Irish population living in Britain. The census will also for the first time give people the chance to describe themselves as "black British" or "Asian British" when they are asked which ethnic group they belong to.

The decision to ask about religion is principally designed to make the first accurate assessment of the size of Britain's largest minority ethnic community - the Muslims - for which estimates vary from 1m to 3m.

Many government departments made a strong push to include questions about individual incomes in next year's census on the basis that it would be a far more accurate way of identifying areas of poverty and affluence in Britain than the current questions on occupation and housing conditions. This information would have been invaluable to government policy planners.

But small scale tests by the office of national statistics showed that people tended not to give wholly honest answers when asked about how much they earned. Others simply refused to answer the question which led to worries that including an income question would pose a serious risk to the census as a whole.

More than 90,000 people will be employed as temporary staff next year to canvass households to carry out the census which is compulsory.

The official statisticians hope that the inclusion of the terms black British and British Asian for the first time will encourage a greater response rate among the minority ethnic communities.

They also amount to official recognition that second and third generation children of West Indian and Asian backgrounds see themselves as British and black or British and Asian.

The use of a question on religion will need legislation and the government is expected to announce that it will support a private member's bill which has been introduced into the Lords by a former speaker of the House of Commons, Lord Weatherill.

The question will ask: "What is your religion?" and people will be asked of the following: none, Christian (including Church of England, Catholic, Protestant and all other Christian denominations), Buddist, Hindu, Muslim, Sikh, Jewish, any other religion.

A question on religion has traditionally been included in the census in Northern Ireland where the information is used to monitor the effectiveness of policies aimed at improving equality. Next year in Northern Ireland the form will also ask those who answer "no religion" to record the religion in which they were brought up - if any.

The religious question will not be asked in Scotland.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, strongly backed the case for the inclusion of the religious question and argued it would give a far more accurate picture of Britain's minority ethnic communities than the outdated classes of white, black, or Asian used in the 1991 census.

fields.headline: Cook dismissed Libyan arms find
fields.standfirst: Decision to restore diplomatic links with Tripoli was taken after missile parts were seized at Gatwick
fields.trailText: The row over a Libyan attempt to breach the arms embargo took a new twist yesterday when it emerged that Britain had discovered an illegal consignment of Scud missile parts last May - two months before diplomatic links with the country were restored.
fields.byline: Richard Norton-Taylor, Ewen MacAskill  and  Ian Black in Brussels
fields.body:
The row over a Libyan attempt to breach the arms embargo took a new twist yesterday when it emerged that Britain had discovered an illegal consignment of Scud missile parts last May - two months before diplomatic links with the country were restored.

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, brushed the disclosure aside at the time, seeing the restoration of relations with Libya as too important to be deflected by an illegal attempt to import missiles through Britain.

Ripples from the Scud missile row continued to spread yesterday, throwing into doubt an invitation to the Libyan president, Colonel Muammar Gadafy, to visit Brussels from the European commission president, Romano Prodi.

In a surprise development, Whitehall sources disclosed that customs and excise officers, along with intelligence staff, had discovered the Scud parts in May last year, not November, as reported at the weekend.

Though they asked British Airways at Gatwick airport to stop the shipment, the crates were put on board the plane bound for Malta and Tripoli. Enraged officials urgently asked the Maltese authorities to seize the shipment.

The crates were returned to Britain in July - the month diplomatic ties between Britain and Libya were officially restored. The shipment was impounded pending investigation and formally seized by customs in November.

The foreign office confirmed yesterday that the crates had been impounded before ties were restored. While the revelation is potentially embarrassing for Mr Cook, the foreign office said the decision was justified, as it was important to have direct links with Libya to be able to discuss difficulties and have an influence.

The foreign office saw the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction as one of the key issues facing the world, but that problem was not confined to Libya.

The 32 crates were labelled as spare parts for cars and were allegedly sent by a clothing company in Taiwan called Hontex.

The firm denied any involvement with arms. "We are an ordinary textile maker. We are not arms sellers," Wang Chuan-cheng, the president of Hontex's parent company, Nam Liong Industrial Corp, said yesterday.

Washington is likely to use the disclosure of Libya's attempt to update its missile arsenal to try to persuade Europeans to join the US in developing a regional anti-missile system to match its national protective shield, which is expected to be given the go-ahead by President Bill Clinton this summer.

Libya is one of the "rogue" states cited by the US as a reason for the US and its European allies developing anti-missile systems.

The Europeans are strongly resisting the US plan, saying it would lead to a new arms race.

Although it was initially feared that the Scud parts had been intended to extend the missile range from 200 to 600 miles, putting southern Italy within Libya's reach, the foreign office said the parts were only spares and would not affect the range.

Col Gadafy's visit to Brussels now looks uncertain. While an EU spokesman said Mr Prodi still wanted to invite the colonel as part of a "process of discussion", Libya had set "unacceptable" conditions.

EU officials said that although Libya had offered to join the 27-member Euro-Mediterranean forum, it insisted last week that Israel and the Palestinian Authority should be excluded from the group.

"If Libya maintains this position it will stay out of the process," said a spokesman for the external relations commissioner, Chris Patten. "The discovery in London certainly shows how wise it is to maintain the arms embargo against Libya."

Mr Patten, along with the EU's new foreign policy chief, Javier Solana, was said to have been outraged by Mr Prodi's Christmas invitation to the Libyan leader.

To join the Euro-Mediterranean forum countries must pledge themselves to free trade, the promotion of human rights and the peaceful settlement of disputes.

The EU has been working to improve relations with Libya since Col Gadafy allowed the handing over for trial in the Netherlands of two suspects in the bombing of Pan Am flight 103 over Lockerbie in 1988, when 270 people died.

Last September the EU lifted most remaining sanctions imposed on Libya after the Lockerbie bombing, although the arms embargo remains.

In Tripoli, meanwhile, the official Jana news agency said reports about the seizure of Scud missile parts were aimed at damaging the improving relations between Libya and Britain.

fields.headline: Unsolved: woman knifed in Jaguar
fields.trailText: Penny Bell was found slumped over the steering wheel of her Jaguar XJS in the car park of a leisure centre in Greenford, west London, on June 6 1991. She had been stabbed and slashed 50 times in the chest and arms with a long knife.
fields.body:
Penny Bell was found slumped over the steering wheel of her Jaguar XJS in the car park of a leisure centre in Greenford, west London, on June 6 1991. She had been stabbed and slashed 50 times in the chest and arms with a long knife.

Nine years, a £20,000 reward, 8,000 interviews and 2,500 written statements later, nobody has been convicted of the businesswoman's murder.

According to John O'Connor, a former flying squad commander, the police investigation into Mrs Bell's murder would have followed a standard pattern. The crime scene would have been sealed off to allow forensic scientists to examine the car, looking for anything that might lead to the identity of the killer.

A detective superintendent was assigned to the case. He set up an incident room and gathered a team of detectives, while civilians were brought in to set up and operate Holmes, the computer database that is the backbone of nearly every murder investigation.

Uniformed officers made house to house inquiries and questioned any other potential witnesses, including 800 car park users, but failed to produce any significant leads.

The police established that Mrs Bell had left home at 9.40am, telling builders working on the property that she was late for an appointment. She drove into the car park of the Gurnell Grove leisure centre at around 10.30am. She was found at midday by two women returning to their car.

There was no obvious motive for the killing. She was not sexually assaulted, and her handbag was found undisturbed in the car.

Forensic evidence revealed that the attack began from the passenger seat, but the killer switched to the driver's side. Two witnesses told police they had seen a woman who looked like the victim wrestling with a man in her car as it drove through Greenford, mouthing "help me" to passing drivers.

Police were convinced Mrs Bell knew her killer. A builder who was a family friend was arrested after his fingerprints were found in the Jaguar, but he was released without charge.

One witness described the man in the car as about 40 with dark hair, possibly sporting a beard and wearing a bracelet on his right hand. But circulation of the description failed to bring any new leads.

Detectives say the anniversary of a murder is a good time to try to reignite public interest in a killing and produce new witnesses. A year after Mrs Bell's murder, police told a press conference that as many as 30 people who may have been in the car park at the time had still not come forward. Her husband also made an appeal for witnesses, but again detectives drew a blank.

Eventually the case was wound down. The files remain open.

fields.headline: So this is Miss Brodie?
fields.standfirst: John Crace  advises on what you should ask when you meet your child's teacher
fields.trailText: A parents' evening can change lives. One mum was offered a job as she shuffled her way to the head of the Dome-like queue to see her daughter's teacher. Another mum spent the interminable waiting time getting to know another dad rather better than she should have, and both ended up ditching their respective partners and eloping together. And, yes, sometimes there's even something in it for your children, too.
fields.body:
A parents' evening can change lives. One mum was offered a job as she shuffled her way to the head of the Dome-like queue to see her daughter's teacher. Another mum spent the interminable waiting time getting to know another dad rather better than she should have, and both ended up ditching their respective partners and eloping together. And, yes, sometimes there's even something in it for your children, too.

Getting to meet the teacher and finding out how your child is doing - even if it is only for 10 minutes, two or three times a year - is unquestionably "a good thing". It's such a "good thing", in fact, that it has even been known to induce some separated parents who wouldn't normally been seen dead together in the same room to gather in icy proximity to get the lowdown on their little darlings.

Whether this is a rare display of solidarity, or an indication that neither can trust the other to give an accurate account of the proceedings is by the by. They're there.

But good things generally come with a heavy price-tag. And with this particular ritual it is often hard to work out who finds it the tougher ordeal - teachers or parents. For teachers, the evening can be a gruelling exercise in five-star diplomacy.

"The arguments over whose turn it is are only the start of the fun," says one teacher from an inner-London primary school. "You get parents reeking of booze, you get parents effing and blinding at you, and you get parents telling you how much they help with the homework when you know they never lift a finger.

"At the other end of the scale, you get the parents who reckon they know the national curriculum better than you and use their slot to interrogate you."

The experience can be equally frustrating for parents.

"The first meeting of the academic year is often a complete waste of time," says Deborah Benady. "The teacher hasn't really had long enough to get to know your child, so you tend to spend your allotted 10 minutes listening to generalisations that you already knew."

Ben Abrahams identifies a different problem. "Teachers are mostly concerned with those children who are failing in some way," he says. "My daughter doesn't fall into this category, so our meetings invariably run along the lines of 'Hannah's performing very satisfactorily.' I want to know more than this, but I can never get her teacher to be more specific. I leave feeling as if I'm a pushy parent, which I don't think I am. A school should be about getting each child to fulfil their potential, not getting them above a 'nothing to worry about level'."

For all the griping on both sides, parents' evenings do serve a useful function - if only to give teachers background on the home life of their pupils and to give parents the chance to find out what their children are up to, as all attempts to extract such information from the treasures themselves will invariably have been greeted with a deadbat 'nothing'.

Moreover, for parents who otherwise take little interest in their children's education it is a time when teachers can deliver a jargon-free explanation of the literacy hour. Just occasionally teachers even get little reminders of why they started in the profession.

"One father is well known locally as a big dealer and no one wants to make home visits because the house is full of drugs and guns," said the inner-London teacher. "So I was dreading meeting him. But he turned out to be genuinely interested in what we were doing and concerned that his son should not turn out as he had."

Such surprises are generally rare. If anything important is going on with your child, the school should have let you know long before the parents' evening. But not always. One mother who asked how her 15-year-old daughter was doing was told, "You tell us. We haven't seen much of Sarah this term."

How to make the most of your time

1 Talk to your child about anything that is worrying him or her before you go.

2 Make a list of all the things that are bothering you and take it with you.

3 Don't automatically assume the teacher has got it in for your child. He or she may know your child in ways you don't.

4 Don't spend too long on any one area if you have a lot you want to discuss.

5 If your child is present, try to make sure you also talk about the things that he or she is doing well.

6 If you don't feel you have had enough time to talk about a problem, make another appointment with the teacher.

7 Take a book to read in the queue.

webTitle: UVF chief killed in loyalist vendetta

fields.headline: UVF chief killed in loyalist vendetta
fields.standfirst: Hardline LVF blamed as father of three is shot dead outside home following post-Christmas confrontation
fields.trailText: An Ulster Volunteer Force commander was shot dead in Portadown last night as warfare erupted within loyalism in mid-Ulster, raising fears of a tit-for-tat bloodbath involving rival groups.
fields.body:
An Ulster Volunteer Force commander was shot dead in Portadown last night as warfare erupted within loyalism in mid-Ulster, raising fears of a tit-for-tat bloodbath involving rival groups.

Richard Jameson, 46, was executed outside his house on the outskirts of the Co Armagh town two weeks after he was involved in a vicious fight with prominent figures in the hardline Loyalist Volunteer Force. He was UVF brigadier in mid-Ulster.

His killers were waiting as Mr Jameson arrived home from working at his roofing company. A gunman pumped several shots into his head and body through the passenger window of his Isuzu Trooper.

Mr Jameson, married with three children, was rushed to the Craigavon area hospital, but was pronounced dead on arrival. He was regarded as a staunch supporter of the Good Friday agreement. His brother lost his legs in an IRA bomb attack more than 10 years ago.

Mr Jameson is the first victim of the Troubles since last July when the IRA killed Charles Bennett, 22, suspected of stealing one of its guns. Another loyalist, Denver Smith, 32, bludgeoned in Antrim on New Year's Day, is thought to have been murdered by a criminal gang.

It was a devastating blow to the fragile peace process. Northern Ireland's fledgling executive meets again today.

The LVF which called a ceasefire in May 1998 after a series of sectarian murders, is suspected of Mr Jameson's assassination. Several members are involved in new dissident loyalist groups, the Orange Volunteers and Red Hand Defenders, and some control the burgeoning drugs trade in mid-Ulster.

David Ervine, assembly member for the Progressive Unionist Party, linked to the UVF, said: "He was a fine and honorable man, widely respected in the community. He was murdered unceremoniously because he stood against those who masqueraded as loyalists as they plied their nefarious trade of drugs."

The First Minister David Trimble, in whose Upper Bann constituency Mr Jameson was executed, said: "This is exactly the sort of thing we though we had finally put behind us. I'm shocked by the news."

Community workers in Portadown last week persuaded the rival groups to appoint a mediator in an effort to defuse the row. The surprise choice is believed to have been Johnny Adair, the former Ulster Freedom Fighters' commander on the Shankill Road in Belfast, freed from the Maze prison four months ago after serving five years of a 16-year sentence for directing terrorism.

A dozen drinkers were badly injured at the Shamrock social club, at the home of Portadown's senior football side, in the pitched battle on December 27, the second anniversary of Wright's murder in the Maze prison by the Irish National Liberation Army.

Robley has already pleaded guilty to the Poyntzpass killings.

Phillips, awaiting trial, is charged with the murder on the LVF wing at the Maze Prison in March 1998 of David Keys, 26, the fourth man charged over the Poyntpass murders.

webTitle: Brown 'paid over odds for Maxwell flat'

fields.headline: Brown 'paid over odds for Maxwell flat'
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown last night moved to squash fresh criticism about his purchase of a Westminster flat from Robert Maxwell's bankrupt empire when he revealed that he paid £5,000 more than his building society's surveyor said the flat was worth in 1992.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown last night moved to squash fresh criticism about his purchase of a Westminster flat from Robert Maxwell's bankrupt empire when he revealed that he paid £5,000 more than his building society's surveyor said the flat was worth in 1992.

The £130,000 which the then-shadow chancellor offered for the one bedroom apartment six months after the fourth Tory election victory was at least £30,000 below market value, according to weekend press claims, backed by senior Tories.

They intend to step up their pressure, convinced, despite denials, that Mr Brown's closeness to Geoffrey Robinson, the millionaire Labour MP who was briefly on the parent board of the firm that owned the flat, must have tipped him off to the "bargain". MPs familiar with both men say that in 1992 they were not the friends they later became.

Mr Robinson was forced to resign over his undisclosed £374,000 home loan to Peter Mandelson.

On top of support from Arthur Andersons, the accountants who handled the Maxwell asset sales, the unnamed surveyor's assessment proves that Conservative complaints to Mrs Elizabeth Filkin, parliamentary commissioner for standards, were "entirely misconceived", aides to the chancellor insisted last night.

The chancellor had had to pay above the odds, they said, because other potential buyers were bidding for the property which is behind Westminster Abbey, five minutes walk from Parliament. In effect, it was a normal purchase, via an estate agent, like any other.

Local estate agents in Westminster last night recalled that late 1992 was a tough time for vendors. Details of the professionals directly involved are all in Mr Brown's constituency home in Fife, it was said.

David Heathcoat-Amory, the former treasury minister, yesterday referred the case to Mrs Filkin, arguing that the chancellor had an obligation to register "any pecuniary interest or other material benefit" he might receive which could affect his conduct or votes as an MP.

Mr Brown was a senior member of the Labour opposition team dealing with the collapse of the Maxwell publishing empire, including AGB International, parent company of AGB Research which owned the flat. "It was therefore highly relevant that he had purchased a flat from the receivers of one of those failed companies," he said in his letter to Mrs Filkin.

Mr Heathcoat-Amory has long demanded information about AGB and missing pension funds. Yesterday he pressed home his demands with fresh questions to Tony Blair and other senior ministers.

webTitle: Council acts to bust teen gangs

fields.headline: Council acts to bust teen gangs
fields.trailText: Nottingham council is set to become the first in Britain to hire police officers full time in a new effort to break up youth gangs which are plaguing city estates. Its "gangbusting" team will tackle the groups, which include children as young as six.
fields.body:
Nottingham council is set to become the first in Britain to hire police officers full time in a new effort to break up youth gangs which are plaguing city estates. Its "gangbusting" team will tackle the groups, which include children as young as six.

A 14-year-old from the Bulwell estate, nicknamed Dangermouse, recently became the youngest person in the country to be placed under an antisocial behaviour order after being arrested more than 100 times, and convicted 55 times, for offences including assault, burglary and threatening behaviour.

Nottingham's problems are no worse than those of comparable cities, the council said. But complaints about child gangs are on the rise, accounting for nearly half the complaints about anti-social behaviour in the city.

Two police officers will join the council to work full time, mainly in plain clothes on surveillance work. The council wants to prosecute ringleaders and prevent other youngsters from being drawn in to gangs.

Assuming, as expected, that the plan receives backing from the full council, the police officers will join a 12-strong group disorder unit.

"It shows our faith in the police. Other councils have gone down the route of private security but we want the real thing and people with real powers," the council leader, Graham Chapman, said. "We don't want to end up with housing estates that are no-go zones because of teenage criminals."

The unit will extend the use of anti-social behaviour orders and curfews. It will work with the local youth crime reduction agency, which involves council departments and voluntary organisations. The scheme adds £120,000 to the city's £382,000 budget for tackling anti-social behaviour.

Lawrie Heighway, the council's anti-social behaviour team leader, said the police were committed to dealing with teenage gangs but numbers were stretched. The new scheme would guarantee police who could work exclusively on the problem.

Nottinghamshire police will recruit two new police officers in replacement.

fields.headline: Nationalists hail Straw's English awakening
fields.standfirst:
Frustrated home secretary is first senior minister to hint at remodelled Westminster to remove anomalies created by devolution

New Labour in power: special report
Devolution in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Eight months after Scotland won self-government, the English backlash finally emerged last night in an unlikely alliance between the home secretary and the Tory leader.
fields.body:
Eight months after Scotland won self-government, the English backlash finally emerged last night in an unlikely alliance between the home secretary and the Tory leader.

That, at any rate, was the view from a band of English nationalists - Labour activists, Tory worthies and middle-class romantics - who believe devolution for the Celtic fringes will inevitably result in big changes at Westminster.

Optimism was fuelled by Jack Straw's comments on Radio 4 about Scottish and Welsh home rule provoking a "rising sense of Englishness".

William Hague followed with an apocalyptic warning about the break-up of Britain, but Mr Straw is the first senior minister to imply that the government may have to consider remodelling Westminster to remove anomalies created by devolution.

As a minister whose department covers the UK, as well as specific English issues such as law and order, the home secretary's intervention could be born out of frustration.

He is known to be uneasy over a mounting campaign in the Scottish parliament to challenge the new asylum and immigration act, under which refugees will be given food vouchers, rather than cash, to buy life's essentials.

Stretching the uneasy settlement between Westminster and Edinburgh to its limits, some MSPs want to wrench control of immigration from the home office.

Along with some cabinet colleagues, Mr Straw is said to feel that the Scottish challenge on student tuition fees - which could see the Edinburgh parliament introducing an alternative post-graduation tax linked to income - is designed to embarrass British ministers.

Like other senior ministers, he doubtless believes that the interim financial settlement between London and Edinburgh, which guarantees the Scots a level of public spending over 20% per head higher than England, is unsustainable in the medium term.

Northern MPs - Mr Straw represents Blackburn - are also feeling the heat from councillors and party activists who think their regions are under-performing because of this generous support.

Last night the home secretary was careful to keep his comments on a philosophical level, noting that "as we move into this new century, people's sense of Englishness will become more articulated and that is partly because of the mirror that devolution provides us with".

But that was enough to prompt Mr Straw's old Commons adversary, Lord (Kenneth) Baker, to send the home secretary his latest book, Children's English History in Verse, which includes the Chesterton lines: "Smile at us, pay us, pass us; but do not quite forget. For we are the people of England, that have never spoken yet".

Lord Baker, like Mr Straw, sees the stirrings of an English backlash. "It's most extraordinary that ministers should now stumble on devolution as a problem when it's a problem they've created," he said.

He sees an English parliament as inevitable to counter a "grossly unfair" post-devolution settlement to Scotland and Wales.

Lord Baker asked: "Why should Scottish and Welsh nationalism be a noble thing, when nationalism in England is seen as something dirty?"

Like many Westminster parliamentarians - Tory and, privately, Labour - Lord Baker is outraged by the government's inability to tackle the so-called West Lothian question, first raised by Tam Dalyell, the anti-devolution MP for that former Scottish constituency.

It asks why Scottish MPs are still allowed to vote on English issues when English members no longer have an equivalent right over Scottish affairs.

This is one reason why Mr Hague briefly flirted with the idea of an English parliament after winning the Tory leadership.

He soon backed off, but he told Radio 4 last night that devolution to Edinburgh and Cardiff had brought a "rise of an English political consciousness."

Like many, he has recently seen one symbolic change in England - substitution of the union flag with the red and white of St George. "You would never have seen that a couple of years ago," he said.

But has English nationalism grown deeper cultural, and political roots beyond the chanting at Wembley?

Tony Linsell would like to think so. In truth, he's not so sure. As a founder of the Campaign for an English Parliament, he's set up a website from his Anglo-Saxon bookshop in Kings Lynn, Norfolk.

Its policy statement invokes Chesterton, urging the people of England to "wake up". It calls for an English devolution referendum, similar to exercises held in Scotland and Wales.

But Linsell laments: "We've got trouble getting any publicity, but someone must care."

According to a small band of Labour members, who briefly flirted with Linsell's enterprise before launching their own campaign, some activists are being converted to the logic of an English parliament in a quasi-federal UK.

"There's a strong case on the left for a radical perspective in the way England is run," says Steve Richards, a Labour member from Lewisham, in south-east London. "There's a certain inevitability about an English parliament."

For many, however, this remains a fanciful notion.

"Although there is a theological case pursued by a few, it doesn't answer the real problem of people in the English regions wanting more control over their own affairs," says Alan Beith, Berwick MP and the Lib Dems' deputy leader.

"An English parliament, far away in London, offers nothing for areas like the north-east or Cornwall."

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Radio
fields.body:
Harold Macmillan certainly caught the leader of the opposition on the wrong foot when he unexpectedly called the 1959 general election. For the first and last time in his life Hugh Gaitskell was lying blind drunk in a Moscow hotel room. But, as Denis Healey recounts in The Rock And Poll Years (11.30am, Radio 4), Aneurin Bevan covered up splendidly. The series is a tangle of reminiscences and the Top Ten of the period. It's entertaining if you ignore the music.

With next week bringing the 100th anniversary of John Ruskin's death, Clive Wilmer begins a two-part assessment of this strange Victorian critic and social reformer in Twenty Minutes (8.20pm, Radio 3). The first segment (the second comes tomorrow) surveys the two main themes of Ruskin's career - his architectural writings, in particular his love affair with Venice, and the deeply unpopular calls for wider social justice which he first aired in Thackeray's Cornhill Magazine.

fields.headline: They call it cupboard love
fields.trailText: Delia's How to Cook - Part Two | Summer In The Suburbs | The Krays | West Wing | Secrets Of The Stone Age
fields.body:
It is always summer through Delia's square window, though her bunch of anemones is from a fashionable florist. Her favourite word is lovely. Capers are lovely. Spring onions are lovely. It is all very lovely though there was the unfortunate occasion when the BBC dropped a portable toilet on her cat. Which expired. Delia's reaction was little less than saintly. After some thought, she said that it had had a good, long life. So have I, but the BBC would rue the day they dropped a loo on me. Delia is, one now sees clearly, a cat person. Or, rather, she was.

The subject of Delia's How to Cook - Part Two (BBC 2) was the contents of her store cupboard. Spices, sugars, sauces and, unexpectedly, an ample supply of booze. Marsala, Manzanilla, Famous Grouse whisky, brandy, rice wine ("This wine is made from rice", she explained kindly). I counted twelve bottles. A modest outlay if looked at with the eye of faith. "You're just using a little bit here and a little bit there", she explained, raising the substantial ghost of Two Ton Tessie O'Shea, who used to sing to a small banjo "There's a little bit here and a little bit there and it all belongs to me!"

What ordinary people keep in their store cupboard is, of course, a tin of rhubarb past its sell-by date and a packet of garlic breadsticks. Starving during the millennium celebrations, I was reduced to eating the garlic breadsticks. I couldn't face the rhubarb.

Delia is a sweet relief from Monday's relentless emphasis on crime. Hang about ITV on Monday, and you will be mugged. The best of the crime, if that is the way to put it, is The Vice (ITV) with the endearingly crumpled Inspector Pat Chappel (a particularly good performance from Ken Stott). He is ping-ponging up and down to Sheffield where men are blunt ("None 'o that bollocks up here!") and girls keep running away to London.

Then there was Summer In The Suburbs (BBC 2), a semi-detached tragedy by Tony Basgallop, which turned on the simple question, what would you do if you discovered that your young son had murdered a girl? James's family ran through all the options. Pretend it never happened, hit him, help him escape, turn him in. Everyone was initially so repellent you expected them to fly apart by the pure power of repulsion. But finally the family drew together as if magnetized and in an eerie scene - with the curtains drawn and the police at the door - sat down to a last supper.

Carlton crammed us like geese with crime. The Krays (ITV), continued tomorrow, dealt with the unpunished murder of Frank Mitchell, better known as the Mad Axemen. Mitchell was not mad. Unfortunately Ron Kray was. The Krays hired two hitmen to kill him, Frankie Foreman and Alfie Gerard (described as "A good man to have with you.") To work for the Krays your name had to end in ie. That's why there were so few Ruperts and Justins in the firm.

Foreman said Mitchell's murder was merciful and quick. His hoarse croak suggested a serious throat condition or over-fondness for Mafia movies. He was tried but not convicted because the jury did not believe Albert Donoghue, the boney Judas who led Mitchell to his death. Donoghue said it was slaughter. "Bang, bang! Ping, ping! I'd say there was 12 shots put in him. He groaned again. That's when Gerard said 'I'm empty. Give him another one.' So Foreman put the gun under his ear and bop!"

West Wing (Sky) is where the spin doctors do their spinning in the White House. This is serious comedy. When you laugh it is not at a joke, more with a little shock of joy. Like being in New York, you have to move up a couple of gears. It is very fast indeed. As the Chief of Staff (John Spencer) says when told it's a nice morning, "We'll take care of that in a hurry, won't we?" It starts with his long circuitous, all-talking, all-walking, tour-de-force arrival at the White House and ends with a deus ex machina descent by the president (Martin Sheen no less). Almost literally, as he has just fallen off his bicycle.

The chief press officer, passing this titbit to an appreciative press conference, said "By all means enjoy yourself." You can't fail to.

"It is an occupational hazard for archaeologists and anthropologists. They tend to see willies pretty much everywhere." Richard Rudgley in Secrets Of The Stone Age (Channel 4) Discuss with diagrams. You may use coloured crayons.
