What ordinary people keep in their store cupboard is, of course, a tin of rhubarb past its sell-by date and a packet of garlic breadsticks. Starving during the millennium celebrations, I was reduced to eating the garlic breadsticks. I couldn't face the rhubarb. Delia is a sweet relief from Monday's relentless emphasis on crime. Hang about ITV on Monday, and you will be mugged. The best of the crime, if that is the way to put it, is The Vice (ITV) with the endearingly crumpled Inspector Pat Chappel (a particularly good performance from Ken Stott). He is ping-ponging up and down to Sheffield where men are blunt ("None 'o that bollocks up here!") and girls keep running away to London. Then there was Summer In The Suburbs (BBC 2), a semi-detached tragedy by Tony Basgallop, which turned on the simple question, what would you do if you discovered that your young son had murdered a girl? James's family ran through all the options. Pretend it never happened, hit him, help him escape, turn him in. Everyone was initially so repellent you expected them to fly apart by the pure power of repulsion. But finally the family drew together as if magnetized and in an eerie scene - with the curtains drawn and the police at the door - sat down to a last supper. Carlton crammed us like geese with crime. The Krays (ITV), continued tomorrow, dealt with the unpunished murder of Frank Mitchell, better known as the Mad Axemen. Mitchell was not mad. Unfortunately Ron Kray was. The Krays hired two hitmen to kill him, Frankie Foreman and Alfie Gerard (described as "A good man to have with you.") To work for the Krays your name had to end in ie. That's why there were so few Ruperts and Justins in the firm. Foreman said Mitchell's murder was merciful and quick. His hoarse croak suggested a serious throat condition or over-fondness for Mafia movies. He was tried but not convicted because the jury did not believe Albert Donoghue, the boney Judas who led Mitchell to his death. Donoghue said it was slaughter. "Bang, bang! Ping, ping! I'd say there was 12 shots put in him. He groaned again. That's when Gerard said 'I'm empty. Give him another one.' So Foreman put the gun under his ear and bop!" West Wing (Sky) is where the spin doctors do their spinning in the White House. This is serious comedy. When you laugh it is not at a joke, more with a little shock of joy. Like being in New York, you have to move up a couple of gears. It is very fast indeed. As the Chief of Staff (John Spencer) says when told it's a nice morning, "We'll take care of that in a hurry, won't we?" It starts with his long circuitous, all-talking, all-walking, tour-de-force arrival at the White House and ends with a deus ex machina descent by the president (Martin Sheen no less). Almost literally, as he has just fallen off his bicycle. The chief press officer, passing this titbit to an appreciative press conference, said "By all means enjoy yourself." You can't fail to. "It is an occupational hazard for archaeologists and anthropologists. They tend to see willies pretty much everywhere." Richard Rudgley in Secrets Of The Stone Age (Channel 4) Discuss with diagrams. You may use coloured crayons.

webTitle: Tory bid to spoil defector's big day backfires

fields.headline: Tory bid to spoil defector's big day backfires
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: An attempt by the Conservative leadership to tarnish the name of Shaun Woodward backfired last night when he released a secret Tory document which accused Margaret Thatcher of destroying the national health service.
fields.body:
An attempt by the Conservative leadership to tarnish the name of Shaun Woodward backfired last night when he released a secret Tory document which accused Margaret Thatcher of destroying the national health service.

The former Tory director of communications, who defected to Labour last month, opened his files after Conservative central office released an edited version of his 1992 general election "war book" which described Neil Kinnock as having an "evil temper".

The Tory vice-chairman, Tim Collins, sent the document to Labour constituency chairmen across Britain in an attempt to block Mr Woodward's chances of securing a safe Labour seat at the next election. But Mr Woodward immediately pointed out that the document, which assessed the strengths and weaknesses of the main political parties, contained much more damaging details about the Tories.

The document, drawn up by the Tories' advertising agency Saatchi and Saatchi before the 1992 election, said the party was vulnerable to Labour attacks that it had destroyed the NHS since its election.

The document also said Labour would win votes by claiming that Tories did not care about children or educational standards.

Mr Woodward, who took his seat as a Labour MP yesterday, said he had planned to keep the document secret, but he would now pass it to Labour's Millbank headquarters because of the "extreme foolishness" of Mr Collins in leaking edited highlights.

"This reveals a lack of judgment which is all about short term political gain, rather than what is in the interests of a determined opposition," Mr Woodward said.

Mr Collins, who served under Mr Woodward as a press officer in 1992, had hoped to restore his reputation by unearthing the "war book". The document said Mr Kinnock had an "evil temper" and that his "understanding of economic policy is nil".

After Mr Woodward's retaliation, however, questions were once again being raised about Mr Collins's judgment.

Last month he came close to being fired when it emerged he had orchestrated attacks on Steven Norris which briefly blocked the ex-minister's bid to become London mayor.

The row over the "war book" came after Mr Woodward was given a distinctly lukewarm reception in the Commons by Labour traditionalists such as Tony Benn and Jeremy Corbyn, who described him as a "fair weather friend".

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Terrestrial
fields.body:
Driving Mum Crazy 8.30pm, C5

Children with Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder have been getting a lot of attention recently, and this three-part documentary shows more youngsters whose severely disruptive behaviour is due to physical causes. A five-year-old girl has been finally diagnosed with ADHD, and appears to be the bane of her mother's and four siblings' lives. Mother Louise has doubts about putting her on the prescribed drug Ritalin, but the terrifying bundle of vicious energy is anything but doped up when she's on medication. C4's recent Kid In The Corner drama was frighteningly realistic, but this is the real thing.

Behind The Crime 9pm, C4

Yes, another series on crime and its many perpetrators, but this four-part series takes a more low-key approach. For the most part, the criminals speak for themselves and almost all agree on the most incredible adrenalin rush they get from getting something for nothing. Which makes it rather difficult for them to stop, even after repeated spells in prison. (One describes an open prison as a hotel, so there's your deterrent.) The series opener focuses on car crime, and all the thieves chorus that it is ridiculously easy. Whatever the manufacturers come up with to deter theft, the thieves are just half a step behind to thwart them. See page 17.

Victoria's Secrets 10pm, C4

Victoria Beckham seems to have everything most people would want, and now she has a one-off chat show to boot. It helps that she is given guests who are either friends or acquaintances (and, in one case, her husband), but even this isn't enough to make riveting viewing of her vacuous and inarticulate questioning. Elton John offhandedly provides some comic relief when he naughtily asks her what she thinks of Geri Halliwell's album, and leaves her completely stumped. But at least she exhibits a healthy sense of self-mockery, a saving grace in an hour of sub-OK! TV.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Satellite, cable and digital
fields.body:
Godzilla (Roland Emmerich, 1998) 12noon, 8pm, Sky Premier

Tokyo's favourite monster takes a tour of Manhattan in Emmerich's disappointing follow-up to Independence Day. State-of-the-art computer generated effects convey the beast's colossal size - provided it's raining, or at night; the story is lame (the military loses the monster? Huh?), and most of the humans - Matthew Broderick's dopey scientist, Maria Pitillo's newshound, Hank Azaria's irksome cameraman - are in urgent need of squashing. But it makes a fine and funny job of trashing New York, and the chase through a stadium full of hatching lizards, with steady Jean Reno leading the way, is thrilling.

The Naked City (Jules Dassin, 1948) 12.30pm, Carlton Cinema

"There are eight million stories in the naked city..." goes the famous closing line of this seminal police procedural thriller. Dassin focuses on just one of the stories, with veteran cop Barry Fitzgerald and rookie Don Taylor hunting the killer (nasty Ted de Corsia) of the blonde in the bath. The detailed depiction of everyday police footwork grows a little humdrum, but it's a fascinating picture of postwar New York, from backstreets to Broadway.

Exotica (Atom Egoyan, 1994) 10.30pm, FilmFour

Another Egoyan study of bruised and puzzled souls, here laid bare at the Exotica strip joint. It's run by the pregnant Arsinée Khanjian; a dancer, a DJ a taxman, and a petshop owner experience varieties of desire, while a Leonard Cohen soundtrack sets the sombre and intense tone.

fields.headline: And they're off
fields.standfirst: They're geezers, they're a bit tasty and they'll nick anything. Career criminals are the compelling subject of a new documentary series by Channel 4, but aren't its makers worried they'll corrupt the nation's youth? By  Mark Morris
fields.trailText: They're geezers, they're a bit tasty and they'll nick anything. Career criminals are the compelling subject of a new documentary series by Channel 4, but aren't its makers worried they'll corrupt the nation's youth? By Mark Morris
fields.body:
Hey, kids, want to know how to steal a car without breaking any windows? How to drive it away without leaving any fingerprints? Want to know how to empty a pay phone without setting off the alarm? Or how to get that diamond ring you've swallowed in the shop out of your system? (Here's the advice of a blowsy old jewel thief: "Just drink a bottle of olive oil, and leave it to nature to get out at the other end - bit messy, but a nice few quid at the end of the day.") These nuggets come from the second episode of Behind The Crime, a four-part series that starts tonight (Channel 4, 9pm) and claims to take us into the lives of the everyday folk who take your car or break into your home. Along the way, they happen to tell you how they make off with a motor or the family silver.

Series producer Alex Sutherland is relaxed about the risk of corrupting the nation's youth. "For legal reasons," she remarks, "we had to remove crucial elements of the actual detail. We weren't able to do just a how-to video manual of getting into a car or stealing money from a telephone box. There is no way a viewer can freeze-frame it and know how to do it. And for the most part, our criminals had some skills to their operations - not anyone could do what they do." Maybe not, although a sharp-eyed practising thief might pick up a few advanced techniques from the programme. But Channel 4 is protected by the same British logic that means you can have erect penises in arthouse films like The Idiots, but not in porn: no need to be alarmed, only the educated middle classes are watching.

There is a lot that is good about Behind The Crime. Just getting this many - three per programme - working or recently retired, non-celebrity criminals on camera is an impressive journalistic feat. It is free from annoying silhouettes, desperately unconvincing disguises and distorted voices: instead we get the lawbreakers openly talking from their living rooms. And there's even some pure comedy: at one stage, the camera follows two phone-box thieves going into a police station to reclaim £1,000 worth of loose change from the police because they hadn't technically been charged with stealing it.

When Sutherland talks about the programmes, she could be one of those unfairly maligned 70s sociology researchers. Her aim is to help us understand the criminals: "It's not that we didn't take a view - its nonsense to say television doesn't take a view - but what we didn't want to do was to see our contributors through the eyes of the police. We wanted them to talk about what they do, and how they justify what they do."

"You see a lot of crime programmes", she continues, "where you've got CCTV pictures of blobs and fuzzy people nicking things from shops, and you rarely get an insight into seeing what those people are."

"It may be uncomfortable for people to realise it, but those people who you see on those fuzzy TV screens are people who have families, have lives. They are people who go around and do normal things. In a sense, it is a more rounded picture of them."

And no, they didn't pay the interviewees anything, which is certainly consistent with the programme's line that crime doesn't pay. "How much did you make in your career?" one car thief is asked. "Hundred grand", he says, plucking a number from the air. "18 years for a 100 grand? It's not a lot!" comes an appalled voice from off camera.

But before you get to that, you've had to withstand a portentous announcement that "Every minute, every day, a car is stolen...", setting the mood for an endless series of supposedly ominous reconstructions. These range from the comically inept - a man with an infrared camera stumbling around a house in the second episode - to those all-too-precise technique lessons which have nothing to do with finding out what makes someone steal and everything to do with illicit kicks for ABC1 viewers.

"Channel 4 were very keen on us showing in detail what the criminals did", Sutherland says. "If we were to interview someone who was an architect you would spend a lot of time interviewing them in their office, interviewing them at their draft board and going out on a site. So there is a legitimacy in looking at what people do, and how they do it." Well, I'm not sure how Richard Rogers designs his buildings, but I'm now conversant with the basics of stripping a car down for parts, because in the, frankly deranged, climax to the first episode is a Rover hacked to pieces for the benefit of the programme makers.

"It wasn't a very good Rover", Sutherland protests. Maybe so. But it certainly makes you think that quick thrills were at least equal to sober minded social investigation in Channel 4's motives for commissioning the series. Or maybe it just looks like that because tonight on BBC1 there is the unambiguously titled Burgled (10.45pm), which is also hoping to let you know about the human being who nicked your video. And maybe - bearing in mind that Sutherland seems open and sincere, and the interviews are good - Behind The Crime looks more suspect than it should because of the Channel 4 effect. Only a week after the hugely tacky Coked Up series, those commissioning editors were already ready for another criminally minded fix. A case for the short sharp shock?

webTitle: Labour will not cap anti-euro spending

fields.headline: Labour will not cap anti-euro spending
fields.trailText: Plans by Euro-sceptic campaigner Paul Sykes to spend up to £23.5m to persuade people to keep the pound will not be stopped by new controls on referendum funding,  Jack Straw, the home secretary, said last night.
fields.body:
Plans by Euro-sceptic campaigner Paul Sykes to spend up to £23.5m to persuade people to keep the pound will not be stopped by new controls on referendum funding, Jack Straw, the home secretary, said last night.

He rejected a call from Denis MacShane, Labour MP for Rotherham, for tougher controls to stop anti-euro campaigners using tens of millions of pounds in advertising years ahead of the government's referendum on the single currency. Mr Straw was speaking during the second reading of the political parties, elections and referendums bill which introduces curbs on spending by political parties and on future referendums on proportional representation and the euro.

The home secretary said the aim was to end "the arms race" between political parties which had seen election spending by each party jump from £5m a year in 1983 to an expected £30m each by the next election. The bill also caps spending by rival organisations fighting yes and no campaigns during the six-month period before referendums. But he ruled out any further controls in the run-up to the election. Mr Straw told MPs: "At the heart of this bill's provisions is the need to ensure that the funding of political parties is open and transparent." He added that the "secrecy which has hitherto been permitted political parties in their funding and the scandals which such secrecy has given rise to in recent years has undoubtedly left a sour taste".

The shadow Commons leader, Sir George Young, said the government was on the "thinnest ice" over the proposals on funding of referendums campaigns. He said: "If there are to be limits, they should surely apply to each side of the argument, rather than to individual political parties whose members may well be on both sides of the argument." Under the bill, spending permitted by parties in referendums is linked to their votes share at the previous general election. This has sparked concern by opponents of entry into the European single currency that pro-euro parties would be able to spend more than their opponents.

Robert Maclennan, for the Liberal Democrats, was concerned that the bill included no absolute limit on political donations by individuals. "So long as those very large sums of money are donated by powerful industrial figures then the public will be extremely suspicious about what they're getting in return."

webTitle: Backlash over Straw veto on release of information

fields.headline: Backlash over Straw veto on release of information
fields.standfirst: Freedom of information: special report
fields.trailText: The home secretary, Jack Straw, waded into a fresh bout of controversy over his much-criticised freedom of information bill yesterday when it emerged he had given himself a new veto to ban the release of any public documents.
fields.body:
The home secretary, Jack Straw, waded into a fresh bout of controversy over his much-criticised freedom of information bill yesterday when it emerged he had given himself a new veto to ban the release of any public documents.

The proposal, which was put into the bill without consulting Parliament, united in opposition Labour rebel MPs, Liberal Democrats and Conservatives on the eve of the measures facing scrutiny in the Commons. The bill was already certain to face a rough ride through Parliament because Mr Straw had blocked reforms to allow the new information commissioner power to override ministers to order publication of contentious information and insisted on wide-ranging exclusions to the release of documents, particularly in policy-making areas.

Mark Fisher, the former arts minister sacked by Tony Blair in his first reshuffle, said yesterday: "This proposal is an extraordinarily huge loophole. It basically allows Jack Straw to put a razor through the whole bill by removing access to any piece of information from the public domain by parliamentary order."

The loophole was only spotted by campaigners and MPs last week when they realised the home secretary had inserted the new powers when he revised the bill before Christmas. The clause says the home secretary may by order limit the release of information by any government department, the Houses of Parliament, Northern Ireland assembly, the Welsh assembly and the armed forces.

Maurice Frankel, director of the Campaign for Freedom of Information, said: "This is an outrageous measure which could allow Jack Straw in theory to reduce the information by any government to just a public inquiry number. It is also giving the same power to any successor government."

MPs are particularly angry that Mr Straw is proposing to use an arcane parliamentary procedure called "a negative resolution" to obtain these powers. This will allow him to ban release of any particular piece of information through an obscure parliamentary order which will become law if it is not spotted by the opposition within 28 days.

The proposals have angered the Liberal Democrats and Robert Maclennan, MP for Caithness, Sutherland and Easter Ross, and David Heath, MP for Somerton and Frome, have tabled an amendment deleting the proposal.

Mr Maclennan said last night: "This amounts to a dispensing clause. It basically says we shall apply the law, except when Jack Straw says so. This seems to be based on excessive caution."

Ann Widdecombe, the shadow home secretary, has also sought to ban the move apart from in cases when a block can be said to be against the public interest.

The home office claimed the new clause was necessary to modernise government legislation. A spokeswoman said: "If a future home secretary used this clause to try to wipe out large sections of the bill I don't think the parliamentary authorities would stand for it."

fields.headline: Sir Leon Radzinowicz
fields.trailText: In raising the question of why London university failed to establish the first institute of criminology, Terence Morris, in his obituary of Sir Leon Radzinowicz (January 1) suggests some chicanery in which Radzinowicz must have played a part.
fields.body:
In raising the question of why London university failed to establish the first institute of criminology, Terence Morris, in his obituary of Sir Leon Radzinowicz (January 1) suggests some chicanery in which Radzinowicz must have played a part. The published home office papers clearly show that London rejected the proposal outright because Hermann Mannheim had already retired and no one in the university had the requisite skills and outstanding personality to lead such a venture. Radzinowicz was the only criminologist in England who had such qualities, and the Cambridge department of criminal science was the only base from which an institute could be developed.

Professor Morris gives credence to the view that "the greater part" of particular volumes of Radzinowicz's massive and outstanding History of the English Criminal Law was written by his co-workers. Of course he had help in drafting, checking and editing this vast work, but, as joint author of volume five of the History, I can testify to his absorption in the work, encyclopaedic knowledge, brilliance in composition, and attention to every word. To imply some kind of absentee editorship is a travesty to the memory of a great scholar.

There is a veiled suggestion that a desire to forge good relations with home office officials is the reason why Radzinowicz's committee favoured dispersing high-risk prisoners rather than concentrating them in one prison as Lord Mountbatten had suggested. Furthermore, that it must have troubled him to go against Mountbatten "since he was totally sycophantic about royalty". This is a smear on a man who was totally convinced that whatever the disadvantages of dispersing high-risk prisoners around a few prisons, it was preferable to the Mountbatten alternative of bottling them up in an "Alcatraz". His judgment remained fiercely independent, devoted to a liberal conception of penal policy, whatever the home office views might have been.

Radzinowicz was the first to acknowledge that he could be a "difficult man" and that, in his determination to build up the Cambridge Institute within a few years into an international centre of excellence, he had been "rough and tough". But he had also been "rough and tough" on himself. He worked with prodigious energy and demanded from his colleagues the same dedication. It is hardly surprising that they felt the stress. But nearly all of them admired his intellectual vitality and came to recognise that he had galvanised them to play a part in a remarkable achievement. Twenty-eight former colleagues, pupils and admirers contributed to his festschrift in 1974. Aged 87, his address to the British Criminology Conference received a standing ovation.

He could be demanding - but he was also charming, witty, generous, loyal, an extraordinary judge of character and brilliant company. Life with Sir Leon was never dull.

fields.headline: Sir Arnold Hall
fields.standfirst: A talented engineer whose short break from academia turned into a glittering career at the heart of British aviation
fields.trailText: A talented engineer whose short break from academia turned into a glittering career at the heart of British aviation.
fields.body:
World famous for his investigation in the mid-1950s of the mysterious and catastrophic crashes of De Havilland Comet 1 jet airliners, Sir Arnold Hall has died aged 84. The brilliant aeronautical engineer, scientist and industrialist designed the compressor for Frank Whittle's first jet engine, shaped the gyroscopic gun-sights in D-day fighter aircraft, defended the aerospace industry against nationalisation and built the giant Hawker Siddeley Group.

Hall's Comet investigation brought new technical profundity to complex failure analysis and is still seen as the model for major aviation inquiries. It revealed the scale of his reach as a scientist and administrator, and his calmness in crisis.

When the first passenger-service Comet took off from Heathrow on May 2 1952, Britain's aviation industry and its major operator, the British Overseas Airways Corporation, led the world into the era of high-altitude, high-speed civil jet flight. After De Havilland's costly and seemingly exhaustive test programmes, the world's most advanced and elegant passenger aircraft appeared to be as safe and sound as prudent engineering could make it. Orders flooded in.

In those grey post-war years, the Comet 1 was a symbol of confidence and national recovery, a harbinger of future successes for British industry and enterprise in a new and hard world. But after only two years in commercial service, three Comets failed catastrophically in flight - the last one only a few days after a normal but very costly investigation into the second accident had given the aircraft the all-clear. There was despair in industry and near-panic in government.

All Comets were grounded, all contracts were put on hold and the nation, already mourning the dead of the accidents, went into mourning for itself. At this crucial time Hall, then the youngest-ever director of the Royal Aircraft Establishment at Farnborough, was approached by the government for advice. Experts in industry and conventional investigations could produce no explanation: there were suggestions of terrorist bombs and unknown high-altitude atmospheric phenomena. Neither Lennox Boyd (miniser of transport and civil aviation) nor Duncan Sandys (supply) knew what to do or how to save British aviation prestige.

Hall's response was decisive. The industry could not be left floundering in the face of huge investigation costs, nor could the mystery be left unsolved. However unpalatable the idea was to government, the Farnborough teams had to be brought in to carry out an independent investigation of all possible causes - a huge open-ended requirement. Within a couple of days, Sandys gave the go-ahead and, within weeks, Hall had decided that some crucial stress calculations were of such complexity that mathematical theory alone could not be relied upon to provide answers.

Hall promptly built Farnborough's famous "whole pressurised aircraft" test rig, in which the stresses of flight cycles could be simulated rapidly many thousands of times on a complete aircraft. The outcome, clinched by early and massive failure of the test aircraft's pressurised cabin, explained the catastrophes, provided new knowledge of aluminium alloys under repeated stress, gave new meaning to the concept of "fatigue life", and revealed the unexpected inadequacy of conventional and hitherto highly trusted methods of stress testing and analysis.

Within two years, these findings led to the modified and very successful De Havil land Comet 4; but by then the US, and to a lesser extent France, had caught up with the British aircraft industry and the world market slipped away. For Hall, this period at Farnborough, during which he had expanded its activities, forged strong links with research establishments in Europe and the US and received a knighthood (aged just 39), was a major turning point.

He was by choice an academic; now Whitehall wanted him to stay. Instead, when his Farnborough agreement came to an end in 1955, he moved into industry, first as technical director of the Hawker Siddeley Group, then as managing director of the new group member Bristol Siddeley Engines and, later still, as vice-chairman and chairman of the entire group. In 1962 he chaired an Anglo-French Concorde design group then, in the costly wake of cancellation of three of Hawker's military aircraft projects and under growing political pressure for nationalisation of the aircraft industry, Hall broadened the base of the group so that aircraft and engines were no longer dominant. "I felt a great responsibility to the companies we had taken over and to the people we employed. I did what I could to protect them," Hall recalled.

By the mid-1970s, when the Hawker Siddeley Group employed about 85,000 people, 50,000 were engaged in electrical and other forms of civil engineering. Hall, driven by the spirit of private enterprise and professional responsibility which he saw as essential to the creation of an effective industrial base, was vigorously and openly hostile to the government's nationalisation proposals. When the axe fell in 1977 (by a single vote in the Commons), Hall left the aircraft industry for good.

To some this was surprising, for he was very much one of CP Snow's "new men of industry" - men who, themselves technically expert, accelerated the decision-making process by downward diffusion to other experts in specific fields, and evolved a formula particularly suited to shaping high-technology projects. Hall's decision to keep Hawker in the eventually highly successful A300 (European Airbus) project after the British government had pulled out emphasised his gifts and made the government look very slow-witted.

Speculation that Hall would or could be appointed as supremo of the nationalised aircraft and shipbuilding industries was misplaced, for he was neither temperamentally nor politically acceptable. When appointed Businessman of the Year in 1975 for his "vision, courage and commercial discipline" in turning Hawker Siddeley into one of the world's most efficient industries, he said flatly that he wanted no part in any nationalisation programme. When he later spoke of being "deeply saddened" by the enforced takeover of a third of his industrial group, he was perhaps making the understatement of the century.

Hall retired in 1986, but continued to keep in touch with his scientific specialities through the Royal Society (fellow, 1953) and the Royal Aeronautical Society, of which he was president 1958-59.

His flexibility and enormous breadth of grasp are revealed by the fact that not only was he a brilliant success in the very different worlds of academic research, government laboratory administration, high-tech management and industrial development, but he was also a Whitehall insider and adviser in whom Lord Zuckerman, as chief government scientist, declared great trust.

Born in Liverpool to parents who had left school at 12, Arnold Hall grew up during the depression. Many of his older relatives were involved in maritime activities, but his father was an upholsterer and his mother a brilliant self-taught pianist. "My mother tried to teach me, but I'm afraid I was something of a disappointment to her. My interests were always in engineering and science," Hall recalled. "I was too busy making steam engines and other gadgets."

His mathematical gifts and his potential in science and engineering emerged clearly at Alsop High School at Walton, then an all-boys school, to which he won a scholarship. Sheer brilliance took him to Clare College, Cambridge, where, in addition to a first, he won the Moir Prize in Engineering, the Seely Prize in Aeronautics and the Ricardo Prize in Thermodynamics. On a post-graduate fellowship he worked with Frank Whittle and carried out the compressor stress calculations for Whittle's jet engine, the first in the world to run (April 1937), now in the Science Museum in London.

In 1938, Hall joined the Royal Aircraft Establishment where, during the war, he led the teams that produced both the advanced bomb-sight and the gyro gun-sight which, from D-Day onward, more than doubled the kill rate of Allied fighter aircraft. In 1945 he was appointed professor of aviation at the University of London and head of the department of aeronautics at Imperial College. In 1951, when his post-war academic research programme was just getting into its stride, the death of the Farnborough director and fears of the escalation of the Korean war prompted the government to ask him to take over.

The deal was that he would do this for five years and then return to academic life. Instead, Farnborough became an unexpected springboard for a triumphant international industrial career. Although his own flexibility was clear, one of his deep lifelong concerns was the need for breadth and flexibility in technical education.

This was expressed practically through his involvement in the initiation of Warwick university, where he served as pro-chancellor from 1965 to 1970, and by his long spell as chancellor of the Loughborough University of Technology 1980-89.

He appeared to have no recreations, no passions, but in fact there were two: his family and deep-sea sailing. Late in life, when he had given up sailing, Hall said it was his great good fortune to have been blessed by a family who "always put up with my eccentricities and were never too harsh when I made mistakes". For this quiet giant who was usually right, their support was crucial.

He is survived by his second wife Iola; three daughters from his first marriage; a stepdaughter and stepson from his first wife's first marriage; and three stepsons and five stepdaughters from his second wife's first marriage.

Sir Arnold Alexander Hall, aeronautical engineer, scientist and industrialist; born April 23 1915; died January 9 2000

webTitle: Southerners rally round 'racist' confederate flag to keep stars and bars

fields.headline: Southerners rally round 'racist' confederate flag to keep stars and bars
fields.trailText: The southern state in which America's civil war began 139 years ago will start its annual legislative session today amid the biggest confrontation for years over the continuing use of the confederate stars and bars flag.
fields.body:
The southern state in which America's civil war began 139 years ago will start its annual legislative session today amid the biggest confrontation for years over the continuing use of the confederate stars and bars flag.

South Carolina, where the first shots of rebellion were fired in April 1861, is the only one of the 50 united states still to fly the flag of the pro-slavery Confederacy from the top of its state legislature building. And thousands of white confederate supporters who rallied in its shadow in Columbia, the state capital, at the weekend intend to keep it that way.

The flag issue is becoming an increasingly emotive political flashpoint, with inescapable racial overtones.

The National Association for the Advancement of Coloured People (NAACP) has called for South Carolina to be subjected to the kind of economic boycott that was so effective during the civil rights campaigns in the racially segregated south in the 1960s.

An NAACP parade and rally is scheduled for Columbia on Monday, Martin Luther King Day.

"There is a clear right side in this debate," said the South Carolina NAACP executive director, Dwight James, who believes that the flag is an insulting symbol of the south's slave-owning past. "I clearly believe the flag has no legitimate place on the statehouse grounds."

On Saturday, an estimated 7,000 pro-flag supporters - many of them in 19th century costume - rallied at Columbia's confederate cemetery before parading to the sounds of Dixie and other "Rebel" marches to the statehouse.

"If any house or senate members vote to bring down this flag, will you work to destroy them?" Ron Wilson of the Sons of Confederate Veterans (SCV) asked the crowd. "Yes," shouted back the crowd.

Their threat is a real one, as the former South Carolina Republican governor David Beasley discovered in 1998 when he was defeated after saying that he thought the flag should come down.

So-called "southern heritage" groups are threatening to do the same thing to his successor, Democrat Jim Hodges, who has been holding private talks to try to find a compromise on the issue.

"He had better enjoy the next two years and 10 months," Ron Russell of the SCV told Saturday's rally. "Because that's all he's got."

The confederate flag has only flown from the South Carolina statehouse since 1962, when it was hoisted as part of a civil war centennial.

David Smith, a black observer of the parade, said: "The old south is gone. It's not coming back. This is the last symbol of the old south. Until it comes down, we will not go forward."

The argument has also embroiled this year's presidential election candidates. On February 19, the state holds the second primary in this year's election cycle, following New Hampshire on February 1.

The Republican frontrunner in the state, George W Bush, the governor of Texas, also a former confederate state, says that the issue is one for "the people of South Carolina to figure out".

His chief rival, Senator John McCain, takes the same position but is far more critical. "The confederate flag is offensive in many, many ways, as we all know. It's a symbol of racism and slavery," Mr McCain said in an interview on Sunday.

Remnants of Confederacy

Stars and bars flag Flies over South Carolina statehouse and part of state flags of Mississippi and Georgia

Robert E Lee Statue of the general stands outside Virginia statehouse in Richmond, former capital of the Confederacy

Dixie

Alabama uses phrase 'Heart of Dixie' on vehicle licence plates

His chief rival, Senator John McCain, takes the same position but is far more critical. "The confederate flag is offensive in many, many ways, as we all know. webTitle: Britain defends visit by Iranian minister

fields.headline: Britain defends visit by Iranian minister
fields.standfirst: More about Iran
fields.trailText: The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, yesterday pressed Iran to take a less hostile approach to the Middle East peace process during the first visit to Britain by a senior Iranian minister since the revolution 20 years ago.
fields.body:
The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, yesterday pressed Iran to take a less hostile approach to the Middle East peace process during the first visit to Britain by a senior Iranian minister since the revolution 20 years ago.

The arrival of Kamal Kharrazi, the Iranian foreign minister, was met with protests by Jewish groups and Iranian dissidents.

Iran caused consternation at the end of last month in Israel - a sometime ally - when it suddenly adopted a strident tone, with one leader calling for the state's eradication.

Mr Kharrazi met Tony Blair at Downing Street before two hours of talks with Mr Cook.

The visit is part of a gradual restoration in relations between the two countries, and could eventually pave the way for the reopening of links between the US and Iran.

The improvement in British-Iranian relations began two years ago when the Iranian government distanced itself from the clerical fatwa issued against the British author Salman Rushdie in 1989 for alleged blasphemous writing.

But US sources claim Iran has stepped up arms and funds to groups such as Hizbullah, which is fighting in southern Lebanon, and a se nior foreign office spokesman confirmed that there were continued contacts between Iran and groups violently opposed to the Middle East peace process.

The foreign office spokesman defended the British-Iran link, saying: "We think it is better to put our views across than cut them off." He added that recent hardline rhetoric against Israel had to be seen in the context of the Iranian elections, in six weeks' time.

Mr Cook, who negotiated with Iran in 1998 to get the government to distance itself from the fatwa, raised the issue of Mr Rushdie at yesterday's meeting. The foreign secretary has been criticised for failing to win a commitment to suppress organisations inside Iran still offering a bounty for the author's assassination.

Mr Cook also pressed Mr Kharrazi to ensure a fair trial for a group of Jewish and Muslim Iranians alleged to have spied for Israel.

The president of the Board of Deputies of British Jews, Eldred Tabachnik, yesterday expressed concern about the 13 Iranian Jews in detention: "No charges have been proferred and they have, nonetheless, been held for almost a year."

Mr Blair's spokesman said yesterday's visit should not be interpreted as a sign that Britain endorsed everything going on inside Iran.

webTitle: Former governor on trial for corruption

fields.headline: Former governor on trial for corruption
fields.trailText: One of the most colourful figures in 20th century Louisiana politics went on trial for corruption yesterday, amid prosecution hopes that it would be third time unlucky for the former state governor, Edwin Edwards.
fields.body:
One of the most colourful figures in 20th century Louisiana politics went on trial for corruption yesterday, amid prosecution hopes that it would be third time unlucky for the former state governor, Edwin Edwards.

The swashbuckling Mr Edwards, 72, the only man to serve four terms as Louisiana governor, is charged with manipulating the sale of Mississippi riverboat casino licences and accepting pay-offs from friends and cronies who wanted a slice of the state's lucrative gambling market.

Mr Edwards faced two trials in Louisiana in the 1980s, when he was charged with racketeering over hospital and nursing home contracts. Though he admitted to making more than $2m (£1.2m) in the deal, the first case ended in deadlock and he was acquitted by a jury at the retrial.

This time, however, the Cajun-born politician faces a combination of firepower which not even his legendary skills may be able to resist.

The FBI has amassed more than 24,000 hours of tapes covering 918 of Mr Edwards's telephone conversations. Prosecutors will call as witnesses three former associates who have already pleaded guilty in the case, including the ex-owner of the San Francisco 49ers football team, Eddie DeBartolo.

Mr DeBartolo is expected to testify that he gave Mr Edwards a briefcase containing $400,000 (£244,000) in used notes after Mr Edwards warned him that his application for a casino licence would otherwise be at risk.

If convicted, Mr Edwards faces up to 350 years in prison and $7.2m (£4.4m) in fines. But he said when he was indicted: "I can truthfully say if my sentence is 350 years, I don't intend to serve."

"The gambling case has electronic evidence which we did not have," says John Volz, who prosecuted Mr Edwards in the earlier cases. "It changes the whole complexion of the trial."

Mr Edwards was the most powerful politician in the state since the legendary 1930s governor Huey Long. Ever since he was charged in the riverboat casino investigation, he has waged a high-profile campaign proclaiming his innocence.

Mr Volz is taking nothing for granted. "I wouldn't predict the outcome, especially when Edwin Edwards is on trial," he said. "He is a unique individual. He has a constituency in this state that wouldn't convict him no matter what the government proves."

Jury selection began yesterday. Arriving at the court in Baton Rouge, Mr Edwards said he was unable to comment on the case but was "very, very pleased at the encouragements, support and prayers from family and friends".

webTitle: Spread of Aids linked to security

fields.headline: Spread of Aids linked to security
fields.trailText: The UN security council for the first time debated health as a security issue yesterday with a US-led initiative to focus on Aids in Africa.
fields.body:
The UN security council for the first time debated health as a security issue yesterday with a US-led initiative to focus on Aids in Africa.

The US vice-president, Al Gore, outlined new proposals to combat the worldwide Aids epidemic, including $150m (£91.5m) for vaccine research, prevention programmes and new education campaigns in Africa.

Mr Gore said governments must consider the epidemic a true threat to peace in Africa and make it a priority on the world's security agenda.

Aids killed 10 times as many Africans as did wars in 1998, according to the UN's statistics. Two million people died of the disease last year - and the toll is accelerating.

The US ambassador to the UN, Richard Holbrooke, said the meeting was intended to "begin to redefine security as broader in the post-cold war era than it used to be".

The UN secretary-general, Kofi Annan, said the high death rate from Aids among Africa's elites threatenened the stability of governments and the security of some countries, because so many among the police and military are infected. He said Aids not only contributed to wars, but was spread by them.

Mr Annan is pressing for a strategy to reduce infection rates by a quarter among 15- to 24-year-olds in the next five years.

webTitle: Sectarian mobs slaughtering villagers in eastern Indonesia

fields.headline: Sectarian mobs slaughtering villagers in eastern Indonesia
fields.trailText: Sectarian fighting between Christians and Muslims is intensifying in Indonesia's eastern islands and spreading to other areas of the country.
fields.byline: John Aglionby  in  Masohi on Seram island, the Moluccas
fields.body:
Sectarian fighting between Christians and Muslims is intensifying in Indonesia's eastern islands and spreading to other areas of the country.

The latest island to explode is Seram, a jungle-covered wilderness 20 miles north-east of Ambon, the provincial capital of the Moluccas group. Fifty people are feared dead in two days of fighting.

On Halmahera island, in the north of the Moluccas, workers from a local Muslim aid group said yesterday they were burying hundreds of Muslim corpses, the victims of recent attacks by Christians.

"It is very difficult to count the bodies ... [they] were torched and burned by unidentified people," said Mursal Amal Tomagola of the Medical Emergency aid group.

"We found most of the bodies inside mosques that were also burned." The dead could run into thousands, he claimed.

Deadly clashes have also been reported in south Sulawesi, several hundred miles south-west of Ambon. Local authorities deny any link with the Moluccas violence but community leaders warn it could be the start of a nationwide conflict.

On Seram yesterday morning a Muslim mob attacked a Christian community on the north coast, killing at least a dozen people.

Shortly afterwards, dozens of Muslims wiped out the village of Kilo 10, named after its distance from the island's main town of Masohi. The Muslim area of the town stood between the burning buildings and those who wanted help in the Christian quarter.

"We wouldn't get 100 metres if we tried to get through," said Roxy, nervously holding his hands as if in prayer. "They would just kill us all."

At least half a dozen residents were killed as they tried to defend their homes in the ensuing battle. It is not known how many Muslims died but the figure is likely to be much higher.

"Whenever they [the Muslims] have attacked us they've done it in big groups which we have found easy to mow down," said Johnny, a member of Nusa Laut (land and sea), the "elite" Christian force in Seram. "They usually succeed in their aim but at a great cost."

The fighting continued into yesterday as the Muslims retreated and got caught in a flanking counter-attack by Christians operating out of Masohi. Skirmishes were also reported in several other parts of the island as people fled to seek safety in religious centres, police stations and army bases that quickly turned into refugee camps.

Until last month, Seram had remained largely unaffected by the year-long sectarian conflict that has torn the little archipelago of hundreds of islands to pieces.

Now it is one of the two main battlegrounds in the spiralling revenge war. As reports filter through from Halmahera about Christian attacks on Muslims, so Muslims on Seram seem to respond in kind.

About 200 people have been killed on Seram in the last two weeks. More than 1,300 Christians were evacuated yesterday from the remote town of Tehoru on the south coast.

"There's nothing else we can do but get them out," said Reverend Marcus Saimima, the priest organising the evacuation.

Muslim villages have also been destroyed on Seram and some Christians proudly boast of slaughtering their enemies.

Caught in the middle is the Indonesian military. "We just don't have enough troops," said the deputy commander, Major Wairata. "As events at Kilo 10 show, we can't even prevent all-out attacks on villages."

Tanks appeared in the Moluccas for the first time yesterday, rolling through Ambon in a show of force that aimed to stop the conflict spreading.

On the big island of Sulawesi, next to the Moluccas, local media reported yesterday that several people had died in three days of fighting between locals and migrants driven out of the Moluccas.

webTitle: Going nowhere - French lorry owners keep up roads protest

fields.headline: Going nowhere - French lorry owners keep up roads protest
fields.trailText: French hauliers decided last night to maintain their blocking of frontier posts, motorways and main roads today in protest at the price of fuel and the introduction of a 35-hour week.
fields.body:
French hauliers decided last night to maintain their blocking of frontier posts, motorways and main roads today in protest at the price of fuel and the introduction of a 35-hour week.

Border posts into Italy, Germany, Spain and Belgium were blocked as hundreds of trucks took part in the first day of action by lorry owners yesterday. Police warned that the situation would probably be worse today.

The worst chaos was in the north, where protesters disrupted traffic on the main routes south from the Channel ports by setting up roadblocks or driving at low speed in three lanes.

Access was left open to Calais and Boulogne, but truck owners made it difficult for cars to board the cross-Channel ferry at Le Havre.

The owners' spokesman, Stéphane Levesque, said a 35-hour week would put businesses "at a further disadvantage" compared with other EU countries.

But drivers' unions have told the transport minister, Jean-Claude Gayssot, that concessions over the 35-hour week would lead to a counter-strike by employees.

fields.headline: Genocide lawsuit against UN
fields.trailText: The families of two victims of the 1994 genocide in Rwanda are filing an unprecedented lawsuit against the United Nations accusing it of complicity in murder. The action is to be filed in the American courts.
fields.body:
The families of two victims of the 1994 genocide in Rwanda are filing an unprecedented lawsuit against the United Nations accusing it of complicity in murder. The action is to be filed in the American courts.

Two Rwandan women are claiming that UN soldiers handed their relatives to Hutu death squads, challenging the UN's immunity from legal accountability for the actions of its officials and peacekeepers.

Anonciata Kavaruganda - whose husband was a senior legal official - alleges that Ghanaian peacekeepers assigned to protect her family were drinking with her husband's killers while she and her children were tortured.

Louise Mushikiwabo says that her brother, Lando Ndaswinga, the only Tutsi member of the cabinet when the genocide started, was shot, along with their mother, his wife and two children, after UN peacekeepers allegedly ran away.

Geoffrey Robertson, the London-based lawyer who is acting for the women, said: "The UN and its agents are not above the law, and when it comes to credible allegations of complicity they should be tested by criminal or civil actions".

At the very least, there should be compensation, he argued.

Last month, an independent report commissioned by the UN condemned the organisation for ignoring evidence that a genocide was being planned, and for pulling most of its peacekeepers out of Rwanda once the killing started.

webTitle: Poison pen is eating away Bach's manuscripts

fields.headline: Poison pen is eating away Bach's manuscripts
fields.standfirst:
JS Bach home page
www.classical.net/music/
fields.trailText: Even as Germany honours Johann Sebastian Bach this year, the 250th anniversary of his death, many of his greatest works are falling to pieces.
fields.body:
Even as Germany honours Johann Sebastian Bach this year, the 250th anniversary of his death, many of his greatest works are falling to pieces.

Entire passages of the Christmas Oratorio, the St Matthew Passion and the Mass in B Minor have been reduced to blurred squiggles, there are holes in the fugues and rips in the toccatas and cantatas.

Yet the keepers of the bulk of his works have been unable to find anyone willing to pay for them to be saved from slow destruction, highlighting the limitations of commercial heritage sponsorship.

About 80% of Bach's original manuscripts are held in a high-security vault at the German state library in Berlin.

The head of the music section, Helmut Hell, said that conserving the badly damaged pages would cost between DM2m (£1.34m) and DM3m. "Not very much when you consider that the collection as a whole is worth hundreds of millions of marks," he added.

The problem was that sponsors wanted to see something for their money, Dr Hell said. "We have a difficulty with the nature of the object. We are talking purely about arresting the process, and not about restoring. With a picture, the effect is visible at the end. With a manuscript, the whole idea is to ensure that things stay the same."

The problem with the scores comes at a time when DM2m is being spent on just one event, the international Bach festival, to be held in Leipzig in July.

The Bach manuscripts are falling to pieces because of the ink he used, which was made from gum arabic, iron and either water or wine.

The acid in the ink is speeding up the disintegration of the paper and the iron is slowly oxidising on the paper, turning it brown. On parts of the manuscripts, the ink has eaten right through the sheet. Elsewhere, the score can be seen from the other side as succession of smudgy brown marks.

It is a series of chemical reactions which affects only scores left by 18th century composers working in northern and central Germany.

"This is not a problem with either Mozart or Haydn because they used a different kind of ink and maybe also because the paper they used, which came from Italy, was of a higher quality", said Dr Hell.

The state library holds around 300 of Bach's original scores. About a quarter of it is in an advanced state of decay. "We reckon we are going to have to repair between 1,000 and 1,500 leaves", said Harmut Böhrenz, head of the library's restoration and conservation department.

The fact that he can contemplate doing so is thanks, partly, to the fall of the Berlin wall.

Reunification meant that scientists could swap data on a technique in which damaged pages are split and a leaf of highly alkaline material is inserted to neutralise the acidic ink.

It is a method which has been known since the last century, but the librarians entrusted with Bach's manuscripts in West Germany considered it too dangerous. They opted instead to wait till technical progress allowed them to repair the scores without risk.

Unknown to them, however, the advances they needed had already been made by two East Germans, Günter Müller and Wolfgang Wächter. It was not until Dr Böhrenz met Mr Müller at a congress in Vienna in 1986 that he learned how far the East Germans had developed the technique. Even so, it took years to convince western experts that it was safe.

Most of the Bach manuscripts in public ownership have now been brought together in the state library, which is in East Berlin. It is hoped they can be treated there by a team headed by a former pupil of Mr Müller's, Gertrud Schenck.

But the library's own budget is unable to bear the cost and no one else is ready to fund the project. "We have had some private donations, but no one big sponsor who could put in the bulk of the money," Dr Hell said.

He fears that the deterioration of the manuscripts could mean knowledge about the way that Bach composed will be lost forever. New computer scanning techniques are revealing previously invisible corrections in manuscripts, allowing musicologists to uncover the working process as never before.

The question is how much of Bach's work will be in a fit state to be examined when those possibilities arise.

"It would be really bad if such a rich country as Germany were unable to find this money," Dr Hell said.

It is hoped they can be treated there by a team headed by a former pupil of Mr Müller's, Gertrud Schenck. But the library's own budget is unable to bear the cost and no one else is ready to fund the project. "We have had some private donations, but no one big sponsor who could put in the bulk of the money," Dr Hell said. He fears that the deterioration of the manuscripts could mean knowledge about the way that Bach composed will be lost forever. New computer scanning techniques are revealing previously invisible corrections in manuscripts, allowing musicologists to uncover the working process as never before. The question is how much of Bach's work will be in a fit state to be examined when those possibilities arise. "It would be really bad if such a rich country as Germany were unable to find this money," Dr Hell said.

fields.headline: Goat joins dodo and dinosaur
fields.trailText: A rare goat native to a mountainous region of northern Spain has become extinct, with the last known specimen found dead last week under a fallen tree, authorities said yesterday.
fields.body:
A rare goat native to a mountainous region of northern Spain has become extinct, with the last known specimen found dead last week under a fallen tree, authorities said yesterday.

Vets working for the Aragon regional government captured the 13-year old female last spring and took a tissue sample from its ear. They released the animal after attaching an electronic tracer. No decision has been made on whether to use preserved cells to try to make a clone.

The animal belonged ot one of several subspecies of Pyrenees mountain goat and was known in Spanish as a bucardo. Its scientific name is Capra pyrenaica pyrenaica. It was distinguished by a thick coat and its females had horns with a broader base than that of other goats.

Forest rangers in Ordesa national park in Huesca province found the female on Thursday with its skull crushed.

The park's director, Luis Marquina, said the subspecies had once stretched north across the border into the French Pyrenees, But its numbers dwindled steadily over the past century as a result of poaching and environmental factors.

The breed was declared a protected species in 1973. "This is a case of extinction", Mr Marquina said.

webTitle: Man shot breaking in at embassy

fields.headline: Man shot breaking in at embassy
fields.trailText: An intruder identified as a drunken Russian soldier apparently trying to steal a car broke into the US embassy compound in the heart of Moscow yesterday and was shot and wounded, officials said.
fields.body:
An intruder identified as a drunken Russian soldier apparently trying to steal a car broke into the US embassy compound in the heart of Moscow yesterday and was shot and wounded, officials said.

Russian police said that two soldiers broke in and were stopped by a US marine guard who opened fire, the Interfax news agency reported. The wounded man was identified as Yevgeny Taynakov, 23. The embassy confirmed that an intruder had been wounded.

Russian police said the man was trying to steal a car and was drunk, the Itar-Tass news agency reported. He was spotted breaking into and trying to start up an embassy vehicle, which he then crashed, the embassy said.

"He was warned several times to stop," the embassy spokesman said. "He was subdued by force ... His actions potentially endangered the lives and safety of embassy personnel."

The wounded man was turned over to Russian authorities and was being treated last night at a Moscow hospital.

The embassy made no mention of a second man. It was not clear how access was gained to the heavily guarded compound.

Russian police were hunting for a second man, also believed to be a member of the interior ministry's paramilitary unit 3388, Interfax said.

fields.headline: You won't know me...
fields.standfirst: Why is it that in every group of celebrities there's one person whose name you can never remember?  Tim Dowling goes in search of... you know, whatsisname, thingummy...
fields.trailText: Why is it that in every group of celebrities there's one person whose name you can never remember?  Tim Dowling goes in search of... you know, whatsisname, thingummy...
fields.body:
It is the time of year when half-finished year-end newspaper trivia quizzes fill the basket next to the fireplace and we are all reminded that fame is not only fleeting, but fickle. Every time the white-hot spotlight of celebrity shines brightly on a chosen few, it casts a sharp shadow over someone nearby.

One staple of the trivia quiz is the universal what's-his-face who makes up the numbers in any famous aggregation - the other guys, the so-and-sos, the see-through celebrities who are covered by the Latin phrase "et al", so that a pop group like Blur, even at the height of their fame, are referred to as Damon Albarn, Alex James, Graham Coxon et al - the et al in this case being ginger drummer Dave Rowntree. How can someone be so famous, and yet so unknown?

If Blur were the Teletubbies, Dave Rowntree would be Laa-Laa. Even among the under-fours, only die-hard fans can routinely pick Laa-Laa out of the line-up. Po is the smallest, Dipsy has a funny hat and Tinky Winky is, as we all know, gay. But what about Laa-Laa? When the Teletubbies' memoirs are finally written, Laa-Laa's will almost certainly be called I Was The Yellow One.

This strange phenomenon is by no means limited to rock drummers and fuzzy children's entertainers. Almost any group you care to mention has a walking trivia quiz candidate lurking down at the bottom of the roster. Take, for example, the Rat Pack. It's easy enough to visualise all five of them: Frankie, Dino, Sammy, Peter Lawford and... uhh... who? Step forward nightclub comedian and sometime talk show host Joey Bishop. I'll bet it was right on the tip of your tongue.

And what about the Brat Pack? While this group of self-satisfied twentysomething actors was always a Where Are They Now? file waiting to happen, the names of Rob Lowe, Judd Nelson and Molly Ringwald remain etched into the brains of people who never even saw any of their films. There was also a second tier, comprising Emilio Estevez, Ally Sheedy and Andrew McCarthy. And then there was that other girl - you know, the boss-eyed one, the Dave Rowntree of St Elmo's Fire. Her name was Mare Winningham, but there is no earthly reason for anyone to know that.

Being famous and forgotten at once must be difficult to live with. Imagine being the actor Brad Dexter, walking through life unnoticed, desperately trying to convince people at parties that you were one of the Magnificent Seven. "What do you mean? In the film?" they would say, staring at your unfamiliar face and backing away uncomfortably. The best you could hope for is to become famous as the one nobody can ever remember.

We might like to believe that there was less of this sort of thing in the past, before celebrity was conferred in job lots, but the phenomenon probably dates to biblical times. Jesus, though a natural communicator, lived a life free from spin, and thus had no one to advise him that 12 apostles was about four too many. The situation was not helped by the fact that several of the apostles had the same name, while some had two names. In the bible two or three disciples seem to do all the talking - the quiet ones at the back barely get a look in. This is why for most of us today the apostles are Simon, Peter, Judas et al. If pushed you might mumble something about John, or doubting Thomas, but even people who memorised them at school have difficulty with the rest. For the record, they are Simon (called Peter), Andrew (his brother), James the Elder, John (his brother), Matthew (or Levi, confusingly), Philip, Bartholomew, Thomas, James the Younger, Judas (bad Judas), Judas (other Judas) and Simon Zelotes. For the bonus point you might recall that someone called Matthias eventually came off the disciples' substitute bench to replace bad Judas, a tactic widely regarded as too little too late.

The full list of apostles contains four or five potential Dave Rowntrees, but the et al phenomenon is at its most poignant when the et al refers, albeit ungrammatically, to just one person. Take the trio known as the Ground Force team, and more specifically known as Alan Titchmarsh, Charlie Dimmock et al. Even the recent makeover the team gave to Nelson Mandela's back garden failed to help Ground Force's Third Man creep into public consciousness. He shares equal billing and screen time with his partners, and we can all picture his face, but who is he? Since you ask, he's none other than Tommy Walsh, the fact-checker's friend.

Famous families are not immune. They may stick together, but in our memories somebody always goes missing. There is at least one McGann brother that no one can name, out there in the reaches beyond the comfortable familiarity of Paul and Joe. So it is with the Baldwin brothers, the Carradine brothers and the Jackson Five - Michael, Tito, Marlon, Jermaine et al. At least we know there are meant to be five of them. How many Osmonds are there?

The reasons for this phenomenon are unclear. Is it them, or is it us? Is there something cruel and wilful in our inability to remember that last name on the cast list? Are these people purposefully exuding an air of impermanence? Perhaps it's caused by some primitive kink in our brain, a shedding of unnecessary information designed to make the most of limited storage capacity. It is sometimes said that we can only cope with remembering three things at once, but this will come as small comfort to Tommy Walsh, who is one of three, or to the third astronaut on the Apollo 11 mission, the one who isn't Neil Armstrong or Buzz Aldrin. He's the one who stayed in the capsule, remember? Okay, it's Michael Collins, but I had to look it up.

It doesn't seem to be anything personal. Certainly it happens with things as well as people. Try to name all the G7 nations, and you're bound to leave out Canada. The seven deadly sins are always hard to recall. Ironically it's usually sloth that no one can be bothered to remember. But it is the forgotten people who break your heart, those ostensibly famous folk who could walk straight off a stage in a packed stadium and be asked for two forms of ID. What happens when Dave Rowntree forgets his backstage pass? "Hold on, sunshine, there's a bit of a queue. You? Blur? Pull the other one."

While the et al effect is widespread, it is by no means universal. Some groups do manage to crowd into the limelight together. There is scarcely a person alive who cannot name all four Beatles in what is generally accepted to be descending order of importance. Curiously the Spice Girls seem to have achieved permanent memorability by creating confusion. The tricky chore of pairing up their real names with their silly nicknames - Posh/Victoria, Scary/Mel B - must have acted as some kind of aide memoire. We will never forget them now, try as we might.

In this delicate post new year period, our memories, frail at the best of times, are hardly operating at peak efficiency. Most of us can barely remember all the members of our own families, much less all of the Waltons. So perhaps we should spare a thought for the lost souls at the edge of fame's radar, the Dave Rowntrees, the Joey Bishops, the bloke who played Mike in the Young Ones, the fourth horseman of the Apocalypse, the fifth member of the Famous Five and the thousands of actors, drummers and cabinet members who, for obvious reasons, cannot be named here.

fields.headline: No: 1559 Madonna
fields.body:
Appearance: Dramatic, covert and brandishing £900,000.

Must have been some party. This particular personal appearance was at Notting Hill's little known hotspot, the former telephone exchange on Portobello Road.

Don't think that was in the film. What's the appeal? Its redbrick industrial living space, say west London estate agents, although critics of its flamboyant Edwardian architecture think it a bit "pantomime dame". Any other insights are exclusive to residents and Hello! magazine, unless you possess the million-pound chequebook necessary to get past the gates to the flat that Madonna didn't spend her £900,000 on.

Ah, so the Hollywood hills won out over Notting Hill after all. Not quite. La Ciccone has always been a bit of an Anglophile. She loves our schools (OK, daughter Lourdes is lined up for the French Lycée, but it is in Kensington), our men and our property (although she's selling her £4.5m Kensington semi because there's no yoga room). But she's just become the latest victim of gazumping.

Outbid for an old phone exchange next door to a pub and a fruit and veg market? Hush! London doesn't have many real houses any more - look at all those poor people who have to live in lofts. But the rival bid from a mystery buyer means it's back to the estate agent's window for Madonna.

So she won't have Julia Roberts as a neighbour? Forget the movie. The neighbourhood is not awash with celebs popping into bookshops and falling in love with Notting Hill bachelors. Although rumour has it that Roberts has shown an interest in the same building.

Didn't Claudia Schiffer buy a place there too? Hmm, yes.

And Woody Allen's said to be pondering a move to west London this year? Yep.

And Tom and Nicole bought that big place... OK, stop. Anyway, that was in Dulwich.

Do say: "And through here is the Edwardian meditation chamber."

Don't say: "Hello? Is that directory enquiries?"

fields.headline: Too much, too soon
fields.standfirst: New multimillionaires are in crisis. They can make all the money they like but can they stop their children catching 'affluenza' and turning into megaspoiled brats? US banks are offering counselling to help them cope. By  Edward Helmore
fields.trailText: New multimillionaires are in crisis. They can make all the money they like but can they stop their children catching 'affluenza' and turning into megaspoiled brats? US banks are offering counselling to help them cope. By  Edward Helmore
fields.body:
The rich spoiled brat may be an endangered species, if a new counselling service offered by American investment banks proves effective. Two of America' s largest financial institutions, Goldman Sachs and Merrill Lynch, are offering psychiatric counselling to the children of its wealthiest private investors to counter "affluenza" - a new name for an old condition which often turns the over-funded, over-connected offspring of the seriously rich into profligate, dissolute and obnoxious pariahs.

It's a malady that may generate little sympathy in a society that cherishes money as a solution to most ills. But to America's new one-stock internet rich, having to deal with the sudden acquisition of vast wealth themselves, the prospect of simply handing over hundreds of millions of dollars to their children without any guidance has become a cause for serious concern.

The big Wall Street institutions are offering "financial parenting" services for clients worth more than $100 million to help teach their children about share trading, charitable and philanthropic giving and to help them adjust to the idea of inheriting a couple of hundred million dollars.

The new billionaires and millionaires are reluctant to adopt the practice of America's "old-money" ultra-rich, who traditionally have simply passed the whole lot on to the next generation without strings. "There's been a lot of new wealth created by the Silicon Valley goldrush and the need for financial parenting has grown in recent years," says Merrill Lynch's Susan Thompson.

"Parents often aren't sure how to articulate it to us but we hope to offer a programme that fits in with their goals for sensitising their children to all the responsibilities of new-found wealth, transferring the values they want to impart, and the understanding of the value of money."

Anxiety over the perils of inherited wealth has become so commonplace among the ultra-rich that a financial estate-planning conference in Miami this month features a presentation called "Planning to Influence Behaviour: Guiding [and Controlling] your Children and Grandchildren." In San Francisco in November, the vast financial services company Charles Schwab sponsored a conference at which newly-minted millionaires learned, with the guidance of lawyers, brokers and a psychotherapist, how to give children "more than just financial wealth."

The notion of affluenza has been building for years but has only recently begun to be identified as a fully-fledged condition with the publication of The Golden Ghetto, a recent book by psychologist Jessie O' Neill. In it, the author, granddaughter of a one-time president of General Motors, looked at how the attainment of great wealth often proves to be a hollow achievement, often accompanied by extreme anxiety and a raft of other emotional and psychological fears which get passed on to their heirs.

Of course, the problems of inheritance are not new, but they recently gained a sense of urgency for newly-rich baby-boomers who began to consider retirement - and their inevitable demise. Now, with many more overnight plutocrats wondering just how to handle their assets, and the well-documented examples of trust fund babies going off the rails serving as grim cautionary tales, there is a new resolve to try to circumvent the pitfalls of inherited wealth.

Last year, Bill Gates, the world's richest man, announced that he and his wife would restrict their two children's inheritance to $100 million and leave the rest of what is projected to grow to a $1 trillion estate to charity and philanthropic foundations. America' s second richest man, Warren Buffett, said he would do the same, in the hope that by leaving his children a relatively paltry amount they will have the drive to do something for themselves.

While this may or may not protect the Gates and Buffet children from catching affluenza, other antidotes to the problems of inherited wealth are being tried. Some millionaires, by creating built-in incentives, have begun linking the transfer of wealth to an acceptance by their children of parental values. Estate planners setting up inheritance trusts are increasingly being asked to make provisions to deny payments, for instance, if children don't set up pre-nuptial agreements, or if they fail periodic drug tests.

One Florida millionaire, whose son has anxiety attacks, stipulated that the boy should only receive payments if he has treatment. Another tycoon, whose brother died in a car crash, has instructed that his children would only receive money if their driving licences were clean.

Elsewhere, in contrast, financial re-wards would come with charitable work, helping in family foundations, or more generally adhering to specially drawn-up "family mission statements". Incentives not to blow the inheritance take other forms, too, such as by tying future trust pay-outs to audits of the deployment of wealth already received.

"We see more and more of these 'incentive' trusts that give the trustee the framework to make sure the intended results become reality," says Cooper. Another technique is to delay the passing of wealth. "In prior generations giving access to their inheritance at 25 was common. Now we see families wanting to pass it later in life and wanting to dribble it out at 40 or 45. Or perhaps they'll get a first taste earlier, so if they have trouble hanging on to it at least they'll have a second or third bite of the apple.

"The issue of how, and how much, wealth to leave children is probably one of the most serious issues our clients face," says Cooper. "The whole issue of providing resources to ward against the affluenza bug is a common theme that we see . Horror stories abound, so the families come to us to ask how they can take measures so their children don't turn out that way."

Parents want to be able to encourage their children to do good, but they don't want to give them so much money that there's nothing left to achieve. "It' s a balancing act," he says.
