But to America's new one-stock internet rich, having to deal with the sudden acquisition of vast wealth themselves, the prospect of simply handing over hundreds of millions of dollars to their children without any guidance has become a cause for serious concern. The big Wall Street institutions are offering "financial parenting" services for clients worth more than $100 million to help teach their children about share trading, charitable and philanthropic giving and to help them adjust to the idea of inheriting a couple of hundred million dollars. The new billionaires and millionaires are reluctant to adopt the practice of America's "old-money" ultra-rich, who traditionally have simply passed the whole lot on to the next generation without strings. "There's been a lot of new wealth created by the Silicon Valley goldrush and the need for financial parenting has grown in recent years," says Merrill Lynch's Susan Thompson. "Parents often aren't sure how to articulate it to us but we hope to offer a programme that fits in with their goals for sensitising their children to all the responsibilities of new-found wealth, transferring the values they want to impart, and the understanding of the value of money." Anxiety over the perils of inherited wealth has become so commonplace among the ultra-rich that a financial estate-planning conference in Miami this month features a presentation called "Planning to Influence Behaviour: Guiding [and Controlling] your Children and Grandchildren." In San Francisco in November, the vast financial services company Charles Schwab sponsored a conference at which newly-minted millionaires learned, with the guidance of lawyers, brokers and a psychotherapist, how to give children "more than just financial wealth." The notion of affluenza has been building for years but has only recently begun to be identified as a fully-fledged condition with the publication of The Golden Ghetto, a recent book by psychologist Jessie O' Neill. In it, the author, granddaughter of a one-time president of General Motors, looked at how the attainment of great wealth often proves to be a hollow achievement, often accompanied by extreme anxiety and a raft of other emotional and psychological fears which get passed on to their heirs. Of course, the problems of inheritance are not new, but they recently gained a sense of urgency for newly-rich baby-boomers who began to consider retirement - and their inevitable demise. Now, with many more overnight plutocrats wondering just how to handle their assets, and the well-documented examples of trust fund babies going off the rails serving as grim cautionary tales, there is a new resolve to try to circumvent the pitfalls of inherited wealth. Last year, Bill Gates, the world's richest man, announced that he and his wife would restrict their two children's inheritance to $100 million and leave the rest of what is projected to grow to a $1 trillion estate to charity and philanthropic foundations. America' s second richest man, Warren Buffett, said he would do the same, in the hope that by leaving his children a relatively paltry amount they will have the drive to do something for themselves. While this may or may not protect the Gates and Buffet children from catching affluenza, other antidotes to the problems of inherited wealth are being tried. Some millionaires, by creating built-in incentives, have begun linking the transfer of wealth to an acceptance by their children of parental values. Estate planners setting up inheritance trusts are increasingly being asked to make provisions to deny payments, for instance, if children don't set up pre-nuptial agreements, or if they fail periodic drug tests. One Florida millionaire, whose son has anxiety attacks, stipulated that the boy should only receive payments if he has treatment. Another tycoon, whose brother died in a car crash, has instructed that his children would only receive money if their driving licences were clean. Elsewhere, in contrast, financial re-wards would come with charitable work, helping in family foundations, or more generally adhering to specially drawn-up "family mission statements". Incentives not to blow the inheritance take other forms, too, such as by tying future trust pay-outs to audits of the deployment of wealth already received. "We see more and more of these 'incentive' trusts that give the trustee the framework to make sure the intended results become reality," says Cooper. Another technique is to delay the passing of wealth. "In prior generations giving access to their inheritance at 25 was common. Now we see families wanting to pass it later in life and wanting to dribble it out at 40 or 45. Or perhaps they'll get a first taste earlier, so if they have trouble hanging on to it at least they'll have a second or third bite of the apple. "The issue of how, and how much, wealth to leave children is probably one of the most serious issues our clients face," says Cooper. "The whole issue of providing resources to ward against the affluenza bug is a common theme that we see . Horror stories abound, so the families come to us to ask how they can take measures so their children don't turn out that way." Parents want to be able to encourage their children to do good, but they don't want to give them so much money that there's nothing left to achieve. "It' s a balancing act," he says.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In yesterday's G2 cover story, we mistakenly said that John McCain, the US Vietnam war veteran who is now running for president, was shot down over Haiphong and rescued from the sea. He was shot down over Hanoi and pulled from a lake.
fields.body:
In yesterday's G2 cover story, we mistakenly said that John McCain, the US Vietnam war veteran who is now running for president, was shot down over Haiphong and rescued from the sea. He was shot down over Hanoi and pulled from a lake.

Distribution difficulties meant that some readers did not receive G2 yesterday. Many apologies.

Anthony Payne completed Elgar's Third Symphony, from the composer's sketches, not the Second, as we mistakenly said in our radio review, page 4, Saturday Review, January 8. The work in this version is known as The Sketches for Symphony No.3 by Edward Elgar elaborated by Anthony Payne.

The ancient "Anastasia people", mentioned in a reference to Colorado, page 7, Travel, January 8, are, in fact, the Anasazi, the ancestors of the modern Pueblo Indians. Anasazi is a Navajo word meaning "the ancient ones" or "the ancient enemies". Modern Pueblo people prefer the term to be rendered in English as "ancestral Puebloans." More information: www.co. blm.gov/ahc/anasazi.htm

Lloyds in our headline and the accompanying report, page 6, January 8, was lacking an apostrophe. The headline should have read Lloyd's sues over lost Shelley letter. It is Lloyds TSB and Lloyd's of London. They are not the same institution.

In welcoming back Frasier in our television notes, page 20, G2, January 7, we called him a psychologist. He is, of course, a psychiatrist.

Homophone corner, from a short profile of Monica Mason, of the Royal Ballet, page 14, January 8. The role in Giselle is not Queen of the Willies. It is Queen of the Wilis. A wili is the ghost of a girl who died betrayed by her lover.

January 8 was Saturday and not, as we suggested in the folio line on page 13, an extra holiday called Satyrday.

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. webTitle: Someone in the City may yet be sacked for selling sterling

fields.headline: Someone in the City may yet be sacked for selling sterling
fields.trailText: Back in the summer of 1992 the then prime minister John Major predicted that the pound would become a strong international currency rivalling the German mark. He was right. Unfortunately his timing was five years out.
fields.body:
Back in the summer of 1992 the then prime minister John Major predicted that the pound would become a strong international currency rivalling the German mark. He was right. Unfortunately his timing was five years out.

Within weeks of the Major boast sterling was being trashed on the foreign exchanges. Black Wednesday and the subsequent 30% devaluation of the pound not only made Mr Major's words look vainglorious they cost him his job and the Tories the 1997 election.

However, over the past four years the pound has stopped being the butt of the currency markets. The old City adage that no one ever got sacked for selling sterling has been stood on its head. The pound is now trading right at the top of its old exchange rate mechanism (ERM) band after the first decade since the war in which it has appreciated in value.

So has sterling been fundamentally re-rated by the foreign exchange markets and, if it has, what does this mean for the British economy? Or is the recent strength merely temporary?

Sterling's strength matters. In the late 1970s, as North Sea oil came on stream and monetarist policies were imposed to drive down inflation, the pound's value rose 40%. This culminated in the deep recession of the early 1980s when unemployment soared and large chunks of manufacturing industry were wiped out.

From 1981 onwards the pound went into decline so that by 1986 it was actually cheaper than it had been when the International Monetary Fund had turned up in Britain during the sterling crisis of a decade earlier. Devaluation helped spur the economic recovery of the mid-1980s.

Between 1986 and 1992 the exchange rate again firmed as Britain first shadowed the German mark and then formalised the arrangement through membership of the ERM. The strength of the pound - and the interest rates necessary to defend it - again had consequences for industry, and once more it was a devaluation via the humiliating exit from the ERM that brought salvation.

The subsequent appreciation of the pound should have spelled another period of retrenchment. Instead the economy has so far escaped with little more than a brush with recession in the winter of 1998-99.

There are two explanations. Firstly, the economy is now much less dependent on exchange rate-sensitive manufacturing industry. In areas such as finance, law and accountancy, Britain has a competitive advantage over many rivals, which makes them less vulnerable to a stronger pound. Some of Britain's big exporters, in pharmaceuticals for example, have also sharpened their competitive edge through innovation and improvement.

In addition, those bits of manufacturing which came through the recessions of the early 1980s and early 1990s are now battle hardened and more capable of coping with a near 30% appreciation in the pound.

But coping is one thing, making money another. Many businesses are just hanging on. The extent to which the pound is overvalued was illustrated in an IMF working paper earlier this month which reckoned Britain could not cope with joining the single currency without a 20% devaluation. One look at Britain's payments deficit shows that there is still a competitiveness problem.

Don't hold your breath for any immediate response. The Bank of England has been forecasting a fall in the pound since it was given its independence but has been forced to modify its view in the light of what has actually been happening.

Scent an opportunity

According to the Bank's economic models, if interest rates in Britain are above those of the 11-nation eurozone smart investors will scent an opportunity to make money by borrowing cheap euros and buying sterling. This game only pays off if the pound does not fall against the euro. The Bank assumes that in the end the arbitrage opportunity will close itself out and equilibrium will return.

Sushil Wadhwani, a member of the Bank's monetary policy committee, has a different explanation. He believes that the exchange markets "might have re-rated sterling against the mark because, in recent years, the German unemployment rate has risen relative to that in the UK."

Therein may lie the key. Historically the British economy has underperformed that of Germany and other leading industrial nations.

However, in the 1990s Britain has been the second most successful country in the Group of Seven leading industrialised nations after the US. It has had a faster growth rate since Black Wednesday and a much lower level of unemployment than any of the other big European economies.

Some of the pressure on the pound could ease if, as expected, the single currency zone starts to close the gap in terms of economic growth rates. But that is hardly like to bring about the 20% devaluation the IMF has talked about. In the past the factor that has normally undermined sterling has been inflation, with devaluation used as a back door method to restore competitiveness.

But British inflation rate is broadly in line with the rest of Europe, especially as Britain is at a more advanced stage of the economic cycle. Economic policy is geared to keeping inflation at 2.5%. If inflation stays low, growth robust enough to prevent unemployment from rising and interest rates remain higher than those in the eurozone it is not easy to see what will sway sentiment away from sterling. Someone may yet get sacked because they sold the pound.

fields.headline: How to become a millionaire
fields.trailText: Standard Life Investments has found an alternative to the pressure of Chris Tarrant's questions on Who Wants to be a Millionaire.
fields.body:
Standard Life Investments has found an alternative to the pressure of Chris Tarrant's questions on Who Wants to be a Millionaire.

To succeed contestants would need £25,000 in spare change every year, and be ready to take the risks related to investing in equities.

But provided that contestants will play by these rules, Standard Life Investments calculates that they could have expected to achieve the modern-day equivalent of millionaire status in 18.7 years in the last century.

Standard Life cites statistics dating from 1918 in support of its argument that there is compelling argument to invest in equities rather than bonds - gilts - or leaving money on deposit - cash. The fund management group uses these to show that if investors maintain their investment in the stock market for five years, the probability of their outperforming cash or gilts is about 80%, which rises to 100% for gilts if the stocks are held for 20 years.

The shortest time in which any £25,000 investor would have achieved £1m since the first world war is 14 years. This happened when investments were started in the early 1920s or in the years shortly after 1973. Standard points out that both periods were shortly after weak periods in the stock market. Investors would have to have been more patient if they started their investments in the late 1920s and 1950s, when the markets had been enjoying periods of strength.

Standard Life has stripped out inflation, so investors starting to save in 1950, for instance, would have needed an initial investment of £1,236, rising every year in line with inflation, which would have reached more than £101,000 by 1968 - the equivalent of today's £1m in buying power.

Investors who started to save in 1956 would have had to wait 27 years before being rewarded with their million.

Standard argues the standard deviation around the average 18.7 years is "only" 3.7 years, which it says supports its claim that the result is statistically sound and implies that in 70% of start years, a "real" million would have been made in about 20 years.

The sting in the tail is that as markets have provided high real returns in the recent past, savers starting to invest now might take longer to reach £1m.

webTitle: How the west was won back

fields.headline: How the west was won back
fields.trailText: Brutal movie in black and white
fields.body:
Brutal movie in black and white

You could almost hear that deep, growling voice which used to come on with every single video trailer as Time Warner formally got on the net in the form of America Online yesterday ... "this strategic merger of equals to create the world's first fully integrated media and communications company for the Internet Century."

The immediate reaction is to curl up on the sofa and hope it's all just a bit of fantastic futurology. But then it's difficult to avoid the show when the instant reviews have just about added up $100bn - the value attached to the rise in Time and AOL's share prices between the deal leaking and the market digesting the news. Wall Street, and London for that matter, clearly like what they have seen.

On the surface, this really is everything we'd all like to see: top quality media content plugging into first-rate technology, with lots and lots of energy in the form of entrepreneurial zeal. This heady mix is called convergence in action. The promise is in bringing together some of the finest talents of the journalistic and movie worlds with some of the savviest software engineers in existence. The new paradigm-ers should be dancing in cyber street.

But there are also lots and lots of reasons to hold off on the festivities. Aside from the connotations that come with the creation of a not-so-little brother to Bill Gates, with American culture being forced ever deeper down our delicate European throats, there are some simple questions of business sensibility and consumer-protection which need to be answered first.

For a start, it was not at all clear yesterday whether this was a "merger of equals" or a takeover or even a "semi-reverse" takeover. Time shareholders get rather more bang for their paper than their AOL counterparts, but then it's an AOL man in the chair. And the new company will be called AOL Time Warner, rather than the other way around. (Transfer the scene to investment banking and no-one knows what happened to Pearce and Fenner at Merrill Lynch, while everyone does know what's going to happen to Dillon and Read at Warburg - they will be called UBS for short.)

In the US, on a subsidiary note, there are bound to be questions about the number one ISP being squirted down the tubes of the number one cable concern. In Britain, too, we are hurtling down a path that leads to just a small handful of huge corporations controlling a strictly-limited number of information delivery platforms. "Open access" on cable networks is just one aspect of a big and crucial fight for the rights of small innovative companies to deliver their goods to consumers.

But, in the case of AOL Time Warner, the real unknown is about corporate culture. The original Time/Warner/CNN marriage a decade ago was famous for its Hollywood-style volatility and we can now expect some severe testing of the corporate vows between AOL and Time over the coming months.

So many of the incredibly young but nevertheless great brands being trumpeted by AOL yesterday were established in the face of at best apathy, and at worst intense resistance, from the American corporate establishment. The history of Netscape, which started as an academic's software doodle and peaked with the biggest anti-trust case ever seen in the US, with Microsoft in the dock, serves as just one stark illustration. Rather than watching a new paradigm in action, we might just have tuned in to a brutal old black-and-whiter about how the west was won back for the American corporate machine.

Blow for Blair

It was always clear that the government's effort to swing British public opinion behind the European Union was going to be an uphill battle and it has long been suspected that it would largely have to fight alone. But friendly fire on top might make it impossible.

Yesterday it was the turn of the European parliament in the form of Christa Randzio-Plath, the chair of its economic and monetary affairs committee, to fill the air with shrapnel. Ms Randzio-Plath, a German social democrat, is suggesting there is support for the idea of holding-up legislation on financial services liberalisation in order to increase the pressure for a settlement of the long-running row over withholding tax.

The move looks a less than subtle effort to extend the European parliament's writ to decisions on taxation where, at present, it only has the right to be consulted.

But in trying to puff up its own powers by threatening to tie legislative progress to tax reforms which, in their present form are unacceptable to the British government, Ms Randzio-Plath and her colleagues are delivering yet another blow to the Blair administration's campaign to show that Britain's interests in Europe are best served by constructive engagement, not handbags at 10 paces.

fields.headline: Time gentlemen please
fields.standfirst: Whitbread leaves Chiswell street
fields.trailText: British brewing and leisure group Whitbread is to quit its 250-year-old head office in Chiswell street in the City of London for smaller offices around the corner by the end of the year.
fields.body:
British brewing and leisure group Whitbread is to quit its 250-year-old head office in Chiswell street in the City of London for smaller offices around the corner by the end of the year.

A Whitbread spokesman said the decision was to help maximise the value of assets at the former brewery site and to secure a more modern head office. It hopes to move into the CityPoint building in Ropemaker Street in October or November, subject to contract, with 45 key staff. webTitle: Mannesmann salvo stiffens defence against Vodafone

fields.headline: Mannesmann salvo stiffens defence against Vodafone
fields.trailText: Mobile phone operator Orange would add euro1.2bn to Mannesmann profits if the German telecommunications and industrial group manages to escape the clutches of Vodafone-AirTouch, the company claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
Mobile phone operator Orange would add euro1.2bn to Mannesmann profits if the German telecommunications and industrial group manages to escape the clutches of Vodafone-AirTouch, the company claimed yesterday.

The latest salvo from Mannesmann will form a key part of the company's defence document aimed at convincing shareholders that the business has a strong independent future. It forecasts a contribution of euro1bn from Orange in incremental revenues plus euro200m in cost and capital expenditure savings.

Mannesmann said the figures would deliver an additional 5% in growth to the group's telecoms division to 39% in the next three years.

The claim came amid another round of accusations and counter accusations from the two sides which continue to muddy the £80bn bid.

Vodafone chief executive Chris Gent refuted a series of claims, including the suggestion that the British firm would need 75% of Mannesmann to effect the demerger of Orange. Mr Gent reiterated that only 50.1% would give Vodafone management control of Mannesmann and that a cash sweetener of another euro60bn would not be needed to buy out another 25%.

Mannesmann repeated the claim that a so called "domination agreement" of 75% was necessary with one adviser saying the rule is "in black and white in German corporate law".

The two sides also locked horns over the role of regulators which Vodafone said would cause no problems. Mannesmann believes European regulators could delay matters for up to 12 months.

The Mannesmann defence document, due for publication by the end of this week, will also say the bid undervalues the business by almost 50%.

"Only last week, Orange [won] 30% more new customers than Vodafone in the UK market," Mannesmann chief Klaus Esser said, seizing on the good fortune of Orange's fourth quarter which saw it add 1.4m new customers.

Advisers to Vodafone shrugged off the Orange numbers, accusing Mannesmann of revising its forecasts daily. Vodafone has forecast synergies of £600m by 2004 if it snares its prey, of which 25% will be new revenues and the rest cost savings.

fields.headline: Outlook improves for Blue Circle
fields.trailText: Blue Circle Industries yesterday lifted some of the gloom surrounding it by predicting annual pre-tax profits would be better than the £260m it suggested in October.
fields.body:
Blue Circle Industries yesterday lifted some of the gloom surrounding it by predicting annual pre-tax profits would be better than the £260m it suggested in October.

Some analysts had feared that a continuing price war in Malaysia which had led to the first profit warning might have caused a worsening of the cement maker's position.

But chief executive Rick Haythornthwaite said Blue Circle was winning back market share and he now expected the pre-tax and pre-exceptionals figure to be "slightly ahead of the £260m".

Shares rose 7.75p to 365.5p as investors took confidence from the trading statement and a "buy" recommendation from analysts at HSBC, with a target price of 430p.

But the stock is still at a 30% discount to its main peers. This has made the company a source of bid speculation, with the world's largest cement producer, Lafarge, considered a likely predator.

Mr Haythornthwaite admitted that prices were still volatile in Malaysia but predicted that demand would rise 10% there over the next 12 months. The overall trading outlook for this year remained in line with expectations and a programme to deliver significant savings and performance improvements remained on track, he insisted.

The group said 1999 volumes in Britain were 1% lower than the previous 12 months but prices were up and costs down.

fields.headline: Esat's $2.5m parachute
fields.trailText: Esat Telecom, the Irish business entangled in a $1.9bn hostile bid from Norway's Telenor, is set to grant chief executive Denis O'Brien a $2.5m pay-off if the company is taken over.
fields.body:
Esat Telecom, the Irish business entangled in a $1.9bn hostile bid from Norway's Telenor, is set to grant chief executive Denis O'Brien a $2.5m pay-off if the company is taken over.

An egm has been pencilled in for later this month to approve the pay-off and increase Mr O'Brien's salary from Ir£250,000 to Ir£300,000. Mr O'Brien also holds 13% of Esat, which is Ireland's second biggest telecoms company.

fields.headline: PwC faces investigation
fields.trailText: PricewaterhouseCoopers, one of the world's largest accountancy firms, is to be subjected to a professional disciplinary inquiry over its work as auditor of TransTec, the insolvent engineering group founded by Labour MP and former treasury minister Geoffrey Robinson, the Guardian has learned.
fields.body:
PricewaterhouseCoopers, one of the world's largest accountancy firms, is to be subjected to a professional disciplinary inquiry over its work as auditor of TransTec, the insolvent engineering group founded by Labour MP and former treasury minister Geoffrey Robinson, the Guardian has learned.

It will be quizzed about the $18m (£11m) claim against TransTec which remained under wraps for more than three years. "[It] almost defies belief that the auditors didn't know about it," said one accountancy regulation insider.

Receivers are also investigating the fact that $12m was paid to the claimant, the motor group Ford, but presumably was described in TransTec's books as something else.

PwC is awaiting the verdict of a professional tribunal examining its auditing of Barings, the merchant bank brought to its knees in early 1995 by the £800m-plus losses run up on Far Eastern markets by rogue trader Nick Leeson. The tribunal is expected to report by the end of this month.

In addition, the profession's disciplinary machine is looking at PwC's role as auditor of Resort Hotels, which went into liquidation six years ago with debts of £140m.

Resort's founder, Robert Feld, was convicted of 12 charges of fraud and forgery, most relating to a £20m rights issue in 1992.

Feld had lied about Resort's profit forecasts and its indebtedness to ensure the rights issue succeeded.

TransTec's automotive divi sion supplied Ford with cylinder heads made at its Campsie plant near Londonderry, Northern Ireland. Ford issued an $18m suit against TransTec in mid-1996 after allegedly late deliveries.

PwC unearthed details of the claim and the fact $12m had been paid only late last year -more than three years after the original demand.

The fact that the $12m was not clearly flagged in the books as payment to Ford for part of the claim could prove serious for TransTec, and might trigger an inquiry by the serious fraud office. Yesterday the SFO said it had no immediate plans to investigate.

TransTec is adamant that Mr Robinson, who left the board on becoming a minister in 1997, knew nothing of the claim nor the payment.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Retailers enjoy December
fields.body:
Retailers enjoy December

Retailers enjoyed a boom in December as last minute Christmas purchases and millennium partyware boosted business.

Sales rose 2.9% in December, according to the British Retail Consortium, after a slump in November.

Bridget Rosewell, chief economic adviser to the BRC, said: "Retailers have been relieved by the recovery in sales performance in the run up to Christmas." But she warned that conditions on the high streets remained tough.

Recruitment drive on in City

City firms have put worries about disruptions over the new year behind them and started a recruitment drive, which will see one in two taking on more staff over the next four months.

Job creation will be highest in banking and fund management, according to Confederation of British Industry's quarterly survey of the financial services sector. However, it was not all good news, with venture capitalists and life insurers expecting to shed staff over the first quarter of the year.

Ashanti faces opposition

Intrigue surrounding the future of Ashanti, the gold mining group, deepened yesterday with an attempt by minority shareholders led by Swiss businessman Jean-Claude Gandur to oust the existing management and sell the company's Geita mine in Tanzania. Ashanti said it would "vigorously defend" the proceedings.

Mr Gandur and his associates speak for about 4.2% of the shares, but they have a powerful ally in their plans to sell Geita in the form of the Ghanaian government, which holds about 20%. On the other side is 32% shareholder Lonmin - mining arm of the now-dismembered Lonrho combine - which is opposed to Geita's sale.

GB Railways wins approval

GB Railways Group said the office of the rail regulator has announced that it supports the company's proposed plans to operate new services between London and Hull via the east coast mainline.

The company said it was examining options for implementation of its plans via its 80% owned subsidiary Hull Trains.

Following the completion of the planned upgrade for the east coast mainline in the next two-three years, Hull Trains plans to introduce 125 miles per hour 'interCity standard' rolling stock and increase the frequency of service.

Salomon adds new player

Salomon Smith Barney yesterday lured Michael Fabich to run its investment banking operation in Germany from Dresdner Kleinwort Benson.

He is the third senior appointment in Frankfurt for the US bank in as many months, and the first time the bank has had a head of investment banking based in the city.

Burger king abdicates

The president of Burger King's North American operations has quit the Diageo-owned company after 16 years to join a fruit juice firm. Paul Clayton will become chief executive of Jamba Juice, a chain that serves natural fruit juice products and soups.

fields.headline: Fat chance of fame
fields.standfirst: What's a world-class snapper like Patrick Lichfield doing at a diet club?  Anita Chaudhuri reports
fields.trailText: What's a world-class snapper like Patrick Lichfield doing at a diet club? Anita Chaudhuri reports
fields.body:
Photographers, no matter how hip or hard-up for new subjects, are rarely drawn to the, ahem, calorifically-challenged among us. And for their part, women of a certain size very often view posing for a photograph as a form of ritual humiliation.

How very strange, then, that a world-class photographer, Patrick Lichfield, and a Derbyshire diet club, Slimming World (catchphrase: Turning Dreams Into Reality), should have joined forces to produce a fly-on-the-wall exhibition at a London gallery aiming to celebrate the curious culture of weight-loss.

"Yes, it did take people a while to get their heads round the idea," agrees Claire Crowther, editor of Slimming World magazine. She should know: she was the one who came up with the scheme in the first place, not from any high-minded artistic motive but because she could never find any slimming club shots for her magazine. "We chose Lord Lichfield because we wanted to get a photographer who would really bring charisma to the project. I mean, we could've just got any old photographer to come along and take some snaps of the clubs, but that wouldn't have been the point.

"I wanted someone who could document the journey a slimmer makes when losing weight - we want to use the pictures for training purposes. Our members go through a whole gamut of emotions during the struggle. He built up a real rapport with all the women at the club."

Within seconds of meeting Lord L it becomes apparent that he does indeed enjoy a rapport with women. He stares hypnotically into my eyes and strokes my arm as he reveals why he felt compelled to spend several days skulking round community halls in Derbyshire and the Wirral listening to earnest discussions about eating plans and empowerment. "I was amazed by all the women I met - they were the happiest, most confident women I have ever worked with," he declares.

What, happier and more confident than his royal cousin? He glares: there is a strict veto on questions about "Her Maj" and Diana. Well, then, happier and more confident than all the supermodels he's worked with? "Much happier," he booms.

So he didn't feel guilty meeting all these overweight women desperate to look like the models he photographs? Clearly not. "Those models, a lot of them are miserable. Personally, I think women look better if they eat healthily and are happy with themselves. A lot of models, in my experience, are not."

The members of the two clubs he visited were clearly overawed by the experience of working with someone of his greatness. "He said to me, 'Elle McPherson yesterday, you lot today.' That made me feel fantastic," says Gaynor Budd, whose portrait appears in the exhibition. She lost seven stone with the club and has come down for the private view from Liverpool to drink champagne ("Not many calories in that") and to nibble calorie-controlled canapés (smoked salmon and caviar; avocado was banned at the 11th hour). "I don't think anyone minded being photographed: we were thrilled to have a lord come to visit us. I'm not sure if he knew what to make of us, though - one lady gave him a card and I think it might've been a bit rude."

Was there not a feeling of resentment towards a man who is, after all, one of those responsible for creating impossible ideals of the female form through his photography? "No. Even if we didn't see photos of slim models, we'd still want to be slim," she says. "It's great to see women like us being celebrated by a man like Lord Lichfield - I think it's very empowering for larger women everywhere."

Gaynor Budd's portrait, where she sits in a crowded room engrossed in a copy of Slimming World magazine, is the photographer's favourite picture. Somehow the image captures the obsessive, almost evangelical fervour that possesses the souls of club members. "There is a great atmosphere - it's very supportive. We help one another through the hard times, if we fall by the wayside," she explains. The vocabulary of Slimming World soon begins to sound peculiarly religious. Meetings do sound like non-secular gatherings, with up to 500 members attending. There is even talk of sin, though in a positive way: members are allowed 10 sins - forbidden treats - a week.

"The atmosphere is incredible. There's a lot of emotion going on, elation and real sadness," explains Lichfield. "I tried to be as unobtrusive as possible within the parameters of what I was trying to achieve. Mostly, I think they didn't notice me. I didn't use any flash so it was easy to blend in." With his formidable silver mane and plummy vowels, this does sound a tad unlikely, but we'll take his word for it. "In my mind I knew that I wanted to produce reportage, picking up on all the quirky, unexpected aspects of the women's experiences. I opted to do the whole thing in black and white because I find that has a timeless quality. Looking back at some of my old colour portraits, I realise how dated colour prints look - things like make-up and clothes don't age well. I'm very pleased with the results."

Certainly, the series of 36 grainy shots is surprising territory for Lichfield, a man who has staked his reputation on keeping his family photo album up to date with glossy portraits, working with the world's top models and actresses and doing some more worrying extra-curricular activities - the Unipart calendar and the illustrated guide to Harrow School among them. He claims that he took this assignment because he was given a great deal of discretion - although given how frequently Slimming World magazine sneaks into the photos, this sounds a bit dubious. "No, no, they really did give me a very wide-open brief. I wanted to do reportage, I wanted to do something different and so I went with it."

What does he think of Rankin and other younger photographers, the ones who pioneered CCTV-style reportage? "Well, what people forget is that it's very easy as a photographer to experiment - that doesn't take skill. What takes the skill is being able to buckle down to a commercial brief. The guys I respect are the ones who slave away photographing boiled eggs for ad agencies. Sooner or later these young guys are going to have to do that and I'll be interested to see how they develop then. Meanwhile, I'll be pleased to put this new work in my portfolio. It's something really different for me and I hope it'll make people realise that there's another side to me."

Still, it's unlikely that Dazed & Confused will be rushing to book him. With this exhibition, there is a strong sense not of the photographer trying to rise above his material but of quite the reverse. In one photo, two women hug; one face is hidden, the other etched with unabashed glee, the source of which we can only assume to be colossal weight loss. Yet the shot is a soft-focus blur, as if the photographer has smeared Vaseline over the lens to make these ordinary creatures look more at home in his starry portfolio. In another, the same woman looks down lovingly at a large peach - a great idea, but since it's a head-and-shoulders pose, we have no idea that this woman is overweight. Maybe that's the point - to get away from focusing on body shape - but it tells us nothing.

Some of the images are funny: fat bellies poking out of stubborn zip fastenings, shoes abandoned by fat, blistered feet and the rear view of one slim woman flanked by two corpulent colleagues. One of the most arresting is of a woman undergoing her weekly weigh-in, a confessional moment that focuses on her feet and the digital reading on the scales. Less successful are shots of Slimming World members sitting facing a podium. Viewing these out of context, anyone would think they had been culled from a rather dreary university prospectus.

Taken as a slab of social documentary, the exhibition succeeds because of the vicarious thrill that comes from invading the secret neuroses, the peculiar moments of bonding and intimacy revealed by the Slimming World members. But painful revelations aside, this is more corporate brochure than high art.

 My Weight, My Choice: A Photographic Exhibition by Lord Lichfield is at the Air Gallery, London W1 (0171-409 1544), till January 15.

He claims that he took this assignment because he was given a great deal of discretion - although given how frequently Slimming World magazine sneaks into the photos, this sounds a bit dubious. "No, no, they really did give me a very wide-open brief. I wanted to do reportage, I wanted to do something different and so I went with it." What does he think of Rankin and other younger photographers, the ones who pioneered CCTV-style reportage? "Well, what people forget is that it's very easy as a photographer to experiment - that doesn't take skill. What takes the skill is being able to buckle down to a commercial brief. The guys I respect are the ones who slave away photographing boiled eggs for ad agencies. Sooner or later these young guys are going to have to do that and I'll be interested to see how they develop then. Meanwhile, I'll be pleased to put this new work in my portfolio. It's something really different for me and I hope it'll make people realise that there's another side to me." Still, it's unlikely that Dazed & Confused will be rushing to book him. With this exhibition, there is a strong sense not of the photographer trying to rise above his material but of quite the reverse. In one photo, two women hug; one face is hidden, the other etched with unabashed glee, the source of which we can only assume to be colossal weight loss. Yet the shot is a soft-focus blur, as if the photographer has smeared Vaseline over the lens to make these ordinary creatures look more at home in his starry portfolio. In another, the same woman looks down lovingly at a large peach - a great idea, but since it's a head-and-shoulders pose, we have no idea that this woman is overweight. Maybe that's the point - to get away from focusing on body shape - but it tells us nothing. Some of the images are funny: fat bellies poking out of stubborn zip fastenings, shoes abandoned by fat, blistered feet and the rear view of one slim woman flanked by two corpulent colleagues. One of the most arresting is of a woman undergoing her weekly weigh-in, a confessional moment that focuses on her feet and the digital reading on the scales. Less successful are shots of Slimming World members sitting facing a podium. Viewing these out of context, anyone would think they had been culled from a rather dreary university prospectus. Taken as a slab of social documentary, the exhibition succeeds because of the vicarious thrill that comes from invading the secret neuroses, the peculiar moments of bonding and intimacy revealed by the Slimming World members. But painful revelations aside, this is more corporate brochure than high art.  My Weight, My Choice: A Photographic Exhibition by Lord Lichfield is at the Air Gallery, London W1 (0171-409 1544), till January 15.

webTitle: Commons sketch: Good turnout as turncoat turns up and is turned off

fields.headline: Commons sketch: Good turnout as turncoat turns up and is turned off
fields.trailText: Mr Shaun Woodward, the Tory turncoat, took his seat on the Labour benches yesterday.
fields.body:
Mr Shaun Woodward, the Tory turncoat, took his seat on the Labour benches yesterday.

He arrived, by arrangement, at a side entrance to the Palace of Westminster, to be greeted by a crack squad of his new colleagues, including another former Tory MP, Mr Peter Temple-Morris, who was presumably there in the role of a television evangelist - to assure Mr Woodward that there is a life after death in spite of there being no firm evidence.

These days, events like this are organised with almost as much attention to detail as a royal funeral. The photographers are corralled behind a fence, with a narrow gap into which the apostate must deftly insert himself at the critical moment.

Only when a man with a mobile was satisfied that everyone was present and ready did he hit the button and bark: "Okay, go for it!" Mr Woodward and his minder appeared as if from nowhere to make their final approach, like a 747 over Hounslow, the cameras clacking like elevator flaps.

He looked a little nervous, as anyone would, seeing that the welcoming committee was headed by Mo Mowlam. Those of us who have been embraced by the new cabinet office minister know that once kissed by her, you stay kissed for a long time. Like bungee jumping, this requires considerable mental preparation.

Ms Mowlam puckered up, ready for the big moment. It was all over in a moment.

"Could you just do the kiss again?" shouted the cameramen. "No!" said Mr Woodward in a heartfelt sort of way.

He did agree to kiss Ann Keen, the Labour MP who brought him across the wall, and then he plunged into the palace.

He had arranged to enter the chamber for prayers, a time when the House is closed to the public, but when MPs stand facing the wall with their backs to each other. This meant that he could be sitting in his place before the Tories even realised he was there.

When we were allowed in, he was sitting in the third row back below the gangway, between Harry Barnes, who looked embarrassed, and Martin Salter, the MP for Reading West.

The sight which greeted him must have been astounding. Sitting on the Tory front bench, facing the government, he would not have seen all his colleagues' faces.

To be suddenly faced with this collection of grotesques, like something Hieronymous Bosch might have painted during a particularly nasty attack of Sydney A 'flu, must have been terrifying.

Mr Salter kept up a running commentary throughout. I've sat near people like Mr Salter on the tube. The trick is not to engage with them.

I imagine the discourse went roughly along these lines: "No, that's not William Hague, he's got even less hair, it's David Willetts, Two Brains, well, half-a-brain might be generous; that's David Ruffley, we call him East Ham, because he's one stop from Barking; oh, and there's Julian Lewis, he's wired up to the moon, as the Irish say; and that's Tim Loughton, he's one signature short of an early-day motion; and John Bercow, he's off with the fairies, sorry Shaun, no offence meant and none taken I hope; oh, yeah, James Gray, talk about the flapping of white coats; just on his right, John Townend, blimey, he's not been hooked up to the mains for years now; oh, Julian Lewis, who needs the millennium bug when you've got eyes like that, I'm not boring you, I hope, am I Shaun? Shaun? Anyway..."

fields.headline: AOL deal ignites markets
fields.standfirst:
£8bn added to media shares as City takes a bet on who's next

Aol
Time Warner
fields.trailText: More than £8bn was added to the value of London-listed media shares yesterday as the market rushed to digest news of the shock $350bn all-share merger between America Online and Time Warner.
fields.body:
More than £8bn was added to the value of London-listed media shares yesterday as the market rushed to digest news of the shock $350bn all-share merger between America Online and Time Warner.

Media stocks dominated the list of FTSE 100 risers, taking five of the top six spots, as related stocks on Nasdaq and the Dow Jones drove higher and analysts marked up forecasts in anticipation of further consolidation across the sectors.

Of the top 15 climbers in the FTSE 100, only Royal & Sun Alliance Insurance was not media, software or telecoms related. TechMark, the index of technology stocks, closed up 4.5% at 3654p.

Content providers Pearson and EMI Group led the charge among the blue chips, climbing 15% each. Pearson closed up 261p at £19.62, while EMI added 90.5p to 683.5p.

BSkyB, up 112p at £10.11p, Reed up 44.5p at 490.75p and Granada, up 54p to 639.5p, followed closely behind.

Renewed interest in internet shares helped boost the FTSE Small Cap index after the sell- offs since the new year. It ended the session up 45.9 points at 3,140.9, its high of the day. Walt Disney and Yahoo! led the risers in the US.

Analysts said that Time Warner's readiness to accept AOL's shares to facilitate a merger had convinced many sceptics that internet companies will be a driver of future media consolidation.

"This deal took great vision and courage," said Alan Ackerman, senior vice-president at Fahnestock and Co. "It shows that the high valuations that many analysts have been uncomfortable with may be justified."

In early afternoon trading Time Warner had soared $27.625 to $92.375, while AOL shares were up $0.125 at $73.

Under the terms of yesterday's deal, Time Warner shareholders will receive 1.5 shares of the new company, called AOL Time Warner, for each of their existing shares which are valued at $110.60, a 71% pre mium on Friday's closing price.

AOL shareholders exchange their existing shares for those in the new company on a one- for-one basis and will own 55% of the whole group. AOL's Steve Case will be chairman of the enlarged group, with Gerald Levin, Time Warner's chairman and chief executive, taking on the latter role.

Analysts welcomed the deal, saying AOL's 20m customers would provide an audience for Time Warner's television, magazine and film interests which include CNN, Warner Brothers movie studios and Time Magazine.

"This makes strategic sense," said Merrill Lynch internet analyst Henry Blodget. "It guarantees AOL getting broad access to consumers and it takes Time Warner to another level as far as new media and high-speed data connections."

Filippo Lo Franco, media analyst at BNP Equities in Paris, said: "With all the new distribution channels like the internet, media shares are the first to benefit. This could restart rumours of a merger between BSkyB and Canal Plus. People will say the little Europeans will have to consolidate to face up to the American giants."

Leading European media companies, including Bertelsmann and Vivendi, said the news from the US would not alter their strategies of investing in a variety of media.

"For us this merger demonstrates the convergence between the internet and its contents, and it's the same strategy which Vivendi has pursued for some years now," a Vivendi spokesman said.

webTitle: Cruickshank gives banks a clean bill

fields.headline: Cruickshank gives banks a clean bill
fields.standfirst: The Cruickshank review into banking competition is expected to conclude that the high street banks do not abuse their dominant position in the provision of services to small and medium sized business,  writes Jill Treanor
fields.trailText: Senior bankers claimed that Don Cruickshank, who was commissioned by Gordon Brown to conduct the controversial review, has reached this conclusion after scrutinising each bank's small-business operation in every area in the country.
fields.body:
Senior bankers claimed that Don Cruickshank, who was commissioned by Gordon Brown to conduct the controversial review, has reached this conclusion after scrutinising each bank's small-business operation in every area in the country.

One senior banker said he believed Mr Cruickshank had found that in some parts of the country the leading small-business banks - NatWest, Barclays and Midland - did have dominant shares but were not abusing their position by altering pricing policy or business models.

While the big banks are said to be relieved at the finding, they remain anxious about proposals Mr Cruickshank could make to the government.

He is expected to require changes to the way accounts are provided to make it easier for them to be moved from one bank to another, in a similar way to changes he suggested for telephone numbers when he headed Oftel, the telecoms regulator.

fields.headline: A blanket of Berlioz
fields.standfirst:
National Youth Orchestra/ Roger Norrington
Symphony Hall, Birmingham
****
fields.trailText: Berlioz's Grande Messe des Morts is a work for high days and holidays, massive in its scale, monumental in its effect, and requiring an array of vocal and instrumental forces that can only be assembled on special occasions. But the National Youth Orchestra can call upon exactly those resources - there are usually far more talented young woodwind and brass players coming through the auditions than can be easily accommodated in the standard symphonic repertoire, and who else can provide the four brass bands, eight sets of timpani and multiple woodwind choirs that Berlioz's Requiem (first performed in Les Invalides in Paris, in 1837) demands?
fields.body:
Berlioz's Grande Messe des Morts is a work for high days and holidays, massive in its scale, monumental in its effect, and requiring an array of vocal and instrumental forces that can only be assembled on special occasions. But the National Youth Orchestra can call upon exactly those resources - there are usually far more talented young woodwind and brass players coming through the auditions than can be easily accommodated in the standard symphonic repertoire, and who else can provide the four brass bands, eight sets of timpani and multiple woodwind choirs that Berlioz's Requiem (first performed in Les Invalides in Paris, in 1837) demands?

The chance to replicate a performance on that scale is the kind of challenge that the conductor Roger Norrington would relish. He has explored Berlioz extensively with period instruments and here, with the octuple woodwind ranged to his left, the brass bands arrayed around the balconies of Symphony Hall, and the massed choirs (unidentified in the programme, mysteriously) terraced in front of him, Norrington was in his element. The hall had all the doors to its resonating chambers flung wide for the occasion, creating an acoustic that had enough of an echo to it to give a churchy feel.

Norrington had brought some of his period-performance ideas with him too, encouraging the NYO strings to be parsimonious with vibrato, and cultivating a bare, slightly raw-edged sound from the woodwind. The great climaxes in the Dies Irae and the Rex Tremendae conjured up a fearful noise, enveloping the audience in a blanket of sound, but the quieter moments, in a work that rarely breaks out of its prevailing atmosphere of studied solemnity, had real finesse and clarity, with fine-grained playing from all the orchestral principals.

The choral singing was sometimes a bit ragged, but Berlioz demands a lot, especially from the tenors, and this was first and foremost a showcase for the orchestra after all; the tenor soloist in the Sanctus was Toby Spence, stationed high in one of the resonating chambers, his voice floating down over the orchestra.

fields.headline: How was your day, dear?
fields.standfirst: Why the millennium man finds working late at the office so much more appealing than going home
fields.trailText: A trawl through the latest business research chucks up two - possibly connected - conclusions. One, that working women are stressing out their male partners by discussing business problems around the family hearthside. Secondly, that doing voluntary overtime can actually be good for your health.
fields.body:
A trawl through the latest business research chucks up two - possibly connected - conclusions. One, that working women are stressing out their male partners by discussing business problems around the family hearthside. Secondly, that doing voluntary overtime can actually be good for your health.

Now it doesn't take a degree in rocket science to fathom why blokes are suffering fits of the vapours at the prospect of long winter nights swapping tales of office squabbles as they fork through a microwaved lasagne.

The first, and possibly most important, factor is that men are finally beginning to experience what it is like to be on the receiving - rather than spewing - end of a torrent of work-related angst. "Guess what happened in the office today" is the precursor to some of the most petty, mind-numbing and depressing monologues ever spoken in the history of useless oratory.

If women find it less stressful to listen then I can only suppose - in the best Men Are From Mars tradition of sexual inequality - that it is because we have developed better coping and masking techniques over the years.

So, to help men in their struggle to manage this new phenomenon without cardiovascular combustion, here are some tips from the professionals:

When she gets home

 never start a conversation the minute your partner walks in through the door. Commuting is stressful and even a simple enquiry like "Would you like a cup of tea?" or "How was your day?" can cause a pressure hotspot and consequent curt reply. Follow-up comments like "I only asked" or "You never tell me anything" are hugely unhelpful.

 wait until your partner has unpacked and changed before attempting conversation. Never instigate the subject matter, just smile helpfully and be fragrant.

When she's talking

 always use eye contact when listening, to imply undivided attention. Never interrupt and never attempt to do any non-vital chores - like blinking or breathing - while listening as this implies a lack of interest.

 adopt the "You're so right" or "I don't know how they can treat you like that" stance. A good point to make is that "They're obviously just jealous of your ability" or "They haven't promoted you because they feel threatened by your superior knowledge". Don't worry if these sound insincere or fawning as the troubled worker will never notice.

Never ever

 side with the object of your loved one's venom or give the merest hint that they might be in anyway right. They are totally, absolutely wrong in every aspect of their argument and your partner is blameless.

 use the phrases: "Don't you think that you may be making a big deal of nothing?"; "Why don't you just forget it"; "You've been moaning about your boss every night for three years now, don't you think it's time you took action?"; or "Why don't you just change your job?".

 yawn or look at your watch

 give advice.

Do

 offer alcohol or neck massage

 think of something while listening to avoid going insane.

Of course, If the second piece of research is anything to go by men are coping via the avoidance technique: skulking late at the office on the pretext that the working wife will be snoring or too squiffy to talk by the time he gets home.

Which would explain why doing overtime may be good for your health.

fields.headline: Aladdin
fields.standfirst:
Cochrane Theatre, London WC1
****
fields.trailText: The Bubble theatre is adept at creating quality popular entertainment and is more aware than most that theatre is largely about context and the creation of a community. Creating a community in the antiseptic Cochrane is a tall order, but not one that is beyond the genie-us of Jonathan Petherbridge and his cast. This is considerably more real than all those teeth-and-legs pantos with huge choruses where everyone smiles inanely, it never rains, and the emotions are as false as the highly coloured set.
fields.body:
The Bubble theatre is adept at creating quality popular entertainment and is more aware than most that theatre is largely about context and the creation of a community. Creating a community in the antiseptic Cochrane is a tall order, but not one that is beyond the genie-us of Jonathan Petherbridge and his cast. This is considerably more real than all those teeth-and-legs pantos with huge choruses where everyone smiles inanely, it never rains, and the emotions are as false as the highly coloured set.

This show has villains you really want to hiss and boo, as well as heroes and heroines ordinary enough to be like you and me. Aladdin and the princess meet and become mates with all the faltering awkwardness of a playground romance, and the princess turns out to be a champion swimmer, which is just as well given the fate the evil Abananzer has in mind for her and Aladdin.

The mixture of the traditional and the innovative is neatly balanced too. There is some audience participation that isn't toe-curlingly embarrassing, some really good slapstick routines whose antecedents date back to the music hall, and some hilarious playing with film that is seamlessly spliced into the live action.

Those looking for a grand, all-singing, all-dancing panto might find this a little low-key. But adults and older children will appreciate the exceptionally good script and the little ones will be delighted by the broader humour. Even if you think you hate panto, this could change your mind.

Till January 15. Box office: 0171-242 7040.

There is some audience participation that isn't toe-curlingly embarrassing, some really good slapstick routines whose antecedents date back to the music hall, and some hilarious playing with film that is seamlessly spliced into the live action. Those looking for a grand, all-singing, all-dancing panto might find this a little low-key. But adults and older children will appreciate the exceptionally good script and the little ones will be delighted by the broader humour. Even if you think you hate panto, this could change your mind. Till January 15. Box office: 0171-242 7040.

webTitle: £203,000 award for stress at Gypsy site

fields.headline: £203,000 award for stress at Gypsy site
fields.trailText: A former warden at a Gypsy site yesterday won a record £203,000 in damages for personal injury caused by work-related stress.
fields.body:
A former warden at a Gypsy site yesterday won a record £203,000 in damages for personal injury caused by work-related stress.

Randy Ingram suffered a breakdown and has been unable to work for three years after he was shot at and physically abused.

Mr Ingram, who is a Gypsy, suffered the trauma while trying to enforce licensing laws. He has to take up to 17 tablets a day and attend hospital twice a week for therapy. Worcestershire county council settled out of court and admitted liability.

Mr Ingram, a father of four, took over responsibility for the Lower Heath site, near Kidderminster, which had a track record of problems. Out of 10 wardens employed by the council, seven are off work because of stress. Another warden has received £14,500 after suffering abuse.

Mr Ingram began his £8,700 a year job in 1993 and his responsibilities were to allocate pitches and collect rent as part of enforcing licensing laws. "The council has a lot to answer for," said Mr Ingram. "They have made me very ill with stress and depression and my home life has suffered as a result. I have been in hospital twice and still need medication and painkillers to carry on."

Unison, which supported Mr Ingram, said the case was one of the most extreme examples of stress the union had dealt with. Its regional officer Peter Fennell said Mr Ingram's authority was undermined at sites because the council turned a blind eye when the rules the wardens were supposed to enforce were broken.

Mr Fennell commented: "The council appeared to take the side of the Gypsies. They were not prepared to take sufficient strong action against the troublesome families. This was very difficult for the wardens."

Mr Fennell said the majority of the families were decent people, but there were anti-social elements. "Some of the Gypsies were acting with impunity because they knew whatever they did they were not going to be brought to book by the council."

A former site officer with the council, who declined to be named, said some of Mr Ingram's problems arose because he was a Gypsy himself.

Mr Ingram added that he and his family would continue living in a caravan on a site for Gypsies: "I am part of the Gypsy community, I have always lived in a caravan.

"The council's admission of guilt shows how badly they have treated me."

A former senior site officer with the council said Mr Ingram had been shot at in the site office, and bullets had ricocheted off gas bottles surrounding the office.

Recent figures showed that unions took 783 legal cases against employers for stress-related illness last year, 70% up on the previous 12 months.

In a statement Worcestershire county council said: "These are the only successful stress claims against the council which show we are doing all we can to support staff."

A council spokesman, Chris Carter, said that the case had arisen when Mr Ingram worked for the old Hereford and Worcester county council. "The new county council has improved procedures by giving Gypsy liaison staff more support. These new measures have scooped us a top national award for the Gypsy liaison teams work."

The settlement was the third high-profile stress case brought by Unison. In 1994 a social worker John Walker was awarded an out-of-court settlement of £175,000 against Northumberland county council, and last year housing officer Beverley Lancaster was awarded damages of around £65,000 by a judge after Birmingham city council admitted liability for personal injury caused by stress.

fields.headline: MEPs enter withholding tax fray
fields.trailText: The European parliament is threatening to block a new EU law on investment funds if there is no progress on the issue of withholding tax, which has pitted Britain against fellow members of the union.
fields.body:
The European parliament is threatening to block a new EU law on investment funds if there is no progress on the issue of withholding tax, which has pitted Britain against fellow members of the union.

MEPs said yesterday they would oppose proposals updating existing law on investment funds, as well as new rules liberalising access to the single market and allowing the management of pension funds alongside investment funds. The threat came as the EC president, Romano Prodi, said he was not optimistic a deal could be reached on harmonising tax policies on savings.

"I am not optimistic, but we decided to keep working on it," Mr Prodi said after talks with Portugal's prime minister Antonio Guterres, whose country holds the EU presidency for the first six months of 2000.

Mr Guterres said agreement may be possible if a balance is respected between data exchange and a withholding tax. But in Brussels Christa Randzio-Plath, chairwoman of the parliament's economic and monetary affairs committee, told reporters: "I am in favour of blocking because I don't know how we can organise political pressure [for the tax] if we do not do something concrete."

At the Helsinki summit last month EU ministers failed to agree on a savings tax, mainly due to opposition from Britain and Luxembourg, which have large investment industries.

fields.headline: René Magritte
fields.standfirst:
Dean Gallery, Edinburgh
*****
fields.trailText:
Dean Gallery, Edinburgh
*****
fields.body:
Boy, do people race around this exhibition. No matter that what confronts us are some of the most puzzling, disturbing and beautiful paintings from the last century - see how the people run, stopping only to say, breathlessly, "Oh, that's a famous one." It's partly because this exhibition has "big show" written all over it (it takes up the entire Dean Gallery, the first exhibition to do so) and is drawing big crowds, but also because of the over-familiarity of these surreal images. Magritte started out as a wall-paper designer and an advertising artist, now crowds whizz by his work, giving it little more attention than a billboard ad, maybe even less.

We are now all so au fait with the blurring of boundaries, with odd juxtapositions, with Hammer Horror schlock, that the radical otherness of Magritte's vision - a giant finger pokes up from floorboards, a staircase leads nowhere, a face has pubes for a mouth - is hard to see in these 70 or so paintings. Instead, if you stop to look, what strikes you is how well painted they are. God Is No Saint (1935), a bird on a brown shoe, glistens - the dappled petrol-blue sky, the light hitting the leather - and, for all its controversial title and odd content, it's a classic, superbly executed oil painting.

Elsewhere, it's the two-dimensional flatness of the paintings that overwhelms (or maybe underwhelms when you are face to face with it, hence the civilised trot in the gallery). That early wallpaper training came in handy in ridding his work of conventional perspective. The Key to the Fields (1936), a view through a shattered window onto a landscape, with the shards of glass imprinted with the scene in view, shows this and more, emphatically foregrounding too the dissolving border between inside and outside (the body, the house, even within words) that so fascinated Magritte. Best of all in turning away from perspective is one of the word-paintings, The Delights of Landscape (1928): an empty gilt picture frame, with the title Paysage, in a dramatically lit room. A gun, the only other object, leans against a blood-red wall.

Ironically, given surrealism's exclusive, avant-garde origins, there is something for everyone here. There are well-known paintings, such as Representation (the female torso with its frame cut to her shape) and Golconde, in which it's raining bowler-hatted men, hallelujah! There are a few word-paintings, one example of Magritte's brief Impressionist phase (nasty) and one image painted when he was staying with Dali at Cadaques for a bit of an art historical, biographical buzz. And then there's the joy of hearing parents explain surrealism to tiny tots. "You see that lady has a leg where her head should be, well..."

Till March 26. Details: 0131-624 6200.

webTitle: Asda's plans chill Sainsbury and Tesco shares

fields.headline: Asda's plans chill Sainsbury and Tesco shares
fields.trailText: Asda yesterday underlined its growing ambition and unnerved the competition by unveiling plans to open 12 new stores this year and create 27,000 jobs by 2005, partly by moving into new product lines.
fields.body:
Asda yesterday underlined its growing ambition and unnerved the competition by unveiling plans to open 12 new stores this year and create 27,000 jobs by 2005, partly by moving into new product lines.

Shares in competitors Tesco and J Sainsbury fell as the UK's third largest retailer, now part of US company Wal-Mart Stores, announced it would open two larger "supercentres" this summer stocking electrical and DIY products alongside food and clothing. Asda also plans to double the number of distribution stores - to four - that serve its home shopping business which is growing via the internet.

And Asda was given an extra boost from a Christmas shopping survey by Taylor Nelson Sofres which showed the Leeds-based supermarket chain increasing its market share at the expense of Sainsbury.

Allan Leighton, Asda's chief executive said: "These expansion plans are in line with our strategy of longterm market share growth. We are a people business and we need more colleagues than ever."

Shares in Tesco and Sainsbury fell 2.3% and 1% respectively in early trading on a stronger stock market. "The announcement may have been enough to spook a few people," one retail analyst said, although another said it was in line with store openings in previous years.

Asda will offer permanent posts to 1,500 staff recruited for Christmas with a further 4,500 to be taken on by the end of this year on top of the 100,000 employees already in position.

The supercentres will be in Patchway, Bristol, and Havant in Hampshire with the Bristol store increasing to 93,000 square foot from the current 75,000 square foot size. New stores will also be opened at Donnington Wood near Telford and Leyton in east London, while sites in Wrexham and Bradford are being rebuilt.

Latest industry research puts Asda's share of the UK food retail market at a record 14%, behind Tesco and Sainsbury. Asda has been aggressively cutting prices with plans to spend £200m a year aimed at reducing prices to US levels.

Further details of how Tesco and Sainsbury are dealing with the threat from Asda will be available next Monday when the companies issue their Christmas trading statements.

Asda has been a centre of attention since the summer when it was snapped up for $6.7bn (£4.2bn) by Wal-Mart which has a reputation for vicious price-cutting and aggressive expansion.

Some analysts argued last night that Asda was expanding in the way it would have done with or without Wal-Mart. But an Asda spokeswoman said Wal-Mart's large resources had given Asda the confidence it needed to reduce its prices and rapidly expand its customer base.

Last night Tesco's share price closed at 176.5p, down 5.75p and Sainsbury's 333p, down 5.5p.

fields.headline: Pension move welcomed
fields.trailText: Small businesses yesterday welcomed a government decision to exempt them from having to make stakeholder pensions available to their staff from next year.
fields.body:
Small businesses yesterday welcomed a government decision to exempt them from having to make stakeholder pensions available to their staff from next year.

But consumer groups warned that the change could weaken ministers' attempts to encourage people working for such firms to save more for their retirement.

Stakeholder pensions are the new low-cost, flexible schemes which go on sale in April 2001.

With small firms already struggling under the weight of new regulations, the government has decided that those with fewer than five staff - around two-thirds of all Britain's employers - are to be relieved of the additional burden of having to give workers access to one of these.

Stakeholder pensions are at the forefront of the government's drive to encourage people to put aside more money for their old age - in particular, the 5m people earning £9,000-£18,500 a year who have no private pension provision. Of this total, about 750,000 work for small firms.

The government previously said all employers would have to either offer their staff an occupational scheme or give them access to a stakeholder scheme.

The 150,000-member Federation of Small Businesses described the change as a "very welcome step", but the Consumers' Association said that while those workers affected by it would still be able to buy a stakeholder pension, many of them would be less likely to do so because they will now have to make the arrangements themselves.

Philip Telford, a CA spokesman, said it was also disappointed by the decision to raise the minimum contribution to a stakeholder scheme from £10 to £20 a month. "If you are looking at access for people on lower incomes, why put up an extra hurdle?"

But the government yesterday won praise from many for sticking with its plans for a maximum all-in annual charge of 1% despite protests from many companies that this was too low to be viable.

Anyone will be able to take out a stakeholder pension, whether in work or not, because the government is scrapping the link between pension contributions and earnings.
