webTitle: Hard day at the office, dear?

fields.headline: Hard day at the office, dear?
fields.standfirst: You have a job. So does your partner. Guess who can't handle the other bringing work problems home?  Angela Neustatter examines a gender imbalance
fields.trailText: You have a job. So does your partner. Guess who can't handle the other bringing work problems home? Angela Neustatter examines a gender imbalance
fields.body:
As the quest begins for fresh female role models, the paradigm of the emotionally skilled-up woman seems set to thrive. Rightly or wrongly, it is now accepted as conventional wisdom that women outstrip men in emotional literacy. But the eternal conundrum of how men and women negotiate their emotional lives together remains as confounding as ever.

The rash of reactions to last week's revelations that men find it harder than women to cope with their partners' problems brought this sharply into focus. Sophie Crossfield at Hertfordshire University published the results of a study based on interviews with 40 couples with equal-status jobs. She found that, while women were able to process their partners' problems without being affected themselves, when women bring work problems home, men are twice as likely to become depressed.

How, then, should women react to this news? Initial responses broadly fell into two camps. First there was the compassionate approach, acknowledging that men traditionally suffer from a lack of informal support networks. Others took a tougher line, with some women columnists observing the none too desirable frailty of modern men grappling with a changing world.

This commence de siècle reminder that gender division is becoming ever more complex must surely bring us to a fresh analysis of who and how we support within relationships. There is, of course, an almighty paradox at work: men find themselves increasingly drawn to bright, high-achieving women who are stimulating life companions. But the old traditionalist in them still wants the reassurance of a woman who has him at the centre of her heart and mind, and drips with desire for him. Meanwhile, this modern woman expects her partner to understand her struggles with a changing world at an emotional level. If he can't or won't, she may threaten to exit on a spiked post-modernist heel, her non-shared account chequebook clutched firmly to her hip.

That men want to support their women is besides the point: goodwill notwithstanding, many men still get it wrong because they don't know what kind of support women want. Dr Richard Stevens, head of psychology at the Open University, explains that most men are programmed to seek solutions to problems, so when a partner dumps her briefcase at the front door and begins a tirade about her day at work, he will swing into troubleshooting mode.

"He sees what she is saying as a plea for help in sorting out the problem and wants to make suggestions for dealing with it in a practical way. But the woman may well want no more than to off-load her feelings from a stressful and difficult day, and for her partner to listen and make it plain he has heard how she is feeling. She may not want him to make it his problem and set about sorting it out."

This has less to do with men feeling threatened by women's increased status in the workplace than with the physiological ritual dance that men and women enact in stressful situations. According to Dr John Gottman, who has carried out years of research into couples in America, when men feel stressed or criticised, they flood with emotion far more quickly than women do. Hence women keep their emotional balance while men "stonewall", shuting down their feelings and withdrawing emotionally, leaving women feeling cut off and rejected.

Inevitably, these divergent reactions push men and women further apart, leading to the depression men reported in last week's study. Stevens explains: "Men who realise their way of trying to help their partner is not what she wants may well feel impotent at not being able to fulfil their protective role. Depression typically comes when demands are made on you but you are not sure how to deal with them."

So why do women react so differently to hearing their partners' problems? Evolutionary psychologists would arge that women have selected the good communication and negotiating skills that allow them to raise their children in a protected environment. On the other hand, women have a different emotional framework from men: women's friendship networks have always been the place to which they have turned to unburden themselves, pour out their troubles and debrief. But as increasing numbers of women work long hours, often coping with children, too, the time for a telephone chat or unloading over a coffee with a friend becomes remote. The pressure is on men to give us the emotional support we cannot get elsewhere.

At the same time, we need a bit of emotional honesty if we are to break down the gender divide as well as just chart it. One female columnist remarked last weekend that men's problem with women bringing home work problems is that, in the domestic sphere, what they want is a mummy, not a careerist.

I don't think there's much of a gender divide here. Isn't that nurturing, self-sacrificing person who gives us unconditional love and space to be heard and understood what we all want? If, as many women do, we want to live happily with men, then we need to share our emotional intelligence rather than smile pityingly at men as we find ourselves with the coveted quality in our possession.

Depression typically comes when demands are made on you but you are not sure how to deal with them." So why do women react so differently to hearing their partners' problems? Evolutionary psychologists would arge that women have selected the good communication and negotiating skills that allow them to raise their children in a protected environment. On the other hand, women have a different emotional framework from men: women's friendship networks have always been the place to which they have turned to unburden themselves, pour out their troubles and debrief. But as increasing numbers of women work long hours, often coping with children, too, the time for a telephone chat or unloading over a coffee with a friend becomes remote. The pressure is on men to give us the emotional support we cannot get elsewhere. At the same time, we need a bit of emotional honesty if we are to break down the gender divide as well as just chart it. One female columnist remarked last weekend that men's problem with women bringing home work problems is that, in the domestic sphere, what they want is a mummy, not a careerist. I don't think there's much of a gender divide here. Isn't that nurturing, self-sacrificing person who gives us unconditional love and space to be heard and understood what we all want? If, as many women do, we want to live happily with men, then we need to share our emotional intelligence rather than smile pityingly at men as we find ourselves with the coveted quality in our possession.

fields.headline: Dancing fingers
fields.trailText: An aura of exquisite refinement, of delicate theatricality and sartorial elegance hangs over Melvyn Tan, the cult pianist, born in Singapore, now resident in the UK. Immaculate in a black designer suit, he walks on to the platform with an appealing air of gentle shyness.
fields.body:
An aura of exquisite refinement, of delicate theatricality and sartorial elegance hangs over Melvyn Tan, the cult pianist, born in Singapore, now resident in the UK. Immaculate in a black designer suit, he walks on to the platform with an appealing air of gentle shyness.

Part way through the first half of his recital, his jacket is abandoned to reveal yards of flowing silk. After the interval, he's rolled up his shirt sleeves, so we can see all the better the muscularity of his arms and the grace of his gestures.

Tan is always fascinating to watch though, on occasion, less impressive to hear. There's something balletic about him, as if his performances are choreographic. His back arches and ripples as he bends over the piano. His hands describe fluid arabesques in the air before lighting on the keys. He sometimes gazes round the auditorium in a seeming state of romantic abstraction.

The same grace and refinement characterise his playing, which is rarely less than beautiful, yet sometimes lacks spontaneity, dash and emotional clout. For his Wigmore programme, he chose Beethoven followed by Debussy's Second Book of Preludes, the latter, with its subtle shifts of mood and nuance, suiting him better. The Preludes were written in 1913, on the eve of the first world war, and Tan maintains the uneasy menace that lurks behind the open ing Brouillards (fog) throughout much of the cycle. He briefly breaks the mood with La Puerta del Vino as the Iberian landscape opens to reveal a blinding, crystalline clarity, though its luminosity proves brief and thereafter nostalgia reigns, even in the comic portraits of General Lavine's music hall turns and the grandiloquent buffoonery of Samuel Pickwick.

The improvisatory approach which Tan adopts towards Beethoven, feeling his way through the music with an exploratory tentativeness, isn't entirely successful. The G minor Fantasia, its darting scales and hymnic melodies laced with unusual wit, and the opus 119 Bagatelles, mingling naivety with density, come off best. He pulls the opus 101 A major sonata about a bit, however, overdoing the rubato in the first movement and lacking panache in the finale. The quirky match that forms the sonata's scherzo seemed overlong. Only the slow movement, played with rhapsodic fervour, was genuinely breathtaking.

fields.headline: Greatest roué on legs
fields.standfirst:
Malcolm Hardee's 50th Birthday
Up the Creek, London
****
fields.trailText: Malcolm Hardee is one of the raddled giants of what was once known as alternative comedy. His statue in the Hall of Fame bears the legend Never Compromise on one side, Always Take the Drink on the other. But while he cut his teeth in the Comedy Store 20 years ago alongside Ben Elton and Alexei Sayle, he never followed them into TV. Perhaps it had some thing to do with his inability to keep his zip fastened.
fields.body:
Malcolm Hardee is one of the raddled giants of what was once known as alternative comedy. His statue in the Hall of Fame bears the legend Never Compromise on one side, Always Take the Drink on the other. But while he cut his teeth in the Comedy Store 20 years ago alongside Ben Elton and Alexei Sayle, he never followed them into TV. Perhaps it had some thing to do with his inability to keep his zip fastened.

Instead he plugged away at the live circuit. After making his name with the Greatest Show on Legs, his naked dance troupe, he opened two much-loved but infamous comedy clubs, the Tunnel Club and Up the Creek, where he continued to expose himself to the punters, particularly when he couldn't be bothered with the trip from stage to urinal. Jo Brand once described him as an "appalling trampy old mess" - and she used to be his girlfriend.

So there was plenty to remember at this bash for the old roué's 50th birthday, and a capacity crowd who were determined to play their part.

Fittingly, the bill was a look back to the early days of alternative comedy/cabaret, when anything went. There were bizarre one-trick ponies like Chris Luby, a Battle of Britain type who impersonates aircraft and military bands, and the Bastard Son of Tommy Cooper, a nipple-ringed bloke in boxers and fez who wires himself up to a generator and acts as a human light socket. Rubbing shoulders with them were frankly rubbish turns such as Ivan Steward, a beanpole in a referee's outfit who shouts a lot and deliberately fluffs his punchlines, and the Fast Show's John Thomson, trying our patience with too much stale foolery from his Bernard Right On and Jazz Club routines ("Pissed as a rat," was Hardee's verdict). They used to say that the alternative thing about alternative comedy is that it isn't funny, and Thomson seemed determined to uphold the old ways.

But there was plenty of sparkling stuff, too, particularly from the perennially up-and-coming Boothby Graffoe, who now has his own Radio 4 series, and Brendan Burns, a fearsome Aussie punk who looks like a cross between Johnny Depp and Quentin Willson and talks about sex a lot. So did everyone, in fact, but that seems to be the way they like it in Greenwich.

In the end, of course, it was Hardee's night. Finished with compering, he closed proceedings with the Greatest Show on Legs, all three members past their prime and the worse for wear, but all the funnier for that. After a kit-on dance to Michael Jackson's Thriller, with rubber bands pulling faces into grotesque approximation of the pop star's, we got the full monty - the legendary Balloon Cha-Cha, a sort of low-rent fan dance that ended with Hardee and his partners naked, swaying and unashamed.

A drunken evening that ends with a striptease - now that's a birthday party.
